name: Women and Gender in the Deaf World
description: (Also offered as WGSS 3254.) The roles of women inside and outside the Deaf world. How language and cultural barriers perpetuate the roles defined for and by d/Deaf women within Deaf and hearing societies.
requirements: ecommended preparation: Any 1000 or 2000-level WGSS course.

name: Field Study
description: A practical learning experience, working in an environment that fosters ASL communication and a deeper appreciation and understanding of the Deaf community. Field study placements are arranged or approved by the ASL Coordinator or course instructor.

name: Experiential Learning
description: This course is for students who wish to extend their knowledge and experience in American Sign Language and Deaf studies as tutors and as Instructional Assistants in related courses.
requirements: pproval of Experiential Learning Supervisor, instructor consent required. Recommended preparation: Completion of the course for which the student will provide tutoring services.

name: Advanced American Sign Language
description: Advanced study of American Sign Language and Deaf culture.
requirements: ASLN 1104

name: Advanced American Sign Language Level II
description: Continuation of advanced study of American Sign Language and Deaf culture. Emphasis on composition in ASL, involving critical engagement with primary research in ASL literature and Deaf culture, and guidance on how to compose and revise in ASL using an online video recording platform.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; ASLN 3305 or instructor consent.

name: Deaf Art and Artists
description: Introduction to Deaf art, Deaf artists, and the historical transformation of Deaf art including the De'VIA movement. Topics include diversity of Deaf artists as well as Deaf cultural norms and the role they play in the unique distinction of Deaf art. Varying perspectives and a comparative critical analysis between Deaf art and the various forms of art produced by non-Deaf artists.

name: Deaf Writers and American Sign Language Literature
description: Discussion of deaf, hard of hearing, and hearing scholars in the examination of original ASL poetry. Critical examination of comparative literature in the Deaf Community and linguistic themes from different perceptions and analyses.
requirements: ASLN 1104 or instructor consent.

name: Structure of American Sign Language
description: (Also offered as LING 3800.) Linguistic analyses of American Sign Language focusing on the phonological, morphological, syntactic, and semantic levels.
requirements: ASLN 1102 or LING 2010 Q. Recommended preparation: Both ASLN 1102 and LING 2010 Q.

name: Introduction to American Studies
description: (Also offered as HIST 1503, ENGL 1201.) What is an American?  A multi-disciplinary inquiry into the diversity of American societies and cultures. CA 4.

name: Honors Core: American Landscapes
description: Real and imagined landscapes in the Americas as seen through the history of the land and its uses and through changing representations of those landscapes in art, literature, science, and popular culture. CA 1.
requirements: pen to freshmen and sophomores in the Honors Program.

name: Literature and Culture of North America before 1800
description: (Also offered as ENGL 2200.) An examination of the early written and oral culture of the area that eventually became the United States. CA 1.

name: Introduction to Asian American Studies
description: (Also offered as AAAS 2201.) A multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary introduction to major themes in Asian American Studies. Concepts of identity and community, migration and labor histories, Asians and the law, representations of Asians in visual and popular culture, gender issues, interracial and interethnic relations, and human rights. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Jewish Culture in American Film
description: (Also offered as CLCS 2204, HEJS 2204.) Representations of the diversity of Jewish culture (historical, religious, secular) in American film. Introduction to film analysis and interpretation. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Empire and U
description: (Also offered as ENGL 2207, HIST 2207.) How the frontier and overseas ambitions have shaped U.S. institutions and culture. The impact of U.S. expansion on people outside its borders. These topics are explored through literary narratives and historical documents. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Disability in American Literature and Culture
description: (Also offered as ENGL 2274 W.) An interdisciplinary examination of the symbolic roles of disability and the social implications of those roles. CA 1. CA 4.

name: American Utopias and Dystopias
description: (Also offered as ENGL 2276.) Interdisciplinary approaches to American utopian and dystopian literature of the 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries. CA 1.

name: American Utopias and Dystopias
description: (Also offered as ENGL 2276 W.) Interdisciplinary approaches to American utopian and dystopian literature of the 19th, 20th, and 21st centuries. CA 1.

name: City and Community in Film
description: (Also offered as URBN 2400.) Aesthetics, history, and contemporary relevance of American films that feature the urban, suburban, and/or small town landscape as a major "character" shaping plot and story. Films read closely as texts that make meaning through a range of tools, including narrative, mise-en-scene, editing, camera work, and genre conventions. CA 1.

name: Crime, Policing, and Punishment in the United States
description: (Also offered as HIST 2550.) A survey of political, legal, and cultural development of the American criminal justice system and its social impact from the early republic to the present. Formerly offered as AMST/HIST 2810. CA 1.

name: International Study
description: Special topics taken in an international study program. Consent of department head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure.
requirements: epartment consent.

name: Critical Race Theory as Political Theory
description: (Also offered as POLS 3082.) Interdisciplinary scholarship on racial identity, legal decisions, and political action from the perspective of political science and political theory. Topics include interactions between states and social movements, the intersections of race, class, gender, and membership, and the problems with both post-racialism and identity politics.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1002.

name: American Studies Methods
description: (Also offered as ENGL 3265 W.) Interdisciplinary research and writing centered on a specific topic in U.S. culture. An introduction and overview of research methods in American Studies.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Race and the Scientific Imagination
description: (Also offered as ENGL 3267 W.) How racism has been both reproduced and contradicted in the scientific imagination. Scientific texts and imaginative literature that explore the reparation of past harms and imagine new futures. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Immigration and Transborder Politics
description: (Also offered as LLAS 3271, POLS 3834.) U.S. immigration policy, trans-border politics, and the impact diasporas and ethnic lobbies have on U.S. foreign policy, with emphasis on Latino diasporas.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Visual Culture of the United States, 19th Century
description: (Also offered as ARTH 3440 W.) An exploration of how visual culture in the long 19th century contributed to the formation of the United States.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Colonial America: Native Americans, Slaves, and Settlers, 1492-1760
description: (Also offered as HIST 3502.) The legacy of Columbus, creative survival of native Americans in the face of disease and warfare, religious utopianism and the profit motive in colonization. The growth of a distinctive Anglo-American political culture, gender and family relations, and the entrenchment of a racial caste system.

name: Colonial America: Native Americans, Slaves, and Settlers, 1492-1760
description: (Also offered as HIST 3502 W.) The legacy of Columbus, creative survival of native Americans in the face of disease and warfare, religious utopianism and the profit motive in colonization. The growth of a distinctive Anglo-American political culture, gender and family relations, and the entrenchment of a racial caste system.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Japanese Americans and World War II
description: (Also offered as HIST 3531, AAAS 3531.) The events leading to martial law and executive order 9066, the wartime experience of Japanese Americans, and national consequences. CA 1. CA 4.

name: New England Environmental History
description: (Also offered as HIST 3542 E.) Interdisciplinary history of New England's terrestrial and marine environmental change.  Links among land, sea, and human natural resource use and management, including precontact patterns, colonial impacts, agricultural decline, industrial pollution, overfishing, re-forestation, and the rise of eco-tourism.
requirements: ecommended preparation: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Atlantic Voyages: European Maritime Expansion, 1400-1650
description: (Also offered as HIST 3544, MAST 3544.) Late medieval and early modern European expansion into the Atlantic and Indian oceans, with particular attention to European, Asian, African, and American contexts within which that expansion took place. Topics include the transatlantic slave trade; technology adoption and adaptation; convergence of trade, racial ideology, imperial expansion, and imperial identity construction; piracy and settlement; historiographical legacies and later imperialism; and decolonization of contemporary understandings.

name: Hip Hop, Politics and Youth Culture in America
description: (Also offered as HIST 3568, AFRA 3568, MUSI 3568.) History of hip-hop, its musical antecedents and its role in popular culture. Race, class, and gender are examined as well as hip-hop's role in popular political discourse.

name: History and Theory of Digital Art
description: (Also offered as ARTH 3570, DMD 3570.) Investigates forms of digital and Internet art and the mostly forgotten histories of the technologies behind them. Forms and themes to be explored include games/gaming, surveillance art, cyberfeminism, data visualization, and crowdsourced art. CA 1. CA 4.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to sophomores or higher.

name: Independent Study
description: Supervised reading and writing on a subject of special interest to the student.  May be repeated for credit with a change of topic.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Constitutional Rights and Liberties
description: (Also offered as POLS 3807, HRTS 3807.) The role of the Supreme Court in interpreting the Bill of Rights. Topics include freedoms of speech and religion, criminal due process, and equal protection.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Law and Popular Culture
description: (Also offered as POLS 3822.) Exploration of themes in the study of law and courts by contrasting scholarly work against representations of such themes in movies, televisions, and other media of popular culture.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Law and Popular Culture
description: (Also offered as POLS 3822 W.) Exploration of themes in the study of law and courts by contrasting scholarly work against representations of such themes in movies, televisions, and other media of popular culture.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Honors Thesis
requirements: pen only to junior or higher Honors students.

name: Introduction to Animal Science
description: The biological, physical, and social factors that influence animal production and utilization.

name: Principles of Animal Nutrition and Feeding
description: Digestive anatomy of various species and the classes of nutrients including their digestion, metabolism and sources. Nutrient requirements and feeding standards for livestock, companion animals, exotics and aquatics for purposes of reproduction, lactation, growth, work and maintenance. Classes of feedstuffs, their characteristics, proper utilization, formulating rations and nutritional programs for animal enterprise. Taught with SAAS 113.
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing ANSC 4311.

name: Behavior and Training of Domestic Animals
description: Application of behavior of cattle, horses, sheep, goats, swine, poultry, and companion animals to their management, training, and welfare. Basic principles of genetics and physiology of behavior, perception, training, learning, motivation, and stress with consideration of integrated behavioral management and animal welfare. Students are required to have access to an animal that they will train throughout the semester; the Department of Animal Science will not necessarily provide animals for training. Taught concurrently with SAAS 202.
requirements: pen to Animal Science, Pathobiology and Veterinary Science, Agriculture, Health and Natural Resources majors; others by consent. Recommended preparation: ANSC 1001.

name: The Science of Food
description: (Also offered as NUSC 1645.) An introductory level course for students interested in the application of science to food. Nutritional and functional attributes of various food constituents are discussed. Issues concerning food processing and food safety are covered. CA 3.

name: Introduction to Companion Animals
description: Basic concepts of the nutrition, physiology, health and management of companion animals. Taught with SAAS 276. CA 3.

name: Foreign Studies in Animal Science
description: Variable topics.

name: Special Topics
description: Credits, prerequisites and hours as determined by the Senate Curricula and Course Committee. May be repeated for credit with a change in topic.

name: Horse Science
description: Valuable to animal science majors and includes horse types and breeds and their nutrition, breeding, evaluation, behavior, care and management with attention given to detailed studies of the problems and practices of horse production and use. Taught with SAAS 251.
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing ANSC 3456.

name: Principles of Poultry Science
description: The application of the basic scientific principles to the management of poultry, egg and meat production systems.

name: Companion Animal Science
description: Basic concepts of nutrition, physiology, health, genetics, and management of companion animals emphasizing cats and dogs, but less common ones will also be discussed. Management will encompass keeping companion animals, and behavioral, and mental health management concerns. Also taught with SAAS 276.
requirements: ANSC 1001 or SAAS 101 and ANSC 1111 or SAAS 113.

name: Management Skills and Practices - Dairy
description: Develop hands-on and managerial skills in the handling and care of growing and mature dairy animals. Develop teamwork and communication skills in a dairy environment. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: pen to Animal Science majors and minors.

name: Management Skills and Practices - Equine
description: Develop hands-on and managerial skills in the handling and care followed in an equine operation. Develop teamwork and communication skills required by equine employers. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: Special Topics
description: Contact Department Main Office for list of current topics and instructors. May be repeated for credit with a change of topic.

name: Animal Science Field Excursions
description: A multiple day field trip format. Students in this course will travel with the instructor to visit and tour agri-businesses that represent commercial aspects of different animal science activities. Students will interview agri-business personnel and gain an understanding of how agricultural principles are applied in the field. Each student must submit a formal written report for evaluation and meet all other course requirements as specified by the instructor. Field trip is required. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory). May be repeated for credit with a change in topic.

name: Special Topics
description: Contact Department Main Office for list of current topics and instructors. May be repeated for credit with a change of topic.

name: Independent Study
description: May be repeated for credit. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: Principles of Animal Genetics
description: Principles of Mendelian and molecular genetics. Biosynthesis and function of DNA, RNA, and protein. This course also includes introductions to population and quantitative genetics. Information on molecular methods of genetic analysis and examples of genetics in animals of agricultural significance are also provided.
requirements: BIOL 1108; open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: BIOL 1107.

name: Reproductive Physiology
description: A study of the reproductive anatomy and physiology of domestic animals. Laboratory will include macro and micro anatomy, hormone action, and techniques used in reproductive management of domestic animals.

name: Career Paths in Animal Science
description: A discussion of current employment opportunities in animal sciences. In addition, students will prepare resumes and make oral presentations.

name: Dairy Cattle Management
description: Management of dairy cattle including milking procedures, sanitation, selection, nutrition, reproduction, physiology and anatomy of milk secretion and record keeping. Field trips required. Taught with SAAS 261.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Laboratory Animal Science
description: Principles and practices of laboratory animal care and management in relation to animal characteristics, handling and restraint, animal house design, reproduction and nutrition and legal regulations. Various laboratory animal techniques will be covered.
requirements: BIOL 1107. Recommended preparation: BIOL 1108 or equivalent.

name: Livestock Management
description: The production and management of beef cattle, sheep, and swine. Laboratories involve theory and practice in livestock management, skills, and techniques. Taught with SAAS 273.

name: Comparative Exercise Physiology
description: A comparative study of the effects of exercise on the body, focusing on the three primary athletic species (canine, equine, human). Particular emphasis will be placed on the physiological mechanisms which allow for adaptation to exercise and inactivity.
requirements: PATH 2100 or PNB 2265 or2275; open to juniors or higher.

name: Scientific Writing in Comparative Exercise Physiology
description: A writing intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 3311.
requirements: ANSC 3311, which must be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors and higher.

name: Growth Biology and Metabolism in Domestic Livestock
description: Focuses on the embryonic and postnatal growth and development of domestic livestock with emphasis on metabolic and hormonal regulation of processes that influence growth and development. Discussion period will focus on methods used to measure growth and metabolism.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: PATH 2100.

name: Scientific Writing in Growth Biology and Metabolism of Domestic Livestock
description: A writing intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 3313.
requirements: ANSC 3313 or5613, which must be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Endocrinology of Farm Animals
description: Focuses on endocrine systems and endocrine function in farm animals with emphasis on hormones involved in metabolism, growth, lactation, feed intake and digestion in cattle, pigs, horses and poultry.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: PATH 2100 or equivalent.

name: Scientific Writing in Endocrinology of Farm Animals
description: A writing intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 3316, Endocrinology of Farm Animals.
requirements: ANSC 3316, which must be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Probiotics and Prebiotics
description: Biology, uses, effectiveness and safety of probiotics and prebiotics. Molecular mechanisms underlying the health benefits attributed to the consumption of pre and probiotics. Application of pre- and probiotics to promote human and animal health, including safety and regulation.
requirements: ecommended preparation: MCB 2610 or equivalent (can be taken concurrently).

name: Animal Embryology and Biotechnology
description: Introduction to recent research in animal embryology and related reproductive biotechnologies. Basic principles, methodology and state of the technology for numerous established and emerging animal biotechnologies such as transgenesis and cloning.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: ANSC 3122 or MCB 4219.

name: Scientific Writing in Embryo Biotechnology
description: Writing intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 3323 Animal Embryology and Embryo Biotechnology.
requirements: ANSC 3323, which must be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Animal Food Products
description: A study of the food products derived from animal agriculture, including dairy, meat, poultry and fish. Emphasis will be placed on inspection, grading, processing, biochemistry, nutritive value and food safety concerns of these products. Taught with SAAS 243.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Scientific Writing in Animal Food Products
description: A writing-intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 3343.
requirements: ANSC 3343, which must be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Animal Training Project - Training Assistant
description: Develop and effectively communicate livestock animal handling, training, fitting, and showing techniques to Introduction to Animal Science students at weekly practices.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: Animal Training Project - Chair
description: Oversee and teach Training assistants to ensure appropriate animal handling, training, fitting, and showing instruction to Introduction to Animal Science students. Teach and assist Introduction to Animal Science students at weekly practices, along with Training assistants.
requirements: ANSC 3420 or SAAS 420; instructor consent required.

name: Horse Breeding Farm Management
description: Designed to develop technical and managerial skills necessary for operating horse breeding farms. Programs for herd health, hoof care, nutrition, breeding, foaling, and record keeping will be included.
requirements: ANSC 2251. Open to sophomores or higher.

name: Pleasure Horse Appreciation and Use
description: Open to all University students interested in pleasure horses. The principles of horse management and horsemanship.
requirements: ot open to students who have passed ANSC 3456.

name: Developing the Driving Horse
description: Techniques related to training the driving horse will be described. Prior working experience with horses is recommended.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Advanced Broodmare and Foal Management
description: Management of the pregnant mare and neonatal foal, including foaling practices, foal handling, and postpartum care of the mare.
requirements: ANSC 3452; instructor consent required.

name: Equine Training I - Foundations
description: Fundamental ground work and techniques used to train young horses. Prior working experience with horses recommended.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: Equine Training II - Backing
description: Theory, fundamentals and practice of backing a horse, training horse to accept the rider, and the natural aids. Intermediate level riding skills required. May be repeated once for a maximum of four credits.
requirements: nstructor consent. Recommended preparation: Intermediate level riding skills.

name: Equine Training III - Advanced
description: Training horses for riding, showing, and lessons using the Dressage Training Scale.  Advanced level riding skills are required. May be repeated once for a maximum of four credits.
requirements: nstructor consent. Recommended preparation: Advanced level riding skills.

name: Equine Sports Rehabilitation Practicum
description: Provides students with an opportunity to apply concepts of equine rehabilitation. May be repeated once with change in specific rehabilitation activity.
requirements: ANSC 3551 and instructor consent.

name: Equine Rehabilitation Seminar
description: Different modes of therapy, business topics, and management skills related to the equine rehabilitation field.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: Animal Food Products: Dairy Technology
description: Production and processing of milk and milk-products from a food science perspective including chemical, physical and microbiological components. Technological aspects of the transformation of milk into various food products. Public health regulations, good manufacturing practices, cleaning and sanitizing procedures. Unit operations in dairy food manufacturing, packaging, labeling and quality control procedures.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Scientific Writing in Animal Food Products: Dairy Technology
description: A writing intensive course integrated with course content in ANSC 3641.
requirements: ANSC 3641, which must be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Dairy Management Decision-making
description: Participation in all phases of dairy herd management including decision-making activities, with particular emphasis on impact of decisions on financial health and stability. Course requires participation beyond specific semester calendars. May be repeated twice for credit.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Dairy Cattle Evaluation
description: An introduction to the evaluation of dairy cattle on the basis of conformation. Breed classification and type improvement programs, score card criteria in relation to longevity, physiological efficiency and performance are included. Attention is also given to fitting and showing methods. Field trips may be required.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Livestock and Carcass Evaluation
description: Classification, form to function relationships, grades and value differences of livestock are included. Objective and subjective methods of appraisal are used to evaluate beef cattle, horses, sheep and swine. Taught with SAAS 274.
requirements: ot open for credit to graduate students.

name: Advanced Animal and Product Evaluation
description: Intensive training in the evaluation of selected species of farm animals or their products. Type standards and the relation of anatomical features to physiological function are emphasized. Evaluation skills including justification of decisions will be developed. Intercollegiate dairy cattle, horse, livestock, poultry judging teams will be selected from this course. Field trips are required, some of which may occur prior to the start of the semester. Taught with SAAS 275.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher. Not open for credit to graduate students.

name: Summer Internship Experience
description: Practical experience, knowledge, and professional skills in a work environment related to animal science. Based on a contract and learning experience syllabus. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: pen to students who have earned a minimum of 24 credits and instructor consent.

name: Professional Internship
description: Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory). Credits and hours by arrangement.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Foreign Studies in Animal Science
description: Variable topics.

name: Special Topics
description: Credits and hours by arrangement.  May be repeated for credit with a change of topic. Contact Department Main Office for list of current topics and instructors.

name: Variable Topics
description: Contact Department Main Office for list of current topics and instructors. May be repeated with a change of topic.

name: Undergraduate Teaching Assistance in Animal Science
description: Practical experience gained in teaching methods and materials preparation and assisting student learning through written and verbal communication.
requirements: nstructor consent required. Open only to students with demonstrated competency in target course material.

name: Advanced Animal Nutrition
description: A comparative study of nutritional, physiological, microbiological, immunological and biochemical aspects of digestion and metabolism in the non-ruminant and ruminant animal, particularly livestock and companion animals. Topics include digestive system structures, utilization of nutrients, energy metabolism, control of nutrient metabolism, and experimental techniques used in the study of animal nutrition.
requirements: ANSC 1111; open to juniors or higher.

name: Scientific Writing in Advanced Animal Nutrition
description: Writing-intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 4311.
requirements: ANSC 4311, which must be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Food Microbiology and Safety
description: Current topics in food safety will be discussed, with special emphasis on microbial and chemical contamination of food. Specific topics including the safety of natural versus synthetic chemicals, food additives, irradiation and other practices, basic microbiology and toxicology, current regulatory practices and risk assessment will also be included. The Hazard Analysis Critical Control Points (HACCP) approach to food safety will be discussed.
requirements: iology 1107; open to junior or higher. Recommended preparation: A one semester course in organic chemistry.

name: Scientific Writing in Food Microbiology and Safety
description: A writing-intensive class integrated with course content in ANSC 4341.
requirements: ANSC 4341, which must be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Muscle Biology and Muscle Food Chemistry
description: Molecular and cellular basis of muscle food physical features and its related muscle biological events.
requirements: pen to Juniors and higher. Recommended preparation: ANCS 3343 or CHEM 2241 or CHEM 2443 or one same-level chemistry class.

name: Methods of Equitation Instruction
description: The techniques and procedures of teaching equitation including the theories of riding and teaching methods. Practice teaching will be required under the supervision of the instructor. Taught with SAAS 257.
requirements: ntermediate II or above riding experience required.

name: Dairy Herd Management
description: Dairy farm management practices with emphasis on business and economic decision making. The effects of various programs in selection, nutrition, facilities, reproduction and herd health on overall business health will be evaluated. Each student will manage a computer simulated herd during the semester. Field trips are required. Taught with SAAS 262.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; ANSC 3261; open to juniors or higher.

name: Undergraduate Honors Thesis Writing in Animal Science
description: Writing of a formal thesis based on independent research conducted by the student. Thesis proposal and final thesis must follow guidelines developed by the department.
requirements: hree credits of ANSC 2699 or5692, which may be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Introduction to Animal Science
description: The biological, physical and social factors that influence animal production and utilization. Taught with ANSC 1001.
requirements: ot open to students in an undergraduate program.

name: Anatomy and Physiology of Domestic Animals
description: A study of the anatomy and physiology of the animal body including characteristics that impact animal production systems. The physiology of reproduction and digestion will receive emphasis. Management practices and techniques used to maximize production efficiency will be included.

name: Anatomy and Physiology of Domestic Animals
description: A study of the anatomy and physiology of the animal body including characteristics that impact animal production systems. The physiology of reproduction and digestion will receive emphasis. Management practices and techniques used to maximize production efficiency will be included.
requirements: SAAS 111.

name: Principles of Animal Nutrition and Feeding
description: Focuses on digestive anatomy of various species and the classes of nutrients including their digestion, metabolism and sources. Nutrient requirements and feeding standards for various classes of livestock for reproduction, lactation, growth, work and maintenance are included as well as companion animals, exotics and aquatics.  Classes of feedstuffs, their characteristics and proper utilization will be discussed.  Attention will also be given to characteristics of common feedstuffs and to formulating rations and nutritional programs for animal enterprise. Taught with ANSC 1111.

name: Animal Breeding and Genetics
description: The principles of genetics, chemistry of nucleic acids, replication, transcription, translation and regulation of genes, population and quantitative genetics, and modern molecular genetics approaches as tools for breeding, and improving livestock production.

name: Behavior and Training of Domestic Animals
description: Application of behavior of cattle, horses, sheep, goats, swine, companion animals and poultry to their management, training and welfare. Basic principles of genetics and physiology of behavior, perception, training, learning, motivation, and stress with consideration of integrated behavioral management and animal welfare. Students must have access to an animal that they can train throughout the semester. Taught concurrently with ANSC 1602.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SAAS 101.

name: Animal Products
description: An introduction to meat, dairy and poultry products. Issues concerning regulatory standards, nutritive value, safety and quality assessment will be emphasized. Laboratories will emphasize the production and processing of these animal food products. Taught with ANSC 3343.

name: Horse Science
description: Includes horse types and breeds and their nutrition, breeding, evaluation, behavior, care and management with attention given to detailed studies of the problems and practices of horse production and use. Taught with ANSC 2251.

name: Management of the Horse Breeding Farm
description: Designed to develop technical and managerial skills necessary for operating horse farms. Programs for herd health, hoof care, nutrition, breeding, foaling and record keeping will be included.
requirements: SAAS 251.

name: Foundations of Training
description: Fundamental ground work and training techniques used when working with young horses. Prior working experience with horses is highly recommended.

name: Methods of Equitation Instruction
description: The techniques and procedures of teaching equitation including the theories of riding and teaching methods. Practice teaching will be required under the supervision of the instructor. Taught with ANSC 4457.

name: Dairy Herd Management
description: Management of dairy cattle including milking procedures, sanitation, selection, nutrition, reproduction, physiology and anatomy of milk secretion and record keeping. Field trip required. Taught with ANSC 3261.

name: Applied Dairy Herd Management
description: The organization and management of dairy farms with emphasis upon business and economic decision making. Management programs in the areas of nutrition, disease control, waste management, selection, reproduction and milking will be evaluated. Field trips are required.

name: Introduction to Poultry Industry
description: A practical application of scientific principles in the poultry industry. It will include classification, selection methods, breeding, incubation and chick development, brooding, nutrient requirements, processing and management practices.

name: Sustainable Animal Management
description: An introduction to sustainable agriculture, as related to alternative farm animal production. Basic economics will be discussed in preparation for the creation of a farm business plan. Laboratory/discussion periods will include student presentations and hands-on activities. Field trips required.

name: Livestock Production
description: Biological and economic aspects of beef, sheep, and swine production. Field trips required. Taught with ANSC 3273.

name: Livestock and Carcass Evaluation
description: Classification, form to function relationships, grades and value differences of livestock are included. Objective and subjective methods of appraisal are used to evaluate beef cattle, sheep and swine. Taught with ANSC 3674.

name: Advanced Animal and Product Evaluation
description: Intensive training in the evaluation of selected species of farm animals or their products. Type standards and the relation of anatomical features to physiological function are emphasized. Evaluation skills including justification of decisions will be developed. Students enrolled in this course will have the option to participate on intercollegiate animal and product evaluation teams. Field trips are required, some of which may occur prior to the start of the semester. Taught with ANSC 3675.

name: Introduction to Companion Animals
description: Basic concepts of nutrition, physiology, health, genetics, and management of companion animals emphasizing cats and dogs, but less common ones will also be discussed. Management will encompass keeping companion animals, and behavioral, and mental health management concerns. Taught with ANSC 2276.
requirements: SAAS 101 and SAAS 113.

name: Animal Science Field Excursions
description: A multiple day field trip format. Students in this course will travel with the instructor to visit and tour agri-businesses that represent commercial aspects of different animal science activities. Students will interview agri-business personnel and gain an understanding of how agricultural principles are applied in the field. Each student must submit a formal written report for evaluation and meet all other course requirements as specified by the instructor. Field trip is required. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: Professional Internship
description: Total credits allowed toward graduation requirements are restricted as outlined in Ratcliffe Hicks section.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher; open only with consent of instructor.

name: Career Paths in the Animal Sciences
description: A discussion of current employment opportunities in animal agriculture. In addition, students will prepare resumes and give oral presentations.

name: Special Topics
description: Total credits allowed toward graduation requirements are restricted as outlined in Ratcliffe Hicks section. Contact Department Main Office for list of current topics and instructors.

name: Variable Topics
description: Contact Department Main Office for list of current topics and instructors.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: Independent Study
description: An independent study project is mutually arranged between a student and an instructor. Students are advised to read the Ratcliffe Hicks regulation limiting the number of credits which may be applied to the minimum graduation requirements. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory.)

name: Management Skills and Practices - Horses
description: Practical experience in common management practices is offered by working in the University facilities under supervision. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: Management Skills and Practices - Dairy Cattle I
description: Practical experience in common management practices is offered by working in the University facilities under supervision. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing SAAS 364.

name: Management Skills and Practices - Dairy Cattle II
description: Continued practical experience in common management practices is offered by working in the University facilities under supervision. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: SAAS 363.

name: Management Skills and Practices - Livestock
description: Practical experience in common management practices is offered by working with livestock species in the University facilities under supervisor. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: Management Skills and Practices - Poultry
description: Practical experience in common management practices is offered by working in the University facilities under supervision. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: pen only to students in the Ratcliffe Hicks School of Agriculture. Instructor consent required.

name: Training Assistant
description: Livestock animal handling, training, fitting, and showing techniques for Introduction to Animal Science students at weekly practices.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: Peoples and Cultures of the World
description: An introduction to the anthropological understanding of human society through ethnographic case studies of selected peoples and cultures, exploring the richness and variety of human life. Encourages students to learn about different cultures and to apply their knowledge to make sense of their own society. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: Peoples and Cultures of the World
description: An introduction to the anthropological understanding of human society through ethnographic case studies of selected peoples and cultures, exploring the richness and variety of human life. Encourages students to learn about different cultures and to apply their knowledge to make sense of their own society. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: Anthropology Through Film
description: An introduction to cultural anthropology, approached through the medium of ethnographic film. Particular attention is given to how films represent humans' varied beliefs and behavior.  CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Introduction to Anthropology
description: The biological and cultural development of humans from their origin to the present. A brief survey of human evolution is followed by a comparative study of behavior and beliefs of our own and other societies. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: Global Climate Change and Human Societies
description: A multidisciplinary examination of the nature, anthropogenic drivers, range of expressions, and impacts of contemporary and future global climate change as well as cultural understandings of this significant environmental process and diverse human responses to it. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 17.

name: Special Topics Lecture
description: May be repeated with a change in topic.
requirements: redits, prerequisites, and hours as determined by the Senate Curricula and Courses Committee.

name: Great Discoveries in Archaeology
description: Survey of important discoveries in archaeology spanning the whole of human prehistory across the globe. Current issues, methods, and techniques in the field of archaeology. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: Social Anthropology
description: A comparative study of social structure including an analysis of kinship, marriage, community organization, political and economic institutions, and the role of the individual in these institutions. CA 2. CA 4.
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing ANTH 4001.

name: Social Anthropology
description: A comparative study of social structure including an analysis of kinship, marriage, community organization, political and economic institutions, and the role of the individual in these institutions. CA 2. CA 4.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Not open to students who have passed ANTH 4001.

name: Race and Human Biological Diversity
description: An introduction to race and racism, concepts of racial difference, and the patterns of human biological variation. Special emphasis on understanding human biodiversity within historical, scientific, and social contexts. CA 3. CA 4.

name: Introduction to Archaeology
description: The concepts, methods and practice of anthropological archaeology.
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing ANTH 3521 or3704.

name: Human Evolution
description: The processes and events leading to the origin of human beings. Human physical and cultural development from its beginning to the dawn of settled life, through the approaches of physical anthropology and archaeology.

name: Methods in Maritime Archaeology
description: Methods and techniques in underwater archaeology covering both maritime (ships, ports, etc.) and submerged settlements archaeology. Overview of the aqueous environment, underwater archaeological methods, geophysical/geotechnical surveying and data interpretation, diver and ROV-based documentation and excavation techniques survey methods.
requirements: ecommended preparation: ANTH 2501.

name: Anthropology of Museums
description:
Museums as locales for intersecting issues of identity, memory, place, power, ethnicity, history, representation, and ownership. Special focus on collectors, theories, and methods for the collection and display of Native American bodies, histories, art, and artifacts. Four museum field trips and related field research required.
SM-10/12/09
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher. Recommended Preparation: ANTH 3027 or3904.

name: Microscopy in Applied Archaeobotany Research
description: Introduction to research trends in archaeobotany and use of microscopy tools. Design and execution of a research project. CA 3-LAB.
requirements: ecommended preparation: STAT 1000 Qor1100Q; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Field Research in Social Settings
description: Methods and techniques of field research in social settings, including observational procedures, interviewing, and the construction and use of questionnaires.
requirements: ANTH 1000 or1006.

name: Cultural Research
description: The theoretical foundations and basic methods used to collect and analyze cultural data.

name: Contemporary Latin America
description: (Also offered as LLAS 3021.) Survey of anthropological contributions to the study of contemporary Mexico, Central America, South America, and the Hispanic Caribbean. Special focus on the comparative analysis of recent ethnographic case studies and local/regional/national/international linkages.

name: Contemporary Africa
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3025.) Africa since its partition in 1884. Urbanization, social stratification, racial and ethnic conflict.

name: Peoples and Cultures of North America
description: A survey of representative Native American cultures as they existed prior to the twentieth century, together with a view of the changing life of modern Native Americans.

name: Postcolonial Indigenous Presence
description: An examination of the diverse experiences and political realities of First Nations and Indigenous communities in a post-colonial context. Focusing on North America and the Pacific/Oceania, the course explores Indigenous peoples' histories, contemporary struggles, and cultural complexities through Indigenous and anthropological perspectives. Students will critically engage with the ways anthropology has both supported and harmed Indigenous communities, reflecting on the field's complicated history of objectification and misrepresentation. Themes such as sovereignty, homelands, and tradition will be explored in relation to governance, environmental management, media, and colonization.
requirements: ecommended preparation: ANTH 1000 W, ANTH 1006, and ANTH 2000.

name: Indigenous Rights and Aboriginal Australia
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3028.) An introduction to the study and understanding of Aboriginal ways of life and thought. An exploration of the complexity of contemporary indigenous social orders and land rights issues. CA 4-INT.
requirements: ecommended preparation: ANTH 2000.

name: Indigenous Rights and Aboriginal Australia
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3028 W.) An introduction to the study and understanding of Aboriginal ways of life and thought. An exploration of the complexity of contemporary indigenous social orders and land rights issues. CA 4-INT.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: ANTH 2000.

name: The Caribbean
description: (Also offered as LLAS 3029.) Comparative perspectives on the cultural formation of Caribbean societies; the region's demographic, economic and political links with the wider world.

name: Peoples of the Pacific Islands
description: Survey of the indigenous societies and cultures of the Pacific Islands, from the first settlement to the postcolonial period. Topics include prehistoric canoe voyaging, modes of subsistence, political forms, ritual and religion, ceremonial exchange, gender ideologies, European colonization, and modern indigenous nationalism. Ethnographic examples will be drawn from Polynesia, Melanesia, and Micronesia. CA 4-INT.

name: Latin American Minorities in the United States
description: (Also offered as LLAS 3241.) Emphasis on groups of Mexican, Puerto Rican and Cuban origin, including treatment and historical background, social stratification, informal social relations, ethnic perceptions, relations and the concept of Latino identity.

name: Anthropology of Jews and Jewishness
description: (Also offered as HEJS 3050.) Survey of the rich and growing ethnographic literature on Jews and Jewishness around the globe.  Course materials include ethnographic texts, music, and videos/films.
requirements: ecommended preparation: ANTH 1000 or1006; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Anthropology of Jews and Jewishness
description: (Also offered as HEJS 3050 W.) Survey of the rich and growing ethnographic literature on Jews and Jewishness around the globe. Course materials include ethnographic texts, music, and videos/films.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: ANTH 1000 or1006.

name: Internship in Anthropology
description: Practical experience, knowledge, and professional skills in a work environment related to anthropology. Based on a contract and learning experience syllabus. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: ANTH 1000 or1006or1500; instructor consent required.

name: Directed Field Research in Anthropology
description: The investigation of a sociocultural and/or archaeological problem in some domestic or foreign field location. May be repeated for a maximum of 12 credits.
requirements: ANTH 3003 or consent of instructor.

name: Internship in Anthropology: Directed Study
description: Directed study, analysis, and reflection on internship experience.
requirements: nstructor consent; ANTH 1000 or1006or1500. Corequisite: Must be taken with ANTH 3081.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor. May be repeated for credit.

name: Special Topics
description: With a change of content, may be repeated for credit.

name: Directed Research in Anthropology
description: The investigation of a sociocultural and/or archaeological problem in a non field-based setting. Hours by arrangement.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: Variable Topics
description: Prerequisites, required preparation, and recommended preparation vary. With a change of topic, may be repeated for credit.
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Independent Study
description: With a change of content, may be repeated for credit.

name: Anthropology of Capitalism
description: Ethnographic approaches to classic and contemporary debates about capitalism's transformation of sociocultural dynamics.

name: Migration
description: The social, cultural and economic causes and consequences of internal and international migration in the modern era. Topics include migrant selection, social adaptation, effects on home and host societies, and cultural identity. CA 4.
requirements: ecomended preparation: ANTH 1000 or1006.

name: Migration
description: The social, cultural and economic causes and consequences of internal and international migration in the modern era. Topics include migrant selection, social adaptation, effects on home and host societies, and cultural identity. CA 4.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: ANTH 1000 or1006.

name: Race, Ethnicity, and Nationalism
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3152.) Popular and scholarly theories of human group identity and diversity, in cross-cultural and historical perspective. Topics include: an overview of 'race' and 'ethnicity' in Western thought, ethnic group formation and transformation, political mobilizations of group identity, and systems of inequality. CA 2. CA 4.

name: Anthropology of the African Diaspora
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3155.) An exploration of the racial, political, and social similarities and differences within and between the communities constituting the African Diaspora from an anthropological perspective.

name: Human Behavioral Ecology
description: The application of the theory of natural selection to the study of human culture and behavior, with emphasis on the interaction between humans and their environment.

name: Illness and Curing
description: Cross-cultural analysis of ethnomedicine, major medical systems, alternative medical systems, curing and healing illness and social control, gender and healing, and the role of traditional and cosmopolitan medical systems in international health. CA 4.

name: Propaganda, Disinformation, and Hate Speech
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3230.) Draws on current social science research to understand the effects of false information and hate speech on our politics and culture and to evaluate various private and public initiatives to regulate speech. CA 2.

name: Cognitive Anthropology
description: The study of how the content of thought or knowledge is created, organized, and distributed in human communities. Topics include cultural models of the mind, emotions, personality, and relationships.
requirements: ecommended preparation: ANTH 3002.

name: Psychological Anthropology
description: Cross-cultural overview of critical issues regarding the relationship between individual personality and sociocultural systems, and mental health and illness.

name: Medical Anthropology
description: An introduction to the theory, method, and content of medical anthropology.

name: Medical Ecology
description: Anthropological perspectives on the interrelationships among culture, biology, environment, and disease. Major topics include ecology and adaptation, population dynamics, nutrition, reproduction, disease in sociological context, health seeking behavior, and the complexity of the interaction of western and non-western medical systems.
requirements: ecommended preparation: ANTH 3300.

name: Parent Child Relations in Cross-Cultural Perspective
description: (Also offered as HDFS 3310.) Theory and research on major dimensions of parenting in the U.S.A. and cross-culturally, parental warmth, control and punishment.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Anthropology of Drug Use
description: Uses the anthropological lens to examine the intersection of societies, cultures and psychoactive substances based on a historically informed, cross-cultural, ethnographic and political economic perspective on drug use and related behaviors.

name: Violence and Human Rights
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3309.) Violence and human rights as cultural constructs; human rights claims; war, genocide, terrorism, street crime, domestic violence; deterrence and intervention policy.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Race, Culture, and Reproductive Health
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3320.) An examination of the reproductive health experiences of women in the United States, including those focused on sexuality, birth, and motherhood. An exploration of the complex relationship between women’s reproductive experiences and their contemporary racial and socioeconomic locations in American society.

name: Introduction to Global Health
description: Anthropological perspectives on public health in a globalized world, health inequalities within and across countries; diverse social, cultural, and other determinants of global health; pressing global health issues; organizational players involved in addressing global health issues.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Global Health and Human Rights
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3326.) Theories, methods and controversies in the interconnected fields of global health and human rights.

name: Power and Health in Latin America and the Caribbean
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3327, LLAS 3327.) History, theories, and concepts about the human right to health and structural inequalities in the region.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Culture and Conservation
description: (Also offered as EVST 3340 E.) Interdisciplinary analysis of conservation and the human-environment relationship from a cross-cultural perspective. Major topics include sustainability, environmental ethics, climate change, natural disasters, health, and environmental justice. CA2. CA4-INT.
requirements: ecommended preparation: ANTH 1000 or1006; EVST 1000.

name: Political and Legal Anthropology
description: Anthropological analysis of the state, nation, and human rights from a cross-cultural perspective.
requirements: ot open to students who passed ANTH 3098 with the topic Political and Legal Anthropology.

name: Anthropological Perspectives on Women
description: (Also offered as WGSS 3350.) Major conceptual and historical problems in the study of gender in anthropology. Women's roles in different historical and contemporary settings, and new understandings of family, kinship, power, and cultural ideologies.

name: Sex and Gender
description: Cross-cultural and interdisciplinary analysis of biological sex, gender, sex roles, and sexuality.

name: Culture and Religion
description: Major theories and approaches in the study of religion as a social institution and cultural system. Topics include myth, ritual, taboos and pollution beliefs, shamanism, magical practices, fundamentalism and religion in modern society.
requirements: ANTH 1000 or1006.

name: World Religions
description: A survey of religious belief systems, both polytheistic and monotheistic, from around the world. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Women in the Bible
description: (Also offered as WGSS 3402.) An introduction to Biblical interpretation from a feminist perspective, examining how women are represented in the Hebrew Scriptures and the New Testament.  Issues of authorship, translation, point of view, cultural context and language.

name: Women and Religion
description: (Also offered as WGSS 3403.) Gender issues in the world's religions. Survey of women's theological standing, ritual activities and participation in a cross-cultural sample of religions, both monotheistic and polytheistic.

name: Religion and Mind
description: Cognitive and evolutionary anthropological perspectives on the mental underpinnings of religious thought and behavior.

name: Archaeology of Psychoactive Substances
description: Survey of psychoactive substances and altered states of consciousness in both past and present cultural practice.

name: Anthropological Perspectives on Art
description: Approaches to cultural creativity and aesthetics in the graphic and plastic arts of prestate societies. Examples from North America, Oceania, and Africa. CA 1.

name: Old World Prehistory
description: The origin of humanity in Africa, hunters and gatherers of the Paleolithic, the origins of agriculture and the transition to settled life, and the emergence of civilizations in Africa, Asia and the Near East.

name: Laboratory Techniques in Archaeology
description: The analysis, interpretation, and presentation of archaeological data sets including lithics, ceramics, floral and faunal remains and spatial information from excavated sites.

name: African Archaeology
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3512.) An archaeological perspective on more than three million years of human social and behavioral change in Africa, from Stone Age societies that are the earliest in the world to sweeping changes brought about by the development and spread of cattle and crops, sophisticated metallurgy, and the later rise of kingdoms and complex polities situated at a global crossroads of trade and interaction.

name: Near Eastern Prehistory
description: (Also offered as HIST 3300.) From the earliest hunter-gatherers to the rise of the state: the transition from food-gathering to food-production and the development of complex societies in the Near East.

name: European Prehistory
description: Interdisciplinary survey of the archaeological, biological, cultural, and behavioral evolution of prehistoric humans and their societies across Europe and portions of western Asia.

name: Ecological Anthropology Seminar
description: Interdisciplinary study of the ecology of humans, integrating ecological and anthropological theory with archaeological, historical, and contemporary case-studies.

name: The Origins of Agriculture
description: The origins and spread of agriculture worldwide. Economic, social and ideological ramifications of the agricultural transition. Processes of plant and animal domestication.

name: Maritime Archaeology of the Americas
description: (Also offered as MAST 3531, HIST 3209.) Archaeological and historical sources to examine the development of seafaring practices, exploration, waterborne trade and economic systems, naval warfare and shipbuilding in the Americas from the fifteenth to the beginning of the twentieth century.
requirements: ecommended preparation: ANTH 1500, ANTH 2501, ANTH 2510 or HIST 3544.

name: Archaeology of the Age of Sail
description: (Also offered as MAST 3532, HIST 3210.) Overview of archaeological and historical sources on the development of seafaring and navigation, exploration, waterborne trade and economic systems, colonialism and empire building, naval warfare and shipbuilding in Europe, Asia and Australia from the fifteenth to the beginning of the twentieth century.
requirements: ecommended preparation: ANTH 1500, ANTH 2501, or ANTH 2510.

name: Archaeological Science
description: Survey of scientific methods used to answer archaeological questions. Methods, applications and lab demonstrations.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: The Evolution of Human Diet
description: Investigation of ecological, anatomical, and physiological aspects that shaped the biological and cultural evolution of humans from the Pliocene to the Anthropocene.

name: Lithic Technology
description: The properties of stone tools - the primary evidence of human behavior for humanity's first 2.5 million years - and the processes of their manufacture. Analysis of prehistoric tools and tool replication.

name: Zooarchaeological Method and Theory
description: Method and theory of archaeological faunal analysis, including training in the identification of skeletal materials, the formation of the zooarchaeological record, and  the interpretation of zooarchaeological data.

name: Experimental Archaeology
description: Method and theory of experimental archaeology, including hands-on study of past human behavior through experimentation with modern material culture, and the execution of an experimental research project addressing an archaeological question.
requirements: ANTH 2501.

name: Paleoanthropology
description: Fossil evidence for the evolution of the human family, Hominidae. Anatomical features, behavior, and evolutionary relationships of extinct hominids; the use of biological, geological, and archaeological evidence to reconstruct past hominid adaptations.
requirements: ecommended preparation: ANTH 2501,2502or3503.

name: Archaeobotany
description: Method and theory of studying archaeological plant remains in the laboratory, including sampling, identification, and interpretation of data.

name: Technology and Society: Archaeological Perspectives
description: Using a hands-on and field-based approach and the study of museum-based collections, an examination of archaeological approaches to understanding the ways in which various technologies are used by human societies in the present and past, how new technologies arise and spread, the impacts of technological changes, and how to study social choices in the implementation of various technologies as varied as stone tools, pottery, footwear, gravestones, and industrial-era mill sites.
requirements: ecommended preparation: Introductory coursework in archaeology.

name: Lab Methods in Archaeological and Forensic Science
description: Introduction to scientific lab methods used in archaeology and forensics. Includes three stand alone modules, each dedicated to a different method. Each module consists of 15 contact hours comprised of labs and lectures and takes place during a single weekend. Repeatable to a maximum of three credits.

name: North American Prehistory
description: Prehistoric cultures of North America from the earliest traces to European contact, with emphasis on the region east of the Mississippi. CA 4.

name: Ethnohistory of Native New England
description: Combines archaeological and ethnohistorical data to reconstruct the lifeways of the Native Americans of New England from the prehistoric period to the present. CA 4.

name: Field Work in Archaeology
description: Training in the techniques of archaeological site excavation; mapping; recording; field conservation, and preliminary analysis of materials.

name: Honors Thesis
description: Research and writing of major project exploring a topic within anthropology, with close supervision and production of multiple written drafts.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open only with consent of instructor.

name: The Neanderthals
description: An interdisciplinary consideration of the biological, cultural, technological, and behavioral evolution of the Neanderthals and their societies.
requirements: ecommended preparation: ANTH 1500 or2501or2502.

name: Elementary Arabic I
description: Beginning Modern Standard Arabic. Emphasis on speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Taught in Arabic.
requirements: ot open to students with three or more years of Arabic in high school. Students with prior knowledge of Arabic should contact the instructor or the program coordinator prior to registration. Cannot be taken for credit after passing ARAB 1101, 1102, 1103, 1104, 1112, 1113, 1114.

name: Elementary Arabic II
description: Beginning Modern Standard Arabic. Emphasis on speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Taught in Arabic.
requirements: ARAB 1001 or instructor consent; not open to students with three or more years of Arabic in high school. Those with Arabic knowledge require instructor consent. Cannot be taken out of sequence after passing ARAB 1003,1004, 1102, 1103, or 1104.

name: Intermediate Arabic I
description: Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic. Development of speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Taught in Arabic.
requirements: ARAB 1002 or instructor consent. Students with prior knowledge of Arabic should contact the instructor or the program coordinator prior to registration. Cannot be taken for credit after passing ARAB 1004, 1113, or 1114.

name: Intermediate Arabic II
description: Intermediate Modern Standard Arabic. Development of speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Taught in Arabic.
requirements: ARAB 1003 or instructor consent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ARAB 3100 or3212. Not open for credit to students who have passed ARAB 1104.

name: Traditional Arab Literatures, Cultures, and Civilizations
description: Representative works from the cultures of the Arab world. Pre-Islamic poets to later writers and thinkers. Relation of literary and artistic forms to their historical contexts. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Modern Arabic Culture
description: Introduction to modern Arabic culture from Napoleon's Egyptian Campaign to modern Islamism. Survey of institutions, philosophy, and social customs seen through the medium of literature. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Levantine Arabic
description: Effective communication in Levantine colloquial Arabic. Introduction to words, expressions and grammatical structures used frequently in everyday life. Taught in Levantine Arabic and English.
requirements: ARAB 1002 or three years of high school Arabic or instructor consent.

name: Arabic Folk Tales and Mirrors for Princes
description: Folk tales and advice to princes and rulers of the Muslim World: Arabic, Persian and Moghul texts read in translation, such as The Thousand and One Nights, the Qabusname, and Jahangirname. Comparisons with European frame-tales and advice literature (Chaucer, Boccaccio, Machiavelli). Manuals for rulership from India to Andalusia. Ethics, conduct, and political philosophy in folk literature and elite prose. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Arabic Speculative Fiction
description: Introduction to speculative fiction through contemporary literature from the Arab world in translation. Discussion of science fiction, fantasy, horror, and dystopia. Development of skills of literary analysis. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Advanced Arabic
description: Development of advanced speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Expansion of Modern Standard Arabic vocabulary and grammar. Discussion of historical, social, cultural, political, and religious topics. Preparation for other advanced Arabic content courses. Taught in Arabic.
requirements: ARAB 1004 or instructor consent.

name: Media Arabic
description: Modern Standard Arabic of the news media: television, press, and internet. Taught in Arabic.
requirements: ARAB 3100 or instructor consent.

name: Arabic Composition and Conversation
description: In-depth development of speaking and writing skills.
requirements: ARAB 1004 or instructor consent.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.
requirements: onsent of Department Head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure.

name: Special Topics
description: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Classical Arabic Literature
description: Survey of Classical Arabic Literature from pre-Islamic Arabia to the Late Middle Ages, from the Fertile Crescent to the Iberian Peninsula. Recent scholarship and theory in the field of Arabic literature. Taught in English (Arabic readings optional). CA 1.

name: Arabic Travel Narratives
description: Travel accounts by medieval and modern Arab writers. Transcultural encounters: the Volga Vikings, Norman Sicily, al-Andalus, China, Africa and France. Development of advanced reading and translation skills. Review of grammar and syntax through textual analysis.
requirements: ecommended preparation: Two years of formal Arabic or equivalent proficiency.

name: Arabic Poetry and Poetics
description: Selected Arabic poems from pre-Islamic times to the Middle Ages, from Iraq to the Iberian Peninsula. Modes, genres, periods and authors of the Arabic Classical poetic canon. Arabic poetic terminology, criticism and theory. Development of advanced reading, writing and translation skills. Taught in English and Arabic.
requirements: ecommended preparation: Two years of formal Arabic or equivalent proficiency.

name: The Arab Spring
description: Discussion of the Arab Spring's social and political dimensions, including its origins, events, and outcomes. Study of political, journalistic, social, literary, and artistic texts. Development of advanced Arabic skills. Taught in Arabic.
requirements: ARAB 3100 or instructor consent.

name: Modern Arabic Literature
description: Survey of fundamental texts in modern and contemporary Arabic Literature. Textual criticism in Arabic. Development of advanced oral and written skills in Modern Standard Arabic. Taught in Arabic.
requirements: ARAB 3100 or instructor consent.

name: Climate Change and Energy in the Middle East
description: Discussion of climate change, oil, alternative energy, and climate justice in the Middle East. Development of advanced Arabic skills. Taught in Arabic.
requirements: ARAB 3100 or consent of Instructor.

name: Al-Andalus: Music, Literature, and Science in Muslim Spain
description: The cultural heritage of Muslim Spain through literature, music, philosophy, medicine, art, and architecture. Christian, Jewish and Muslim interactions in medieval Europe. Religious and ethnic coexistence in medieval Iberia. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Cinema in the Middle East and North Africa
description: Film in the Arab World. Historical, social, religious and political phenomena that shape contemporary cultural discourse, analyzed through film screenings and readings. Gender, radicalization, war and displacement; key historical events such as the Arab-Israeli conflict, the Lebanese civil war, decolonization, and Islam in the 21st century. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Stereotypes of Arabs and Muslims
description: Representations of Muslims in medieval textbooks, 18th- and 19th-century Western travel accounts. Their influence on stereotypes of Arabs and Muslims in Western cinema and media from early Hollywood films to the present. Taught in English.

name: Women's Contemporary Writing in the Arab World
description: (Also offered as WGSS 1170.) An exploration of feminist texts, literary texts, and popular fiction. Topics may include: the role of women’s writing from the nineteenth century to the present in public life; women’s writing in social and political movements such as the Arab Spring; the intersectionality of class, race, gender, and nation in Arabic literature; and the unique challenges faced by Arab women writers. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Women's Contemporary Writing in the Arab World
description: (Also offered as WGSS 1170 W.) An exploration of feminist texts, literary texts, and popular fiction. Topics may include: the role of women’s writing from the nineteenth century to the present in public life; women’s writing in social and political movements such as the Arab Spring; the intersectionality of class, race, gender, and nation in Arabic literature; and the unique challenges faced by Arab women writers. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Introduction to Islam
description: An introduction to the study of Islam as an intellectual and lived religious tradition. Revelation, literature, aesthetics, philosophy, theology, and law in relation to faith practices in diverse Muslim societies across time. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Classical Arabic
description: Review of Arabic grammar through Qur'an and literary texts. Practice in translation and composition leading to command of idioms and vocabulary. Taught in English and Arabic.
requirements: RAB 1114 or instructor consent.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of department head required, normally to be granted before the student's departure

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Variable Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Islamic Art History
description: (Also offered as ARTH 3710, HIST 3710.) A survey of the arts associated with Islam from the life of Muhammad in the seventh century through the early modern period, with an emphasis upon the Middle East, North Africa, and the Iberian Peninsula. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Islamic Art History
description: (Also offered as ARTH 3710 W, HIST 3710 W.) A survey of the arts associated with Islam from the life of Muhammad in the seventh century through the early modern period, with an emphasis upon the Middle East, North Africa, and the Iberian Peninsula. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Art Appreciation
description: Introduction to the visual arts, past and present. The visual language of artists, historical and cultural significance of works of art. Intended primarily for students who are not art majors. CA 1.
requirements: ot open to ART majors.

name: Exploring Creativity and Visual Art practices
description: Explores the creative process, employing methods used by visual artists to design and produce artworks. Previous art experience is not required. CA 1.

name: How Design Shapes Our World
description: (Also offered as LAND 1005, DMD 1005.) An engaging exploration into the fundamentals of design. Students will learn how design is part of our everyday life. Designing is a flexible and iterative process that thrives on communication and collaboration. Emphasizing a broad and scalable purpose, the course will illustrate how design can be applied and adapted to different contexts and media.

name: Foundation: Studio Concepts
description: Introduction to key concepts and practices in art making.

name: Foundation: Criticism and Interpretation
description: An introduction to various current critical approaches to the producers, contexts, audiences, and histories of contemporary visual culture.

name: Drawing I
description: Fundamental principles of drawing based on observation.
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 1040,2011,2110,2310,2410,2510or2610.

name: Drawing II
description: Observational drawing; emphasis on spatial organization and structure.
requirements: ART 1030. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 2010,3350.

name: Life Drawing I
description: Introduction to figure drawing.
requirements: ART 1040. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 2210,3010, or 3370.

name: Introduction to Digital Media
description: Introduction to digital media.
requirements: ART 1010 and1030. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 3130,3132, or 3420.

name: Graphic Design: Process and Thinking
description: Introduction to the methods of design thinking and the process involved in translating that thinking into form. Content, meaning, form, typography, layout, structure, craft and process in graphic design, emphasizing conceptual analysis, visualization, and skillful making through the adept use of analog and digital tools.
