requirements: ART 1010 and1030. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 3170.

name: Illustration
description: Introduction to principles of illustration, media, and techniques.
requirements: ART 2010 and2310. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 3210.

name: Animation Fundamentals
description: Fundamental skills required for animation.

name: Basic Studio, Painting
description: Introduction to the principles and techniques of painting media.
requirements: ART 1010 and ART 1030.

name: Basic Studio, Photography
description: Introduction to techniques and aesthetics of photography, with emphasis on the camera.
requirements: ART 1010 and ART 1030. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 2420,3410,3420or3440.

name: Intermediate Photography
description: Principles and techniques of black-and-white photography in fine-art applications, with emphasis on darkroom work.
requirements: ART 2410. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 3430,3450,3455,3460,3465,3470,4410.

name: Basic Studio, Printmaking
description: Introduction to practice and principles of printmaking, including intaglio, relief and lithographic processes.
requirements: ART 1010 and1030. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 3510 or3520.

name: Basic Studio, Sculpture
description: Introduction to principles and techniques of sculpture.
requirements: ART 1010 and1030. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 3610,3620,3625,3630,3640,3650,3655, 3660, 3670.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Department Head required, normally before the student's departure to study abroad.
requirements: epartment consent.

name: Special Topics Seminar
description: Credits and hours as determined by the Senate Curricula and Courses Committee. This course may or may not count for credit toward graduation. Students should consult the course syllabus and the Dean's Office of their School or College.

name: Life Drawing II
description: Drawing from the figure.
requirements: ART 2010. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 3020 or3210.

name: Experimental Drawing
description: Advanced studio course designed to expand the practice of drawing. This may include collaboration, performance, animation, and/or the incorporation of new technologies. A wide range of drawing prompts will allow for personal interpretation and encourage experimentation. Research, reading, writing, discussions, critiques, instructor demonstrations, field trips, and lectures may supplement the course.
requirements: ART 1040. Open only to Art majors; open to non-majors by instructor consent.

name: Graphic Design 1: Typography
description: Examination of typographic concepts and techniques, emphasizing typography as a powerful medium for complex visual communication and expression. exploring theory, technology, tools, and contemporary design philosophies to analyze and manipulate typographic systems across various print and digital media.
requirements: ART 2110; portfolio review; consent of instructor.

name: Graphic Design 2: Visual Systems
description: Investigate creative and effective visual design systems through the use of visual structure, typography, image, grid, information hierarchy and architecture.
requirements: RT 2120; open only to Art majors, others with instructor consent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 4120.

name: Graphic Design 3: Relational Design
description: Exploration of form, content, function, strategy; collaborative and integrative thinking in problem solving; using diverse communication design methodologies.
requirements: RT 2120 and ART 3110; open only to Art majors, others with instructor consent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 4110 or4130.

name: Art Books, Book Arts, and Publishing as Radical Practice
description: (Also offered as WGSS 3125.) A hands-on studio exploration of book arts and independent publishing. Topics include various layout methods, printing technologies, bookbinding structures, and distribution channels, contextualized by an introduction to historical and contemporary artistic, literary, feminist, queer, and BIPOC radical publishing models that challenge conventions.

name: Fundamentals of Web Design
description: Introduction to basic HTML web page design using Cascading Style Sheets.
requirements: ART 2011 and 2120 or instructor consent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ART 3131.

name: Interactive Design
description: Introduction to the design of interactive screenbased experiences.
requirements: RT 2120 and3130or instructor consent.

name: Graphic Design: Motion Graphics
description: Introduction to the multi-faceted diversity of motion design - including film and television title sequences, data visualizations, web-based animations, and sound branding with an emphasis on typography in motion. Students develop competency in producing Motion Graphics via ideation and conceptualization, sketching, storyboarding and animatics, using both analog and digital methods, leading to final animations.
requirements: ART 2011 and2110or instructor consent; open only to majors, open to non-majors with instructor consent.

name: Graphic Design: Survey
description: Survey of contemporary graphic design practice as an artistic and professional discipline in visual media. In addition to critical readings, presentations, and discussions, field trips are planned to engage in dialogues with practicing professional designers and studios.
requirements: ART 2110; open to sophomores or higher; open only to majors, open to non-majors with instructor consent.

name: Topics in Illustration
description: Continuing problems in illustration. Projects may include book, editorial, reportage, or self-promotion illustration.
requirements: ART 2210 and ART 3010; open to juniors or higher.

name: Experimental Animation: Studio Processes
description: Experimental approaches to the translation of still media into time-based form, informed by the student's prior studio art coursework and media approaches. Smart phone technology is employed to capture, organize, edit, and animate images.
requirements: pen only to Art majors, others by instructor consent; open to juniors and higher.

name: Scientific Visualization
description: (Also offered as DMD 3235.) Exploration of techniques for the development of still and animated graphics for use in science education and scientific publications and presentations. Project-based coursework with involvement from scientific experts and close collaboration between student illustrators and animators.
requirements: ART 2210; instructor consent required. Recommended preparation: ART 3210.

name: Stop and Go: Explorations in Stop-Motion Animation
description: A survey of stop-motion animation techniques.

name: Going Pro
description: Professional practices in illustration and animation, including market preparedness, portfolio development, branding, business communication and tools, networking, and promotion.
requirements: ART 3210; open only to juniors or higher studio art majors. Others by instructor consent.

name: Intermediate Painting
description: Conceptually-oriented painting projects.

name: Advanced Painting
description: Individually determined painting projects.
requirements: ART 3310 or3360; open to juniors or higher.

name: Aqua Media I
description: Introduction to the materials and methods of painting in aqua media.

name: Aqua Media II
description: Continuing study in aqua media.

name: Indian Art and Popular Culture: Independence to the Present
description: (Also offered as AAAS 3375, INDS 3375.) An interdisciplinary lecture/studio art course introducing diverse forms of Indian Art from the traditional through the contemporary. Students complete either research or studio art assignments responding to the course content. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Introduction to Video Art
description: Introduction to techniques and aesthetics of video art.
requirements: ART 2410. Open to Art and Art History majors.

name: Digital Imaging
description: Introduction to the use of the computer to digitize and manipulate photographic imagery.
requirements: ART 2011 and ART 2410; open to juniors or higher Art and Art History majors.

name: Alternative Processes (Photography)
description: Photographic printmaking systems outside conventional silver imaging processes.
requirements: ART 2420; open to Art and Art History majors only; others by consent of instructor.

name: Color Photography
description: The processes and aesthetics of color photography.
requirements: ART 2410; open to Art and Art History majors only; others by consent of instructor.

name: Documentary Photography and Video
description: Investigation of techniques and aesthetics of documentary photography and video.
requirements: ART 2420; open to Art and Art History majors.

name: Portrait Photography
description: Studio practice in fine art portraiture with discussion of contemporary and historical approaches to the genre.
requirements: ART 2420; open to Art and Art History majors.

name: Large Format Photography
description: Introduction to the use of the large format camera to create photographs.
requirements: ART 2420; open to Art and Art History majors.

name: Landscape Photography
description: Studio practice in landscape photography with discussion of contemporary and historical approaches to the genre.
requirements: ART 2420; open to Art and Art History majors.

name: Studio Photography
description: Techniques and aesthetics of studio photography.
requirements: ART 2420; open to Art and Art History majors.

name: Intaglio Printmaking
description: Investigation of black-and-white and color intaglio techniques.

name: Lithography
description: Investigation of lithographic techniques.

name: Printmaking Workshop
description: Workshop for students to continue developing ideas in a print medium.

name: Ceramic Art: Materials and Methods
description: Introduction to contemporary ceramic art materials, methods, and studio practices, including clay properties and preparation, ceramic surface treatment investigations, kiln function and firing. Studio assignments focus on enhancement of skill in design and fabrication of ceramic objects. Presentations, discussions and critiques explore ideas and issues in the field of ceramic art.
requirements: ART 2610 or instructor consent.

name: Ceramics: Vessel Constructions
description: Investigation of principles, techniques, and processes for design and expression in ceramic art, with focus on the vessel form as cultural, historical, and contemporary object and idea. This course extends research, development, and realization of artistic concept in clay and glaze. Projects explore a range of fabrication skills, including hand building and wheelwork, and encourage inventive approaches to material, form, and surface.
requirements: ART 2610; open only to Art majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Ceramics: Wheel Work
description: Investigation of techniques and processes for wheel-based ceramic art and design. Extends student research, development, and realization of concept in clay and glaze. Projects explore a range of wheel-throwing skills, encouraging inventive approaches to material, form, and surface. May be repeated for credit with a change in course content to a maximum of nine credits.
requirements: ART 2610; open only to Art majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Ceramics: Sculptural Approaches
description: Investigation of principles, techniques, and processes for design and expression in ceramic sculpture and sculptural installation. This course extends research, development, and realization of artistic concept in clay and glaze. Projects explore a range of fabrication skills and encourage inventive approaches to material, form, surface, space, and context.
requirements: ART 2610; open only to Art majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Ceramics: Surface Engagement
description: Principles and techniques for surface design and expression in ceramic art. Projects based on a variety of clay forming techniques emphasize two- and three-dimensional ceramic surface mark, image, and color development. Class presentations, discussions and critiques explore ideas and issues in the field of ceramic art.
requirements: ART 2610; open only to Art and Art History majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Sculpture: Wood
description: Investigation of sculptural form, process, and environment, using wood.

name: Sculpture: Metals
description: Investigation of sculptural form, process, and environment, using metal fabrication techniques such as welding, forging, and cold forming.
requirements: ART 2610; open only to Art majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Sculpture: Mold Making and Casting
description: Investigation of sculptural mold making and casting principles, techniques, and processes. The course covers rigid and flexible mold making for casting in a variety of materials, emphasizing technical skill, formal design, and conceptual invention using cast forms for the creation of mixed media sculpture and installation art.
requirements: ART 2610; open only to Art majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Ceramics: Mold Making and Casting
description: Investigation of ceramic art mold making and casting principles, techniques, and processes. Covers plaster mold making for clay and slip casting, formal design and conceptual invention with cast forms, ceramic surface treatment, installation and display strategies.
requirements: ART 2610; open only to Art and Art History majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Ceramics: Clay and Glaze Composition
description: Advanced studio investigations exploring clay and glaze formulation and function, as means to technical control and creative discovery in ceramic art practice.
requirements: ART 2610 and one 3000-level Ceramics course from ART 3605,3610,3615,3620,3625, or 3655. Open only to Art and Art History majors, others by instructor consent

name: Industrial Design: Materials and Techniques
description: (Also offered as ID 3701.) Introduction to a variety of processes used in prototyping, and fabrication for Industrial design. Coursework and instruction will focus on the development of skills required to design and engineer physical renderings of concepts with consideration for materials, methods and techniques, and sequence of operations.

name: Industrial Design: Form, Structure, and Space
description: (Also offered as ID 3705.) Introduces spatial visualization through hands-on exercises that explore the dynamics of form, structure and space. Topics progress from elements of design to explorations of scale and formal and functional relationships. Coursework includes basic construction techniques with hand tools and emphasizes sensitivity to materials and appreciation for craft.
requirements: ART 1010 or ART 1030; or DMD 1001 and DMD 1102; or ENGR 1166; others by Instructor consent.

name: Industrial Design: Drawing and Modeling for Design
description: (Also offered as ID 3710.) This course investigates drawing as a practice of exploration, ideation and visual communication essential to the industrial design process. Techniques include basic freehand perspective drawing, sketching for concept development, mechanical drafting, and digital modeling and rendering methods used to represent three-dimensional objects and environments in space.
requirements: 000 level course(s) in the major: ART 1010 or1030; or DMD 1001 and1102; or ENGR 1166; others by Instructor consent.

name: Industrial Design: Process and Practice
description: (Also offered as ID 3720.) Introduction to industrial design processes including research methods, ideation, form generation and visual communication, with a focus on the development of sustainable design practices. Coursework emphasizes strategies for creating products, environments and systems in the context of real-world challenges.
requirements: ART 3705 and3710, others by instructor consent.

name: Industrial Design: Digital Fabrication
description: (Also offered as ID 3730.) Introduces students to established and emerging technologies in the context of art and design practice, to expand their technical and creative capacities. Students will study and train on current industry standard software programs as well as learn to design for and with additive and subtractive manufacturing methods utilized extensively in the fields of art, design, and engineering. Enrollment is capped at 10 students per class, per semester to ensure adequate space for individual coursework, and manage workflow within the classroom based on current technology and equipment capabilities of the department.
requirements: 000 level course(s) in the major: ART 1010 or1030; DMD 1001 and1102; ENGR 1166; others by instructor consent. Recommended preparation: basic proficiency in Illustrator, CAD, or similar computer modeling programs.

name: SolidWorks for Industrial Design
description: (Also offered as ENGR 3735.) Introduction to basic computer aided design, including isometric, orthogonal views, sections and parametric modeling strategies, including advanced modeling techniques. First and third angle projections. Notions of measuring, tolerances and manufacturing techniques associated by hand and CAD modeling. General manufacturing processes and their relation to modeling individual parts and assemblies. CNC principles, GCODE.

name: Packaging Design and Graphics
description: (Also offered as ID 3750.) Packaging design principles are introduced: protection, containment and communication. Work with existing nets and creation of new nets for innovative solutions. Working with primary, secondary and tertiary packages and CAD mold making for densely packed products. General manufacturing processes, use of graphics, brand recognition.
requirements: nstructor consent; open to Art majors and Multidisciplinary Engineering with the specialization in Industrial Design.

name: Advanced Studio Art Projects
description: Cross-media investigation of studio art ideas, processes and materials through both assigned and self-directed projects. Critical assessment occurs in discussion with faculty and peers.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Studio Internship
description: Supervised practical experience in studio and studio related work. Section one: Communication Design Studio Internship. Supervised practical experience in a commercial design studio, agency, or related work. Prerequisite: B average in communication design classes, ART 3120 and consent of instructor. Section two: Photography Studio Internship. Supervised practical experience in a commercial photography studio, agency or in related work. Prerequisite: B average in photography classes, ART 4410 and consent of a photography instructor. Section three: Art Studio Internship. Supervised practical experience in an art studio. Prerequisite: B average in major Junior - Senior course work and consent of instructor from the major. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Investigation of Special Topics
description: Special topics. Field trips may be required.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Variable Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Independent Study
description: For advanced students to develop a special project in advanced studio art.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher who have a GPA of 3.0, with no outstanding incompletes for any other 3999. Exception only by the approval of the department head.

name: Graphic Design 4: Communication Dynamics
description: Team taught by professional guest designers, this course explores graphic design as a personal, social, political, and cultural activity and investigates modality of production in visual media.
requirements: ART 3120; open only to majors, open to non-majors with instructor consent.

name: Publication Design
description: Introduction to publication design.

name: Graphic Design: Design Center Studio
description: Professional graphic design studio housed in its own independent design environment providing students with real world practical experience. Design students work on commissioned, client based, collaborative, commercial and cultural projects from concept to delivery across all media platforms.
requirements: ART 3120; open only to majors; open only with consent of instructor.

name: Advanced Photography
description: Advanced problems in the use of photography as an art medium.
requirements: ART 2420; open to juniors or higher Art and Art History majors.

name: Senior Project
description: Project developed in student's area of concentration, to be exhibited in the Annual Senior Show. A vigorous and consistent thematic body of work which articulates both technical and conceptual concerns required. To fulfill graduation requirement for B.F.A. students, must be passed with grade of C or better.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Global Perspectives on Western Art: Renaissance to the Present
description: Survey of Western art (15th Century through the present) within a global perspective. Explores transformations in Western art in relation to the West's fundamental interconnection with non-Western societies. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Introduction to Art History: Prehistoric - 14th Century
description: Survey of art and architecture from prehistoric times through the fourteenth century. CA 1.

name: Introduction to Art History: 15th Century - Present
description: Survey of art and architecture from the fifteenth century to the present day. CA 1.

name: Introduction to Asian Art
description: Asian art and architecture from prehistory to the present. Asian artistic practices as well as transcultural artistic connections in Asia and beyond. CA 1.

name: From Sun Gods to Lowriders: Introduction to Latin American Art
description: Survey of Latin American art from 200 B.C. to the present. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Introduction to Architecture
description: An introduction to the history of architecture considered in its social, technological and urban context. CA 1.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be repeated for credit with a change in course content.
requirements: onsent of department head required, normally before the student's departure to study abroad.

name: Global Jerusalem
description: An introduction to the art and architecture of Jerusalem and the diverse religious, social, and political contexts of related re-creations across the world, from prehistory to the contemporary period. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Art, Politics, and Propaganda
description: (Also offered as AAAS 2030.) Asian art and propaganda in the Cold War era (1949-1991) and its relation to Europe, the Soviet Union, and the United States. May include analysis of visual arts, film, photography, and multimedia.

name: Variable Topics
description: May be repeated for credit for a maximum of nine credits, with a change in topic.

name: Art and Activism
description: (Also offered as HRTS 2210.) A history of the relationship between art and political activism around the world from the 1960s to the present.

name: Race, Gender, Sexuality, and the Power of Looking
description: (Also offered as AAAS 2222, AFRA 2222.) A beginning investigation into the issues of what constitutes visual culture and how race, gender, and sexuality are seen and not seen. The goals of the course include engaging with the history and scholarly dialogues around visual studies, becoming more active and critical visual consumers and critics, and understanding personal stakes and diverse positions in dialogues about visualizing gender and race. CA 1. CA 4.
requirements: ot open for credit to students who have passed ARTH 2198 when offered as "Race, Gender, and the Power of Looking."

name: Curating Contemporary Art: Issues, Themes, Theories, and Practices
description: Explores premises, concepts, and practices of mounting art exhibitions.
requirements: ot open for credit to students who have passed ARTH 3995 when offered as "Curating Contemporary Art".

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be repeated for credit with a change in course content.
requirements: onsent of department head required, normally before the student's departure to study abroad.

name: Curatorial Intensive: Exhibitions Outside the Museum
description: Explores theory and practice of curating outside traditional art spaces. Culminates in student-curated exhibition. CA 1.
requirements: pen to sophomores and above.

name: Museums and the Interpretation of Culture
description: The history and philosophy of museums. CA 1.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Museums and the Interpretation of Culture
description: The history and philosophy of museums. CA 1.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Asian American Art and Visual Culture
description: (Also offered as AAAS 3220.) Topics in contemporary Asian American art and visual culture, 1960's to present.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Asian American Art and Visual Culture
description: Topics in contemporary Asian American art and visual culture, 1960's to present.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to Art History and Art majors, others with consent of instructor; open to juniors or higher.

name: The Artist and Society
description: An investigation of the artist's professional function throughout history in different Western societies. CA 1.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: African-American Art
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3050 W.) The artistic and social legacy of African American art from the eighteenth century to the present day. CA 4.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Greek Art
description: (Also offered as CAMS 3251.) Greek art and architecture from the ninth century B.C. to the first-century A.D.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Roman Art
description: (Also offered as CAMS 3252.) History of Roman art and architecture.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Roman Art
description: History of Roman art and architecture.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to Art History and Art majors, others with consent of instructor; open to juniors or higher.

name: Early Medieval Art
description: Early medieval art from the fifth through the tenth centuries. Germanic metalwork, Hiberno-Saxon manuscripts, and the art of the era of Charlemagne and his successors.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to Art History and Art majors, others with consent of instructor; open to juniors or higher.

name: Gothic Art
description: Gothic art and architecture, with emphasis on the court styles of England and France.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to Art History and Art majors, others with consent of instructor; open to juniors or higher.

name: The Early Illustrated Book
description: The early history of the illustrated book, from antiquity through the introduction of printing.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to Art History and Art majors, others with consent of instructor; open to juniors or higher.

name: Art of the Italian Renaissance
description: Italian art and architecture 1400-1600.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Art of the Northern Renaissance
description: Painting, sculpture, graphic arts of the Lowlands and Germany, 1400-1600.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Baroque Art
description: Art and architecture of the seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries with emphasis on Italy, Netherlands, France and Spain.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Eighteenth Century European Art
description: Art and architecture of the eighteenth century with emphasis on England and France.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Nineteenth Century European Art
description: European art from Neo-Classicism to Realism. CA 1.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Visual Culture of the United States, 19th Century
description: (Also offered as AMST 3440.) An exploration of how visual culture in the long 19th century contributed to the formation of the United States.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Visual Culture of the United States, 19th Century
description: (Also offered as AMST 3440 W.) An exploration of how visual culture in the long 19th century contributed to the formation of the United States.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: History of Photography: 1839 to World War I
description: Topics in the history of photography from 1839 to World War I. CA 1.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: History of Photography: 1839 to World War I
description: Topics in the history of photography from 1839 to World War I.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Urban Architecture: International Perspectives
description: The historical development of the urban, built environment in Europe, Asia, and the Americas.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Modern Art
description: Topics in the art of the first half of the twentieth century.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Modern Art
description: Topics in the art of the first half of the twentieth century.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to Art History and Art majors, others with consent of instructor; open to juniors or higher.

name: Contemporary Art
description: Topics in the art of the second half of the twentieth century. CA 1.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Contemporary Art
description: Topics in the art of the second half of the twentieth century. CA 1.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: History of Photography: World War I to Present
description: Topics in the history of photography from World War I to the present.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: History of Photography: World War I - Present
description: Topics in the history of photography from World War I to the present.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to Art History and Art majors, others with consent of instructor; open to juniors or higher.

name: History and Theory of Digital Art
description: (Also offered as AMST 3570, DMD 3570.) Investigates forms of digital and Internet art and the mostly forgotten histories of the technologies behind them. Forms and themes to be explored include games/gaming, surveillance art, cyberfeminism, data visualization, and crowdsourced art. CA 1. CA 4.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to sophomores or higher.

name: Human Rights, Digital Media, Visual Culture
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3575.) The problematics of digital media and visual representation in conceptualizing, documenting, and visualizing human rights and humanitarian issues. CA 1.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Image as Witness: Testimony, Witness, Confession
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3580.) Explores the role of visual culture in bearing witness to human rights abuses.
requirements: ot open for credit to students who have passed ARTH 3995 when offered as "Image as Witness."

name: Image as Witness: Testimony, Witness, Confession
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3580 W.) Explores the role of visual culture in bearing witness to human rights abuses.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Not open for credit to students who have passed ARTH 3995 when offered as "Image as Witness."

name: Beyond Recognition: Images, Distance and Speed in and for Human Rights
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3625.) Explores the impact of visual images on the process of “recognition” of other human beings, upon which human rights are based.

name: Beyond Recognition: Images, Distance and Speed in and for Human Rights
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3625 W.) Explores the impact of visual images on the process of “recognition” of other human beings, upon which human rights are based.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Alternative Modernities: Visual Culture of Latin America
description: A thematic survey of Latin American art from the nineteenth century to present. CA 4-INT.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Alternative Modernities: Visual Culture of Latin America
description: A thematic survey of Latin American art from the nineteenth century to present. CA 4-INT.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to Art History and Art majors, others with consent of instructor; open to juniors or higher.

name: Mexican and Chicano Art from Muralism to La Raza
description: Topics in Mexican and Chicano art from Mexican Independence to the present. CA 4.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Mexican and Chicano Art from Muralism to La Raza
description: Topics in Mexican and Chicano art from Mexican Independence to the present. CA 4.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to Art History and Art majors, others with consent of instructor; open to sophomores or higher.

name: Islamic Art History
description: (Also offered as HIST 3710, ARIS 3710.) A survey of the arts associated with Islam from the life of Muhammad in the seventh century through the early modern period, with an emphasis upon the Middle East, North Africa, and the Iberian Peninsula. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Islamic Art History
description: (Also offered as ARIS 3710 W, HIST 3710 W.) A survey of the arts associated with Islam from the life of Muhammad in the seventh century through the early modern period, with an emphasis upon the Middle East, North Africa, and the Iberian Peninsula. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: The Art of China
description: Survey of major art forms in China c. 2500 B.C. to the twentieth century.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: The Art of China
description: Survey of major art forms in China c. 2500 B.C to the twentieth century.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: African Art
description: A survey of African art from antiquity to present.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Field Studies Internship in Art History
description: Supervised practical experience in museum and museum related work.   Section one: Wadsworth Atheneum Internship. Participation in  Museum Studies Seminars, staff meetings and completion of individual  project at the Atheneum. Application must be approved by  Wadsworth Atheneum Education Department; deadlines are in April  for first semester and in November for second semester. May be  repeated for credit.
requirements: wo 1000 level ARTH courses; two 3000-4000 level ARTH courses; open to sophomores or higher.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Department Head required, normally before the student's departure to study abroad. May be repeated with a change in course content.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Investigation of Special Topics
description: Special topics. May be repeated for credit with a change in course content.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Art History Capstone: Professional Development in Visual Culture and the Humanities
description: Introduction to educational and professional paths for students of art history and visual culture. Prepares students for professional paths that make use of critical thinking, communication, media and visual-literacy knowledge and skills gained through the study of art history. Course content brings together academic study with practical knowledge essential to careers in the cultural sector and beyond.
requirements: pen only to Art History Majors; juniors and higher with 15 credits of art history at the 2000-level or above.

name: Independent Study
description: Designed for advanced students who wish to pursue the study of a special topic, culminating in a project in art history. May be repeated for a total of six credits.
requirements: pen to students who are juniors or higher and have a 3.0 departmental GPA or higher.

name: Pathways to Asian American Studies
description: Keywords, themes, and career paths in Asian American Studies; critical and historical perspective on Asian diasporic peoples in the United States within a global framework. Topics may include popular culture, history, social justice, and activism. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Pathways to Asian Studies
description: Keywords, themes, and career paths in Asian Studies. Topics may include geography, languages, international relations, intercultural communication, and geopolitics. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Introduction to Critical Refugee Studies
description: Introduction to concepts, theories, and histories of refugees based on their lived experiences and engagement with local refugee communities.

name: Introduction to Critical Muslim Studies
description: Survey of Muslim cultures across Asia and the Pacific with an interdisciplinary focus on their transnational diasporas and the historical practice of Islamophobia and Anti-Muslim Racism. Students gain knowledge of local Muslim communities in Connecticut and explore diverse ways of being Muslim.

name: Art, Politics, and Propaganda
description: (Also offered as ARTH 2030.) Asian art and propaganda in the Cold War era (1949-1991) and its relation to Europe, the Soviet Union, and the United States. May include analysis of visual arts, film, photography, and multimedia.

name: Asian Theatre and Performance
description: (Also offered as DRAM 2136.) Asian theatre, opera, dance, and other performance forms and their elaboration, reworking, and dissolution in modern and contemporary times, examined in relation to changes in society, politics, religion, and culture. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Introducing India: Diversity and Dynamism
description: (Also offered as SOCI 2200.) An introduction to the historical, political, social, economic, and cultural diversity of India. Topics may include: cultural diversity in languages, religions, and regions; socio-political challenges; power relations that construct patterns of privilege and marginalization; and contemporary human rights issues.
requirements: ecommended preparation: One introductory AAAS or SOCI course.

name: Introducing India: Diversity and Dynamism
description: (Also offered as SOCI 2200 W.) An introduction to the historical, political, social, economic, and cultural diversity of India. Topics may include: cultural diversity in languages, religions, and regions; socio-political challenges; power relations that construct patterns of privilege and marginalization; and contemporary human rights issues.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: One introductory AAAS or SOCI course.

name: Introduction to Asian American Studies
description: (Also offered as AMST 2201.) A multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary introduction to major themes in Asian American Studies. Concepts of identity and community, migration and labor histories, Asians and the law, representations of Asians in visual and popular culture, gender issues, interracial and interethnic relations, and human rights. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Sociological Perspectives on Asian American Women
description: (Also offered as SOCI 2210.) An overview of social structures, inter-group relations, and women's rights, focusing on the experience of Asian American women. CA 4.

name: Sociological Perspectives on Asian American Women
description: (Also offered as SOCI 2210 W.) An overview of social structures, inter-group relations, and women's rights, focusing on the experience of Asian American women. CA 4.

name: Asian Indian Women: Activism and Social Change in India and the United States
description: (Also offered as SOCI 2220, HRTS 2220.) How gender, class, and ethnicity/race structure everyday lives of Asian Indian women in both India and the United States.

name: Race, Gender, Sexuality, and the Power of Looking
description: (Also offered as AFRA 2222, ARTH 2222.) A beginning investigation into the issues of what constitutes visual culture and how race, gender, and sexuality are seen and not seen. The goals of the course include engaging with the history and scholarly dialogues around visual studies, becoming more active and critical visual consumers and critics, and understanding personal stakes and diverse positions in dialogues about visualizing gender and race. CA 1. CA 4.
requirements: ot open for credit to students who have passed ARTH 2198 when offered as "Race, Gender, and the Power of Looking."

name: The Pacific in World History
description: (Also offered as HIST 2225.) The Pacific Ocean as a lens for thinking about modern history. Topics include the flow of people, ideas, goods, elements of nature (such as whales and bird guano), and technology among the nations and peoples of the Pacific World; and the impact of colonialism, war, decolonization, and the Cold War on the history of the region and the fortunes of indigenous peoples. Sources include scholarly works, government documents, diaries, and literature. Formerly offered as AAAS/HIST 2101. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
requirements: ecommended preparation: HIST 1201 and HIST 2100.

name: Modern Japanese Literature
description: (Also offered as ENGL 2305, JAPN 2305.) Japanese literature across genres from 1868 to the present, studied in English translation. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Asian American Experience Since 1850
description: (Also offered as HIST 2530.) Survey of Asian American experiences in the United States since 1850. Responses by Asian Americans to both opportunities and discrimination.

name: Chinese Eco-Literature and Eco-Cinema
description: (Also offered as CHIN 2660 E.) Examines the development of eco-literature and eco-cinema in modern and contemporary China. Taught in English.

name: Early Modern India: From Muslim Rulers to British Raj
description: (Also offered as HIST 2811.) History of India from the 1200s to the 1800s, including the rise and fall of the Muslim-dominated Mughal Empire and the advent of British colonialism. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Modern India
description: (Also offered as HIST 2812.) History of India from the 1800s to the contemporary era, including colonialism under the British crown, the movement for independence, economic development, and ethnic and religious conflict. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Early Modern China: From Mongols to Manchus
description: (Also offered as HIST 2821.) Survey of Chinese history from 1200 to 1800. Topics include economic growth, imperial expansion, ethnic diversity, relations with foreign countries, intellectual currents, and state-society relations. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Modern China
description: (Also offered as HIST 2822.) Survey of patterns of modern China since 1800. Topics will include reforms and revolutions, industrialization and urbanization, and family and population growth. CA 1. CA 4-INT. Formerly offered as AAAS/HIST 3822.

name: Empire and Nation in Southeast Asia
description: (Also offered as HIST 2841.) Major themes in modern Southeast Asian history from the 17th century to the present: growth of global commerce; western imperialism; nationalism; emergence of independent nation-states; challenges of the post-independence period. Emphasis on the region's largest countries: Burma, Cambodia, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: History of Vietnam
description: (Also offered as HIST 2842.) Introduction to the history of the Vietnamese from the late Bronze Age to the present: the ancient culture of the Red River delta, the millennium of Chinese rule, the independent kingdom of Dai Viet and its successors, French colonialism, the Vietnam War, and postwar Vietnam. Formerly offered as AAAS/HIST 3842.

name: China and the West
description: (Also offered as HIST 2866.) Survey of China's political and cultural encounters with the West from the sixteenth-century to 1949. Situates these encounters within the context of world history and a dialogue among civilizations. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Foreign Relations of China Since 1949
description: (Also offered as HIST 2868.) A survey of China's foreign policy from the Cold War to the present, including its domestic politics, Communist ideology, economic reforms, and changing role in global affairs. Formerly offered as AAAS/HIST 2688. CA 1.

name: Foreign Relations of China Since 1949
description: (Also offered as HIST 2868 W.) A survey of China's foreign policy from the Cold War to the present, including its domestic politics, Communist ideology, economic reforms, and changing role in global affairs. Formerly offered as AAAS/HIST 2688W. CA 1.

name: Asian American Literature
description: (Also offered as ENGL 3212.) Literature, theatre, film about Asian American communities and culture in the United States from the mid-nineteenth century to the present. CA 4.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Asian American Art and Visual Culture
description: (Also offered as ARTH 3020.) Topics in contemporary Asian American art and visual culture, 1960's to present.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Topics in Chinese Literature
description: (Also offered as CHIN 3271.) Social and political issues in Chinese modernity and postmodernity. Taught in English.
requirements: CHIN 1121 and1122or instructor consent.

name: Women in Chinese Literature and Film
description: (Also offered as CHIN 3282.) Critical study of representations of women in Chinese film and literature from the early twentieth century to the present. Development of feminist movements in China and gender issues. Taught in English.
requirements: ecommended preparation: CHIN 1121 and1122or equivalent.

name: Special Topics in Asian American Studies
description: Credits and hours by arrangement.
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.

name: Indian Art and Popular Culture: Independence to the Present
description: (Also offered as ART 3375, INDS 3375.) An interdisciplinary lecture/studio art course introducing diverse forms of Indian Art from the traditional through the contemporary. Students complete either research or studio art assignments responding to the course content. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Japanese Americans and World War II
description: (Also offered as HIST 3531, AMST 3531.) The events leading to martial law and executive order 9066, the wartime experience of Japanese Americans, and national consequences. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Immigrants and the Shaping of American History
description: (Also offered as HIST 3554.) The origins of immigration to the United States and the interaction of immigrants with the social, political, and economic life of the nation after 1789, with emphasis on such topics as nativism, assimilation, and the "ethnic legacy." CA 1. CA 4.
requirements: ecommended preparation: One course in American history.

name: The Middle East Crucible
description: (Also offered as HIST 3712.) Twentieth-century developments in the Middle East, focusing on political Islam/Islamism, Orientalism, imperialism, the history of struggles for representative government, nationalism, the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, super-power rivalries, and the search for identity, independence, and peace with justice. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: East Asia to the Mid-Nineteenth Century
description: (Also offered as HIST 3808.) The major problems and issues of traditional Chinese and Japanese history and historiography. Special emphasis on the "Great Tradition" in ideas of both civilizations.

name: East Asia Since the Mid-Nineteenth Century
description: (Also offered as HIST 3809.) The reactions of East Asia to the Western threat, and the rise of Asian nationalism, communism, and fascism. Special attention to the tensions caused by the conflict of ideas.

name: History of Modern Chinese Political Thought
description: (Also offered as HIST 3820.) Survey of Chinese political ideas and ideologies since the nineteenth century, examining the influences of Confucianism and Western conceptions on the revolutionary changes in political thought in China over the last 100 years, including Marxism, liberalism, anarchism, authoritarianism, and democracy. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: History of the People's Republic of China
description: (Also offered as HIST 3823.) Survey of the political, social, economic, and cultural history of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) since 1949, with focus on social struggle, state-building, and economic development. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Environmental History in East Asia
description: (Also offered as HIST 3830 E.) Interactions between humans and the natural world in East Asia, with attention to the environmental impact of politics, economics, and culture. Topics include natural resources, energy, ideas about nature, pollution, and environmentalism. Geographical coverage may include one or more of the following: China, Japan, Korea, and Taiwan. CA 4-INT.

name: The Vietnam War
description: (Also offered as HIST 3845.) Origins, evolution, and aftermath of the Vietnamese conflict: the prewar history of colonialism, nationalism, communism, and anticommunism; the formation and development of the three main Vietnamese belligerents; American intervention; culture and politics in wartime Vietnam; escalation and de-escalation of the war; the postwar legacy. CA 1. CA 4 INT.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Genocide and Mass Killings in Asia
description: (Also offered as HIST 3846, HRTS 3846.) Case studies of historical and/or contemporary genocide and mass killings in Asia. May focus on any time period and any part of the continent. CA4-INT.

name: Genocide and Mass Killings in Asia
description: (Also offered as HIST 3846 W, HRTS 3846 W.) Case studies of historical and/or contemporary genocide and mass killings in Asia. May focus on any time period and any part of the continent. CA4-INT.

name: Variable Topics
description: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Experiential/Service Learning Seminar
description: (Also offered as AFRA 4100, LLAS 4100, WGSS 4100.) Interdisciplinary examination of the history of social justice organizing in the U.S.; theories, strategies, and practice of community organizing movements such as those for immigration, environmental, reproductive, and racial justice. Includes practice in community organizing and political advocacy.

name: Independent Study
description: Credits, not to exceed three per semester, and hours by arrangement. With a change of subject, this course may be repeated for credit.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Foundations of Biology
description: Major biological principles with emphasis on their importance to humans and modern society; designed for non-science majors. CA 3-LAB.
requirements: ot open to students who have passed BIOL 1107,1108or1110. Students may not receive more than 12 credits for courses in Biology at the 1000 level.

name: The Biology of Human Health and Disease
description: A laboratory course designed for non-science majors to introduce the concepts of biology and their application to the individual, society and humankind by focusing on health and disease issues. CA 3-LAB.
requirements: tudents may not receive more than 12 credits in Biology at the 1000 level.

name: Principles of Biology I
description: Designed to provide a foundation for more advanced courses in Biology and related sciences. Topics covered include molecular and cell biology, animal anatomy and physiology. Lab exercises include dissection of preserved animals. CA 3-LAB.
requirements: ecommended preparation: A course in high school level chemistry or concurrent enrollment in CHEM 1127 Q. Students may not receive more than 12 credits in Biology at the 1000 level.

name: Principles of Biology II
description: Designed to provide a foundation for more advanced courses in biology and related sciences. Topics covered include evolution and population genetics, plant physiology and diversity, animal diversity and behavior, and ecology. CA 3-LAB.
requirements: tudents may not receive more than 12 credits for courses in BIOL at the 1000 level.

name: Topics in Modern Biology
description: Readings, lectures, seminars, films and field trips exploring current developments in biology and their social and scientific implications. May be repeated with a change of content.
requirements: oncurrent enrollment in BIOL 1107 or1108required. Students cannot earn more than 12 credits of 1000 level BIOL.

name: Introduction to Botany
description: Designed to provide a foundation for more advanced courses in biology and related sciences. Structure, physiology, reproduction, diversity, evolution and ecology of plants as a basis for understanding the broader principles of biology. Surveys important groups of plants, fungi and algae. CA 3-LAB.
requirements: tudents may not receive more than 12 credits for courses in BIOL at the 1000 level.

name: Special Topics
description: Credits, prerequisites and hours as determined by the Senate Curricula and Course Committee.  May be repeated for credit with a change in topic.
requirements: redits, prerequisites, and hours as determined by the Senate Curricula and Courses Committee.

name: Introduction to Biological Research
description: Internship in Biology research.  May be repeated for credit with a change in content.
requirements: BIOL 1107 or1108and consent of instructor.

name: Introduction to Undergraduate Research
description: Introduction to the variety of research programs in the Life Sciences on the Storrs campus. Required of Sophomore Biology Honor students; also open to students interested in undergraduate research. With a change of content, this course may be repeated for credit.
requirements: ecommended preparation: BIOL 1107 and1108or equivalent.

name: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
description: Fundamental concepts and techniques of engineering and medical science and their integration. The art and science of medicine and the process of medical diagnosis and treatment. Topics include: diagnostic instrumentation, diagnostic measurements and their interplay; bioelectric phenomena, biomechanics, and biomaterials; biochemical engineering; computers in medicine; molecular medicine and biotechnology; medical imaging.
requirements: MATH 1132 Q, which may be taken concurrently; PHYS 1230 or1501Qor 1530, each of which may be taken concurrently; open to non-BME majors with instructor consent. Recommended preparation: BIOL 1107.

name: International Study
description: Special Biomedical Engineering topics taken in an international study program. May be repeated for up to six credits with change in topic. May count toward the major with consent of the adviser and approved plan of study.

name: Physiological Modeling
description: Techniques for analysis and modeling of biomedical systems. Application of advanced mathematics (including Differential Equations, Laplace Transforms and Statistics) and computer-aided methods to study problems at the interface of engineering and biology. Elements of  physiological modeling and the solution of the transient and forced  response for a variety of biomechanical, biomaterial, bioelectrical and biochemical systems.
requirements: MATH 1132 Q, which may be taken concurrently. Open only to Biomedical Engineering majors. Recommended preparation: BIOL 1107.

name: LabVIEW Basics for Engineers
description: Introduces LabVIEW programming environment. The fundamentals of using graphical programming to collect, analyze, display and store data are covered. Learn techniques for designing stand alone applications, creating interactive user interfaces and optimizing data flow.
requirements: CSE 1010 or 1100. Open only to Biomedical Engineering majors, others by instructor consent. Not open for credits to students who have passed ENGR 3120.

name: International Study
description: Special Biomedical Engineering topics taken in an international study program. May be repeated for up to six credits with change in topic. May count toward the major with consent of the adviser and approved plan of study.

name: Biosensors and Nanodevices for Biomedical Applications
description: Current and emerging technologies in biosensors for biomedical applications. Topics include principles of molecular and bio/chemical sensing, techniques for sensor integration, nano/micro electro mechanical systems (NEMS/MEMS) technologies used in biosensors, and commercial/clinical applications of biosensors.
requirements: pen only to BME majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Biosystem Analysis
description: A lecture course that covers Fourier analysis, Laplace analysis and Z-transforms. Techniques for generating quantitative mathematical models of physiological control systems; the behavior of physiological control systems using both time and frequency domain methods.
requirements: ECE 2001; open only to Biomedical Engineering majors, others by instructor consent. This course and ECE 3101 may not be both taken for credit.

name: Introduction to Computational and Systems Biology
description: Introduction to the role of computational and mathematical analyses in biological sequence (DNA, RNA, proteins) analysis and quantitative mathematical models of cell biological processes (systems and quantitative biology). Algorithms for sequence alignment, analysis of networks involved in transcription, development, and signal transduction. Programming in the Python language will be an integral part of the course, but no prior experience with Python is necessary.
requirements: MATH 2210 Q,2410Q; STAT 3025 Qor3345Qor MATH 3160.

name: Stem Cells for Regenerative Medicine
description: Introduces the fundamental concept and translational application of regenerative medicine such as stem cells, gene therapy, cell and tissue therapy. Topics include tissue-specific stem cells, embryonic stem cells, induced pluripotent stem cells and their potential therapeutic applications for musculoskeletal, cardiovascular and nervous systems.
requirements: pen only to BME majors, others with consent.

name: Biomedical Engineering Measurements
description: A lecture and laboratory course that covers fundamentals of biomedical measurement and patient safety. Measurements of physical quantities by means of electronic instruments, mechanical devices and biochemical processes. Analysis of measurement systems using  mathematical models. Methods of measuring signals in the presence of  noise. Use of  computers in measurement systems.
requirements: ECE 2001, open only to BME majors, others by instructor consent. Recommended preparation: BME 3120 and BME 3400 or ECE 3101.

name: Developing Mobile Apps for Healthcare
description: Mobile apps are changing the way doctors and patients approach health care. Designed for use by doctors, patients or both, the apps available range from handy databases about drugs and diseases to sophisticated monitors that read a person's physiological signals. Students will learn the basic elements of apps development on Android platforms, including XML, and Java, UI amongst others. Topics include how to handle patient data in the cloud using HIPAA-Compliant web service and how to integrate machine learning models in app development. No previous programming experience is needed.
requirements: pen only to BME majors, others with consent.

name: Principles of Biomedical Optical Sensing: A Laboratory-Based Course
description: Undergraduate laboratory course that covers the fundamental optical sensing principles of devices used in medicine and research. Topics include laser beam manipulation and forming, optical fibers and photodetectors, polarizers and polarimetry, molecular sensing, pressure mapping via FTIR, blood oxygen concentration (Pulse Oximetry), interferometric-based imaging systems and photo spectrometry. The course is designed for students’ who seek to acquire skills in handling and working with optical components.
requirements: PHYS 1502 Q, open only to Biomedical Engineering majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Biomechanics
description: Application of solid mechanics theory to describe and analyze mechanical behaviors of biological tissues. Basic concepts in mechanics of materials, including the essential mathematics, kinematics of deformation and motion, stress, constitutive relations. Biomechanics principles; identifying, formulating and solving problems related to bone, cartilage, tendon, cardiac and vascular tissues. Introduction of experimental methods and computational modeling of biological tissues. A separate laboratory component will introduce students to experimental methods in more detail. Laboratory reports with revisions are required.
requirements: CE 2110; open only to Biomedical Engineering majors; others by instructor consent.

name: Failure Analysis for Biomedical Application
description: Study and analysis of the causes of material and device failures as it relates to biomedical engineering. Types of material failures and failure mechanisms. Discussion of appropriate material selection, design and application as it relates to mitigating failure risk. Case studies of historical material failures in biomedical engineering.
requirements: MSE 2001 or2101; open only to Biomedical Engineering majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Multiphysics Finite Element Analysis
description: The course material emphasizes basic mathematical and physical principles underlying finite element analysis (FEA), general procedure of identifying and solving engineering problems using COMSOL Multiphysics FEA software, and interpretation of FEA results.
requirements: MATH 1132 Qand2410Q, or by instructor consent.

name: Human Factors Engineering
description: This course introduces students to the field of human factors engineering. Topics include user-centered design and the different tools available to anticipate and solve human-use issues.
requirements: pen only to Biomedical Engineering majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Biomaterials
description: A lecture and laboratory course that introduces a series of implant materials including metals, ceramics, glass ceramics, polymers, and composites. These materials are compared with the natural materials, with consideration given to issues of mechanical properties, biocompatibility, degradation of materials by biological systems, and biological response to artificial materials. Particular attention is given to the materials for the total hip prosthesis, dental restoration, and implantable medical devices.
requirements: MSE 2101 and MATH 2410; open only to BME majors. Cannot be taken for credit after passing MSE 3700.

name: Drug Delivery
description: Introduction to drug delivery systems that provide pharmaceutical agents at target tissues, the mechanism of pharmacokinetic regulation, the basics, technology, and applications of drug delivery systems. Emphasis on understanding the principles of pharmacokinetics and drug delivery systems to improve clinical efficacy as well as to reduce side effects.
requirements: BME 3700; open only to BME majors, others with consent.

name: Introduction to Microscopy and Biophotonics
description: Basic principles of modern light microscopy and related biophotonics techniques. Matlab will be used to model various imaging platforms. Topics include geometrical optics; image processing in spatial and Fourier domain; lensless microscopy imaging; light scattering and absorption in tissue; wave propagation; coherent and incoherent imaging; lens-based imaging systems; optical aberrations; phase retrieval; brightfield, darkfield, phase-contrast, and confocal microscopy; holographic imaging; light field microscopy; 3D tomographic imaging; autofocusing for whole slide imaging; two-photon imaging; structured illumination and other super-resolution techniques; Fourier ptychographic imaging; detectors and photon transfer curve; image denoising via regularization; optical coherent tomography.
requirements: BME 3400 or ECE 3101; open only to Biomedical Engineering majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Tissue Engineering Laboratory
description: This is an undergraduate laboratory course designed to provide hands on training in tissue engineering methods and techniques. Students will learn the necessary skills required for culturing and maintaining cells to practice tissue engineering strategies. The students will also learn basic tissue engineering lab techniques and develop assays and staining methods related to the development and evaluation of in vitro tissue engineering products.
requirements: BME 3700; open only to Biomedical Engineering majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Microfluidics and Lab-on-Chip
description: The course provides a broad overview of microfluidics technology, lab-on-chip, wearable/implantable devices and smartphone-based optical sensing technology, and their biomedical applications. It also covers the fundamentals of micro/nano fabrication technologies and additive manufacturing (e.g., 3D printing). In addition, the basic principles of biology and chemistry, with a focus on how to integrate them into microfluidic devices and biomedical microsystems are introduced and discussed.
requirements: pen only to Biomedical Engineering majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Introduction to Biomanufacturing: Pharmaceutical Proteins
description: This course provides an overview of the large scale bioprocessing and biomanufacturing of biopharmaceutical products (biologics). Topics include conventional versus biologic drug manufacturing, key phases in the process of drug manufacturing (bench to bottle), upstream and downstream operations, bioreactor design, purification process, safety and efficiency of biologics, quality assurance, regulation and introduction to Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP) in bio-manufacturing.
requirements: pen only to Biomedical Engineering majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Computational Genomics
description: (Also offered as CSE 3810.) Computational methods for genomic data analysis. Topics covered include statistical modeling of biological sequences, probabilistic models of DNA and protein evolution, expectation maximization and Gibbs sampling algorithms, genomic sequence variation, and applications in genomics and genetic epidemiology.
requirements: CSE 1729 or CSE 2050; STAT 3025 Qor3345Qor3375Qor MATH 3160; open only to students in the College of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors. Recommended preparation: BIOL 1107.

name: Junior Design
description: Students work through a structured process that emulates an open-ended, real-world design of a biomedical engineering product. Project definition and product specifications, project scheduling and management, team interactions, failure and safety criteria, progress reporting, marketing concepts, ethical issues, prototype development, proper documentation and technical presentation of the final project outcomes. Includes a significant writing component, makes use of computers and design software, and involves hands-on design explorations. Students will complete a semester-long design project that demonstrates the skills and knowledge learned during the course in preparation for the capstone design experience.
requirements: CE 2110, ECE 2001, and MSE 2101; open only to Biomedical Engineering majors.

name: Neural Information Processing and Sensory Coding
description: Processing, transmission, and storage of information in the central and peripheral nervous systems. Mechanisms of signal generation, transmission and coding by neurons and dendrites. Analysis of invertebrate and vertebrate visual and auditory systems, including: mechanisms of neurosensory transduction, coding, and signal-to-noise ratio enhancement. Neural spatio-temporal filters for feature extraction and pattern recognition. Information theoretic analysis of signal encoding and transmission in the nervous system. Assumes a background in linear systems and feedback control systems.
requirements: BME 3400 or ECE 3101; open only to Biomedical Engineering majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Neural Prostheses
description: Development of neural prostheses. Topics will cover physiology of neurological disorders, key concepts of neural prostheses, electrode designs and materials, fabrication methodologies, measurement techniques, histological evaluations, and clinical translations. Students will also learn to critique journal articles and to write their own NIH research proposal.
requirements: pen only to Biomedical Engineering majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Nanomedicine: From Concepts to Applications
description: Teaches students competency and practical skills in applying nanotechnology to solve problems in medicine. Upon completion of the course, the students will be able to understand the basic concept of Nanomedicine and have an overview of the Nanomedicine field; understand principles and experimental methods in designing, generating, charactering and evaluating nanotechnology-enabled therapeutics; understand how Nanomedicine is translated from scientific innovation to clinical applications; understand how Nanomedicine is applied in the cutting-edge breakthroughs of biotechnology and medicine; develop critical thinking and independent learning skills; and design a successful Nanomedicine project.
requirements: pen only to Biomedical Engineering majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Introduction to Medical Imaging
description: Introduction to spatial signals including spatial impulse response, spatial sampling and filtering, spatial Fourier transforms, and back projection.  Principles, systems and clinical applications of X-ray, X-ray CT, ultrasound, Positron Emission Tomography (PET) and Single Photon Emission Tomography (SPECT), and MRI imaging.
requirements: PHYS 1502 Q; BME 3500, and BME 3400 or ECE 3101; open only to Biomedical Engineering majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Physiological Control Systems
description: Analysis of human physiological control systems and regulators through the use of mathematical models. Identification and linearization of system components. Systems interactions, stability, noise, and the relation of system malfunction to disease. The analysis and design of feedback systems to control physiological states through the automatic administration of drugs.
requirements: BME 3400 or ECE 3101; open only to BME majors.

name: Systems Biology of Cells and Tissues
description: The course will present a broad systems level overview of how cells and tissues interact with each other at different physical scales to create complex physiological outcomes. In addition, it will cover a variety of techniques and experimental models in biology, as well as introduce examples to observe cells and tissues at multiple scales.
requirements: pen only to BME majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Bioinstrumentation
description: Modeling, analysis, design, and operation of transducers, sensors, and electrodes, for physiological systems; operational and instrumentation  amplifiers for bioelectric event signal conditioning, interfacing and  processing; A/D converters and hardware and software principles as related to sampling, storing, processing, and display of biosignals and digital computers.
requirements: BME 3500; BME 3400(or ECE3101); open only to Biomedical Engineering majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Biomedical Signal Processing Laboratory
description: This course provides students the opportunity to develop skills to use computational methods in time- and frequency domains to analyze some of most commonly used biomedical signals such as ECG, photoplethysmogram (PPG), electromyogram (EMG), and electrodermal activity (EDA). All data analyses are performed using Matlab software.
requirements: BME 3100,3500, and BME 4500; Open only to Biomedical Engineering majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Biomedical Materials and Implants
description: This advanced course will enable students to further expand their knowledge in various aspects of biomaterials science, engineering and applications. The course will focus on the strategies to improve cell-material and tissue-implant interaction. An emphasis is placed on the biomaterial innovations and technologies that integrate bioactivity, functionality to improve the performance of the implants. The course will also provide an overview of the FDA regulatory pathways for biomaterial and implant approvals.
requirements: BME 3700; open only to BME majors. Not open to students who have passed MSE 4701.

name: Tissue Engineering
description: Presents basic principles of biological, medical, and material science as applied to implantable medical devices, drug delivery systems and artificial organs.
requirements: BME 3700; open only to BME majors.

name: Cellular Engineering
description: Cellular engineering emphasizes the navigation and understanding of discoveries in stem cell, molecular, and developmental biology from an engineering perspective. Student projects and an active learning approach enable students to practice the complex and open-ended process of synthesizing and translating basic discoveries for the rational design of tissue regeneration therapies.

name: Biomicrofluidics, Biofabrication, and Biomanufacturing
description: This course is an introduction to the fundamentals of micro- and nanofabrication processes. In addition, transport phenomena in microfluidic systems, bioprinting and additive manufacturing technologies are discussed. Topics covered during the semester include microfabrication, non-conventional microfabrication, microfluidics, transport phenomena in miniaturized systems, microfluidic assisted manufacturing, bioprinting, biofabrication and organs-on-a-chip.
requirements: pen only to Biomedical Engineering majors, others by instructor consent. Not open for credit to students who have passed BME 4985 when offered as Biomicrofluidics, Biofabrication, and Biomanufacturing.

name: Bioinformatics
description: (Also offered as CSE 3800.) Fundamental mathematical models and computational techniques in bioinformatics. Exact and approximate string matching, suffix trees, pairwise and multiple sequence alignment, Markov chains and hidden Markov models. Applications to sequence analysis, gene finding, database search, phylogenetic tree reconstruction.
requirements: CSE 1729 or CSE 2050; STAT 3025 Qor3345Qor3375Qor MATH 3160; open only to students in the College of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors, others by instructor consent. Recommended preparation: BIOL 1107.

name: Machine Learning Methods for Biomedical Signal Analysis
description: The objective of this course is to learn the basic machine learning concepts and tools that are required in modern biomedical engineering to model, analyze, and classify physiological time series. Specific focus is on multivariate data and time series extracted from multiple physiological sources, including (but not limited to) ECG, EEG, and EMG. Through a mix of lectures and hands-on laboratory experiences, the students will learn how to design and implement a machine learning project, how to use advanced statistical tools and methods to classify data, infer predictions, and validate data-driven predictive models.
requirements: CSE 1010; and STAT 3025 Qor STAT 3345 Qor STAT 3375 Qor MATH 3160; open only to Biomedical Engineering majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Biomedical Engineering Design I
description: Discussion of the design process; project statement, specifications project planning, scheduling and division of responsibility, ethics in engineering design, safety, environmental considerations, economic constraints, liability, manufacturing, and marketing. Projects are  carried out using a team-based approach. Selection and analysis of a design project to be undertaken in BME 4910 is carried out. Written  progress reports, a proposal, an interim project report, a final report, and oral presentations are required.
requirements: pen only to Biomedical Engineering majors; prerequisites vary by track as follows: Biomaterials and Tissue Engineering, BME 3500,3600,3700, and 3900; Biomechanics and Mechanobiology, BME 3600 and3900; Computational and Systems Biology, BME 3900; Systems, Imaging and Instrumentation, BME 3500 and3900; no track: BME 3500,3600, and 3700.

name: Biomedical Engineering Design II
description: Design of a device, circuit system, process, or algorithm. Team solution to an engineering design problem as formulated in BME 4900, from first concepts through evaluation and documentation. Written progress reports, a final report, and oral presentation are required.
requirements: BME 4900; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open only to Biomedical Engineering majors.

name: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering
description: Classroom and/or laboratory courses in special topics as announced for each semester.  With a change of topic, this course may be repeated for credit.
requirements: pen only to BME majors. Prerequisites and/or consent announced separately for each topic.

name: Independent Study
description: Independent study project carried on by the student under the guidance of a faculty member. The student is required to submit a report on the study at the end of the semester. With a change in content, this course may be repeated for credit.
requirements: pen only to Biomedical Engineering majors.

name: Contemporary Issues in the World of Business
description: Today's business world is a complex, challenging and exciting place. Each section of this course will capture some aspect of that challenge and excitement. Students will be exposed to undercurrents that challenge and perplex today's managers and executives around the globe. Students should consult the scheduling booklet for specific topics offered. May be repeated in different sections for up to three credits maximum. May not be used to satisfy junior-senior level major requirements of the School of Business.
requirements: pen only to freshmen and sophomores; others with instructor consent.

name: Personal Financial Literacy
description: (Also offered as BADM 2235.) Introduction to essential topics in personal finance for individuals and entrepreneurs. Financial literacy, personal finance topics including recordkeeping, budgeting, risk, insurance, credit, purchasing decisions, savings/investment options, income taxation of individuals and small businesses, and retirement savings.
requirements: pen only to business majors.

name: Foreign Study Internship
description: Provides students the opportunity to be engaged in meaningful professional activity without the expectation of a significant level of prior academic experience in business. Student performance will be evaluated on the basis of an appraisal by the field supervisor and a detailed written report submitted by the student.
