name: Introduction to Chinese Linguistics
description: Introduction to Chinese phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, writing system, and sociolinguistic aspects. Taught in English.
requirements: CHIN 1112.

name: Networking in China
description: Development of cross-cultural awareness by learning how to analyze and imitate observable behaviors in professional Chinese environments. Taught in both English and Chinese. CA 4-INT.
requirements: CHIN 1114 or equivalent.

name: Women in Chinese Literature and Film
description: (Also offered as AAAS 3282.) Critical study of representations of women in Chinese film and literature from the early twentieth century to the present. Development of feminist movements in China and gender issues. Taught in English.
requirements: ecommended preparation: CHIN 1121 and1122or equivalent.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Applied Mechanics I
description: Fundamentals of statics using vector methods. Resolution and composition of forces; equilibrium of force systems; analysis of forces acting on structures and machines; applications of friction; centroids; moment of inertia.
requirements: MATH 1132 Q.

name: Applied Mechanics II
description: (Also offered as ME 2120.) Fundamentals of dynamics using vector methods. Rectilinear and curvilinear motion, translation, rotation, plane motion; work, energy, and power; impulse and momentum.
requirements: CE 2110; MATH 2110 Qor MATH 2130Q. May not be taken for credit after PHYS 3101.

name: International Study
description: Special civil engineering topics taken in a foreign study program. Credits and hours by arrangement, up to a maximum of six credits. Consent of Department Head or Designee required, normally to be granted prior to the student’s departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor and approved plan of study. May be repeated for credit with change in topic.

name: Engineering Economics I
description: Time value of money. Simple, compound, nominal, and effective interest rate. Present, future, and annual worth methods. Single payment, annuity series, gradient series. Rate of return method. Evaluation of alternative projects.
requirements: pen only to Civil and Environmental Engineering majors.

name: Probability and Statistics in Civil and Environmental Engineering
description: (Also offered as ENVE 2251.) Fundamentals of probability theory and statistics. Hypothesis testing, linear and multiple regression.
requirements: ecommended preparation: MATH 1131 Qor 1151Q. May not be taken out of sequence after passing CE 3220 or4210.

name: Environmental Engineering Fundamentals
description: (Also offered as ENVE 2310 E.) Concepts from aqueous chemistry, biology, and physics applied in a quantitative manner to environmental problems and solutions. Mass and energy balances, chemical reaction engineering. Quantitative and fundamental description of water and air pollution problems. Environmental regulations and policy, pollution prevention, risk assessment. Written and oral reports.
requirements: CHEM 1125 Qor CHEM 1128 Qor CHEM 1148 Q; CHEM 1128 Qor CHEM 1148 Qmay be taken concurrently.

name: Introduction to Geospatial Analysis and Measurement
description: Elementary plane surveying, geospatial coordinate systems, error and accuracy analysis, introduction to geographic information systems, theory and uses of global positioning systems, introduction to land-surface remote sensing in the context of civil and environmental engineering.
requirements: ecommended preparation: MATH 1060 or 1131.

name: Introduction to Computer Aided Design
description: (Also offered as ENVE 2411.) Introduction to computer-aided design and drawing, emphasizing applications in civil and environmental engineering and landscape design. Introduction to fundamental CAD concepts and techniques, such as drawing commands, dimensioning, layers, editing techniques, and plotting, and additional software packages to create planimetric and topographic maps. Related topics include scale, coordinate geometry, and terrain representation.
requirements: nrollment in the School of Engineering; this course and CE 2410 may not both be taken for credit.

name: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems
description: (Also offered as GEOG 2500.) Fundamental principles of geographic information systems (GIS). Topics include history of the field, components of a GIS, the nature and characteristics of spatial data, methods of data capture and sources of data, database models, review of typical GIS operations and applications. Laboratory exercises provide experience with common computer-based systems.

name: Transportation Engineering and Planning
description: Design of transportation facilities. Traffic flow and capacity analysis. Travel demand analysis and planning methods.
requirements: PHYS 1201 Qor1401Qor1501Q. Prerequisite or corequisite: CE 2251 or STAT 1100 Q; CE 2411 or ENVE 2411.

name: Mechanics of Materials
description: Simple and combined stress, torsion, flexure and deflection of beams, continuous and restrained beams, combined axial and bending loads, columns.
requirements: CE 2110; enrollment in School of Engineering.

name: Fluid Mechanics
description: (Also offered as ENVE 3120.) Statics of fluids, analysis of fluid flow using principles of mass, momentum and energy conservation from a differential and control volume approach. Dimensional analysis. Application to pipe flow and open channel flow. Laboratory activities and written lab reports.
requirements: CE 2110; MATH 2110 Qand2410Q; open only to students in the School of Engineering. Recommended preparation: CE 2120. Not open for credit to students who have passed ME 3250.

name: International Study
description: Special advanced civil engineering topics taken in an international study program.
requirements: onsent of Department Head or Designee required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor and approved plan of study.

name: Principles of Construction I
description: Concepts and techniques of construction, including construction process and procedures, contracts and delivery methods, scheduling, cost estimation, project control, project change management, and construction safety issues.
requirements: CE 2251, which can be taken concurrently; enrollment in School of Engineering.

name: Civil and Environmental Engineering Applications of Probability and Statistics
description: Multiple regression. Analysis of variance. Student project applying probability or statistics in a civil or environmental engineering context.
requirements: STAT 1100 Q; open only to CE and ENVE majors. This course and CE 2251 or ENVE 2251 may not both be taken for credit. Recommended preparation: MATH 1121 or1131Qor 1151Q.

name: Environmental Engineering Laboratory
description: (Also offered as ENVE 3200.) Aqueous analytical chemical techniques, absorption, coagulation/flocculation, fluidization, gas stripping, biokinetics, interpretation of analytical results, bench-scale design projects, written and oral reports.
requirements: CE 2251, CE/ ENVE 2310 E; enrollment in the School of Engineering.

name: Water Quality Engineering
description: (Also offered as ENVE 3220.) Biological unit processes in wastewater treatment systems, disinfection, and bioremediation scenarios. Applications to design of wastewater treatment systems.
requirements: CE 2251, CE/ ENVE 2310 E; enrollment in the School of Engineering.

name: Soil Mechanics
description: Fundamentals of soil behavior and its use as a construction material. Effective stress principle, seepage and flow nets, consolidation, shear strength, limit equilibrium analysis. Written reports.
requirements: CE 3110, which can be taken concurrently; enrollment in the School of Engineering. Recommended preparation: CE 3120.

name: Civil Engineering Materials Laboratory
description: Engineering properties of steel, Sieve and Hydrometer analysis, properties and performance of soil, Portland cement concrete, Bituminous cement concrete, and timber; laboratory measurement of properties; interpretation of results. Written reports.
requirements: CE 3110 and CE 3510, which may be taken concurrently; enrollment in School of Engineering.

name: Engineering and Environmental Geology
description: (Also offered as ERTH 3710, ENVE 3530.) Application of geological principles to engineering and environmental problems. Topics include site investigation, geologic hazards, slope processes, earthquakes, subsidence, and the engineering properties of geologic materials. Course intended for both geoscience and engineering majors.
requirements: ecommended preparation: ERTH 1050 or1051.

name: Introduction to Structural Analysis and Design
description: Structural loads and load combinations; analysis and design philosophies; analysis of statically determinate structures; influence lines; deflection of trusses, beams, and frames; introduction to indeterminate analysis; matrix analysis of structures; structural analysis and design software.
requirements: CE 3110, which may be taken concurrently; enrollment in the School of Engineering.

name: Design of Steel Structures
description: Steel material and structural shapes; LRFD and ASD design philosophies; design of steel members for tension, compression, bending, and combined effects of axial forces and bending moments; design of simple connections; design project.
requirements: CE 3610; enrollment in the School of Engineering.

name: Design of Reinforced Concrete Structures
description: Loads; design philosophies, current design codes to analyze and design reinforced concrete beams, columns, slabs, foundations for flexure, shear, axial loads and torsion; serviceability considerations; applications to buildings, design project.
requirements: CE 3110; enrollment in the School of Engineering. Corequisite: CE 3610.

name: Special Topics in Civil Engineering
description: Classroom or laboratory courses as announced for each semester. For independent study see Civil Engineering 4999.
requirements: nnounced separately for each course; open only to School of Engineering students.

name: Directed Research in Civil Engineering
description: Individualized or group research conducted under the supervision of the instructor.
requirements: pen only to students in the School of Engineering.

name: Operations Research in Civil and Environmental Engineering
description: Critical path method for scheduling and managing engineering project tasks. Resource allocation subject to constraints. Facility location problems. One and two-phase simplex method for linear programming. Optimization of non-linear problems. Introduction to integer programming and network flow problems.
requirements: CE 2251; MATH 2110 Q; and enrollment in the School of Engineering. This course and CE 5200 may not both be taken for credit.

name: Principles of Construction II
description: Time, cost, productivity, decision-making, and sustainability challenges in the construction industry. Advanced scheduling, construction sequencing, economic analysis, financial management, construction equipment and methods, risk management, and sustainability issues.

name: Environmental Modeling
description: (Also offered as ENVE 4310.) Systematic approach for analyzing contamination problems. Systems theory and modeling will be used to assess the predominant processes that control the fate and mobility of pollutants in the environment. Assessments of lake eutrophication, conventional pollutants in rivers and estuaries and toxic chemicals in groundwater.
requirements: CE 2310 E; CE 3120 or CHEG 3123; enrollment in School of Engineering.

name: Computer Aided Site Design
description: Roadway and street network design and site development using computer software, including grading and earthwork, runoff and drainage structures.
requirements: CE 2410 or CE 2411 or ENVE 2411; enrollment in the School of Engineering. Recommended preparation: CE 2710

name: Foundation Design
description: Application of soil properties to design of foundations, retaining structures, excavation drainage, shallow footings, deep foundations, specifications, subsurface exploration.
requirements: CE 3510; enrollment in the School of Engineering.

name: Geoenvironmental Engineering
description: (Also offered as ENVE 4530.) Subsurface contaminant fate and transport, site characterization, overview of soil remediation techniques.
requirements: ENVE 2310 E; open to juniors or higher in the School of Engineering. Recommended preparation: CE 3510.

name: Advanced Soil Mechanics
description: Introduction of soil as a multi-phase material; stress and strain analysis in soil; soil compression and consolidation; shear strength of sand and clay; critical state soil mechanics; advanced topics in complex constitutive relationships; introduction to fracture mechanics.
requirements: CE 3510 or equivalent; enrollment in the School of Engineering. Not open for credit for students who have passed CE 5541.

name: Earthquake Engineering
description: Global tectonics and earthquake sources, seismic wave propagation, strong ground motion analysis, seismic hazards, site effects and liquefaction, seismic load to slopes, retaining structures and foundations, structure response to dynamic loads.
requirements: CE 3510 and3610. Recommended preparation: CE/ ENVE 3530/ ERTH 3710. Not open for credit for students who have passed CE 5542.

name: Coastal Hazard Engineering
description: Characteristics of wind hazards; characteristics of flooding and wave hazards; design of coastal infrastructures and resilience assessment. Group project and report.

name: Advanced Structural Analysis
description: Analysis of indeterminate structures using force method and moment distribution method, matrix analysis of truss, beam, and frame structures using computer programming and graphical finite element software, particle dynamics, introduction of dynamic analysis of single degree of freedom structures under various loads.
requirements: CE 3610; enrollment in the School of Engineering.

name: Case Studies in Transportation Engineering
description: Analysis of case studies in transportation and urban planning and design. Application of transportation engineering and planning skills. Oral and written group reports, group discussions, individual written papers.
requirements: CE 2710; enrollment in the School of Engineering.

name: Street and Highway Design
description: History of street and highway design; land-use context, street design data collection and analysis, speed, safety and street network characterization; pedestrian and bikers in design, cross-section and alignment design.
requirements: CE 2710; enrollment in the School of Engineering. Recommended preparation: CE 4410. This course and CE 5720 may not both be taken for credit.

name: Transportation Planning
description: Transportation economics, urban transportation planning process, evaluation of transportation improvements, transportation systems management.
requirements: CE 2211, CE 2251, and CE 2710; enrollment in the School of Engineering. This course and CE 5730 may not both be taken for credit.

name: Traffic Engineering I
description: Traffic flow characteristics; traffic control devices; traffic signs and markings; traffic data collection; traffic signal timing and operation; capacity of streets, intersections, and highways; traffic impact studies; traffic simulation.
requirements: E 2210 or2251, CE 2710; enrollment in the School of Engineering. This course and CE 5740 may not both be taken for credit.

name: Pavement Design
description: Analysis and design of flexible and rigid pavements; testing and characterization of paving materials.
requirements: CE 3110 and3520; enrollment in the School of Engineering. This course and CE 5750 may not both be taken for credit.

name: Engineering Hydrology
description: (Also offered as ENVE 4810.) Hydrologic cycle: precipitation, interception, depression storage, infiltration, evaportranspiration, overland flow, snow hydrology, groundwater and streamflow processes. Stream hydrographs and flood routing. Hydrologic modeling and design. Computer applications. Design project.
requirements: CE 3120 or ENVE 3120 or CHEG 3123; enrollment in the School of Engineering.

name: Hydraulic Engineering
description: (Also offered as ENVE 4820.) Design and analysis of water and wastewater transport systems, including pipelines, pumps, pipe networks, and open channel flow. Introduction to hydraulic structures and porous media hydraulics. Computer applications.
requirements: CE 3120 or both CHEG 3123 and CHEG 3124; enrollment in the School of Engineering.

name: Thesis in Civil Engineering
description: Introduction to research through literature review and preparation of a research proposal, execution of the research proposal, preparation of written report and oral defense.
requirements: pen only to students in the School of Engineering.

name: Civil Engineering Projects I
description: Issues in the practice of civil and environmental engineering: management, business, public policy, leadership, importance of professional licensure, professional ethics, procurement of work, law/contracts, insurance/liability, global/societal issues (e.g. sustainable development, product life cycle), and construction management. Students working singly or in groups prepare proposals for civil engineering design projects, oral presentation and written reports.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Prerequisites or corequisites: CE 2251; CE 2411 or ENVE 2411; two courses from the list: CE 2710, CE 3510, CE 3610, ENVE 2310 E, ENVE 3120. Open only to senior Civil Engineering majors. Not open for credit to students who have passed CE 4900W.

name: Civil Engineering Projects II
description: Design of civil engineering projects. Students working singly or in groups implement previously developed proposals for civil engineering design projects from first concepts through preliminary proposals, sketches, cost estimations, design, evaluation, consideration of realistic constraints such as economic, environmental, social, political, ethical, health and safety, manufacturability, and sustainability, oral presentation and written reports.
requirements: E 4900W or4910W; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open only to senior Civil Engineering majors.

name: Independent Research in Civil Engineering
description: Independent research conducted under the supervision of the instructor.
requirements: pen only to students in the School of Engineering.

name: Independent Study in Civil Engineering
description: Individual study in specialized area of civil engineering as mutually arranged between student and instructor.
requirements: pen only to students in the School of Engineering.

name: Greek Civilization
description: A survey of classical Greece, with emphasis on literature, thought, and influence on contemporary culture. Taught in English. CA 1.

name: Roman Civilization
description: A survey of classical Rome, with emphasis on literature, thought, and influence on contemporary culture. Taught in English. CA 1.

name: Classical Mythology
description: Origin, nature, and function of myth in the literature and art of Greece and Rome and the re-interpretation of classical myth in modern art forms. Taught in English. CA 1.

name: Elementary Latin I
description: A study of the essentials of Latin grammar designed to prepare the student to read simple classical Latin prose.
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing CAMS 1122,1123,1124. May not be taken for credit after passing any 2000-level or above course taught in Latin, or three or more years of high school Latin.

name: Elementary Latin II
description: Further study of the essentials of Latin grammar designed to prepare the student to read simple classical Latin prose.
requirements: CAMS 1121 or one year of Latin in high school. May not be taken out of sequence after passing CAMS 1123,1124. May not be taken for credit after passing any 2000-level or above course taught in Latin, or three or more years of high school Latin.

name: Intermediate Latin I
description: Review of the essentials of grammar. Reading of classical Latin prose and poetry with emphasis on Cicero and Ovid or Vergil.
requirements: CAMS 1122, two years of Latin in high school, or instructor consent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing CAMS 1124.

name: Intermediate Latin II
description: Introduction to the reading of classical Latin prose and poetry with emphasis on Cicero, Ovid or Virgil, with particular attention given to a review of the essentials of grammar.
requirements: CAMS 1123 or instructor consent.

name: Intensive Elementary Ancient Greek
description: Intensive introduction to ancient Greek. Basic morphology, syntax, and vocabulary through simple readings from the New Testament.
requirements: ot open to students who have had three or more years of Greek in high school. May not be taken out of sequence after passing CAMS 1172.

name: Intensive Intermediate Ancient Greek
description: Transition to classical Greek through selections from Xenophon, reading of Plato's Apology complete.
requirements: CAMS 1171. Not open to students who have had three or more years of high school Greek. May not be taken out of sequence after passing CAMS 3101.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program.
requirements: epartment Head consent, normally before the student's departure.

name: Pyramids, Pirates, and the Polis: The Ancient Mediterranean
description: (Also offered as HIST 2020.) Political and intellectual history of the civilizations that emerged around the ancient Mediterranean, including the Near East, Egypt, Greece, and Rome, with emphasis on their interactions and influences. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Topics in Advanced Greek
description: Reading of Ancient Greek texts in the original. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit. Involves reading in Greek.
requirements: CAMS 1172.

name: Topics in Advanced Latin
description: Reading of Latin texts in the original. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit. Involves reading in Latin.
requirements: CAMS 1124 or 3 years or more of high school Latin.

name: Greek Philosophical Writings
description: Selections from Plato and Aristotle.

name: Homer
description: Selections from the Iliad or Odyssey. Taught in English.

name: Greek Historical Writings
description: Selections from Herodotus and Thucydides.

name: Ovid and Mythology
description: Selections from Ovid, mainly from the Metamorphoses, and a study of the myths of Greece and Rome.

name: Medieval Latin
description: Reading of texts from a number of periods and in a variety of styles, with consideration of morphological, syntactical, and semantic developments. Taught in Latin.
requirements: CAMS 1124 or 3 years or more of high school Latin.

name: Greek and Roman Epic
description: A study of classical epic, with special emphasis on Homer's Iliad and Odyssey and Vergil's Aeneid, but including also other examples of the genre. Oral and literary epic, their social and political contexts, and the influence of classical epic on later literature. Taught in English.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: CAMS 1101 or1102or1103. A knowledge of Latin or Greek is not required.

name: Greek and Roman Drama
description: Selected plays from the works of Aeschylus, Sophocles, Euripides, Aristophanes, Plautus, Terence, and Seneca. The origin and development of Greek drama, its transformation in the Roman period, and the influence of classical drama on later literature. Taught in English.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: CAMS 1101 or1102or1103. A knowledge of Latin or Greek is not required.

name: Ancient Fictions
description: Examines a range of novels and other fictions from the Greco-Roman world. Works read will include the Greek sentimental novels, the satirical Roman novels of Petronius and Apeleius, and a variety of other pagan, Jewish, and Christian fictions. Taught in English.

name: Ancient Mediterranean World in Cinema
description: Survey of contemporary (1950-present) films set in the ancient Mediterranean world or referencing the ancient world throughout. Topics include the development over time of a self-referential "ancient epic" genre, in Hollywood and beyond; the impact of technological change on the making of ancient epic films; the use of films about the ancient world to comment on social and political issues at the time the film was made; and the striking of an appropriate balance between "fidelity" to historical or literary sources and the creative vision of contemporary producers, directors, screenwriters and actors.

name: Greek Art
description: (Also offered as ARTH 3140.) Greek art and architecture from the ninth century B.C. to the first-century A.D.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Roman Art
description: (Also offered as ARTH 3150.) History of Roman art and architecture.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Ancient Greek Philosophy
description: (Also offered as PHIL 2221.) Greek philosophy from its origin in the Pre-Socratics through its influence on early Christianity. Readings from the works of Plato and Aristotle. May include related ancient philosophical traditions.

name: Ancient Greek Philosophy
description: (Also offered as PHIL 2221 W.) Greek philosophy from its origin in the Pre-Socratics through its influence on early Christianity. Readings from the works of Plato and Aristotle. May include related ancient philosophical traditions.
requirements: ne three-credit course in Philosophy at the 1100 level; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.
requirements: onsent of Department Head required, normally granted prior to the student's departure.

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Variable Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Ancient Near East
description: (Also offered as HIST 3301.) The history of Near Eastern civilization from the Neolithic period to the Persian Empire. The birth of civilization in Mesopotamia and Egypt. The political, economic, social and cultural achievements of ancient Near Eastern peoples. Taught in English.

name: Ancient Greece: Troy to Sparta
description: (Also offered as HIST 3320.) The history of Greece from Minoan and Mycenaean times until the Hellenistic Period and Alexander the Great, with special emphasis on the Fifth Century and the "Golden Age" of Athens.

name: Hellenistic World: Alexander to Cleopatra
description: (Also offered as HIST 3321.) The Eastern Mediterranean (the Greek east) from Alexander to Cleopatra (336-30 BCE), including historical, cultural, social, and religious developments.

name: Ancient Rome: Aeneas to Augustus
description: (Also offered as HIST 3325.) From the beginning of Rome to the growth of the Roman Republic and the onset of Empire. Roman civilization and its influence upon later history.

name: Ancient Rome: Emperors and Barbarians
description: (Also offered as HIST 3326.) The Roman Empire, from its beginnings until its transformation (or "fall") under the "barbarian" invasions, and its influence on later history. CA 1.

name: Palestine Under the Greeks and Romans
description: (Also offered as HIST 3330, HEJS 3330.) The political, historical and religious currents in Greco-Roman Palestine. Includes the Jewish Revolts, sectarian developments, the rise of Christianity and the Talmudic academies. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. Taught in English.

name: The Early Christian Church
description: (Also offered as HIST 3335.) The evolution of Christian institutions, leadership and doctrines in the Roman Empire ca. 50-451 CE. Topics may include gnosticism, prophecy, martyrdom, asceticism, pilgrimage, heresy, orthodoxy. Taught in English.

name: World of the Later Roman Empire
description: (Also offered as HIST 3340.) The profound social and cultural changes that redefined the cities, frontiers, and economies of the classical Mediterranean world and led to the Middle Ages. Developments in the eastern and western Mediterranean between the second and seventh centuries.

name: Senior Thesis in Classics and Ancient Mediterranean Studies
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; 12 credits in CAMS at 2000-level or above, three of which may be taken concurrently.

name: Foundations of Cognitive Science
description: Origins of and current developments within scientific study of the mind-brain. Topics include: computational theories of mind, artificial and natural intelligence, cognitive neuroscience and the mind/body problem, embodied and distributed cognition, neural networks, self-organizing cognitive systems, learning and innateness. CA 3.
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing COGS 3584,3599or 4596.

name: Language and Racism
description: (Also offered as AFRA 2345.) Examines the relationships between language use, both historically and across the lifespan, and the social construction of race, racism, and racial identity, with particular emphasis on racial politics in the United States.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: One course in AFRA or COGS.

name: Coding for Cognitive Science
description: Introduction to computer programming for students with little or no prior programming experience. Core concepts and essential skills, with special emphasis on typical tasks and applications in the Cognitive Sciences.

name: Seminar in Cognitive Science
description: Recent developments in Cognitive Science.
requirements: COGS 2201; open only to Cognitive Science majors and minors who are juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: at least two of ANTH 3250, CSE 4705, LING 2010 Q, PHIL 3250/W, PSYC 2501, or SLHS 4245/W.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Participation in activities related to cognitive science research.
requirements: pen only with consent of instructor and program director of Undergraduate Studies. Recommended Preparation: At least two of ANTH 3002, CSE 4705, PHIL 3250, PSYC 2501.

name: Independent Study
description: Knowledge and skills necessary to perform a research project.
requirements: COGS 2201; open only with the consent of instructor. Recommended preparation: At least two of ANTH 3002, CSE 4705, PHIL 3250, or PSYC 2501.

name: Variable Topics in Cognitive Science
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Senior Thesis in Cognitive Science
description: Preparation of a research thesis.
requirements: COGS 2201 and3599; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: At least two of ANTH 3002, CSE 4705, PHIL 3250 or PSYC 2501.

name: The Process of Communication
description: A study of modern communication theories and principles useful in understanding how people affect and are affected by others through communication. CA 2.

name: Principles of Public Speaking
description: Theory and performance in public speaking: overcoming apprehension; audience analysis; development of concepts; maximizing message impact; professional presentation skills; group projects; evidence; listening and speech evaluation.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in foreign study program. Consent of department head required, normally granted prior to the student's departure.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Research Methods in Communication
description: The scientific approach as it specifically applies to communication. CA 3.
requirements: COMM 1000. Recommended preparation: MATH 1011 Qor equivalent.

name: Applied Communication Research Methods
description: Principles and practices of research and data analysis in communication industries.
requirements: COMM 1000. Recommended preparation: MATH 1011 Qor equivalent.

name: Professional Communication
description: The principles of communication in business and professional environments. Focus on the refinement of communication skills necessary to succeed in professional contexts.
requirements: ecommended preparation: COMM 1000 or1100.

name: Presenting in the Digital World
description: Fundamentals of applying computer mediated communication skills, with emphasis on best practices for producing a range of effective digital presentations.
requirements: COMM 1000. Recommended preparation: COMM 2100.

name: Interpersonal Communication
description: An introduction, analysis and critique of recent theories of interpersonal communication. Topics include person perception, theories of communication management, and the structural analysis of face to face communication behavior.
requirements: COMM 1000. May not be taken out of sequence after passing COMM 3222,4200, or 4222.

name: Effects of Mass Media
description: An analysis of the roles of the mass media and of the effects they exert on individuals and society.
requirements: COMM 1000.

name: Persuasion
description: Introduction to theories of attitude formation, change and reinforcement. Research is used to evaluate past and present models of persuasion.
requirements: COMM 1000.

name: Media in the Information Age
description: The history, organizational structure, economics, policy, and functioning of technologically-based communication systems, and the relationship of these factors to media issues, effects, and culture. Formerly offered as COMM 1300.
requirements: ecommended preparation: COMM 1000, which may be taken concurrently.

name: Fundamentals of Digital Production
description: Fundamentals associated with the production of digital video, audio, and images to communicate with various audiences. Students rotate through various roles of pre-production, production, and post-production processes in the creation of multimedia projects.
requirements: COMM 1000. May not be taken out of sequence after passing COMM 4710 or 4720.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in foreign study program. Consent of department head required, normally granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward major with consent of the advisor.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Organizational Communication
description: Communication in formal organizations; horizontal and vertical communication; effectiveness of different organizational structures and channels; feedback; networks; norms and roles.
requirements: COMM 2100 or2200.

name: Small Group Communication
description: Approaches, methods, and findings of research in small group communication and development of an ability to engage effectively in small group situations.
requirements: COMM 2100 or2200.

name: Small Group Communication
description: Approaches, methods, and findings of research in small group communication and development of an ability to engage effectively in small group situations.

name: Communication in Conflict Management
description: The principles of communication underlying conflict and its management, including negotiation and intervention strategies, in interpersonal, group/organizational, and inter-group conflict.
requirements: COMM 2100 or2200.

name: Variable Topics in Professional Communication
requirements: COMM 2100 or instructor consent.

name: Gender and Communication
description: (Also offered as WGSS 3210.) Differences in male/female communication, and an examination of cultural assumptions regarding gender in the communication process. Critically analyze the theory, politics and practice of communication and gender.
requirements: COMM 1000 or instructor consent. Recommended preparation: COMM 2200.

name: Intercultural Communication
description: Communication behavior within and across cultures and subcultures. How cultures impact social structures, communication styles, and behavior.
requirements: COMM 1000. Recommended preparation: COMM 2200.

name: Intercultural Communication
description: Communication behavior within and across cultures and subcultures. How cultures impact social structures, communication styles, and behavior.
requirements: COMM 1000. ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: COMM 2200.

name: People of Color and Interpersonal Communication
description: Impact of race, ethnicity, and culture on interpersonal interactions. Surveys key theories and empirical works of past and current race relations in the U.S., negotiation of identity, and ways identity is communicated in various personal relationships.
requirements: COMM 2200.

name: People of Color and Interpersonal Communication
description: Impact of race, ethnicity, and culture on interpersonal interactions. Surveys key theories and empirical works of past and current race relations in the U.S., negotiation of identity, and ways identity is communicated in various personal relationships.
requirements: COMM 2200; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Family Communication
description: The role of communication theories and processes in family contexts, construed broadly to include the biological, legal, and voluntary kin comprising diverse families today. Formerly offered as COMM 4240.
requirements: COMM 2200.

name: Nonverbal Communication
description: Facial expression, body movement, spatial behavior and para-language, with a consideration of applications for information theory.
requirements: COMM 2200 or2500.

name: Motivation and Emotion
description: (Also offered as PSYC 3241.) Cognition, brain mechanisms, biofeedback, aggression, sex, competence, social influence, and conformity.
requirements: PSYC 1100, and 1101 or 1103; open to juniors or higher.

name: Variable Topics in Interpersonal Communication
requirements: COMM 2200 or instructor consent.

name: Media Literacy and Criticism
description: History, analysis and evaluation of technique, content and aesthetic effect of media messages. Cultural, political, economic, and institutional factors that help define the grammar of popular mass media content; social scientific perspectives addressing how audiences learn to comprehend media content including efforts to promote media literacy.
requirements: COMM 2300 or2600.

name: Media Literacy and Criticism
description: History, analysis and evaluation of technique, content and aesthetic effect of media messages. Cultural, political, economic, and institutional factors that help define the grammar of popular mass media content; social scientific perspectives addressing how audiences learn to comprehend media content including efforts to promote media literacy.

name: Media and Diverse Audiences
description: (Also offered as LLAS 3320.) Issues of race, ethnicity, culture, class, gender, and sexuality in mainstream and alternative media. Analysis of how diverse groups use the media, are represented in, and interpret media content.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: COMM 1000,2300or2600.

name: Latinas and Media
description: (Also offered as LLAS 3321, WGSS 3321.) The role of ethnicity and race in women's lives. Special attention to communication research on ethnic and racial minority women. CA 4. Formerly offered as LLAS 3264/ WGSS 3260.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Soap Opera/Telenovela
description: (Also offered as LLAS 3322.) Socio-cultural functions of soap operas/telenovelas as mediated serials constructed by commercial organizations and consumed by United States and global audiences.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: COMM 1000,2300or2600.

name: Children and Mass Media
description: Child development and the effects of mass media on young children. Educational television, frightening media, violent television, computer games, the Internet and media policy.
requirements: COMM 2300.

name: Children and Mass Media
description: Child development and the effects of mass media on young children. Educational television, frightening media, violent television, computer games, the Internet and media policy.
requirements: COMM 2300; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Variable Topics in Media Effects
requirements: COMM 2300 or instructor consent.

name: Political Communication
description: Communication in political processes and the role of mass media in American politics. Topics may include campaigning, issue management, lobbying, interest-group strategies, government relations, grassroots action, and coalition building.
requirements: COMM 2300 or2500.

name: Political Communication
description: Communication in political processes and the role of mass media in American politics. Topics may include campaigning, issue management, lobbying, interest-group strategies, government relations, grassroots action, and coalition building.

name: Protest and Communication
description: Protest movement - past and current - in light of principles, models, and theories of communication.
requirements: COMM 2300 or2500.

name: Health Communication
description: Overview of health communication, including health behavior change interventions, emergency communication, risk assessment, media influences, provider-patient communication, socialization and identity, stereotyping, social support, diverse populations, and new communication technologies.
requirements: COMM 1000. Recommended preparation: COMM 2300 or2500.

name: Health Communication
description: Overview of health communication, including health behavior change interventions, emergency communication, risk assessment, media influences, provider-patient communication, socialization and identity, stereotyping, social support, diverse populations, and new communication technologies.
requirements: COMM 1000; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: COMM 2300 or2500.

name: Science Communication
description: The role of communication and media in shaping science and technology in society. Topics include theories and debates in the field, media coverage of science, activism and science campaigns, and using new and social media to communicate science issues.
requirements: COMM 1000. Recommended Preparation: COMM 2300 or2500.

name: Science Communication
description: The role of communication and media in shaping science and technology in society. Topics include theories and debates in the field, media coverage of science, activism and science campaigns, and using new and social media to communicate science issues.
requirements: COMM 1000; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended Preparation: COMM 2300 or2500.

name: Environmental Communication
description: Survey of best practices for communicating environmental issues and engaging diverse communities and publics. Development of communication strategies to effectively promote environmental literacy and increase environmental equity.
requirements: COMM 1000. Recommended preparation: COMM 2300 or2500.

name: Sport Communication
description: Communication theory and best practices in the realm of sport, with a focus on application to modern issues for organizations, athletes, and fans at varying levels of competition.
requirements: COMM 1000. Recommended Preparation: COMM 2100 or2300or2500. Not open for credit to students who have passed COMM 3498 when offered as Sports Communication.

name: Marketing Communication
description: Principles, strategies, and theories of communication in product and brand marketing contexts.
requirements: COMM 2500 or2600.

name: Communication Processes in Advertising
description: Advertising theory and practice, with specific application to digital, omni-channel and multimedia strategies for implementation in advertising campaigns.
requirements: COMM 2500 or2600.

name: Public Relations
description: Practical applications of major theories of communication and mass media to public relations practiced by organizations.
requirements: COMM 2500 or2600.

name: Variable Topics in Persuasion and Promotion
requirements: COMM 2500 or2600or instructor consent.

name: New Communication Technologies
description: An overview of new communication technologies. Topics include the uses, evolution, diffusion, operation, and effects of new communication technologies.
requirements: COMM 2600.

name: New Communication Technologies
description: An overview of new communication technologies. Topics include the uses, evolution, diffusion, operation, and effects of new communication technologies.
requirements: COMM 2600; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Communication Technology and Social Change
description: Examination of new communication technologies and their influence on social change.  Provides a foundation for students with professional as well as academic interests in communication technology.
requirements: COMM 2300 or2600.

name: Computer Mediated Communication
description: How computer media increasingly influence communication processes and how computer media are changing society. Students will examine critically both exposure to and use of computer media with particular attention to how people use computer media and the effects of this use.
requirements: COMM 2200 or2600.

name: Computer Mediated Communication
description: How computer media increasingly influence communication processes and how computer media are changing society. Students will examine critically both exposure to and use of computer media with particular attention to how people use computer media and the effects of this use.

requirements: COMM 2600 or instructor consent.

name: Visual Communications
description: Strategic use of imagery and multimedia to improve communication in professional and public contexts. Students will create media to solve communication-based problems.
requirements: COMM 2500 or2700.

name: Variable Topics in Multimedia Production
requirements: COMM 2700 or instructor consent.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in foreign study program. Consent of Department Head required, normally granted prior to the student's departure.

name: Advanced Interpersonal Communication
description: An advanced approach to interpersonal communication focusing on theories and their applications. Topics may include affection exchange theory, theories of uncertainty, attachment theory, communication privacy management theory, interpersonal deception theory, and relational dialectics theory.
requirements: COMM 2000 Qand2200.

name: Advanced Interpersonal Communication
description: An advanced approach to interpersonal communication focusing on theories and their applications. Topics may include affection exchange theory, theories of uncertainty, attachment theory, communication privacy management theory, interpersonal deception theory, and relational dialectics theory.
requirements: COMM 2000 Qand2200; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Advanced Media Effects
description: Contentious topics in current media effects research, and their theoretical implications. Topics may include sexual content on television, pornography, alcohol on television, video games, and media impact on body image.
requirements: COMM 2000 Qand2300.

name: Advanced Media Effects
description: Contentious topics in current media effects research, and their theoretical implications. Topics may include sexual content on television, pornography, alcohol on television, video games, and media impact on body image.
requirements: COMM 2000 Qand2300; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: International Communication and Conflict
description: Communication in international conflicts and crises. Negotiation, mediation, and transformational approaches; globalization and the media; communication in war and peace; cultural, social, political, and economic effects.
requirements: COMM 2200 and2500.

name: Advanced Persuasion and Communication
description: Advanced consideration and criticism of selected modern persuasion theories and research in communications.
requirements: COMM 2000 Qand COMM 2500.

name: Communication Campaigns and Applied Research
description: Application of media, persuasion, and social change theories to the design of communication campaigns, including focus groups, interviews and other background research. Students will work with community organizations.
requirements: COMM 2000 Qand2500. Recommended preparation: COMM 2300.

name: Public Relations Writing
description: Philosophy and practice of good, ethical and effective public relations for advanced students. Writing projects such as press releases, media advisories, briefing packets, speech introductions, brochures, newsletters, and op-eds.
requirements: COMM 3530; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Crisis Communication
description: Principles and practices of effective crisis response. The management processes and leadership skills necessary to anticipate, plan for, manage, communicate about, and recover from organizational and public crises.
requirements: COMM 3530 or instructor consent.

name: Social Media: Research and Practice
description: Examines social media from multiple perspectives, including understanding their effects through theoretical approaches and empirical research, as well as practical applications across various contexts.
requirements: COMM 2600; COMM 2200 or2300or2500.

name: Social Media: Research and Practice
description: Examination of the use and effects of social media through theoretical approaches and empirical research; practical applications across various contexts.

name: Human-Computer Interaction
description: Human interaction with computer technology and methods of evaluating communication systems for different populations and usage goals.
requirements: ix credits of 2000-level or higher coursework in Communication or Computer Science Engineering. Recommended preparation: COMM 2600 or3600.

name: Independent Study in Multimedia Production
description: Credits and hours by arrangement.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher with instructor consent.

name: Digital Portfolio
description: Development of a digital portfolio for presentation to professional and graduate-level audiences. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: t least 12 credits of 2000 level or above COMM courses; open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: COMM 2100 and2700.

name: Internship in Communication
description: Provides students with an opportunity for supervised field work in a professional communication organization. Student's performance will be evaluated both by the field supervisor and course instructor. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: t least 12 units of 2000 level or above Communication Sciences courses; open to juniors or higher. Should be taken senior year.

name: Research Practicum in Communication
description: Participation in supervised research activities in communication. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: t least 12 credits of 2000-level or above Communication courses which must include COMM 2000 Q; open to juniors or higher. May be repeated once for a total of six credits.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in foreign study program. Consent of Department Head required, normally granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.

name: Undergraduate Research in Communication
description: Students conduct an original research investigation under the guidance of a faculty mentor. The student is required to submit a brief report at the end of the semester. May be repeated once for credit.
requirements: COMM 2000 Q; at least 12 credits of COMM courses at the 2000 level or above; open only to junior or higher Communication majors; instructor consent required.

name: Reading Between the Arts
description: Introduction to interrelations between literature, music, and the visual arts, including multi-media. CA 1.

name: World Literature I
description: Introduction to world literature. Comparative approach to representative works of Africa, Asia, the Mediterranean, the Middle East, the Americas, and Europe, from the earliest written sources to 1600. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: World Literature II
description: Introduction to world literature. Comparative approach to representative works of Africa, Asia, the Mediterranean, the Middle East, the Americas, and Europe, from 1600 to the present. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Introduction to Film Studies
description: Introduction to film and film studies. Tools for analyzing and reading film. Techniques and language of film. Film theories. CA 1.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of department head required, normally before the student's departure.

name: Media Literacy and Data Ethics
description: An introduction to information literacy on the basis of media studies, research methods in the humanities, and media and data ethics. The course will address three or more interconnected areas that are pivotal to gathering, analyzing, and disseminating information in today’s research and data landscapes, including, but not exclusive to, the study of media as a cultural product, structures of data, and aspects of ethics. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Introduction to Genocide Studies
description: (Also offered as HRTS 2200, HEJS 2205.) Interdisciplinary introduction to the study of genocide as an historical, legal, social, political, and conceptual phenomenon, including response, prevention, and commemoration efforts. CA 2. CA 4-INT.
requirements: ot open for credit to students who have passed HEJS 3298 when offered as Introduction to Genocide Studies.

name: Intercultural Competency Towards Global Perspectives
description: Introduction to the interdisciplinary and international field of intercultural communication in cultural studies, including culturally determined communicative behaviors, identity, semiotics, multi-disciplinary theories of culture, and stereotypes. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Jewish Culture in American Film
description: (Also offered as AMST 2204, HEJS 2204.) Representations of the diversity of Jewish culture (historical, religious, secular) in American film. Introduction to film analysis and interpretation. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Jewish Humor
description: (Also offered as HEJS 2301.) The history of Jewish humor in modern times with attention given to its various forms, including oral traditions, fiction and humor writing, stand-up comedy, live performance, television, film, and music. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Fascism and its Opponents
description: (Also offered as ENGL 2609.) A comparative study of fascist and antifascist movements, ideologies, aesthetics, and states across a number of national contexts, before and after the Second World War. Readings may consist of literary works, films and visual culture, autobiographies, political rhetoric, histories, and other cultural artifacts. CA 1.

name: Comparative Literary and Cultural Studies
description: Literary and cultural questions that go beyond national boundaries: the relationship of literature to other disciplines and to the other arts; cinema as a cultural phenomena. (No foreign language required.) This course may be repeated with a change of topic.

name: Film Genres
description: Conventions, history, and development of selected film genres.

name: Studies in Film History
description: The history of cinema from its origins to the present in relation to relevant historical and cultural developments.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of department head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: Independent Study
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Variable Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Introduction to Computing for Engineers
description: Introduction to computing logic, algorithmic thinking, computing processes, a programming language and computing environment. Knowledge obtained in this course enables use of the computer as an instrument to solve computing problems. Representative problems from science, mathematics, and engineering will be solved.
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing CSE 1729 or2050.

name: Introduction to Principles of Programming
description: Introduction to computer programming in a structured programming language including fundamental elements of program design and analysis. Data and functional abstraction as tools for constructing correct, efficient, and intelligible programs for a variety of common computing problems.

name: Data Structures and Object-Oriented Design
description: Introduction to fundamental data structures and algorithms. The emphasis is on understanding how to efficiently implement different data structures, communicate clearly about design decisions, and understand the relationships among implementations, design decisions, and the four pillars of object-oriented programming: abstraction, encapsulation, inheritance, and polymorphism.
requirements: CSE 1010 or1729. Not open to students who have passed CSE 2100.

name: Introduction to Software Engineering
description: Software engineering concepts including the software life cycle and other software-development process models. Specification techniques, design methodologies, performance analysis, and verification techniques. Team-oriented software design and development, and project management techniques.Use of appropriate design and debugging tools for a modern programming language. Homework and laboratory projects that emphasize design and the use/features of a modern programming language.
requirements: CSE 2050

name: International Study
description: Special Computer Science and Engineering topics taken in an international study program. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor and approved plan of study.

name: Principles and Practice of Digital Logic Design
description: Representation of digital information. Analysis, design, and evaluation of combinational and sequential logic circuits. Debugging techniques. Use of computer facilities for circuit simulation, CAD, and report preparation and presentation. Introduction to structure and operation of digital computers. Design projects. Written reports with revisions are required for each project.
requirements: CSE 1010. Not open for credit to students who have passed CSE 2300W.

name: Introduction to Discrete Systems
description: Introduction to formal mathematical thinking including discrete systems and proofs. Discrete system topics include logic, set theory, basic number theory, basic combinatorics, functions, relations, sequences, sums, products, recurrence, and countability. Proof topics include direct proof, including proof by cases and induction, and indirect proof, including proof by contrapositive and contradiction.

name: Blockchain Technology I
description: Introduction to the basics of blockchain technology. The course will cover the semantics of blockchains, cryptocurrencies, types of blockchains and consensus algorithms, wallet operation, privacy, threat modeling and security aspects of blockchains and cryptocurrencies, the paradigm of decentralized internet, and some ethical and environmental concerns from a technical lens.
requirements: CSE 2050. Recommended preparation: CSE 3140.

name: Introduction to Data Science and Engineering
description: Introduction to a broad selection of challenges and methodologies in working with big data. Topics to be covered include fundamental data science lifecycle topics such as data acquisition, management, integration, visualization, modeling, analysis, prediction, as well as data security, data privacy and ethics.
requirements: CSE 1010. Not open for credit to students who have passed CSE 4095 when offered as "Introduction to Data Science and Engineering." May not be taken out of sequence after passing CSE 4820 or CSE 5819.

name: Contemporary Issues in Computer Science and Engineering
description: Information management, the global and societal impact of computer science and engineering decisions, professional and ethical responsibility.
requirements: CSE 3140; open only to Computer Science and Engineering, Computer Science, and Data Science and Engineering majors.

name: Systems Programming
description: Introduction to system-level programming with an emphasis on C programming, process management and small scale concurrency with multi-threaded programming. Special attention will be devoted to proficiency with memory management and debugging facilities both in a sequential and parallel setting.
requirements: CSE 2050 or 2100; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Cybersecurity Lab
description: Introduction to the design of secure systems. Explores issues that arise in multiple design phases to understand the limitations of the platform and the source of opportunities for attackers. Each unit will explore a system, its design, its vulnerabilities and how to exploit them, culminating with the creation, implementation and deployment of counter-measures to eliminate the vulnerabilities and nullify the threat.

name: C++ Essentials
description: Leverages existing knowledge of C and covers all the essential capabilities of the most recent C++ standard, illustrating their specificities as well as how the language can be used to model object-oriented implementation of a number of classic problems.
requirements: CSE 3100; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Functional Programming Fundamentals
description: The course covers fundamental techniques in functional programming. While the primary focus is purely functional programming, side effects are explored for various purposes such as modeling I/O and rendering stateful objects. The course introduces elementary types, control flow, environments and scoping, closures, and other structural features of typical functional programs. The course may cover additional topics such as typed functional programming languages, type inference, continuation-passing, streams, and monads.

name: International Study
description: Consent of the department head or undergraduate coordinator required, normally before the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor and either the department head or undergraduate coordinator.

name: Mobile Application Development
description: Introduction to mobile application development. Its focus is on Android native development. Android Development is done using Java. The central objective is to develop students’ problem-solving skills for mobile app development. This course is typically only offered to Stamford Campus students.
requirements: CSE 2102 and3100; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors; typically only offered to Stamford Campus students.

name: Introduction to Cloud Computing
description: Introduction to the design and implementation of applications that take full advantage of the cloud-delivery model. Lectures will be a mix between topics, discussion, and in-class demonstrations. Weekly hands-on coding assignments will be given utilizing a modern cloud platform. Coding will be done using modern programming languages, such as Python, Javascript, and GOLang.
requirements: CSE 2050; open only to students in the College of Engineering or declared Computer Science minors. Recommended preparation: CSE 2102.

name: Computer Networks and Data Communication
description: Introduction to computer networks and data communications. Network types, components and topology, protocol architecture, routing algorithms, and performance. Case studies including LAN and other architectures.
requirements: CSE 3100; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Digital Systems Design
description: (Also offered as ECE 3401.) Design and evaluation of control and data structures for digital systems. Hardware design languages are used to describe and design alternative register transfer level architectures and control units with a micro-programming emphasis. Consideration of computer architecture, memories, digital interfacing timing and synchronization, and microprocessor systems.
requirements: SE 2300W or2301; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Digital Design Laboratory
description: (Also offered as ECE 4401.) Digital designing with PLA and FPGA, A/D and D/A conversion, floating point processing, ALU design, synchronous and asynchronous controllers, control path; bus master; bus slave; memory interface; I/O interface; logic circuits analysis, testing, and trouble shooting; PCB; design and manufacturing.
requirements: CSE 3302 or ECE 3401, which may be taken concurrently; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Introduction to Cryptography and Cybersecurity
description: Introduction to applied cryptography and cybersecurity. The course covers basic elements of symmetric-key and public-key cryptography, including encryption, authentication, signatures and key agreement, as well as integrity (hash functions, blockchains and more), pseudorandomness, shared key protocols, and the Transport Layer Protocol (TLS). Discuss principles of cybersecurity and ethics.
requirements: CSE 2500 and3140; open only to students in the College of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Algorithms and Complexity
description: Design and analysis of efficient computer algorithms. Algorithm design techniques, including divide-and-conquer, dynamic programming, and greedy approaches. Graph algorithms and advanced data structures. Worst-case and average-case analysis, reductions, and NP-completeness.
requirements: CSE 2050 or 2100; and 2500; open only to students in the School of Engineering, Cognitive Science majors, and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Theory of Computation
description: Formal models of computation, such as finite state automata, pushdown automata, and Turing machines, and their corresponding elements in formal languages (regular, context-free, recursively enumerable). The complexity hierarchy. Church's thesis and undecidability. NP completeness. Theoretical basis of design and compiler construction.
requirements: CSE 2050 or 2100; and 2500; open only to students in the School of Engineering, Cognitive Science majors, and declared Computer Science or Cognitive Science minors.

name: Probabilistic Performance Analysis of Computer Systems
description: Introduction to the probabilistic techniques which can be used to represent random processes in computer systems. Markov processes, generating functions and their application to performance analysis. Models which can be used to describe the probabilistic performance of digital systems.
requirements: CSE 2050 or 2100; CSE 2500; STAT 3025 Qor3345Qor3375Q, or MATH 3160; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Blockchain Technology
description: Introduction to the basics of blockchain technology from a technical/systems security lens. The course will cover the semantics of blockchains, popular examples of cryptocurrencies, types of blockchains and consensus algorithms, threat modeling of blockchain-based systems, formal security notions of consensus and ledgers, privacy and anonymity of payments and smart contracts, the paradigm of blockchain-based distributed services, and some ethical issues with respect to deployments in practice.
requirements: CSE 3400; open only to students in the College of Engineering or declared Computer Science minors. Recommended preparation: CSE 3140. Not open for credit to students who have passed CSE 2550.

name: Introduction to Computer Architecture
description: Structure and operation of digital systems and computers. Instruction sets and assembly language. Integer and floating-point arithmetic. Machine organization, control and data paths, pipeline, and the memory hierarchy.
requirements: CSE 2050 or 2100, and CSE 2301 or2500; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors. Not open for credit after passing CSE 2304. May not be taken out of sequence after passing 4302.

name: Bioinformatics
description: (Also offered as BME 4800.) Fundamental mathematical models and computational techniques in bioinformatics. Exact and approximate string matching, suffix trees, pairwise and multiple sequence alignment, Markov chains and hidden Markov models. Applications to sequence analysis, gene finding, database search, phylogenetic tree reconstruction.
requirements: CSE 1729 or CSE 2050; STAT 3025 Qor3345Qor3375Qor MATH 3160; open only to students in the College of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors, others by instructor consent. Recommended preparation: BIOL 1107.

name: Numerical Methods in Scientific Computation
description: (Also offered as ECE 3431.) Introduction to the numerical algorithms fundamental to scientific computation. Equation solving, function approximation, integration, difference and differential equations, special computer techniques. Emphasis is placed on efficient use of computers to optimize speed and accuracy in numerical computations. Extensive digital computer usage for algorithm verification.
requirements: CSE 1729 or2050; MATH 2110 Qand2410Q; MATH 2210 Q, which may be taken concurrently; open only to students in the School of Engineering, Cognitive Science majors, and declared Computer Science and Cognitive Science minors.

name: Computational Genomics
description: (Also offered as BME 3810.) Computational methods for genomic data analysis. Topics covered include statistical modeling of biological sequences, probabilistic models of DNA and protein evolution, expectation maximization and Gibbs sampling algorithms, genomic sequence variation, and applications in genomics and genetic epidemiology.
requirements: CSE 1729 or CSE 2050; STAT 3025 Qor3345Qor3375Qor MATH 3160; open only to students in the College of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors. Recommended preparation: BIOL 1107.

name: Special Topics in Computer Science and Engineering
description: Classroom course in special topics as announced in advance for each semester.
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary. Open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Independent Study in Computer Science and Engineering
description: Exposes the student to management principles and practices and the knowledge and skills necessary to develop an education project and to perform a research project.
requirements: onsent of instructor and department head required; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Programming Language Translation
description: Introduction to the formal definition of programming language syntax and semantics. Design and realization of programming language processing systems such as assemblers, compilers, and interpreters.
requirements: CSE 3502; CSE 2304 or3666; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Programming Languages
description: The study of programming language features and programming paradigms. Data types, control, run-time environments, and semantics. Examples of procedural, functional, logical, and object-oriented programming. Features used for parallel and distributed processing. Classic and current programming languages and environments.
requirements: CSE 3100; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Operating Systems
description: Introduction to the theory, design, and implementation of software systems to support the management of computing resources. Topics include the synchronization of concurrent processes, memory management, processor management, scheduling, device management, file systems, and protection.
requirements: CSE 3100; CSE 2304 or3666; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Computer Organization and Architecture
description: Organization and architecture of modern computer systems. Emphasis is on alternatives and advances to the basic Von Neumann architecture: topics such as pipelining, memory hierarchy and management, multiprocessor and alternative architectures, reconfigurable hardware, and other techniques for performance enhancement.
requirements: SE 2304 or3666; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Computer Security
description: Computer security and the design of secure systems. Cryptographic tools. Operating system security and access control. Network, software and database security. Randomness generation. Malicious software. Anonymity and privacy. Various attacks and countermeasures. Ethical, legal and business aspects.
requirements: CSE 3100; CSE 2304 or3666; and CSE 3400, which may be taken concurrently; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Network Security
description: The principles and practices of how to provide secure communication between computer systems. Includes protection techniques at the physical, network, transport layers, and major approaches in Internet security. How cryptography is applied in network security. Topics include: denial-of-service, DNS, BGP, IPSec, SSL/TLS, Authentication/Kerberos, VPNs, PKI, firewalls, intrusion detection/prevention systems, blockchains, and wireless security.
requirements: CSE 3140; open only to students in the College of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Introduction to Quantum Computing, Cryptography, and Networking
description: Fundamentals of quantum computing (qubits, superposition, measurements, quantum circuits) including basic quantum algorithms and quantum complexity. Quantum cryptography and networking, including quantum key distribution protocols and their security proofs, and the design and use of large-scale quantum networks (e.g., quantum repeaters). Hands-on programming of the IBM quantum computer.
requirements: CSE 3500 or5050; MATH 2210 Q.

name: Big Data Analytics
description: Focuses on basic concepts of data science and big data analytics. Different algorithmic techniques employed to process data will be discussed. Specific topics include: Parallel and out-of-core algorithms and data structures, rules mining, clustering algorithms, text mining, string algorithms, data reduction techniques, and learning algorithms. Applications such as motif search, k-locus association, k-mer counting, error correction, sequence assembly, genotype-phenotype correlations, etc. will be investigated.
requirements: CSE 3500; MATH 2210 Q; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science and Analytics minors.

name: Principles of Databases
description: Fundamentals of data base design and data indexing techniques. Hierarchical, network, and relational data models. Data base design theory. Query languages, their implementation and optimization. Data base security and concurrent data base operations.
requirements: CSE 3500; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Introduction to Modern Cryptography
description: Covers the foundations of modern cryptography introducing basic topics such as one-way functions, pseudorandom generators, and computational hardness assumptions based on number theory. The course will cover fundamental cryptographic constructions such as hard-core predicates, secure symmetric encryption and message-authentication codes, and public-key cryptography.
requirements: CSE 3400 and3500; and STAT 3025 Qor3345Qor3375Qor MATH 3160; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Computational Geometry
description: An extension of sorting, searching, selection, and graph algorithms to geometric problems. This includes algorithms and data structures for constructing geometric objects, computing geometric properties, and answering geometric queries as well as techniques for the analysis of their correctness and complexity.
requirements: CSE 3500; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Artificial Intelligence
description: Design and implementation of intelligent systems, in areas such as natural language processing, expert reasoning, planning, robotics, problem solving and learning. Students will design their own versions of "classic"  AI problems, and complete one substantial design project.
requirements: CSE 3500; open only to students in the School of Engineering, Cognitive Science majors, and declared Computer Science and Cognitive Science minors.

name: Networked Embedded Systems
description: Introduction to the basic concepts, challenges, and methods for designing networked embedded systems. Examines related hardware, software, and system-level design. Hardware topics include various design alternatives (such as microcontrollers, digital signal processors (DSP), and field-programmable gate array (FPGA)) in resource-constrained environments. Software issues include operating systems, programming languages, program verification and analysis. System-level topics include autonomous wireless sensor network design, power and resource management, security and privacy.
requirements: SE 2304 or3666; CSE 3300, or equivalent with instructor permission; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Introduction to Machine Learning
description: An introduction to the basic tools and techniques of machine learning, including models for both supervised and unsupervised learning, related optimization techniques, and methods for model validation. Topics include linear and logistic regression, SVM classification and regression, kernels, regularization, clustering, and on-line algorithms for regret minimization.
requirements: MATH 2210 Q; STAT 3025 Qor3345Qor3375Qor MATH 3160; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors; juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: CSE 3500.

name: Computer Vision and Machine Learning for Image Analysis
description: Computer vision, image processing, machine learning and deep learning techniques and their application to digital photography and medical image analysis.  Students will gain theoretical and practical skills in 2D and 3D image classification, segmentation, reconstruction and registration using computer vision and machine learning.
requirements: MATH 2210 Q; STAT 3025 Qor STAT 3345 Qor STAT 3375 Qor MATH 3160; open only to students in the College of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors; juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: CSE 3500 and CSE 4820.

name: Independent Design Laboratory
