description: Experimental design project undertaken by the student by special arrangement with a faculty member of the Department of Computer Science and Engineering.
requirements: CSE 2102; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Computer Science and Engineering Design Project I
description: The first semester of the required two-semester major design experience. Teams of students propose, design, produce, and evaluate a software and/or hardware system. Culminates in the delivery of the design, analysis, and initial working system, to be used as a basis for CSE 4940, formal public presentation, and written documentation. Oral and written progress reports are required.
requirements: CSE 3500; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to students with a minimum of 70 earned credits, with a minimum of 23 earned CSE credits; open to Computer Science and Engineering, Computer Science, Data Science and Engineering, and Robotics Engineering majors.

name: Computer Science and Engineering Design Project II
description: The second semester of the required year long major design experience. The semester will be spent developing, testing, and evaluating the software and/or hardware system begun in CSE4939W. The project will culminate in the delivery of a working system and will include a formal public presentation, and written documentation. Oral and written progress reports are required.
requirements: CSE 4939 W; open only to Computer Science and Engineering, Computer Science, Data Science and Engineering, and Robotics Engineering majors.

name: Electrical and Computer Engineering Design I
description: (Also offered as ECE 4901.) Discussion of the design process; project statement, specification, project planning, scheduling and division of responsibility, ethics in engineering design, safety, environmental considerations, economic constraints, liability, manufacturing, and marketing. Projects are carried out using a team-based approach. Selection and analysis of a design project to be undertaken in CSE 4951/ ECE 4902 is carried out. Written progress reports, a proposal, an interim project report, a final report, and oral presentations are required.
requirements: ECE 3101; ECE 3201; open only to seniors in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Electrical and Computer Engineering Design II
description: (Also offered as ECE 4902.) Design of a device, circuit, system,  process, or algorithm. Team solution to an engineering design problem as formulated in CSE 4950/ ECE 4901, from first concepts through evaluation and documentation.  Written progress reports, a final report, and oral presentations are required.
requirements: ECE 4901; open only to students in the School of Engineering and declared Computer Science minors.

name: Senior Thesis in Computer Science and Engineering
description: Students are expected to choose an advisor and seek approval of a thesis topic by the time of registration. Students will author a formal thesis based on independent research conducted under the advisor supervision. Thesis proposal and final thesis must follow the guidelines developed by the department.
requirements: enior standing in Computer Science, Computer Science and Engineering, or Computer Engineering.

name: Coop Education Work Placement
description: Coop Ed Wk Placement
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Elementary Level I
description: Some critical languages, because of area study requirements or other specific circumstances, may be offered under the regular instructional method. The method of instruction for most critical language courses follows the self-study format established by the National Association of Self-Instructional Language Programs (NASILP). This method relies on four hours of student self-instruction per week, using the approved book/tape program; two hours per week of drill sessions led by the Conversation Partner; four or five quizzes per semester; and an oral final examination conducted by the Outside Examiner, a member of the faculty of an Institution of Higher Education which offers the language. In order to be eligible to register for a course offered through the NASILP method, students must have sophomore standing, a B (3.0) cumulative Grade Point Average, and the support of their academic advisor. Students seeking to register should bring an unofficial transcript and a letter from their advisor to Room 128, J.H. Arjona Building during pre-registration for the following semester.
requirements: pen only to students with no prior contact with the language.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program.
requirements: onsent of Department Head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.
requirements: onsent of Director required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure.

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Variable Topics
description: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Cytogenetic Technologies
description: Study of human chromosome morphology and identification, including chromosome variants and abnormalities. Methodologies in cytogenetic testing for multiple sample types.
requirements: pen to students in the Diagnostic Genetic Sciences Program and Diagnostic Genetic Sciences certificates.

name: Current Genetic Research
description: Retrieval, review, and discussion of current primary genetics literature in addition to attending and reviewing University research seminars/guest speakers.
requirements: DGS 3100 or MCB 2400 or MCB 2410. Open to DGS majors, others with instructor consent. May be repeated for a total of 6 credits with instructor consent.

name: Independent Study for Undergraduates
description: Designed primarily for students who wish to extend their knowledge in some specialized area in the field of diagnostic genetic sciences.

name: Special Topics
description: Application of the scientific method of inquiry to planning, implementation, evaluating and reporting a study of a problem in cytogenetics.

name: Diagnostic Molecular Technologies
description: DNA and RNA diagnostic technologies used in clinical settings; clinical applications in prenatal diagnosis; cancer management, transplantation, paternity testing, forensic medicine and microbiology.
requirements: MCB 2400 or2410; AH 3121 or MCB 4211(which may be taken concurrently); open to students in DGS & MLS Programs, others w/ instructor consent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing DGS 4235,4503,4510, 4511, 4514,4515, 4550.

name: Diagnostic Molecular Technologies
description: DNA and RNA diagnostic technologies used in clinical settings; clinical applications in prenatal diagnosis; cancer management, transplantation, paternity testing, forensic medicine and microbiology.
requirements: MCB 2400 or2410; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; AH 3121 or MCB 4211(can be taken concurrently); open to students in DGS or MLS Prgm, others with instructor consent. Cannot be taken out of sequence after passing DGS 4235,4503,4510, 4511, 4514,4515, 4550.

name: Laboratory in Molecular Diagnostics
description: Nucleic acid isolation, blotting techniques, fluorescencet in situ hybridization, conventional and real-time polymerase chain reaction. Adhering to clinical laboratory quality guidelines, students obtain practical experience with molecular techniques for the detection and diagnosis of disease.
requirements: DGS 4234; open only to students enrolled in the DGS and MLS programs, others with instructor consent.

name: Case Studies in Molecular Pathology
description: Clinical cases in molecular pathology are presented and discussed.
requirements: DGS 4235; open to Diagnostic Genetic Science students and Diagnostic Genetic Sciences certificate students in either Cytogenetics or Molecular concentrations.

name: Introductory Bioinformatics for Genomics Analysis
description: An introductory bioinformatics course working with genetic and genomic data for clinical and research applications.
requirements: DGS 3100 or MCB 2410 or 2413; open to students in the Diagnostic Genetic Sciences program, others with instructor consent.

name: Contemporary Issues in Human Genetics
description: Historical and contemporary issues relevant to human genetics, including the layperson's understanding of genetic testing and diagnosis; and the ethical, legal, and social issues associated with them.
requirements: pen to junior and senior Allied Health Sciences and Diagnostic Genetic Sciences majors and Diagnostic Genetic Sciences certificate students in either Cytogenetics or Molecular concentrations; others with consent of instructor.

name: Specimen Preparation, Nucleic Acid Isolation and Assessment
description: Practicum experience in specimen preparation for molecular testing, nucleic acid isolation, and nucleic acid quality control assessment.
requirements: tudents must earn a "C" or better in DGS 4234/W and 4235; open to Diagnostic Genetic Sciences Molecular concentration majors and Diagnostic Genetic Sciences Molecular concentration certificate students.

name: Amplification Methods
description: Practicum experience in DNA and/or RNA amplification stressing polymerase chain reaction.
requirements: tudent must have earned a "C" or better in DGS 4234,4235, and 4236; open to Diagnostic Genetic Sciences Molecular concentration majors and Diagnostic Genetic Sciences Molecular concentration certificate students.

name: In Situ Hybridization Methods
description: Practicum in fluorescence in situ hybridization or other in situ hybridization techniques.
requirements: "C" or better in DGS 4234 and4235; open to Diagnostic Genetic Sciences Molecular concentration majors and Diagnostic Genetic Sciences Molecular concentration certificate students.

name: Cloning Techniques
description: Theory and techniques of cloning.
requirements: "C" or better in DGS 4234 and4235; open to Diagnostic Genetic Sciences Molecular concentration majors and Diagnostic Genetic Sciences Molecular concentration certificate students.

name: Blotting Applications
description: Theory and techniques of nucleic acid and/or protein blotting (e.g. Southern blot, reverse clot blot).
requirements: "C" or better in DGS 4234 and4235; open to Diagnostic Genetic Sciences Molecular concentration majors and Diagnostic Genetic Sciences Molecular concentration certificate students.

name: Microbiological Applications of Molecular Diagnostics
description: Practicum experience in the application of molecular technologies to microbiology.
requirements: tudent must have earned a "C" or better in DGS 4234 and4235; open only to Diagnostic Genetic Sciences Molecular concentration majors and Diagnostic Genetic Sciences Molecular concentration certificate students; others with consent of the instructor.

name: Sequencing Techniques and Data Analysis
description: Practicum experience in nucleic acid sequencing and data analysis.
requirements: tudents must earn a "C" or better in DGS 4234/W and 4235; open to Diagnostic Genetic Sciences Molecular concentration majors and Diagnostic Genetic Sciences Molecular concentration certificate students.

name: Investigative Topics in Laboratory Genetics
description: Exploration of an area of individual interest in laboratory or clinical genetics.
requirements: grade of "C" or better in DGS 4234 or4234W,4235, and 4236; open only to Diagnostic Genetic Sciences majors, others with instructor consent.

name: Honors Research
description: Design and implementation of an honors research project.
requirements: pen only to Diagnostic Genetic Sciences honors students and Diagnostic Genetic Sciences certificate students in either Cytogenetics or Molecular concentrations.

name: Independent Study for Undergraduates
description: Designed primarily for students who wish to extend their knowledge in some specialized area in the field of dietetics.
requirements: pen only to Dietetics majors, others by consent of the Director of Dietetics.

name: Medical Nutrition Therapy I
description: (Also offered as NUSC 3150.) Introduction to the nutrition care process, nutrition assessment, planning of special diets and applications of medical nutrition therapy to selected disease states and conditions.
requirements: MCB 2000; PNB 2264,2265; NUSC 1165; open only to Dietetics majors and NUSC Didactic Program students: open to juniors or higher.

name: Clinical Dietetics Practicum I
description: Supervised practice experience in the health care setting.
requirements: MCB 2000; PNB 2264 and2265; NUSC 1165; open only to Dietetics majors, others by consent of the Program Director.

name: Food Service Management Practicum I
description: Supervised practice experiences in food service settings.
requirements: grade of C or better in DIET 3150 and3155; open only to Dietetics major, others by consent of Program Director.

name: Community Nutrition
description: (Also offered as NUSC 3230.) An introduction to public health and community-focused issues in food and nutrition. Topics will center public health infrastructures, behavior change, determinants of health, and more.
requirements: NUSC 2200; open to junior or higher Dietetics, Nutritional Sciences, and Allied Health Sciences majors; others by consent.

name: Writing for Community Nutrition Research
description: Develops critical thinking skills through research and writing in community nutrition.
requirements: "C" or better in DIET 3150,3155; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; concurrent enrollment in DIET 3230; open only to Dietetics majors.

name: Community Nutrition Practicum I
description: Supervised practice experiences in community agencies.
requirements: grade of C or better in DIET 3150 and3155; open only to Dietetics major, others by consent of Program Director.

name: Medical Nutrition Therapy II
description: (Also offered as NUSC 3250.) Continuation of Medical Nutrition Therapy I. Further investigation of the interrelationships of physiology and biochemistry of disease and dietary intervention.
requirements: DIET 3150 or NUSC 3150; open only to Dietetics majors and NUSC Didactic Program students.

name: Clinical Dietetics Practicum II
description: Supervised practice experience in the health care setting.
requirements: grade of C or better in DIET 3150 and3155; open only to Dietetics major, others by consent of Program Director.

name: Food Service Systems Management I
description: (Also offered as NUSC 3272.) Quantity food procurement, preparation and distribution; recipe standardization and menu development; sanitation and safety; portion and quality control; systems approach and delivery systems.
requirements: pen only to junior or higher Dietetics and Nutritional Science majors, others with instructor consent. Recommended preparation: NUSC 3233,3234. Not open to students who have passed NUSC 3270.

name: Applied Research for Dietetic Professionals
description: Provides Dietetic majors research experience under the guidance and supervision of a department faculty member; designed to engage a student in inquiry and investigation on a topic of interest.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: Special Topics
description: Application of the scientific method of inquiry to planning, implementing, evaluating, and reporting a study of a problem related to dietetics.  May be repeated for credit with a change of topic.
requirements: pen only to Dietetics majors, others by consent of the Director of Dietetics.

name: Food Service Systems Management II
description: (Also offered as NUSC 4272.) Institutional menu development; cost and budgeting; equipment layout and design; personnel management; marketing and merchandising; purchasing and inventory control.
requirements: DIET 3272 or NUSC 3272.

name: Applied Honors Research for Dietetic Professionals
description: Dietetic majors research experience under the guidance and supervision of a department faculty member; designed to engage a student in inquiry and investigation on a topic of interest.
requirements: nstructor and advisor consent.

name: Food Service in Health Care
description: Supervised practice experience applying didactic learning to foodservice experiences will be in a healthcare establishment.
requirements: tudent must earn a "C" or better in DIET 3215,3230,3231W,3235,3250,3272.

name: Clinical Nutrition in Acute Care
description: Supervised practice experience applying didactic learning to clinical nutrition.
requirements: tudent must earn a "C" or better in DIET 3215,3230,3231W,3235,3250,3272.

name: Applied Medical Nutrition Therapy III
description: Medical nutrition therapy for complex medical problems. Continuation of DIET 3250.
requirements: grade of C or better in DIET 3215,3230,3231W,3235,3250,3255and3272; open only to Dietetics majors, others by consent of the Dietetics Program Director.

name: Contemporary Nutrition Practice
description: Application of knowledge, skills, and competencies affecting contemporary nutrition practice in the clinical dietetics, food service management, and community nutrition settings.
requirements: grade of C or better in DIET 3215,3230,3231W,3235,3250,3255and3272; open only to Dietetics majors, others by consent of the Dietetics Program Director.

name: Advanced Nutrition for the Dietetics Practitioner
description: Relationship of nutrients to each other and to body function.
requirements: or better in DIET 4272,4350,4360, and 4365; open to Dietetics majors, others by consent of Dietetics Program Director.

name: Food Service Management Practicum II
description: Application and synthesis of performance requirements in food service systems.
requirements: or better in DIET 4272,4350,4360, and 4365; open to Dietetics majors, others by consent of Dietetics Program Director.

name: Community Nutrition Practicum II
description: Application and synthesis of performance requirements in community nutrition.
requirements: grade of C or better in DIET 4272,4350,4360and 4365; open to Dietetics majors, others by consent of Dietetics Program Director.

name: Clinical Dietetics Practicum III
description: Application and synthesis of performance requirements in clinical dietetics.
requirements: or better in DIET 4272,4350,4360, and 4365; open to Dietetics majors, others by consent of Dietetics Program Director.

name: Seminar in Dietetics
description: Special problems and issues in dietetics. The management role in patient care, nutrition education, and the integration of nutrition and food service units.
requirements: or better in DIET 4272,4350,4360, and 4365; open to Dietetics majors, others by consent of Dietetics Program Director.

name: Dietetics Externship
description: Culminating supervised practice experiences in application and synthesis of performance in clinical, community, food service or research; and practice experience in a specialty area of individual professional interest.
requirements: tudents must earn a "C" or better in DIET 4370 and4470; open only to Dietetics majors.

name: Digital Foundation
description: Introductory studio experience in designing for the digital arts; concepts, media and strategies for making creative digital work.
requirements: nterview and/or portfolio review required.

name: Foundations in Digital Media and Design I
description: Creative problem solving; empathy, ideation, prototyping, and testing as means to innovate discovery in diverse fields.
requirements: pen to Digital Media and Design majors only, others by instructor consent. Not open for credit to students who have passed DMD 1000.

name: Foundations in Digital Media and Design II
description: Introduction to the fundamentals of storytelling through the use of a variety of practical digital media applications.
requirements: DMD 1001, open to Digital Media and Design majors, others by instructor consent.

name: How Design Shapes Our World
description: (Also offered as LAND 1005, ART 1005.) An engaging exploration into the fundamentals of design. Students will learn how design is part of our everyday life. Designing is a flexible and iterative process that thrives on communication and collaboration. Emphasizing a broad and scalable purpose, the course will illustrate how design can be applied and adapted to different contexts and media.

name: Fundamentals of Programming for Game, Web, and Interactive Media Design
description: Introduction to programming for artists and designers through a combination of lecture and hands-on studio exercises. Students learn the basic principles of computer programming which set the foundation for future courses in game, web, and interactive media design.
requirements: DMD 1001; open only to Digital Media and Design majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Web Design I
description: Introduction to concepts, technologies and strategies for building contemporary websites.
requirements: DMD 1002 and1102; open to Digital Media and Design majors only, others with instructor consent.

name: Design Lab I
description: Exploration of the creation, manipulation, and reception of digital images through project-based work using image-editing software. Through lecture, discussion, projects and critique, students will develop, refine, and evaluate digital images and understand their artistic, social, and ethical ramifications.
requirements: pen only to Digital Media and Design majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Design Lab II
description: Theory, principles, and practices of digital screen­based visual communication. Through a multi­disciplinary perspective involving art, design, art history, and media studies, students will address how culture visualizes screen­based communication through both image and type.
requirements: DMD 1000 or DMD 1001, DMD 1101. Open to Digital Media and Design majors only, others by instructor consent. Not open to students who have completed DMD 3020.

name: History of Digital Culture
description: Key episodes in the history of digital technology and digital media; values and norms that adhere to digital culture. CA 1. CA 3.

name: Design Thinking
description: Core values that shape creative production. Mindset that promotes diversity, inquiry, and a human-centered approach to designing and implementing real-world technological solutions. CA 1.

name: Generative AI for Creative Minds: The Future of Work
description: This course delves into key developments in generative AI, investigating how these platforms are reshaping the boundaries of creativity and innovation.
requirements: tudents must have completed 15 credits. Recommended preparation: DMD 2010.

name: Special Topics in Digital Media
description: Seminar focusing on a special, limited topic in the digital media space.
requirements: pen to Digital Media Design majors only, others by instructor consent.

name: Motion Design and Animation I
description: Introduction to concepts and strategies for creating motion designs, animations, and visual effects.
requirements: DMD 1002 and1102; open to Digital Media and Design majors; others with instructor consent.

name: Film and Video Editing I
description: Introduction to digital editing, project management, working with sound and time-based storytelling.
requirements: DMD 1002 and1102; open only to Digital Media and Design majors; others by instructor consent.

name: 3D Motion I
description: Introduction to techniques of 3D motion such as modeling, lighting and texturing 3D forms; keyframes and keyframe interpolations; and motion graphics effectors and simulations.
requirements: DMD 2200, open to Digital Media and Design majors only, others by instructor consent.

name: 3D Animation I
description: Introduction to 3D Animation techniques including key framing, curve editing, timing, squash and stretch, walk cycles, and the 12 principles of animation.
requirements: DMD 1001 and1101; open only to Digital Media and Design majors; others by instructor consent. Corequisite: DMD 1002 and1102.

name: 3D Modeling I
description: Introduction to creating polygonal 3D models using industry standard modeling tools, focusing geometry construction based on reference images, edge flow, clean topology, and polygon density.
requirements: DMD 1002 and1102; open only to Digital Media and Design majors, others with instructor consent.

name: 3D Lighting and Rendering I
description: Introduction to dramatic lighting, 3-point lighting, shadows, materials, procedural textures, bump maps, displacement maps, ambient occlusion, ray tracing, and global illumination.
requirements: DMD 1002 and1102; open only to Digital Media and Design majors, others with instructor consent.

name: User Interface Design
description: Interface design fundamentals of websites, mobile applications, and interactive media installations. Students learn aesthetically engaging and usable human-computer interfaces through hands-on course projects, critiques, and discussions.
requirements: DMD 1070; open to Digital Media and Design majors only, others with instructor consent.

name: Introduction to Digital Game Design
description: Introduction to the principles of game design and development. History of the industry, story and game mechanics.
requirements: DMD 1002 and1102; open to Digital Media and Design majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Introduction to Game Scripting
description: Fundamentals of gameplay scripting utilizing an off-the-shelf video game engine. Scripting concepts and constructs like vector math, classes, raycasting, deltaTime, and other available engine commands.
requirements: DMD 1060; open only to Digital Media and Design majors; others by instructor consent.

name: Game Production
description: Practical investigation into the successful management of video game projects. Budgets, asset management plans, and risk evaluation of game development options. Relationship and team management, business aspects of the video game industry, and development of a video game project.
requirements: DMD 2500; Open to Digital Media and Design majors and Digital Arts and Digital Media minors, others with instructor consent.

name: 2D Game Art
description: Introduction to figure and perspective drawing, character and environmental concept art, pixel art, sprite animation, vector art, game UI design, texture painting, and 2D art for 3D games.
requirements: DMD 1002 and1102; open to Digital Media and Design majors only, others with instructor consent.

name: Introduction to Digital Humanities
description: (Also offered as ENGL 2610, HIST 2102.) The application of digital technology and media to such subjects as art history, classics, cultural and area studies, history, languages, literature, music, and philosophy. This course will provide a broad survey of the landscape of international and interdisciplinary digital humanities through the lens of ongoing work of faculty and staff researchers at the University of Connecticut.

name: Human Development, Digital Media, and Technology
description: (Also offered as HDFS 2620.) Social, economic, and cultural influences on youths' interactions with, and use of, technology for formal and informal learning. Examples include media literacy, digital divide, technology in education, cyberbullying, and other issues that have emerged since the rise of the World Wide Web and growth of social media. CA 2. CA 4.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: HDFS 1070 or DMD 2010.

name: Digital Media Strategies for Business
description: Introduction to digital media concepts and platforms used in companies' marketing strategies and plans.
requirements: DMD 1002 and1102; open only to Digital Media and Design majors and minors, others by instructor consent.

name: Social Media Business Applications
description: Introduction to social media marketing and advertising, focusing on the platforms and strategies being deployed by brands.
requirements: DMD 2700, which may be taken concurrently; open only to Digital Media and Design majors, others by instructor consent. Recommended preparation: DMD 1002 and1102.

name: Digital Cinematography I
description: Introduction to the fundamentals of cinematography in the digital realm, including both technical knowledge and aesthetics. Emphasis on camera angles, movements, composition, and lighting to enhance storytelling.
requirements: DMD 2210; open to BFA Digital Media and Design majors only, others by instructor consent.

name: Critical Perspectives on Digital Media
description: Critical thinking and writing about digital media objects, contexts, and "texts," and how these participate in the social construction of human identities and belonging.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to DMD majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Design Lab
description: The theory, principles and practices of digital screen-based visual communication. Through a multi-disciplinary  perspective involving art, design, art history, and media studies, students will address how culture visualizes screen-based communication through both image and type.
requirements: DMD 1000; DMD 1030; open only to Digital Media and Design majors.

name: Narrative Workshop
description: An open forum where students will "workshop" their own narratives and works-in-progress, using each other as collaborators, editors, and ideators to investigate emerging forms of storytelling.
requirements: DMD 2200 and2210; open to Digital Media and Design majors, others with instructor consent.

name: Interaction Design
description: Provides a critical overview of interaction design (including usability, evaluation, and cultural aspects) and a practical program of website and computer software interface creation.
requirements: DMD 1002 and1102; open to Digital Media and Design majors only, others by instructor consent.

name: Special Topics in Digital Media
description: Seminar focusing in digital media. Content will vary each semester based upon instructor expertise.
requirements: pen only to Digital Media and Design majors; others by instructor consent.

name: Independent Study
description: Independent study in a Digital Media area of concentration.
requirements: pen only to Digital Media and Design majors, others with instructor consent.

name: Brand Lab
description: An interdisciplinary lab that explores and deploys the principles of strategic branding and identity design across traditional and digital environments.
requirements: DMD 1002 and1102. Open to juniors or higher. Open to Digital Media and Design majors only, others with instructor consent. Recommended preparation: DMD 2700 or3730.

name: Motion Design and Animation II
description: An intermediate to advanced exploration of motion design, animation, and visual effects.
requirements: DMD 2200 and2210; open only to Digital Media and Design majors; others by instructor consent.

name: History of Animation
description: A history of animation from the late 19th-century through contemporary and emerging digital technologies.
requirements: DMD 1002 and1102; open only to Digital Media and Design majors, others with instructor consent. Recommended preparation: DMD 3010 W.

name: Experimental and Alternative Techniques
description: An exploration of non-traditional techniques and mediums for creating motion graphics and animation.
requirements: DMD 2200 and2210; open only to Digital Media and Design majors; others by instructor consent.

name: Character Animation
description: An in-depth exploration of character animation using a combination of digital and traditional techniques and principles.
requirements: DMD 2200. Open to Digital Media and Design majors only, others by instructor consent.

name: Broadcast Graphics and Title Sequence
description: A survey of broadcast design and title sequences made for film, games and television.
requirements: DMD 2200 and2210; open only to Digital Media and Design majors; others by instructor consent. Recommended preparation: DMD 2230.

name: Cinematic Storytelling
description: A survey of film and media, in particular, the close analysis of graphic storytelling techniques in television, animation, shorts, and movies.
requirements: DMD 1002 and1102; open to Digital Media and Design majors, others with instructor consent.

name: Scientific Visualization
description: (Also offered as ART 3235.) Exploration of techniques for the development of still and animated graphics for use in science education and scientific publications and presentations. Project-based coursework with involvement from scientific experts and close collaboration between student illustrators and animators.
requirements: DMD 2200; open only to Digital Media and Design students, others with instructor consent. Recommended preparation: DMD 3200.

name: Animating Science
description: A project-based exploration of animated scientific visualizations and digital artworks inspired by science.
requirements: DMD 2200 and2210; open to Digital Media and Design majors, others with instructor consent.

name: Visual Effects
description: Exploration of compositing and visual effects through production, manipulation, and combination of live action footage with 2D and 3D animated effects.
requirements: DMD 2200 and2210; open to Digital Media and Design majors, others with instructor consent. Recommended preparation: DMD 2230.

name: 3D Animation II
description: Continuation of the core animation principles to explore advanced animation techniques including character animation, deformations, and non-linear animation.
requirements: DMD 2300,2310and2320; open to B.F.A Digital Media and Design 3D Animation concentration students, others with instructor consent.

name: History of Computer Graphics
description: The history of computer-generated imagery (CG) from its beginnings to the present.
requirements: pen to Digital Media and Design majors; others with instructor consent.

name: 3D Modeling, Lighting and Rendering II
description: Instruction and guidance in the techniques and critical understanding of modeling, including texturing the model, lighting, and rendering in animation specific to a 3D environment.
requirements: DMD 2310 and2320; open to B.F.A Digital Media and Design 3D Animation concentration students, others by instructor consent.

name: Storyboarding and Visual Development
description: Previsualization processes and techniques for time-based projects.
requirements: DMD 2210,2200,2300,2500,2700, or 1070; open to Digital Media and Design majors, others by instructor consent.

name: 3D Simulations
description: Offers students an intermediate understanding of the art and science of creating physical simulations, using particle systems and collision detection. Creation of complicated rendering and compositing setups that make animations both easier to render and more flexible within the bounds of any animation or VFX sequence.
requirements: DMD 3310; open to B.F.A Digital Media and Design 3D Animation concentration students only; others by instructor consent. Recommended preparation: DMD 3300.

name: Wearable Electronics and Interactive Objects
description: (Also offered as DRAM 3420.) Provides a basic understanding of electronics, key components, function, construction, and project design for wearable electronics and interactive objects. Concepts learned will form the core for students to continue to proactively explore and experiment with wearable electronics and interactive objects beyond the classroom.
requirements: DMD 1060; others with instructor consent.

name: Introduction to Mobile Application Development
description: Through lecture and hands on exercises, students will be introduced to the processes, technologies, and environment of mobile applications.
requirements: DMD 1060 and1070; open only to Digital Media and Design majors, others with instructor consent.

name: Advanced Web Design and Development
description: Explores intermediate and advanced web design and development techniques, covering Cascading Style Sheets, XML, dynamic HTML with Javascript, common frameworks, and the principles of site management. The course will also cover more advanced design concepts in website creation, such as efficient navigation design, designing for portability and accessibility, separating content from presentation for easy site updating and maintenance, planning interactivity, and search engine optimization.
requirements: DMD 1070; open only to Digital Media and Design majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Coding for Web and Interactive Media Design
description: Explores intermediate programming techniques for web and interactive media projects.
requirements: DMD 1060 and1070; open to Digital Media and Design majors; others with instructor consent. Recommended corequisite: DMD 3470.

name: Interactive Storytelling
description: A project-based exploration of the relationship of story, character, and player in games. Students will develop narrative digital projects, examine a selection of popular storytelling games, and explore ways that games have historically visualized and communicated their stories.

name: 3D Virtual World and Simulations
description: Investigation of different virtual environments, simulations, and serious games and examine how game engines can be used to generate a three-dimensional computer-based environment. Students will create a 3D environment based on their own imagination and research.
requirements: DMD 2310,2320,2500, and 2542; open only to Digital Media and Design majors, others with instructor consent.

name: Game Systems Design
description: Students in this course learn and apply advanced game design techniques and game theory. Students focus on the concepts of balance, design, and player psychology, synthesizing these elements into cohesive and interesting gameplay.
requirements: DMD 2500; open to Digital Media and Design majors, others with instructor consent.

name: Multiplayer Game Development
description: Students create a multiplayer game experience based in a relevant game engine that adheres to or modifies the core mechanics to create a new multiplayer game experience.
requirements: DMD 2500; open to Digital Media and Design majors; others with instructor consent.

name: History and Theory of Digital Art
description: (Also offered as ARTH 3570, AMST 3570.) Investigates forms of digital and Internet art and the mostly forgotten histories of the technologies behind them. Forms and themes to be explored include games/gaming, surveillance art, cyberfeminism, data visualization, and crowdsourced art. CA 1. CA 4.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to sophomores or higher.

name: 3D Game Art I - Modeling and Texturing
description: Basic introduction to all parts of the 3D asset creation pipeline for games including subdivision, surface, and spline modeling for game assets, UV unwrapping, PBR material painting, asset creation for game props, characters, and environments.
requirements: DMD 2500; Open to Digital Media Design majors only, others with instructor consent.

name: 3D Game Art II - Motion and Technical Art
description: Introduction to elements of motion and detailing with an emphasis on in-engine techniques including digital sculpting and retopology, rigging and animation for games, physics simulations, particle effects, custom shader design, camera animation and post-processing effects.
requirements: DMD 3581; Open to Digital Media Design majors only, others with instructor consent.

name: Historical Fiction in Games and Film
description: (Also offered as HIST 3107.) Critique of historically themed films and video games; comparison to surviving primary documents and artifacts; assessment of historical accuracy and cultural impact.
requirements: pen to Digital Media and Design and History majors only, others with instructor consent; open to sophomores or higher.

name: Collaborating with Cultural Organizations I: Methods
description: (Also offered as HIST 3103.) Introduction to mission-driven cultural organizations and methods for meaningful, effective collaboration with them and their communities in the digital age.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: DMD 2010 and/or DMD 2610.

name: Collaborating with Cultural Organizations II: Practice
description: (Also offered as HIST 3104.) Project-based application of digital public history tools and methods undertaken in partnership with a cultural organization. Provides immersion in issues of contemporary practice while building collaborative competency. Includes an integrated service learning component.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: DMD 3610/ HIST 3103.

name: Human Rights Archives I: Documenting and Curating Community Memory
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3640.) The use of human rights archival materials in documentary storytelling. Students will learn methods and best practices of collecting and managing digital visual and audio-visual archival assets. This is the first part of a two-semester unit addressing a common theme. Part I is not a prerequisite for Part II.
requirements: pen to Digital Media Design majors and Human Rights majors or minors only; open to juniors or higher; instructor consent required. Recommended preparation: DMD 2200,2210, or HRTS 3149 W.

name: Human Rights Archives II: Visual Storytelling Practices
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3641.) The use of human rights archival materials in documentary storytelling. Students will be trained in different documentary techniques and storytelling approaches working with oral history narratives and archival materials. This is the second part of a two-semester unit addressing a common theme. Part I is not a prerequisite for Part II.
requirements: pen to Digital Media Design majors and Human Rights majors or minors only; open to juniors or higher; instructor consent required. Recommended preparation: DMD 2200,2210,3640, or HRTS 3149 W.

name: Creative Content Strategy
description: Explores key concepts and methods of content marketing, including digital content planning, creation, and distribution, by integrating multiple forms of media into a content strategy to maximize the impacts.
requirements: DMD 2700 and2710; open to Digital Media and Design majors only, others by instructor consent.

name: Digital Media Analytics
description: Provides a working knowledge of the array of metrics and analytics needed to understand the digital consumer and measure the effectiveness of digital media marketing.
requirements: DMD 2700; open to Digital Media and Design majors only, others with instructor consent. Recommended preparation: DMD 2710,3730and1000-level STAT course.

name: Digital Consumer Behavior
description: Explores and analyzes the changes in consumer decision-making and behavior in today's digital world.
requirements: DMD 2700, which may be taken concurrently; open to Digital Media and Design majors only, others by instructor consent. Recommended preparation: DMD 1002 and1102, STAT 1000 Qor higher.

name: Digital Sports and Entertainment Studio
description: The digital marketing landscape in sports and entertainment, including changes in the production, marketing, distribution, and consumption of sports and entertainment media properties.
requirements: DMD 2700 and3730; open to Digital Media and Design majors only, others with instructor consent. Recommended preparation: DMD 2710.

name: Digital Media and Technology Ethics
description: Explores the intersection of ethics, technology, and humanity in order to equip students with the critical thinking skills necessary to navigate the digital landscape.
requirements: DMD 2700; open to Digital Media and Design majors, others with instructor consent.

name: Documentary Film Production
description: This course introduces students to camera and sound recording for small-crew documentary filmmaking. Students learn interviewing, ethics in documentary, and basic story structure. Through analysis of short and feature length documentary films, as well as hands-on directing, filming, and editing, students will learn the art and technique of documentary filmmaking.
requirements: DMD 2210 and2810. Open to BFA Digital Media and Design majors in the Digital Film/Video Production concentration only, others by instructor consent.

name: Social Documentary in Theory and Practice
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3828.) The study of the evolution of the documentary genre and its potential use as a vehicle for social discourse and change. Through sustained engagement with the documentary genre, students will gain direct experience in shooting and editing short form documentary films.
requirements: pen to Digital Media Design majors and Human Rights majors or minors only; open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: DMD 2210,2810,3820, or HRTS 3149 W.

name: Film Writing
description: (Also offered as DRAM 3145, ENGL 3707.) Theoretical and practical work in the content and form of the fiction scenario.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher, others with instructor consent.

name: Creative Producing for Independent Film
description: Examination of each phase of the filmmaking process, from conception to marketing and distribution, through the role of a creative producer. Students develop pitching materials and entrepreneurial business plans for their original narrative, documentary or new media film projects.
requirements: DMD 2700 or3230; open to Digital Media and Design majors only, others with instructor consent.

name: Digital Sound Design
description: A practical introduction to sound recording, editing, and mixing, designed to give students both the technical and artistic skills necessary to provide sound design for a variety of different media, including stand-alone audio, live-action film, animation, games, and more.
requirements: DMD 2210; open only to BFA Digital Media and Design Film/Video Production concentration students, others by instructor consent.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program (Fall, Spring, or Summer). Departmental consent required, normally before the student's departure to study abroad.

name: Variable Topics
description: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Degree Exhibition
description: Preparation of a project or portfolio for presentation in the Digital Media and Design Department's Degree Exhibition. May be taken in conjunction with the B.F.A. internship or senior project or B.A. senior thesis. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: pen to DMD majors with the consent of the instructor.

name: Portfolio and Professional Development: Putting it All Together
description: Prepares Digital Media and Design BFA students for transition to careers through the development of a professional portfolio, resume, website, social media presence, other collateral, and associated skills, as well as BFA Degree Exhibition participation.
requirements: pen to senior Bachelor of Fine Arts Digital Media and Design majors only, others by instructor consent.

name: Agency
description: An immersive study of the role, structure, procedures, techniques and processes employed by a Brand Agency within the digital and social media spaces.
requirements: pen to Digital Media Design majors only, others by instructor consent.

name: Digital Content Design, Creation and Distribution Studio
description: Develop marketing communications strategies, design, produce and distribute digital content for the Digital Media and Design Department and outside projects with corporate partners.
requirements: DMD 1102 and4040; open only to senior and graduate Digital Media and Design majors, instructor consent required. Recommended preparation: DMD 2710,3035,3200and3300.

name: Senior Project
description: Development of a project in the student's area of concentration that demonstrates vigorous and consistent thematic engagement and articulates both technical and conceptual sophistication. To be taken twice in two consecutive semesters in the student's senior year. To fulfill the graduation requirement for B.F.A., students must pass with a grade of C or better.
requirements: pen to senior B.F.A Digital Media and Design majors only.

name: Digital Media Internship/Co-op
description: Supervised professional experience in the student's field of study. A minimum GPA of 2.7 is required. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: pen to Digital Media Design majors only, others by instructor consent.

name: Senior Thesis
description: Preparation and presentation of a thesis that demonstrates vigorous and consistent intellectual engagement and articulates technical, conceptual, and scholarly sophistication. To be taken twice in two consecutive semesters in the student's senior year.
requirements: pen to Digital Media and Design majors only, others with instructor consent.

name: Advanced Motion Media
description: Advanced exploration of motion media topics, including large-scale, collaborative, and interdisciplinary projects, and investigations in emerging motion media technologies.
requirements: DMD 3200; open only to Digital Media and Design majors, others with instructor consent.

name: 3D Rigging
description: Concepts of rigging, with emphasis on animated props and characters. Techniques for using and creating bones, constraints, skeletons, skinning and weight painting.
requirements: DMD 3350; open to B.F.A Digital Media and Design 3D Animation concentration students, others with instructor consent. Recommended preparation: DMD 3300.

name: Advanced Compositing for Visual Effects
description: Takes the students further into the art of visual effects, combining computer generated animation together and with live action footage.
requirements: DMD 3350; open to B.F.A Digital Media and Design 3D Animation concentration students only, others by instructor consent. Recommended preparation: DMD 3300 and4310.

name: Advanced 3D Research and Production
description: Explores, develops and evaluates the research and skills in 3D animation production, focusing on each student's own path of study.
requirements: DMD 3310; open to B.F.A Digital Media and Design 3D Animation concentration students only, others by instructor consent. Recommended preparation: DMD 3300,3350,4310and4340.

name: Web 3: Expert Topics in Web Development
description: Expert topics in web design and development, including intensive instruction and hands-on development with databases and server-side programming to build web applications.
requirements: DMD 3470 and3475; open to Digital Media and Design majors only, others with instructor consent.

name: Web and Interactive Media Design Practicum
description: Digital technology is ever-changing and so too are techniques and workflows required in the production of web and interactive media projects. Through the completion of real-world projects, this course examines emerging technologies and techniques in the world of web and interactive media design.
requirements: DMD 3470 and3475; open to Digital Media and Design majors only, others with instructor consent. Recommended preparation: DMD 4470.

name: Advanced Digital Game Design and Development
description: Advanced study and application of digital game design and development, programming, 3D game environments, game testing, human computer interaction, quality assurance, and publishing.
requirements: DMD 2542 and 3522; open only to Digital Media and Design seniors and graduate students, others with instructor consent.

name: Disruptive Technologies
description: Exploration of emerging interactive technologies through the creation of rapid-fire prototypes utilizing experimental hardware and software. These skills enable students to develop interactive installations and unique gameplay scenarios.
requirements: MD 3522 and2542; must be taken senior year; open only to Digital Media and Design majors, others with instructor consent.

name: Advanced Game Scripting
description: Master gameplay scripting within a commercial game engine. Emphasis is on foundational knowledge required for developing artificial intelligence models, rendering, and networking for games.
requirements: DMD 2542; open to Digital Media and Design majors only, others with instructor consent.

name: Digital Public History Project
description: (Also offered as HIST 4640.) Students work collaboratively, with instructor guidance and feedback, to design and complete a digital public history project or prototype.
requirements: HIST 3102; DMD 3610/ HIST 3103; DMD 3620/ HIST 3104; three credits of HIST 3890 or3991; open to DMD majors or Digital Public History minors only, others with instructor consent.

name: Advanced Digital Analytics
description: A project-based study of advanced digital analytics and social media listening tools and techniques. Students will utilize social listening and media intelligence platforms to conduct market research, analyze campaigns and digital initiatives, develop marketing strategy, and execute ongoing brand listening, crisis management, competitive intelligence, content analysis and reputation management initiatives.
requirements: DMD 3720; open to juniors or higher; open only to Digital Media and Design majors; others by instructor consent. Recommended preparation: 1000 level statistics course.

name: Advanced Digital Cinematography
description: Advanced course focused on the technical craft and aesthetics of cinematography / videography in the digital realm. Emphasis on advanced camera techniques (angles, movements, composition and blacking) and complex lighting and shot designs to enhance storytelling. Students will be required to buy/own a DSLR or mirrorless camera, a lens, data storage tools and basic cinematographer grip kit needed for class.
requirements: DMD 2810. Open to Digital Media and Design majors only, others by instructor consent.

name: Narrative Short Film Production
description: Production of narrative short films, delineating the role of the director, from script breakdown through post-production, with emphasis on directing actors and other methodologies necessary to realize the dramatic possibilities of a cinematic story. Students create several shorts and analyze the works of master directors.
requirements: DMD 2810 and3830; open only to Digital Media and Design majors, others with instructor consent.

name: Color Grading for Film and Video
description: An advanced post-production course on the technical craft and aesthetics of color grading for digital film and video.
requirements: DMD 2810; open to B.F.A Digital Media and Design majors in the Digital Film/Video Production concentration only, others by instructor consent.

name: Introduction to the Theatre
description: Analysis of the functions of the theatre artists and their contributions to the modern theatre. CA 1.

name: Introduction to Film
description: A basic study of film as both a means of communication and as an art form. CA 1.
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing DRAM 4151 or 4152.

name: Drafting for the Theatre
description: The basics of hand drafting techniques and the drafting conventions for scenic designers, lighting designers and technical directors.

name: Computer Drafting for the Theatre
description: Computer Aided Drafting techniques for theatrical applications. Use of design software for creating various 2-D plans, including light plots, set designs and technical shop drawings. Assumes a good working knowledge of theatrical drafting conventions and techniques.
requirements: equires one or more of the Adobe Creative Cloud software programs; students are responsible for purchasing the latest version of Adobe's Creative Cloud for education apps and installing it on their personal computer.

name: Design Fundamentals
description: An introduction to the basic principles of design, its major components, and the application of design principles in performance as it relates to scenic, costume, lighting, sound, projection design, and puppetry.
requirements: pen to Design and Technical Theatre B.F.A and Puppetry B.F.A majors; others with instructor consent.

name: Drawing and Painting Techniques for the Theatre
description: An introduction to theatrical sketching and rendering emphasizing color composition in various media.

name: Computer Rendering for the Theatre
description: Computer rendering for theatre design in 2-D and 3-D format.
requirements: equires one or more of the Adobe Creative Cloud software programs; students are responsible for purchasing the latest version of Adobe's Creative Cloud for education apps and installing it on their personal computer.

name: Theatre Production: Makeup And Wardrobe For The Actor
description: An introduction to the technology, tools, and materials used in makeup and wardrobe for actors.

name: Theatre Production: Lighting And Sound
description: An introduction to the technology, tools, and materials used in lighting and sound for the theatre.
requirements: equires one or more of the Adobe Creative Cloud software programs; students are responsible for purchasing the latest version of Adobe's Creative Cloud for education apps and installing it on their personal computer.

name: Theatre Production: Costumes And Makeup
description: Introduction to the technology, tools, and materials used in costumes and makeup for the theatre.

name: Theatre Production: Stagecraft
description: Introduction to the technology, tools, and materials used in constructing and rigging theatrical scenery.

name: Practicum in Dramatic Arts
description: Practical work in all areas of dramatic arts, with emphasis on running crew assignments. May be repeated for credit with a change in course content to a maximum of 6 credits. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: pen only to Dramatic Arts majors.

name: Introduction to World Puppetry
description: Introduction to the global culture of puppetry, from Punch and Judy and Javanese shadow theater to robots, sports mascots, and Burning Man. Puppet performances in terms of their combination of visual art, performance, text, and music; social, political, and religious contexts of puppet performances. CA 1.CA 4-INT.

name: Acting I
description: Basic acting techniques.
requirements: pen to BFA Acting majors only. May not be taken out of sequence after passing DRAM 1702.

name: Acting II
description: Additional basic acting techniques with emphasis on the presentation of scenes from contemporary plays.
requirements: DRAM 1701.May not be taken out of sequence after passing DRAM 2701.

name: Exploration of Acting
description: The basic elements of the acting process and related skills for those not intending to pursue professional acting careers. May be repeated for credit to a total of six credits with change of instructor, or with instructor consent.
requirements: ot open to Acting majors or students who have passed DRAM 1701. May not be taken out of sequence after passing DRAM 3710.

name: Introduction to Acting and Directing Practices
description: An introduction to fundamental techniques in acting and directing through practical exercises, collaborative projects, and critical reflection.
requirements: pen to Dramatic Arts majors. Others by instructor consent.

name: Stage Movement I
description: Conditioning the body to increase strength, flexibility, and sensitivity. Exploration of movement concepts in space, time and energy values, and mind body and environment relationships.
requirements: pen to BFA Acting majors only. May not be taken out of sequence after passing DRAM 1802.

name: Stage Movement II
description: Developing physical awareness and continuing body conditioning for the stage. Analyzing the natural world and how it moves. Work may include beginning mask, mime and tumbling skills.
requirements: DRAM 1801. May not be taken out of sequence after passing DRAM 2810.

name: Dance Appreciation
description: Overview of dance history, technique, and choreography based on lecture, discussion, films and practicum. No previous dance experience required. CA 1.

name: Voice and Speech I
description: Study of the skills required to develop an expressive, injury-free voice and improved speech on and off the stage.
requirements: pen to BFA Acting majors only. May not be taken out of sequence after passing DRAM 1902.

name: Voice and Speech II
description: Additional vocal and articulation/phonetics skills applied to the performance of both realistic and elevated language in dramatic literature.
requirements: DRAM 1901.

name: Entrepreneurship in the Arts
description: Unique entrepreneurial skills needed to navigate careers in the performing arts. Students will learn how to take on a leadership role, schedule, budget, fundraise, and market themselves and their projects.
requirements: pen to sophomores, juniors and seniors.

name: Histories of Drama and Performance I
description: Dramatic literature and performance histories from various cultural traditions from the 5th century BCE through the 17th century.
requirements: pen to Dramatic Arts majors only. May not be taken out of sequence after passing DRAM 4711 W.

name: Histories of Drama and Performance II
description: Dramatic literature and performance histories from various cultural traditions from the 17th century to contemporary examples.
requirements: pen to Dramatic Arts majors only. Recommended preparation: DRAM 2130. May not be taken out of sequence after passing DRAM 4711 W.

name: Honors Core: Sports as Performance
description: Rigorous critical investigation of parallels between sports and performance. Includes writing, critical readings, experiential activities, viewing sporting events/performances, multimodal research. Critical and theoretical perspectives on athletics, spectacle, performance, national identity, community, race, gender, sexuality, and more. CA 1.
requirements: pen to students in the Honors Program; others by consent of instructor.

name: History of Popular Theatre and Live Entertainment
description: Global survey of popular forms such as circus, stage magic, melodrama, vaudeville, musicals, and clowning in relation to themes such as expressing identity, speaking back to power, questioning gender norms, and making money. CA1. CA4 INT.

name: Asian Theatre and Performance
description: (Also offered as AAAS 2136.) Asian theatre, opera, dance, and other performance forms and their elaboration, reworking, and dissolution in modern and contemporary times, examined in relation to changes in society, politics, religion, and culture. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Script and Performance Analysis
description: An exploration of how theatre and performance tell stories. Introduces foundational techniques for analyzing texts and preparing them for production and identifying and evaluating non-textual elements of performance.
requirements: pen only to Dramatic Arts Majors, others by instructor consent.

name: Devising Theatre for Social Justice I
description: (Also offered as HRTS 2150.) Making theatre without a pre written script to address a social justice topic of interest, moving from initial stimulus to concluding performance. Students will center a contemporary issue of social justice while developing theatre making skills, emphasizing collaborative co creation, small group work, and the development and presentation of a range of performance forms. CA 1.

name: The Holocaust in Print, Theater, and Film
description: (Also offered as HEJS 2203, HRTS 2203.) Representations of the Holocaust, including first-hand accounts and documentaries; artistic choices in genre, structure, imagery, point of view, and the limits of representation. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Acting III
description: The study and practice of techniques for realism and naturalism typically used in performing works by the modern realists.
requirements: DRAM 1702.

name: Acting IV
description: A continuation of the study and practice of techniques utilized in the performance of modern realists.
requirements: DRAM 2701.

name: Introduction to Directing
description: Emphasis on theory and play analysis from the director's point of view.
requirements: DRAM 1701. May not be taken out of sequence after passing DRAM 2712.

name: Stage Movement III
description: Beginning the process of applying the actor's movement skills to the unique requirements of different theatrical forms and structures. Applied skills may include tumbling, gymnastics, clowning, mask work, ethnic arts, hand-to-hand combat, armed combat and many theatrical forms and styles of dance.
requirements: DRAM 1802. May not be taken out of sequence after passing DRAM 2812.

name: Stage Movement IV
description: Developing and applying additional movement skills to different types and styles of dramatic expression.
requirements: DRAM 2810.

name: Voice and Speech III
description: In-depth study of applied voice and speech skills, particularly flexibility of the voice and application of vocal variety to understanding and expressing the structure and meaning of language and text.
requirements: DRAM 1902. May not be taken out of sequence after passing DRAM 4911.

name: Vocal Performance Techniques
description: Basic skills in voice production, vocal variety, articulation, and voice characterization for those in the dramatic arts pursuing careers other than stage acting.
requirements: ot open to Acting majors.

name: Dramatic Arts: The Practice and the Profession
description: A forum for Dramatic Arts students to meet, share and discuss ongoing work, engage collaboratively across programs and cohorts, discuss emerging issues in the department and the field, and learn from the skills and experiences of guest artists.
requirements: pen to Dramatic Arts majors and minors.

name: Stage Management for the Theatre
description: Studies of the vocation and profession of stage management as defined by modern theatre practice. Also examines inter-relationships between the stage manager and the other members of the theatrical production staff.

name: Advertising, Publicity, and Promotion in the Dramatic Arts
description: An introduction to the basic techniques of advertising copy, news releases, and feature stories.

name: Women in Theatre: Gender Identity and Expression on the Stage
description: (Also offered as WGSS 3130.) A critical study of women's participation in the art of theatre, with particular attention to theatre as a tool for exploring gender identity and expression. Focus on plays and performances, primarily from the 20th- and 21st-century United States, analyzing how evolving feminist concerns are reflected in women's theatrical work and how changing concepts of gender and other intersectional identities are embodied on the stage. CA 4.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: African-American Theatre
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3131.) The significant developments in African American theatre and its antecedents and an examination of selected play scripts that exemplify those developments. CA 4.

name: African-American Women Playwrights, 1900 to the present
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3132.) African American women's playwriting in relationship to social, historical, and political contexts. CA 1. CA 4.
requirements: ecommended preparation: AFRA/ DRAM 3131.

name: Latina/o Theatre
description: A study of Latina/o theatre and performance in the U.S. CA 4.

name: Trends in Contemporary Theatre
description: A study of the major trends in drama and theatrical production of the western world today.
requirements: pen to Dramatic Arts Majors Only.

name: Theatre and Human Rights
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3139.) Provides a critical study of theatre production as political discourse in global areas of conflict and how that discourse defines, or is defined by, human rights issues.

name: Playwriting
description: (Also offered as ENGL 3705.) The writing, workshopping, revision, and structuring of plays. Key themes include character development, world-building, action, the voice of the playwright, incorporating dramaturgical feedback, revision, and cultivating consistent writing habits.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher, others with instructor consent. Recommended preparation: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Playwriting
description: (Also offered as ENGL 3705 W.) The writing, workshopping, revision, and structuring of plays. Key themes include character development, world-building, action, the voice of the playwright, incorporating dramaturgical feedback, revision, and cultivating consistent writing habits.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher, others with instructor consent.

name: Dramaturgy I
description: Offers students a broad overview of the historical, critical and theoretical background of dramaturgy and introduces them to dramatic criticism, literary office dramaturgy, and the fundamentals of production dramaturgy.
requirements: ecommended preparation: DRAM 2130,2131, and 2141.

name: Film Writing
description: (Also offered as ENGL 3707, DMD 3830.) Theoretical and practical work in the content and form of the fiction scenario.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher, others with instructor consent.

name: Practicum in Dramatic Arts
description: Practical work in all areas of dramatic arts. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory.)

name: Dramaturgy Seminar
description: Practical work in dramaturgy. Students enrolled in the course have been assigned as dramaturgs for Connecticut Repertory Theatre productions or are undertaking alternative dramaturgical assignments such as performance curation or audience outreach projects.
requirements: nstructor consent required. Recommended preparation: DRAM 2141 and3142.

name: Independent Study
description: A reading or project course under the direction of an appropriate staff member.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher; open only with consent of instructor.

name: Scene Construction
description: Basic techniques of constructing two dimensional and three dimensional scenery.
requirements: DRAM 1218 or equivalent preparation through independent studies and other shop time; open to sophomores or higher; open only to Dramatic Arts Majors, instructor consent required.

name: Rigging
description: Rigging systems and the basic techniques for flying scenery, with an emphasis on rigging safety.
requirements: DRAM 1218 or equivalent preparation through independent studies and other shop time; open to sophomores or higher; open only to Dramatic Arts Majors, instructor consent required.

name: Sound Technology and Production Audio
description: Introduction to the characteristics and properties of sound, as well as the design, assembly, and operation of audio systems for the theatre and live entertainment.
requirements: DRAM 1216; open to soph or higher; open only to Dramatic Arts majors, others with instructor consent. Students are responsible for purchasing the latest version of Adobe's Creative Cloud for education apps and installing it on their PC.

name: Sound for the Theatre
description: Art of sound design for the theatre and live performance. Using collaborative techniques and creative methods to develop original sound compositions.
requirements: DRAM 1216; open to sophomores or higher; open only to Dramatic Arts majors, others with instructor consent.

name: Scene Design
description: Introduction to scene design fundamentals, analysis, and techniques.
requirements: DRAM 1216 and1218; open to junior or higher Dramatic Arts majors; instructor consent required. Adobe Creative Cloud for education apps is required. May not be taken out of sequence after passing DRAM 3302.

name: Scene Design
description: Introduction to scene design fundamentals, analysis, and techniques.
requirements: DRAM 3301;open to juniors or higher in a Dramatic Arts major. students are responsible for purchasing the latest version of Adobe's Creative Cloud for education apps and installing it on their personal computer.

name: Scenic Painting Techniques
description: Students will learn drawing and painting techniques used by scenic artists in the theatre. Students will be required to purchase scenic brushes and other basic tools needed for class.
requirements: DRAM 1209. Open to sophomores and above.

name: Costume History
description: A slide survey class covering the origins and development of dress to the present day. Specifically African, Middle Eastern, and Euro-Centric dress, along with the societies and manners which created fashion.
requirements: pen only to juniors or higher in a Dramatic Arts major.

name: Costume Design
description: An introductory class centering on the designer's approach to the text, the creation of the designed look for the characters in the play, and the process of how to realize the costumes.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher; open only to Dramatic Arts Majors, others with instructor consent. Recommended preparation: DRAM 1209 or an equivalent introductory art course.

name: Wearable Electronics and Interactive Objects
description: (Also offered as DMD 3420.) Provides a basic understanding of electronics, key components, function, construction, and project design for wearable electronics and interactive objects. Concepts learned will form the core for students to continue to proactively explore and experiment with wearable electronics and interactive objects beyond the classroom.
requirements: DMD 1060; others with instructor consent.

name: Costume Technology
description: Basic foundation in the fabrication of clothing and costume items for the theater, wider entertainment fields and related industries.
requirements: DRAM 1215 or DRAM 1217 or instructor consent, open to sophomores or higher.

name: Lighting for the Theatre
description: Introduction to lighting design fundamentals, analysis, and techniques.
requirements: DRAM 1216 and1218; open only to Dramatic Arts majors. Students are responsible for purchasing the latest version of Adobe's Creative Cloud for education apps and installing it on their PC. May not be taken out of sequence after passing DRAM 3502.

name: Lighting for the Theatre
description: Introduction to lighting design fundamentals, analysis, and techniques. Requires one or more of the Adobe Creative Cloud software programs; students are responsible for purchasing the latest version of Adobe's Creative Cloud for education apps and installing it on their personal computer.
requirements: DRAM 3501; open to Dramatic Arts majors only.

name: Mask Theatre
description: Masking as a theatrical and sculptural practice is studied through the design, fabrication and performance of historical and contemporary forms.
requirements: nstructor consent, open to sophomores or higher.

name: Paper Sculpture
description: Sculpture and design techniques are practiced using the Roser Papier Methode for puppet fabrication. Full realization and performance of the sculptures as puppets completes the design exploration.
requirements: nstructor consent, open to sophomores or higher.

name: Rod Puppetry
description: A practical exploration of Rod Puppet Theatre through the design, fabrication and performance of several forms of Rod Puppet.
requirements: nstructor consent, open to sophomores or higher.

name: Puppetry in Television
description: Analysis and practical experience with television techniques for the Puppet Arts. Projects include design, fabrication and performance of Moving-mouth Puppets and other forms suited for the televisual medium.
requirements: nstructor consent, open to sophomores or higher.

name: Shadow Theatre
description: The worldwide phenomena of Shadow Theatre are explored through cultural studies; figure design, fabrication and performance; storyboarding; and production development for both direct screen and projected presentations.
requirements: nstructor consent, open to sophomores or higher.

name: Materials Techniques
description: Techniques such as character design, clay sculpture, mold making, casting, painting, foam carving, over-casting and wood carving are explored through practice as foundations for puppet fabrication.
requirements: nstructor consent, open to sophomores or higher.

name: Hand Puppetry
description: Hand puppet animation techniques are developed via forms such as Hand Pantomime, Glove Puppet and Moving-mouth Puppet performance. Design and fabrication methods complement the performance study.
requirements: nstructor consent, open to sophomores or higher.

name: UV/Czech Black Theatre
description: Practical exploration of UV ("Black Light") and Czech Black Theatre ("Curtain of Light") techniques as applied in the Puppet Theatre.
requirements: nstructor consent, open to sophomores or higher.

name: Movement-Based Performance for the Puppet Theatre I
description: Awaken and develop imaginative and skilled theatrical performers through devising work and exploration of movement-based theatre techniques.

name: Trends in the Contemporary Puppet Theatre
description: A study of the major trends in drama, design styles and production of the puppet theatre in the western world today. Additional project required for graduate credit.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Plays for Puppet Theatre
description: Surveying the dramatic repertoire of plays written or devised for puppets, this course considers translation from page to stage, develops skills in textual analysis and dramaturgy, and mines these playtexts as models for composing new plays for puppets.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: Object Theatre
description: A practical exploration of object theatre, also known as thing theatre or found object performance, a modern form of stage animation in which ordinary household objects and materials take on the appearance of life. Emphasis is placed on creating original performances in established and emerging styles of performance.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: Advanced Study of Acting and Directing
description: While focusing on the creative process of actors and directors working together, students will engage in practical exercises, collaborative projects, and critical reflection.
requirements: DRAM 1701, DRAM 1710, or DRAM 1711; open to Dramatic Arts majors and minors; others by instructor consent. Recommended preparation: DRAM 2141.

name: Performance Techniques
description: Performance study and practice in selected areas of dramatic arts.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Special Topics in Dramatic Arts
description: Course content may vary each semester based on instructor expertise.
requirements: pen to Dramatic Arts majors and minors.

name: Variable Topics in Dramatic Arts
requirements: pen to Dramatic Arts majors and minors.

name: Theatre Management
description: An exploration of the critical questions and challenges facing theatre managers today. Students will broaden their knowledge of leadership, fundraising, board relations, community development, equity, diversity, and inclusion, among other competencies necessary to run a theatre. The course culminates in the creation of a comprehensive business plan.
requirements: DRAM 2120; open to juniors or higher.

name: Advanced Topics in Theatre and Performance
