description: The study of French and Francophone culture through fiction, non-fiction, journalism and film. Emphasis on perfecting both oral and written expression through discussion, presentations, and composition on assigned topics. CA 1.
requirements: ecommended preparation: French 1104, three years of high school French, or equivalent proficiency level.

name: Grammar and Composition
description: Advanced study of French texts and extensive written practice in a variety of forms ranging from compositions, essays, summaries and film reviews. CA 1.
requirements: ecommended preparation: French 1104, three years of high school French, or equivalent proficiency level.

name: Grammar and Composition
description: Advanced study of French texts and extensive written practice in a variety of forms ranging from compositions, essays, summaries and film reviews. CA 1.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: French 1104, three years of high school French, or equivalent proficiency level.

name: Advanced French Grammar
description: An overview of grammar from points familiar to students to more sophisticated elements of the French language. Focus on texts from written, spoken, and electronic sources. Includes short creative writing projects to encourage reflection on and appreciation of the organizational function of grammar. Taught in French.
requirements: ecommended preparation: French 1104, three years of high school French, or equivalent proficiency level.

name: French Literature and Civilization in English
description: Representative works of French literature, on a particular theme. How literary forms articulate the ideas and values of different periods. CA 1.

name: French Philosophy
description: Introduction to the French philosophical tradition from the Enlightenment to the post-structuralist revolution. Topics include theories of freedom, knowledge, power, language, subjectivity, sexuality, and the mind/body dialectic. Critical practice applied to literature, film, and other genres. Taught in English. CA 1.

name: Diversity in France: Migration, Refugees, and Minorities
description: Study of the culture and diversity of France through history, literature, music and the news media. Themes and topics include: religion and secularism, international relations between former French colonies and France, the politics of immigration, social stratification, racial discrimination, and police violence. Taught in French.
requirements: ecommended preparation: French 1104, three years of high school French, or equivalent proficiency level.

name: Fiction and Nonfiction by Women
description: Study of a range of topics related to female subjectivity and freedom in the context of feminism, the LGBTQ movement, postcolonialism, and critical race theory. Examples include autonomy, rebellion, justice, love, sexuality, motherhood, fantasy, anxiety, mortality, and other themes that women writing in French have explored over the centuries. Taught in French.
requirements: ecommended preparation: FREN 1104, three years of high school French, or equivalent proficiency level.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Department Head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Variable Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: French Internship
description: Use of linguistic and cultural skills in French in a professional training context such as an internship or in industry in a French-speaking country. Requires contract agreed to in advance by student, internship field supervisor, and program director, detailing expectations for the credits earned. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: BGS Internship
description: Open only with consent of instructor and BGS mentor/advisor.
requirements: GS students only.

name: Independent Study
description: Open only with consent of instructor and BGS mentor/advisor.
requirements: GS students only.

name: Integrating General Studies
description: Integrates the fields of general and interdisciplinary studies. Traces emergence of interdisciplinary studies and compares different academic disciplines. Future of interdisciplnary studies is assessed.

name: Introduction to Geography
description: Principles, concepts and methods of modern geography are developed both in general form and specific case studies. Examples pertaining to both the human and physical environment will be discusssed. CA 2.

name: New Digital Worlds of Geographic Information Science
description: An overview of geospatial data and emerging technologies that are common in our everyday lives and how they are shaping society. Topics include the use of geospatial technologies like GPS, Google Earth, Satellite Imagery, and GIS, and how these technologies address environmental, societal, and political issues. Discussion of career opportunities in GIScience. CA 3.

name: Natural Disasters and Environmental Change
description: (Also offered as ERTH 1070 E.) Climate change, global warming, natural hazards, earth surface processes, and the impact these have on human populations now and in the past. Students who complete both ERTH 1070 and ERTH 1052 may request that ERTH 1070 be converted to a CA 3 Laboratory course. CA 3.
requirements: ot open for credit to students who have passed ERTH 1010,1050,1051,1055.

name: International Study
description: Special topics are taken in an international study program. Consent of Department Head or advisor may be required prior to the student's departure.
requirements: onsent of Department Head or advisor may be required prior to the student's departure.

name: Global Urbanization
description: (Also offered as URBN 1200.) A broad discussion of the role and structure of cities around the world from the first cities to contemporary times. Special emphasis will be placed on the mechanisms by which cities and ideas about them have been diffused from one place to another and on the changing forces that have shaped cities over time and across space. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Climate, Weather, and the Environment
description: Interactions between weather and climate and the human and natural environment.  Emphasis on understanding the linkages between natural processes and societal/environmental issues. CA 3.

name: GIS Modeling of Environmental Change
description: An introduction to environmental processes and patterns, especially assessing change in environmental systems using spatial analysis techniques.  Students will map field sites using Global Positioning System technology and aerial photographs, collect field data on various environmental systems, and build and test a Geographical Information System-based environmental model. CA 3-LAB.

name: World Regional Geography
description: Study of geographic relationships among natural and cultural environments that help to distinguish one part of the world from another. Analysis of selected countries as well as larger regions, with specific reference to the non-western world. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: Globalization
description: Globalization as a complex-multidimensional process. Linkages and interconnectedness between spatial processes and social, cultural, economic, political, and environmental change around the world today. Theory and impacts of economic, social, political, and cultural globalization through case studies at the local, regional, national, and international scales. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: Economic Geography
description: Examination of the relationship among economic, cultural, and geographic processes which affect the patterns, structure, and growth or decline of economic activities. The global extent of the agricultural, manufacturing, and service sectors is presented with particular emphasis on the interdependency of non-western and western economies. CA 2.

name: Introduction to Human Geography
description: Geographic perspectives on the relationships between human behavior/activities, and the physical, economic, and cultural environments. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: Introduction to Physical Geography
description: The physical elements and processes of the lithosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere, and biosphere in relation to one another and to the distribution of the world's environments. Emphasis on the basic concepts and theories of physical geography and relationships between humans and the physical environment they interact with every day. CA 3.
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing GEOG 4300.

name: Creating and Sustaining National Parks
description: (Also offered as ERTH 2310 E.) Geologic processes that create the Earth’s iconic landscapes through the study of National Parks, Monuments, and Seashores. Plate tectonics, climate and biotic change, natural hazards, Earth materials and resources, environmental conservation, and the interactions between human society and the natural world.

name: Climate Change: Current Geographic Issues
description: The science, impacts, and politics of climate change from a geographic perspective. Examination of physical mechanisms, extreme weather events, impacts on water, food and energy systems, impacts on polar regions, energy strategies and solutions, policy and negotiations, and mitigation and adaptation strategies. CA 2.

name: Geography of Energy for Sustainability
description: Introduction to energy solutions for global sustainability. Topics may include the geographic context of global and local energy use, energy transition, renewable energy, solar, offshore wind, and energy justice. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: Introduction to Sustainable Cities
description: Pathways to make cities more sustainable from social, economic, and environmental perspectives. Topics include sustainable transportation, renewable energy, recycling of waste, and green infrastructure in contemporary metropolitan areas in developed and developing nations. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems
description: (Also offered as CE 2500.) Fundamental principles of geographic information systems (GIS). Topics include history of the field, components of a GIS, the nature and characteristics of spatial data, methods of data capture and sources of data, database models, review of typical GIS operations and applications. Laboratory exercises provide experience with common computer-based systems.

name: Applications of Geographic Information Systems
description: Applications of geographic information systems. Particular attention to land use planning and resource management.
requirements: GEOG 2500.

name: Research
description: Primary research under faculty supervision.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: Race, Sex, Space, and Place
description: Focuses on cities, sexualities, and race relations through a study of racial segregation in American cities; emergence of gay neighborhoods; globalization; migration; and human rights.

name: Indigenous Geographies in Abya Yala and Turtle Island (The Americas)
description: An examination of Indigenous spatial knowledges and their relations with history, place, gender, research work, and advocacy.

name: Urban Geography
description: (Also offered as URBN 3200.) Analysis of the growth, distribution, and functional patterns within and among Western cities. Application of urban geographical concepts to city planning problems.

name: Health Geography: Connecting People, Place, and Health
description: An exploration and understanding of the connection and interplay of physical and social geographies of places and their impact on physical and mental health. What we eat, the air we breathe, where we live, where we work, people we interact with, and the health services we have access to all play a part in our health.

name: Environmental Evaluation and Assessment
description: Concepts and methods of environmental analysis in contemporary geography. Emphasis on the ecological impact of human activities and on the evaluation and assessment of existing and future environments.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: GEOG 2300 or 3410.

name: Environmental Planning and Management
description: The basic elements of the conflict between human environments and natural systems are considered, along with the methods of analysis and resolution of problems caused by that conflict. Emphasis on public policy related to environmental issues.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: GEOG 3410.

name: Global Change, Local Action: A Geography of Environmentalism
description: A systems thinking approach exploring global-local linkages of environmental politics and human-environmental interactions across scales using case studies and future modeling simulations. Emphasis will be placed on stakeholders and community-based initiatives to achieve environmental justice and sustainability.

name: Climate and Weather
description: Analysis of atmospheric processes giving rise to weather systems and climatic patterns. The dynamic integration of atmospheric systems is emphasized.
requirements: ecommended preparation: GEOG 1300 or2300E.

name: Human Modifications of Natural Environments
description: A geographical and historical interpretation of the changing relationships between culture and environment. Emphasis on the modifications of the natural environment by preagricultural, agricultural, and urban societies.

name: Field Methods in Geography
description: Overview of field methods for collecting data relevant to physical, human, and technical areas of Geography. Methods include identification of existing data to support field studies, assessment of field sources for commonly used datasets, surveys, geospatial technologies, and integration of these data for further analysis.
requirements: ecommended preparation: GEOG 2300 and2500.

name: GIS and Remote Sensing for Geoscience Applications
description: (Also offered as ERTH 3430.) Application of Geographic Information Systems, remote sensing, and image interpretation to problems in geoscience. Data acquisition, processing and analysis of Digital Elevation Models and satellite imagery. Geologic materials, processes, landforms and landscapes. Formerly offered as ERTH 4230 and GEOG 4230.
requirements: EOG 2300, or ERTH 1050, or both ERTH 1052 and one of ERTH 1010 or1051or1055or 1070 or GEOG 1070.

name: Geographic Data Analysis
description: An introduction to the use of quantitative methods in conducting research, with particular emphasis on the processing and analysis of geographic data.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: 1000 level STAT course.

name: Remote Sensing of Marine Geography
description: (Also offered as MARN 3505.) Introduction to remote sensing applications in oceans and seas. Applications include image analysis of sea surface temperature, winds, altimetry, sea ice, chlorophyll, primary productivity, and bathymetry.
requirements: ecommended preparation: GEOG 2300 or MARN 1002.

name: Cartographic Techniques
description: A laboratory-oriented introduction to computer-based map design and compilation. Concepts of scale, symbolization, map balance, and layout are emphasized for both general and thematic mapping.
requirements: ecommended Preparation: GEOG 2500 and2505.

name: Introduction to Spatial Data Science
description: An introduction to the fundamentals of spatial data science. Application of a high-level programming language (R) for spatial data analysis, visualization, and modeling.
requirements: GEOG 2500 and GEOG 3500 Q, or instructor consent.

name: Introduction to GeoComputing
description: Introduction to GIS programming and scripting to automate GIS and spatial analyses. Students will develop geospatial models using geoprocessing tools within ArcGIS, gain fundamental programming skills in the Python programming language, and employ Python scripting to solve geospatial problems.
requirements: GEOG 2500. Recommended preparation: GEOG 2505.

name: Global Dynamics of the Shipping Industry
description: (Also offered as MAST 3600.) Introduction to the global shipping industry and the essential role it plays in the conduct of world trade and the growth of the global economy.

name: Capstone Seminar in Geography
description: Techniques for, and practice in, research, writing, citation, and data presentation in geography.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to junior or higher Geography or Geographic Information Science majors, others by instructor consent. Prerequisite or corequisite: One Geography course at the 3000 level or higher.

name: Writing in Geography
description: Techniques for, and practice in, research, writing, citation, and data presentation in geography.
requirements: ne Geography course at the 2000 level or higher; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to junior or higher Geography and GIS majors. Corequisite: One Geography course at the 3000 level or higher.

name: Internship in Geography: Field Study
description: A fieldwork internship program under the direction and supervision of the geography staff. Students will be placed in agencies or industries where their academic training will be applied. One eight-hour work day per week (or its equivalent) for the host agency during the course of the semester will be necessary for three academic credits. Hours by arrangement with hosting agency, not to exceed 16 hours per week. Only six credits of internship (between GEOG 4090 and4091) may count towards the GEOG or GIS major. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: nstructor consent; open to sophomores or higher; must be taken with at least one credit of GEOG 4091 if more than one internship credit is requested in a semester.

name: Internship in Geography: Seminar
description: Description, analysis, and evaluation of the fieldwork portion ( GEOG 4090) of the internship. Written reports are required.
requirements: ust be taken with GEOG 4090; open to juniors or higher.

name: International Study
description: Special topics are taken in an international study program. Consent of Department Head or advisor may be required prior to the student's departure.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Special Topics
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Senior Thesis
requirements: ne advanced seminar in geography and/or three units of independent study in geography; open to junior or higher Honors students.

name: Senior Thesis
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; one 3000-level or above course in GEOG and/or 3 credits of independent study in geography; open to juniors or higher.

name: Variable Topics
requirements: pen only to juniors or higher. Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section.

name: Independent Study
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Geographical Analysis of Transportation
description: Investigation of the role of transportation in global trade, spatial organization, economic development, and the natural and built environment. Application of GIS to the study of transport systems and modeling.
requirements: ecommended preparation: GEOG 2100.

name: Applied Data Analysis in Earth Science
description: (Also offered as ERTH 4150.) Multivariate spatial analysis methods and statistical inference in earth science, emphasizing how to translate conceptual understanding into computer code.
requirements: ecommended preparation: STAT 1000 Qor1100Q, GEOG 3500 Q; open to juniors or higher.

name: Urban and Regional Planning
description: Urban and regional planning, with emphasis on duties of local planners, especially land use planning, and the political context for planners' work. Legal and political issues in communities and organizations.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: GEOG 2100 or instructor consent.

name: Disaster Risk, Vulnerability, and Resilience
description: Overview of geographical perspectives on disaster risk, vulnerability, and resilience using an integrated environmental, social, and infrastructural approach. The theory, methods, metrics, and tools necessary to measure and understand risk, vulnerability, and the resilience of societies worldwide.
requirements: ecommended preparation: Introductory course on natural hazards and disasters.

name: Biogeography
description: An examination of how physical environments, historical processes, and human activities shape current biogeographical patterns and influence future changes.
requirements: EOG 1000 or GEOG 2300 Eor EEB 2244 Eor EEB 2245 or NRE 1000 E.

name: Web GIS
description: Introduction to Internet GIS. The basics of system architecture, geospatial web services, mashups, key elements of mobile GIS solutions, the functionality of geoportals and web technologies, web mapping interoperability using universal data standards such as OGC (Open Geospatial Consortium) web services, and the current state of e-business and e-government web mapping interests.
requirements: GEOG 2500,2505and consent of instructor.

name: Fundamentals of Spatial Database Systems
description: The theories and principles behind the Spatial Database Systems. Students will learn how to design and implement spatial databases.
requirements: GEOG 2500, or instructor consent.

name: Mobile GIS
description: This course covers how to develop, test, and publish mobile GIS web and native apps across multiple mobile platforms (Android, iOS, etc.).
requirements: GEOG 2500 or instructor consent. Recommended preparation: GEOG 4515.

name: Spatial Big Data Analytics
description: Covers the collection, analysis, and visualization of spatial big data to support better decision-making in geographic contexts.
requirements: GEOG 2500 or instructor consent. Recommended Preparation: GEOG 4515.

name: Elementary German I
description: Using project-based learning and authentic materials, students will learn to communicate in the German language about familiar topics and gain intercultural competence.
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing GERM 1002,1003, or 1004; may not be taken for credit after passing any 2000-level or above course taught in German, or three or more years of high school German.

name: Elementary German II
description: Further development of interpersonal, interpretive and presentational communicative skills on a variety of topics. Applying linguistic skills as well as intercultural competence in projects.
requirements: GERM 1001; may not be taken out of sequence after passing GERM 1003 or1004; may not be taken for credit after passing any 2000-level or above course taught in German, or three or more years of high school German.

name: Intermediate German I
description: Further development of communicative abilities and intercultural competence by investigating topics such as contemporary politics, the environment, history, film, music, fine arts, literature, and technology.
requirements: GERM 1002 or two years of high school German. May not be taken out of sequence after passing GERM 1004. May not be taken for credit after passing any 2000-level or above course taught in German.

name: Intermediate German II
description: Solidifying communicative abilities and intercultural competence by investigating topics such as contemporary politics, the environment, history, film, music, fine art, literature, and technology.
requirements: GERM 1003. May not be taken out of sequence after passing any 2000- level or above course taught in German.

name: German Literature in English
description: Representative works of German literature in English, especially from the 20th and the 21st centuries. Development of close reading and critical thinking skills, improvement of student composition, and the development of a conceptual framework for understanding another culture. CA 1.

name: Contemporary Germany in Europe
description: Familiarizes students with contemporary German society and the cultural and historical aspects that shape everyday life in Germany in the 21st century. Students will explore a range of topics, including reunification, minorities, education and youth, the arts, and gender. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: The German Film
description: Weekly showings of German films from the twenties to the present. Introduction to film history, analysis and interpretation of films, outside readings, term papers. Reading and lectures in English. May not be used to meet the undergraduate language requirement. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Human Rights and German Culture
description: Study of philosophical discourse on human rights from the Enlightenment to the present and analysis of related ethical problems in conjunction with an examination of relevant literary texts, film, and other art forms. Study of Germany's role in the development of international human rights instruments. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Department Head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure.

name: Special Topics
description: May be repeated for a maximum of 12 credits with a change in topic.

name: Cyborgs, Robots, and Androids in the German Imaginary
description: An examination of the figure of the nonhuman-human and representations of artificial beings in the German imaginary with a focus on issues of technology, art, philosophy of subjectivity, and culture. Discussion of imaginary and real robots, cyborgs, homunculi, and automata as representations of humanity’s understanding of futurity and innovation. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: The Environment in German Culture
description: Ecological thinking in German culture from the Greeks (Plato) to the Greens (Amery). The second half of the semester consists of student projects on current environmental policies in the European Union. CA 1.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Intercultural Citizenship: Sustainable Futures through Creative Solutions and Human Rights Advocacy
description: This course draws on interdisciplinary intercultural citizenship, creativity, plurilingualism, human rights education, and critical thinking to address environmental sustainability challenges. Throughout the course, students plan an action to address a problem related to environmental sustainability.

name: Sensation, Perception, Expression: Media Aesthetics and Environmental Humanities
description: Exploring sensory, environmental and creative processes and production focused on the human/machine interface in the context of German-speaking media studies past and present. Emphases on concepts such as aesthetics, authorship, the anthropocene, media ecology, experimentation, imagination and creativity. Course materials include a variety of historical and contemporary texts, films, images and other media and integrating active, invention-oriented participation taking place at a variety of locations across campus. Taught in English.

name: Intensive Language Practice
description: Two or three weeks of concentrated study in Europe. Exclusive use of the language, with three to four daily contact hours. Practice in all active and passive language skills, combined with periodic review sessions during the rest of the semester.
requirements: GERM 1003, which may be taken concurrently, or equivalent.

name: Engineering Texts: Technology and German Culture in the 20th and 21st Centuries
description: Survey of interactions between engineering and literature in the twentieth and twenty-first century German and transnational contexts. Focus on examining how both the possibilities and the pitfalls of new technology were thematized by writers and artists at the beginning of the twentieth century. Development of skills in critical thinking, cultural competence, and new media literacy, emphasizing the new possibilities afforded to German-speaking cultures with the arrival of cybernetics and the Internet. Taught in English.

name: German Recitation in Applied Mechanics
description: Technical German in engineering through the basic concepts and problem solving techniques used in applied mechanics.
requirements: GERM 1003, which may be taken concurrently, or equivalent.

name: Introduction to the Sciences in German
description: A series of lectures and discussion periods about basic concepts in the physical sciences presented in German. Topics will be primarily from the various engineering disciplines, chemistry, physics, and mathematics.
requirements: GERM 1004; CHEM 1128 Q; PHYS 1502 Qor equivalent, all of which may be taken concurrently. May not be taken out of sequence after passing 3222.

name: Fields of Technology
description: A series of lectures and discussion periods on special topics in science and engineering.
requirements: GERM 3220 and3221.

name: German for Professional Use I
description: Development of oral and written skills using a content-based methodology and drawing on authentic documents in a variety of formats that convey the language and culture of professional environments in the German-speaking countries. Preparation for the Goethe Institutes's test of German for Professional Purposes (Deutsch f\r den Beruf).
requirements: GERM 1004 or equivalent. Recommended preparation: GERM 3233- 3234.

name: German for Professional Use II
description: Development of oral and written skills using a content-based methodology and drawing on authentic documents in a variety of formats that convey the language and culture of professional environments in the German-speaking countries. Preparation for the Goethe Institutes's test of German for Professional Purposes (Deutsch f\r den Beruf).
requirements: GERM 3231. Recommended Preparation: GERM 3234.

name: Building Language Skills Through Culture I
description: Development of oral and written skills using a content-based methodology and drawing on texts that deal with issues in contemporary culture of German-speaking countries. Emphasis on acquisition of a sophisticated understanding of cultural differences while building vocabulary, improving accuracy, and increasing facility in self-expression and communication.
requirements: GERM 1004. Not open to students who have passed GERM 2201, 2202, 2204, or 2205. May not be taken out of sequence after passing GERM 3234.

name: Building Language Skills Through Culture II
description: Development of oral and written skills using a content-based methodology and drawing on texts that deal with issues in contemporary culture of German-speaking countries. Emphasis on acquisition of a sophisticated understanding of cultural differences while building vocabulary, improving accuracy, and increasing facility in self-expression and communication.
requirements: GERM 3233. Not open for credit to students who have passed GERM 2202 or 2205.

name: German Grammar and Etymology
description: German grammar and etymology for advanced students. A conceptual foundation for communicative language skills and comparison with English.
requirements: GERM 3233, which may be taken concurrently, or consent of instructor.

name: German Culture Across Time
description: An interdisciplinary course on Germany and other German-speaking countries, analyzing cultural life and past and present developments. Discussion of selected non-fictional and fictional readings, films, and other media. Taught in English.

name: Studies in 19th Century German Literature
description: Study of a cohesive group of texts that mark the periods of Late Romanticism, Vormärz, Realism and Naturalism. Emphasis may vary. Attention will be given to the relevant socio-historical context and to the visual and performing arts.  Taught in German. CA 1.
requirements: GERM 3233, which may be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Studies in 20th Century German Literature
description: Study of a cohesive group of texts that mark the period. Attention will be given to the relevant socio-historical context and to the visual and performing arts.  Taught in German. CA 1.
requirements: ecommended Preparation: GERM 3233, which may be taken concurrently.

name: Studies in 20th Century German Literature
description: Study of a cohesive group of texts that mark the period. Attention will be given to the relevant socio-historical context and to the visual and performing arts.  Taught in German. CA 1.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended Preparation: GERM 3233, which may be taken concurrently.

name: Germans in Africa, Blacks in German-Speaking Countries, Colonial and Post-Colonial Perspectives
description: Interdisciplinary study of former German colonialism in Africa and Blacks in German-speaking societies, past and present. Construction of intercultural and interracial power and dialog in historical perspective. Diversity of black and white experiences and perspectives across class, racial-ethnic groups, gender, cultures, religions, and national borders. Discussion of selected literary and non-fictional readings, films, other visual images, and recordings. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: German Film and Culture
description: Critical analysis of artistic issues in writing screenplays and making movies. Dynamic interplay between German film, the other arts, their socioeconomic context and the cinematic traditions of other cultures. Taught in German. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
requirements: GERM 3233, which may be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: German Cinema in Cross-Cultural Perspective
description: Cross-cultural comparison of film genres using examples from German film history and other cinematic traditions. Taught in English. CA 1.

name: Topics in German Culture
description: An analysis of the cultural trends of a selected period or theme in a German-speaking country, taking into account the historical, political, and socioeconomic background, aspects of daily life, philosophical trends, major literary works and other artistic achievements in art, music, and architecture. Specialists from other departments will be invited as guest lecturers.
requirements: GERM 3233, which may be taken concurrently, or consent of instructor.

name: German Language Practicum
description: Placement of students as trainees in business, industry and social or government agencies where foreign language skills can be put to use.
requirements: hree years of college-level German or the equivalent. Open only to juniors and seniors.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be repeated for credit. Consent of Department Head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of advisor.

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Variable Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: The Finishing Touch: A Capstone in German Studies
description: Advanced students assess and polish their German language skills, consolidate their learning in German Studies, and demonstrate that learning in a final project.
requirements: GERM 3234; Six additional 2000 level or above credits in GERM.

name: Risk Management and Insurance
description: A study of the concept of risk and its treatment by insurance. It covers why the individual or corporation purchases insurance, what constitutes an intelligent insurance plan and what products are available in the insurance marketplace.
requirements: pen only to Business and Mathematics-Actuarial Science-Finance majors of junior or higher status. Not open to students who have passed FNCE 3221.

name: Introduction to Health Care Management
description: Presents and examines various aspects of the U.S. health care delivery system as well as introduces and compares the health care systems in different countries. Attention is paid to the financing, reimbursement, and delivery of medical care, the adoption of new medical technologies, and the role of the market and government. The effect of health care system design on cost, quality, efficiency, and equity is studied.
requirements: pen to Business students and Allied Health students in the Healthcare Administration concentration of sophomore or higher status. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HCMI 4225,4243, or 4250.

name: Health Care Economics
description: This course demonstrates how basic economic concepts, principles, and theories can be used to think about and illuminate various health care issues. Rather than focus on a few current health care problems, attention is directed toward an array of health-related topics. Students are provided with a set of economic tools to evaluate a theoretical or empirical argument relating to health or medical care. The course culminates with an in-depth analysis of the structure, conduct, and performance of the markets for physician services, hospital services, pharmaceutical products, and long-term care.
requirements: HCMI 3240, or ECON 1201, or ARE 1150; open only to business majors and Allied Health majors in the Healthcare Administration concentration of junior or higher status.

name: Health and Social Insurance
description: Addresses various business practices associated with providing private health insurance such as underwriting, medical claims cost control, pricing, and marketing. In that context, managed care techniques and benefit package designs including consumer directed health plans, and value-based insurance design, are discussed. Attention is also paid to design and functioning of various social insurance programs such as Medicare, Medicaid, unemployment compensation, disability insurance, workers compensation, and social security.
requirements: HCMI 3240; open only to business majors of junior or higher status.

name: Health Law and Policy
description: Introduction to the United States legal system as it relates to health care, public health and ethics. Sessions represent important applications of law to health including the powers of the state governments; privacy and confidentiality in health care; the right to privacy; the right to refuse treatment and end of life issues; hospital, physician and managed care liability; the Americans with Disabilities Act; and public health policy and advocacy. Structured to encourage lively and interesting in-class discussions of legal and ethical principles as they relate to the health care system.
requirements: HCMI 3240; open only to business majors of junior or higher status.

name: Cost-Benefit Analysis for Healthcare Business and Policy
description: This course provides students with cost-benefit analysis tools to enhance healthcare business and policy decision making. The following topics will be covered: methods to estimate the monetary equivalence of costs and benefits; interpretation of research findings; simulation methods to derive the aggregate effects of firm and policy interventions; time value of money and discounting; hypothesis testing; cost-effectiveness analysis; causal inference concepts to differentiate descriptive associations from cause-and-effect studies. In addition to course lectures, the instructor will present research articles providing credible input for business- and policy-level cost-benefit analysis.
requirements: HCMI 3240; open only to business majors of junior or higher status.

name: Clinical and Social Issues in Health Care
description: Covers clinical and social issues affecting health care provider organizations, such as the health needs of special population groups, public health concerns, epidemiological issues, and health care quality. Discussion will include how health care organizations address such issues through methods including clinical studies, disease management, partnership between private and public sectors, and legislative initiatives.
requirements: pen only to business majors of junior or higher status.

name: Internship in Health Care Management
description: Supervised internship in a health care organization where students work with health care professionals to expand their expertise in solving health systems problems and increase their awareness of the issues involved in the day to day operations of a health care institution. Student performance will be evaluated on the basis of an appraisal by the field supervisor and a detailed written report submitted by the student. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: pen only to Business majors of junior or higher status; consent of instructor and Program Director required prior to beginning the internship.

name: Special Topics
description: Classroom course in special topics in health systems management as announced in advance for semester.
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open only to business majors of junior or higher status.

name: Independent Study for Undergraduates
description: Individual study of special topics in health systems management as mutually arranged between a student and an instructor.
requirements: pen only to business majors of junior or higher status.

name: Senior Thesis in Health Care Management and Insurance Studies
description: Individual study of special topics on health care management and insurance.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open only to Health Care Management and Insurance Studies majors enrolled in the Honors program; instructor consent required.

name: Elementary Modern Hebrew I
description: Phonetic reading, cursive script, basic conjugations, simple syntax, and vocabulary. Oral and written expression through videos, songs, and exposure to Israeli culture.
requirements: ot open for credit to students who have had three of more years of Hebrew in high school. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HEJS 1002,1003, or 1004.

name: Elementary Modern Hebrew II
description: More complex grammatical structures including the construct state, verb patterns, and more advanced vocabulary. Oral and written expression through study of videos and popular culture.
requirements: HEJS 1001 or equivalent. Not open to students who have had three or more years of Hebrew in high school. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HEJS 1003 or1004.

name: Intermediate Modern Hebrew I
description: Building on first-year skills, more advanced grammar, vocabulary, and conversation. Examples from popular media and culture along with short readings continue to enhance students' language acquisition.
requirements: HEJS 1002 or the equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HEJS 1004. May not be taken for credit after passing HEJS 3251.

name: Intermediate Modern Hebrew II
description: More advanced communicative proficiency using readings and examples from media and popular culture. Focus on grammar, vocabulary, and conversation with more context from the history, culture, and religious traditions of the Jewish people.
requirements: HEJS 1003. Not open for credit to students who have passed HEJS 3251.

name: Who Are the Jews? Jewish Identity through the Ages
description: The major concepts, personalities and literary works that inform Jewish identity from the Biblical and Talmudic periods to the present. Taught in English.CA 1. CA 4.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Department Head required, normally before the student's departure.

name: Modern Jewish Thought
description: Nationalism, culture, ethics and philosophy in the writings of the major Jewish thinkers from Spinoza to the present. Emphasis will be placed on the work of Moses Mendelssohn, Hermann Cohen, Franz Rosenzweig, Martin Buber, Mordecai Kaplan, Judith Plaskow, and others. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
requirements: ecommended preparation: HEJS 1103. Not open for credit for students who have passed HEJS 1104.

name: Israel: History and Society
description: Major themes in Zionist and Israeli history and the development of Israeli art, literature, film, popular music, dance, theater, and popular culture, with a focus on the central questions that have both unified and divided Israeli society and politics. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Diversity and Inclusion in Israeli Society: A Cinematic View
description: Overview of Israeli films with a particular focus on contemporary cultural, social, and political tensions. Topics may include the uneasy relationship between an ancient patriarchal conservative religion and modern western secular society; Jerusalem as a holy city for three monotheistic regions, as a modern metropolis, and as a tourist attraction; the culture of masculinity promoted by the Israeli military; the status of women; attitudes toward the LGBTQ+ community; the treatment of minoritized groups in general, including those based on race or religion; and questions of citizenship and immigration, both legal and illegal. Taught in English.

name: The Holocaust in Print, Theater, and Film
description: (Also offered as HRTS 2203, DRAM 2203.) Representations of the Holocaust, including first-hand accounts and documentaries; artistic choices in genre, structure, imagery, point of view, and the limits of representation. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Jewish Culture in American Film
description: (Also offered as AMST 2204, CLCS 2204.) Representations of the diversity of Jewish culture (historical, religious, secular) in American film. Introduction to film analysis and interpretation. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Introduction to Genocide Studies
description: (Also offered as HRTS 2200, CLCS 2200.) Interdisciplinary introduction to the study of genocide as an historical, legal, social, political, and conceptual phenomenon, including response, prevention, and commemoration efforts. CA 2. CA 4-INT.
requirements: ot open for credit to students who have passed HEJS 3298 when offered as Introduction to Genocide Studies.

name: Jewish Humor
description: (Also offered as CLCS 2301.) The history of Jewish humor in modern times with attention given to its various forms, including oral traditions, fiction and humor writing, stand-up comedy, live performance, television, film, and music. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Anthropology of Jews and Jewishness
description: (Also offered as ANTH 3050.) Survey of the rich and growing ethnographic literature on Jews and Jewishness around the globe.  Course materials include ethnographic texts, music, and videos/films.
requirements: ecommended preparation: ANTH 1000 or1006; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Anthropology of Jews and Jewishness
description: (Also offered as ANTH 3050 W.) Survey of the rich and growing ethnographic literature on Jews and Jewishness around the globe. Course materials include ethnographic texts, music, and videos/films.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: ANTH 1000 or1006.

name: Selected Books of the Hebrew Bible
description: Literary structure and content of biblical book(s) using modern approaches as well as midrashic and medieval exegesis. Historical and archaeological material. With a change in content, may be repeated for credit and consent of instructor. A knowledge of Hebrew is not required. Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. CA 1.
requirements: NTD 3260 or HIST 3301 or HEJS 1103, which may be taken concurrrently, or instructor consent.

name: Sects and Movements in Judaism
description: Varieties of Jewish expression and belief from Biblical times to the present. Topics include: the Dead Sea Sect, Pharisees, Sadducees, Karaites, Marranos, Hasidism and the Reform, Conservative, Orthodox and Reconstructionist movements of the modern era. Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement.

name: The Holocaust
description: (Also offered as HIST 3418.) Origins, development, and legacy of the Holocaust. Topics include the history of modern European anti-Semitism, the creation of the Nazi state, the catalytic role of the Second World War, the actions and attitudes of the perpetrators, victims, and bystanders, and the diverse ways in which scholars and societies have dealt with the legacy of the Holocaust. Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement.

name: Introduction to Holocaust Studies
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3205.) This course provides students with an introduction to the study of the Holocaust. It examines the political, cultural, and religious contexts in which the mass murder of European Jews and others unfolded, considers the conditions under which the Holocaust became possible, the possibilities for resistance and dissent, and the impact of the Holocaust on contemporary culture and understanding of human rights.

name: Jewish Magic: from Late Antiquity through the Early Modern Period
description: Jewish magical beliefs and practices from the rabbinic period through the early modern period.  Texts include spells, kabbalistic lore, magical books, incantations, legends, prayers, medical texts, exempla.

name: Advanced Hebrew
description: Further grammar study. Practice in composition involving the use of everyday vocabulary and idiomatic expressions. Readings and films relevant to Israeli culture and history.
requirements: HEJS 1004 or instructor consent.

name: Advanced Hebrew
description: Further grammar study. Practice in composition involving the use of everyday vocabulary and idiomatic expressions. Readings and films relevant to Israeli culture and history.
requirements: HEJS 3251.

name: The Bible, the Holy Land, and History
description: The historical, literary, and archaeological investigation of the Old and New Testaments. Formerly offered as INTD 3260. CA 1.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Department Head required, normally granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Variable Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: The Jewish Middle Ages
description: Survey of sacred and secular literature in a wide variety of genres produced by Jews in the medieval period from major centers of European settlement. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Palestine Under the Greeks and Romans
description: (Also offered as HIST 3330, CAMS 3330.) The political, historical and religious currents in Greco-Roman Palestine. Includes the Jewish Revolts, sectarian developments, the rise of Christianity and the Talmudic academies. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. Taught in English.

name: The Black Death: Medieval and Modern Responses to Catastrophe
description: (Also offered as HIST 3362.) The Black Death (1346-50) from its origins in China through Europe. Institutional, medical, religious, literary, and social responses to the plague; how modern scholars reconstruct medieval experience; and new findings by historians and scientists that shed light on the challenges of past, present and future pandemics. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Jewish American Literature and Culture
description: (Also offered as ENGL 3220.) Interdisciplinary study of literary and artistic productions by and about Jews in the United States. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Jewish American Literature and Culture
description: (Also offered as ENGL 3220 W.) Interdisciplinary study of literary and artistic productions by and about Jews in the United States. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Jewish Responses to the Holocaust
description: (Also offered as HIST 3419.) Interdisciplinary exploration of Jewish responses to the Holocaust. Examines social, religious, theological, political, cultural, psychological, and literary responses both during and after the Second World War. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Holocaust Memoir
description: (Also offered as ENGL 3629.) Literature of the Holocaust focusing on memoir in various genres and forms. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to sophomores or higher.

name: Elementary Hindi I
description: Development of ability to communicate in Hindi, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic communicative needs within a cultural setting.
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing HIND 1102,1103, or 1104.

name: Elementary Hindi II
description: Development of ability to communicate in Hindi, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic survival needs within a cultural setting.
requirements: HIND 1101 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HIND 1103 or1104.

name: Intermediate Hindi I
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Hindi within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Hindi-speaking world.
requirements: HIND 1102 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HIND 1104.

name: Intermediate Hindi II
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Hindi within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Hindi-speaking world.
requirements: HIND 1103 or equivalent.

name: Special Topics
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Independent Study
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: The Historian as Detective
description: Uses historical documents focusing on a single incident in the past to reconstruct what happened and why.  Emphasizes development of historical research skills such as evaluating evidence, explaining cause and effect, and understanding events in their larger social, political, cultural, and economic contexts. CA 1.

name: The Historian as Detective
description: Uses historical documents focusing on a single incident in the past to reconstruct what happened and why.  Emphasizes development of historical research skills such as evaluating evidence, explaining cause and effect, and understanding events in their larger social, political, cultural, and economic contexts. CA 1.

name: World History, 1200-1800
description: A global approach to human history, 1200CE to 1800CE, emphasizing political, intellectual, economic, and social interactions among peoples with diverse cultures, ideas, and values. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Modern World History
description: A survey of the historical experiences of the world's major civilizations during recent centuries with particular attention to the modernization of the traditional cultures of Asia, Latin America, and Africa. CA 1.

name: Women in History
description: (Also offered as WGSS 1121.) The historical roots of challenges faced by contemporary women as revealed in the Western and/or non-Western experience: the political, economic, legal, religious, intellectual and family life of women. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Living Through War in World History Since 1500
description: Experiences and perceptions of both military and civilian participants in different kinds of wars around the world over the past 500 years. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Sports in History
description: The sports peoples around the globe have played and watched from ancient Greece to the present and the meanings of athletic performance and spectacle. CA 1.

name: Western Traditions Before 1500
description: An analysis of the traditions and changes which have shaped Western political institutions, economic systems, social structures and culture in ancient and medieval times. CA 1.

name: Modern Western Traditions
description: History of political institutions, economic systems, social structures, and cultures in the modern Western world. CA 1.

name: Global History of the Second World War
description: A study of the origins, development, and legacy of World War II from a global perspective. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: United States History to 1877
description: Surveys political, economic, social, and cultural developments in American history through the Civil War and Reconstruction. CA 1.

name: United States History to 1877
description: Surveys political, economic, social, and cultural developments in American history through the Civil War and Reconstruction. CA 1.

name: U
description: Surveys political, economic, social, and cultural developments in American history from 1877 to the present. CA 1.

name: U
description: Surveys political, economic, social, and cultural developments in American history from 1877 to the present. CA 1.

name: Introduction to American Studies
description: (Also offered as ENGL 1201, AMST 1201.) What is an American?  A multi-disciplinary inquiry into the diversity of American societies and cultures. CA 4.

name: Migrant Workers in Connecticut
description: (Also offered as LLAS 1570.) Interdisciplinary honors course on the life and work experiences of contemporary Latin American and Caribbean migrant workers with focus on Connecticut. Integrated service learning component. Field trips required. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Introduction to Latin America and the Caribbean
description: (Also offered as LLAS 1190.) Multidisciplinary exploration of the historical development of such aspects of Latin America and the Caribbean as colonization and nation formation; geography and the environment; immigration and migration; race, ethnicity, and gender in society, politics, economy, and culture. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Introduction to Latin America and the Caribbean
description: (Also offered as LLAS 1190 W.) Multidisciplinary exploration of the historical development of such aspects of Latin America and the Caribbean as colonization and nation formation; geography and the environment; immigration and migration; race, ethnicity, and gender in society, politics, economy, and culture. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Latin American Histories through Popular Cultures
description: (Also offered as LLAS 1630.) A consideration of art and popular culture as vehicles for understanding Latin American history from the late 1800’s to today. Dynamic primary sources such as songs, films, carnival parades or professional soccer matches, television programs, and works of art will serve as case studies that students will analyze, contextualize, and historicize. Each week considers a different time period and focuses on a particular political, economic, or social movement or ideological trend, using a cultural text of the era to understand each.

name: Latin American Histories through Popular Cultures
description: (Also offered as LLAS 1630 W.) A consideration of art and popular culture as vehicles for understanding Latin American history from the late 1800’s to today. Dynamic primary sources such as songs, films, carnival parades or professional soccer matches, television programs, and works of art will serve as case studies that students will analyze, contextualize, and historicize. Each week considers a different time period and focuses on a particular political, economic, or social movement or ideological trend, using a cultural text of the era to understand each.

name: History of Asia in the World to 1500
description: Development and spread of the Indic and Sinitic civilizations to 1500, with attention to cross-cultural contacts and sources of historical knowledge. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Key Words in East Asian History and Culture
description: East Asian history taught through analysis of select "hanzi" (Chinese ideographic symbols), focusing on their changing meanings and institutional manifestations in different regions over time. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Foreign Study
description: Credits and hours by arrangement. Open only with consent of department head, Normally granted before the student's departure.

name: Special Topics Lecture
description: Credits, prerequisites and hours as determined by the Senate Curricula and Course Committee.

name: Pyramids, Pirates, and the Polis: The Ancient Mediterranean
description: (Also offered as CAMS 2020.) Political and intellectual history of the civilizations that emerged around the ancient Mediterranean, including the Near East, Egypt, Greece, and Rome, with emphasis on their interactions and influences. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: The Historian's Craft
description: Learning critical reading, thinking and writing skills by interpreting a variety of primary sources.
requirements: pen only to history majors. May not be taken out of sequence after passing passing HIST 4996 or 4997.

name: The Historian's Craft
description: Learning critical reading, thinking, and writing skills by interpreting a variety of primary sources.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Open only to history majors. May not be taken out of sequence after passing HIST 4996 or 4997.

name: Introduction to Digital Humanities
description: (Also offered as DMD 2610, ENGL 2610.) The application of digital technology and media to such subjects as art history, classics, cultural and area studies, history, languages, literature, music, and philosophy. This course will provide a broad survey of the landscape of international and interdisciplinary digital humanities through the lens of ongoing work of faculty and staff researchers at the University of Connecticut.

name: Biography as History: Individuals in their Times
description: What the lives of interesting individuals reveal about major historical periods and themes. Course materials may include biographies, memoirs, autobiographies, diaries, and letters. Formerly offered as HIST 3100W.

name: History through Fiction
description: What novels and other works of fiction reveal about major historical periods and themes in history. Variable topics. Formerly offered as HIST 3101W.

name: History through Film
description: An exploration of the ways in which film can communicate complex cultural, historical, and political ideas. Topics may include film's ability to translate philosophical and religious ideas, portray accurate or revisionist history, play a role in subverting or critiquing the social and political status quo, and act as a chronicler of change. Formerly offered as HIST 3105. CA 1.

name: Revolution and Social Change
description: An exploration of the mechanisms of revolution and the role that revolution plays in social change and in the creation and maintenance of political institutions in a specific country or region and time period. Specific topics in revolution and social change will vary. CA 1.

name: Revolution and Social Change
description: An exploration of the mechanisms of revolution and the role that revolution plays in social change and in the creation and maintenance of political institutions in a specific country or region and time period. Specific topics in revolution and social change will vary. CA 1.

name: History of Technology
description: The development of technology and its relation to society in a specific country or region of the world, such as the United States, Europe, or South Asia. CA 1. CA 3.

name: Personality and Power in History
description: Analysis of the links between personality and power in various countries and across different eras. CA 1.

name: Personality and Power in History
description: Analysis of the links between personality and power in various countries and across different eras. CA 1.

name: History of Science
description: Development of modern science and technology in relation to culture, politics, and social issues. CA 1.

name: Empire and U
description: (Also offered as AMST 2207, ENGL 2207.) How the frontier and overseas ambitions have shaped U.S. institutions and culture. The impact of U.S. expansion on people outside its borders. These topics are explored through literary narratives and historical documents. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Science, Technology, and Society
description: Historical perspectives on the social construction of scientific knowledge and technological systems, examining scales from the local to the global as well as the ramifications for society and the natural world. May focus on any country or world region. May be repeated once for credit with a change in topic. CA 1. CA 3.

name: Science, Technology, and Society
description: Historical perspectives on the social construction of scientific knowledge and technological systems, examining scales from the local to the global as well as the ramifications for society and the natural world. May focus on any country or world region. May be repeated once for credit with a change in topic. CA 1. CA 3.

name: History of the Ocean
description: (Also offered as MAST 2210 E.) Cultural, environmental, and geopolitical history of the ocean from prehistory to the present. Examines the impact of migration, industrialization, modernization, and globalization on the relationships between people and oceans. CA 1.

name: Global Environmental History
description: Transformations of the global environment since 1450: the effects of human practices and ideas, especially on energy, landscapes, and commodities. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: The Pacific in World History
description: (Also offered as AAAS 2225.) The Pacific Ocean as a lens for thinking about modern history. Topics include the flow of people, ideas, goods, elements of nature (such as whales and bird guano), and technology among the nations and peoples of the Pacific World; and the impact of colonialism, war, decolonization, and the Cold War on the history of the region and the fortunes of indigenous peoples. Sources include scholarly works, government documents, diaries, and literature. Formerly offered as AAAS/HIST 2101. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
requirements: ecommended preparation: HIST 1201 and HIST 2100.

name: Global History of Capitalism
description: Exploration of definitions of capitalism in existing literature, its place(s) of origin, and the initial period of the genesis of capitalism from late medieval times. Examination of how capitalism has changed throughout time and space. Explanation of why some individuals and countries are rich while others are poor, as well as the impact of capitalism on global history, notions of time, slavery, class, race, gender, law, and the contemporary world. Formerly offered as HIST 2845. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Global History of Capitalism
description: Exploration of definitions of capitalism in existing literature, its place(s) of origin, and the initial period of the genesis of capitalism from late medieval times. Examination of how capitalism has changed throughout time and space. Explanation of why some individuals and countries are rich while others are poor, as well as the impact of capitalism on global history, notions of time, slavery, class, race, gender, law, and the contemporary world. Formerly offered as HIST 2845W. CA 1. CA 4.

name: History of War in the Modern World
description: Selected topics analyzing the interactions of warfare, military theories and practice with social, economic and technological developments since 1815.
requirements: ecommended preparation: HIST 1400.

name: Byzantium
description: A survey of the major developments from the fourth through the fifteenth centuries: religious controversies, the theme system, the Crusades, Byzantine civilization, its law, art, literature, and its impact upon European and Russian civilization. Previously offered as HIST 3350.

name: Europe in the Nineteenth Century
description: Examines the Restoration, the mid-century revolutions, and the forces of nationalism, liberalism and imperialism. New social and economic movements and currents of thought are described and explored. CA 1.
requirements: ecommended preparation: HIST 1400.

name: Europe in the Nineteenth Century
description: Examines the Restoration, the mid-century revolutions, and the forces of nationalism, liberalism and imperialism. New social and economic movements and currents of thought are described and explored. CA 1.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: HIST 1400.

name: Europe in the Twentieth Century
description: Twentieth Century Europe and its world relationships in the era of two world wars, the great depression, and the cold war. CA 1.
requirements: ecommended preparation: HIST 1400.

name: Europe in the Twentieth Century
description: Twentieth Century Europe and its world relationships in the era of two world wars, the great depression, and the cold war. CA 1.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: HIST 1400.

name: From Revolution to Nihilism: Ideas and Ideologies in Nineteenth-Century Europe
description: An examination of nineteenth-century European thinkers and their ideas in their social contexts. CA 1.

name: From Revolution to Nihilism: Ideas and Ideologies in Nineteenth-Century Europe
description: An examination of nineteenth-century European thinkers and their ideas in their social contexts. CA 1.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: From Nietzsche to Neo-liberalism: Ideas and Ideologies in Twentieth-Century Europe
description: An examination of twentieth-century European thinkers and their ideas in their social contexts. CA 1.

name: History of Modern England
description: Cultural, political, economic, and intellectual development of modern Britain, with special emphasis on changing ideas of national identity.

name: Germany Since 1815
description: German political, social, and intellectual history since the Napoleonic Wars. European and world problems as reflected in the emergence of Germany as a pivotal force in international affairs.

name: Power and Resistance: History of Eastern Europe
description: Political, social, and intellectual history of Eastern Europe. Main themes include imperial legacies, national identity and state-building, minority identities and politics, democracy, nationalism, fascism, communism, genocide, and war. Special attention to the politics of diversity versus nationalism, political ideologies, dissent and resistance, and contributions to the understanding of rights. CA 4-INT.

name: History of Russia Since 1855
description: Continuation of History 3470. Late imperial Russia, the former Soviet Union, and contemporary Russia.
requirements: ecommended preparation: HIST 3470.

name: New England and the Caribbean Plantation Complex, 1650-1900
description: (Also offered as LLAS 2507, MAST 2507.) New England’s role in the creation and expansion of the Caribbean plantation complex. CA 1. CA 4.

name: LGBTQ+ History in the United States
description: (Also offered as WGSS 2525.) This course traces the history of LGBTQ+ identities, relationships, and politics in the United States from the late 18th century to the present, with a focus on changing forms of romantic and sexual relationships; the growth of LGBTQ+ communities; and the history of LGBTQ+ activism.

name: Asian American Experience Since 1850
description: (Also offered as AAAS 2530.) Survey of Asian American experiences in the United States since 1850. Responses by Asian Americans to both opportunities and discrimination.

name: The History of Urban America
description: (Also offered as URBN 2541.) The development of Urban America with emphasis on social, political, physical, and environmental change in the industrial city.

name: The History of Urban America
description: (Also offered as URBN 2541 W.) The development of Urban America with emphasis on social, political, physical, and environmental change in the industrial city.

name: Crime, Policing, and Punishment in the United States
description: (Also offered as AMST 2550.) A survey of political, legal, and cultural development of the American criminal justice system and its social impact from the early republic to the present. Formerly offered as AMST/HIST 2810. CA 1.

name: American Indian History
description: Surveys American Indian History in what is now the United States from precolumbian times up to the present. Cultural diversity among Indian peoples the effects of European contact, tribal sovereignty, and other current issues. CA 4.

name: Cuba in Local and Global Perspective
description: (Also offered as AFRA 2621, LLAS 2621.) Major themes in Cuban politics and culture. Local and global perspective. Key topics include race, gender, class, cultural movements and practices, slavery, political economy and movements, nationalism. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: History of Gender and Sexuality in Latin America and the Caribbean
description: (Also offered as LLAS 2622, WGSS 2622, AFRA 2622.) Topics may include: empire and colonialism/anti-colonialism; slavery, science, and the state; cultural practices and institutions; feminisms and masculinities; law and public policies; immigration; forms of labor and political mobilization; sex and reproduction; and human rights from historical perspective. Formerly offered as AFRA/HIST/LLAS/WGSS 3622.

name: Role Playing History: The Mexican Revolution
description: (Also offered as LLAS 2630.) Students study the early history of Mexico as preparation for immersive role-playing its Revolution. Students recreate interactions among figures of the nation’s civil war, and then apply lessons of imaginative dialogue to a historical assessment of the war and its aftermath.

name: History of Urban Latin America
description: (Also offered as URBN 2650.) The development of Latin American cities with emphasis on social, political, physical and environmental change, from Spanish conquest to present. CA 1.

name: Africa in Global History
description: (Also offered as AFRA 2752.) Broad historical survey of civilizations in Africa, including origins of human life in Africa, economic livelihoods, socio-economic and political structures, state formation, trade, commerce, urbanization, and indigenous systems of belief and world religions. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: History of Modern Africa
description: (Also offered as AFRA 2753.) The history of African perceptions of and responses to the abolition of the slave trade, Western imperialism and colonialism, and the development of nationalism and struggle for independence. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Early Modern India: From Muslim Rulers to British Raj
description: (Also offered as AAAS 2811.) History of India from the 1200s to the 1800s, including the rise and fall of the Muslim-dominated Mughal Empire and the advent of British colonialism. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Modern India
description: (Also offered as AAAS 2812.) History of India from the 1800s to the contemporary era, including colonialism under the British crown, the movement for independence, economic development, and ethnic and religious conflict. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Early Modern China: From Mongols to Manchus
description: (Also offered as AAAS 2821.) Survey of Chinese history from 1200 to 1800. Topics include economic growth, imperial expansion, ethnic diversity, relations with foreign countries, intellectual currents, and state-society relations. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Modern China
description: (Also offered as AAAS 2822.) Survey of patterns of modern China since 1800. Topics will include reforms and revolutions, industrialization and urbanization, and family and population growth. CA 1. CA 4-INT. Formerly offered as AAAS/HIST 3822.

name: Modern Japan
description: Examines the dawn of the modern era to the present day in a place we call Japan. In each of our readings, we will seek to understand what constitutes, as one scholar put it, "history versus the radiant myth of belonging."

name: Empire and Nation in Southeast Asia
description: (Also offered as AAAS 2841.) Major themes in modern Southeast Asian history from the 17th century to the present: growth of global commerce; western imperialism; nationalism; emergence of independent nation-states; challenges of the post-independence period. Emphasis on the region's largest countries: Burma, Cambodia, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: History of Vietnam
description: (Also offered as AAAS 2842.) Introduction to the history of the Vietnamese from the late Bronze Age to the present: the ancient culture of the Red River delta, the millennium of Chinese rule, the independent kingdom of Dai Viet and its successors, French colonialism, the Vietnam War, and postwar Vietnam. Formerly offered as AAAS/HIST 3842.

name: China and the West
description: (Also offered as AAAS 2866.) Survey of China's political and cultural encounters with the West from the sixteenth-century to 1949. Situates these encounters within the context of world history and a dialogue among civilizations. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Foreign Relations of China Since 1949
description: (Also offered as AAAS 2868.) A survey of China's foreign policy from the Cold War to the present, including its domestic politics, Communist ideology, economic reforms, and changing role in global affairs. Formerly offered as AAAS/HIST 2688. CA 1.

name: Foreign Relations of China Since 1949
description: (Also offered as AAAS 2868 W.) A survey of China's foreign policy from the Cold War to the present, including its domestic politics, Communist ideology, economic reforms, and changing role in global affairs. Formerly offered as AAAS/HIST 2688W. CA 1.

name: Foreign Study
description: Consent of department head required, normally granted before the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of advisor.

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section.

name: Variable Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section.

name: Topics in Public History
description: Introduction to the field of public history; in-depth study and practice of one selected topic in public history, such as exhibit design, oral history, institutional history, or archive management.

name: Collaborating with Cultural Organizations I: Methods
description: (Also offered as DMD 3610.) Introduction to mission-driven cultural organizations and methods for meaningful, effective collaboration with them and their communities in the digital age.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: DMD 2010 and/or DMD 2610.

name: Collaborating with Cultural Organizations II: Practice
description: (Also offered as DMD 3620.) Project-based application of digital public history tools and methods undertaken in partnership with a cultural organization. Provides immersion in issues of contemporary practice while building collaborative competency. Includes an integrated service learning component.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: DMD 3610/ HIST 3103.

name: Historical Fiction in Games and Film
description: (Also offered as DMD 3589.) Critique of historically themed films and video games; comparison to surviving primary documents and artifacts; assessment of historical accuracy and cultural impact.
requirements: pen to Digital Media and Design and History majors only, others with instructor consent; open to sophomores or higher.

name: The History of Human Rights
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3201.) Case studies in the emergence and evolution of human rights as experience and  concept.

name: International Human Rights
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3202.) Historical and theoretical survey of the evolution of human rights since 1945.

name: History of the Family
description: (Also offered as HDFS 3423.) Pre-industrial and industrial family life in Western society since the Middle Ages, with emphasis on the changes in demography, family size and structure, family economy, social expectations, sex roles, sexuality, and affective bonds.

name: Black Experience in the Americas
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3206.)
