requirements: pen to Digital Media Design majors and Human Rights majors or minors only; open to juniors or higher; instructor consent required. Recommended preparation: DMD 2200,2210, or HRTS 3149 W.

name: Human Rights Archives II: Visual Storytelling Practices
description: (Also offered as DMD 3641.) The use of human rights archival materials in documentary storytelling. Students will be trained in different documentary techniques and storytelling approaches working with oral history narratives and archival materials. This is the second part of a two-semester unit addressing a common theme. Part I is not a prerequisite for Part II.
requirements: pen to Digital Media Design majors and Human Rights majors or minors only; open to juniors or higher; instructor consent required. Recommended preparation: DMD 2200,2210,3640, or HRTS 3149 W.

name: Constitutional Rights and Liberties
description: (Also offered as POLS 3807, AMST 3807.) The role of the Supreme Court in interpreting the Bill of Rights. Topics include freedoms of speech and religion, criminal due process, and equal protection.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Social Documentary in Theory and Practice
description: (Also offered as DMD 3828.) The study of the evolution of the documentary genre and its potential use as a vehicle for social discourse and change. Through sustained engagement with the documentary genre, students will gain direct experience in shooting and editing short form documentary films.
requirements: pen to Digital Media Design majors and Human Rights majors or minors only; open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: DMD 2210,2810,3820, or HRTS 3149 W.

name: Genocide and Mass Killings in Asia
description: (Also offered as AAAS 3846, HIST 3846.) Case studies of historical and/or contemporary genocide and mass killings in Asia. May focus on any time period and any part of the continent. CA4-INT.

name: Genocide and Mass Killings in Asia
description: (Also offered as AAAS 3846 W, HIST 3846 W.) Case studies of historical and/or contemporary genocide and mass killings in Asia. May focus on any time period and any part of the continent. CA4-INT.

name: Service Learning Seminar/Internship
description: Combination of supervised fieldwork within the larger human rights community with regular classroom meetings for reflection/analysis on the application of human rights concepts and practices. Students must secure a satisfactory intern position before the end of the second week of the semester of enrollment in this course; students should be in consultation with the instructor several months in advance.
requirements: nstructor consent; nine credits of 2000-level or above HRTS courses (six of which may be taken concurrently).

name: Senior Thesis
description: Research and writing of major project exploring a topic with human rights, with close supervision and production of multiple written drafts.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May be taken for a maximum of 15 credits. Consent of Coordinator of India Studies required prior to departure.

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Independent Study
description: Supervised reading and writing on a subject of special interest to the student.

name: Indian Art and Popular Culture: Independence to the Present
description: (Also offered as ART 3375, AAAS 3375.) An interdisciplinary lecture/studio art course introducing diverse forms of Indian Art from the traditional through the contemporary. Students complete either research or studio art assignments responding to the course content. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Senior Thesis
description: Research and writing of a thesis.

name: Industrial Design: Materials and Techniques
description: (Also offered as ART 3701.) Introduction to a variety of processes used in prototyping, and fabrication for Industrial design. Coursework and instruction will focus on the development of skills required to design and engineer physical renderings of concepts with consideration for materials, methods and techniques, and sequence of operations.

name: Industrial Design: Form, Structure, and Space
description: (Also offered as ART 3705.) Introduces spatial visualization through hands-on exercises that explore the dynamics of form, structure and space. Topics progress from elements of design to explorations of scale and formal and functional relationships. Coursework includes basic construction techniques with hand tools and emphasizes sensitivity to materials and appreciation for craft.
requirements: ART 1010 or ART 1030; or DMD 1001 and DMD 1102; or ENGR 1166; others by Instructor consent.

name: Industrial Design: Drawing and Modeling for Design
description: (Also offered as ART 3710.) This course investigates drawing as a practice of exploration, ideation and visual communication essential to the industrial design process. Techniques include basic freehand perspective drawing, sketching for concept development, mechanical drafting, and digital modeling and rendering methods used to represent three-dimensional objects and environments in space.
requirements: 000 level course(s) in the major: ART 1010 or1030; or DMD 1001 and1102; or ENGR 1166; others by Instructor consent.

name: Industrial Design: Process and Practice
description: (Also offered as ART 3720.) Introduction to industrial design processes including research methods, ideation, form generation and visual communication, with a focus on the development of sustainable design practices. Coursework emphasizes strategies for creating products, environments and systems in the context of real-world challenges.
requirements: ART 3705 and3710, others by instructor consent.

name: Industrial Design: Digital Fabrication
description: (Also offered as ART 3730.) Introduces students to established and emerging technologies in the context of art and design practice, to expand their technical and creative capacities. Students will study and train on current industry standard software programs as well as learn to design for and with additive and subtractive manufacturing methods utilized extensively in the fields of art, design, and engineering. Enrollment is capped at 10 students per class, per semester to ensure adequate space for individual coursework, and manage workflow within the classroom based on current technology and equipment capabilities of the department.
requirements: 000 level course(s) in the major: ART 1010 or1030; DMD 1001 and1102; ENGR 1166; others by instructor consent. Recommended preparation: basic proficiency in Illustrator, CAD, or similar computer modeling programs.

name: Packaging Design and Graphics
description: (Also offered as ART 3750.) Packaging design principles are introduced: protection, containment and communication. Work with existing nets and creation of new nets for innovative solutions. Working with primary, secondary and tertiary packages and CAD mold making for densely packed products. General manufacturing processes, use of graphics, brand recognition.
requirements: nstructor consent; open to Art majors and Multidisciplinary Engineering with the specialization in Industrial Design.

name: Special Topics
description: Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: International Study
description: Course work undertaken within approved Study Abroad programs.

name: Independent Study
requirements: pen to First-Year or Sophomore students only.

name: Introduction to Diversity Studies in American Culture
description: An interdisciplinary introduction to comparative multicultural studies in the United States. Topics may include: African American, Asian American, Latino/a, and Native American cultures; gender, feminism, religious and sexual identities; and disability studies. CA 4.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Seminar in Urban Problems
description: Discussions based upon assigned readings and led by faculty and invited speakers from outside and within the University. CA 4.
requirements: ust be taken concurrently with INTD 3590 and3594; open to juniors or higher.

name: Urban Field Studies
description: Field experience supervised by the director and an examining committee consisting of the director and two or more faculty members from two departments in the College of Liberal Arts and Sciences.
requirements: ust be taken concurrently with INTD 3584 and3594; open to juniors or higher.

name: Urban Semester Field Work Seminar
description: Students make analytic presentations of their field experiences, relating these to the pertinent available literature. Particular issues are discussed with experts invited from inside and outside the University.
requirements: ust be taken concurrently with INTD 3590 and3584; open to juniors or higher.

name: Urban Semester Field Work Seminar
description: Students make analytic presentations of their field experiences, relating these to the pertinent available literature. Particular urban problems are discussed with invited experts from outside the University.
requirements: INTD 3590 and3584, which must be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Special Topics
description: Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: International Study
description: Course work undertaken within approved Study Abroad programs.

name: Elementary Irish I
description: Development of ability to communicate in Irish, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic communicative needs within a cultural setting.
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing IRIS 1002,1003, or 1004.

name: Elementary Irish II
description: Development of ability to communicate in Irish, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic communicative needs within a cultural setting.
requirements: IRIS 1001 or one year of Irish in high school. May not be taken out of sequence after passing IRIS 1003 or1004.

name: Intermediate Irish I
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Irish-speaking world.
requirements: IRIS 1002 or two years of Irish in high school. May not be taken out of sequence after passing IRIS 1004.

name: Intermediate Irish II
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Irish-speaking world.
requirements: IRIS 1003 or three years of Irish in high school.

name: Elementary Italian I
description: Elementary Italian grammar. Practice of oral skills through pronunciation and easy conversation. Reading of simple texts and exposure to Italian media and culture.
requirements: ot open for credit to students with three or more years of h.s. Italian. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ILCS 1002,1003, or 1004 or after passing any 2000-level or above course taught in Italian.

name: Elementary Italian II
description: More elements of grammar and culture with integrated readings. Further practice in conversation and exposure to culture though simple examples from media, politics, and art.
requirements: ILCS 1001 or equivalent. Not open for credit to students with three or more years of high school Italian. Students with questions about placement should contact the head of the Department of Literatures, Cultures and Languages.

name: Intermediate Italian I
description: Intensive oral-aural practice based on selected readings and exposure to a wide range of contemporary cultural themes through materials such as newspaper articles, advertising material, and videos. Emphasis on more complex grammatical structures and vocabulary.
requirements: ILCS 1002 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing ILCS 1004. May not be taken for credit after passing any 2000-level or above course taught in Italian, or three or more years of high school Italian. Students with questions about placement should contact the head of the Department of Literatures, Cultures and Languages.

name: Intermediate Italian II
description: Intensive oral-aural practice. Practice in speaking through a combination of group-based and individual activities, focusing on grammatical structures, language functions, and vocabulary. Further exposure to a wide range of contemporary cultural themes through materials such as newspaper articles, advertising material, and videos.
requirements: ILCS 1003 or equivalent. May not be taken for credit after passing any 2000-level or above course taught in Italian. Students with questions about placement should contact the head of the Department of Literatures, Cultures and Languages.

name: The Italian Renaissance
description: A survey of Italian Renaissance civilization, with emphasis on literature and intellectual life. Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. A knowledge of Italian in not required. CA 1.

name: From Baghdad to Florence: Medieval Short Stories Across Cultures
description: An introduction to short stories and frame tale collections as part of a cross-cultural genre of storytelling that flourished during the European medieval era, rooted in different traditions and languages from Asia and the Mediterranean to Europe and the Atlantic world. Students will engage with short stories by rewriting and adapting them to different media. Taught in English. CA1. CA4-INT.

name: Cinema and Society in Contemporary Italy
description: A critical analysis of contemporary Italian society seen through the media of film and literature.  Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. Films in Italian with English subtitles. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Italian American Experience in Literature and Film
description: Focuses on the Italian American experience as represented in a variety of fields, including literature and cinema. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Culture of Fascist Italy
description: The way Italian literary and cinematic culture justified, survived, and fought the terrors of the Fascist totalitarian regime.  Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Italian Literature into Film
description: Survey of literary genres adapted into film in an Italian context. Theories of adaptation. Strategies of cinematic adaptation taking into account the relationship between written and visual languages, and the ways foundational texts can speak to modern audiences or contemporary texts can be written cinematically. Culminates in the development of an original model for adaptation drawing upon student-lived experience. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Introducing Italy through Its Regions
description: The diverse culture of Italy, studied through analysis of sociological,  literary, artistic, and cinematic works from and about a single one of the different Italian regions and that region's cultural centers, such as Rome, Naples, Florence, Palermo, or Venice. Taught in English. May not be used to meet the foreign language requirement. CA 1.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Department Head required, normally before the student's departure.

name: Italy Today
description: A survey of contemporary Italian political, social, economic and cultural life.
requirements: ILCS 1004.

name: Italian Composition and Conversation I
description: Practice in written and oral composition. Syntax study.
requirements: ILCS 1004.

name: Italian Composition and Conversation II
description: Further practice in written and oral composition. Treatment of the finer points in syntax.
requirements: ILCS 3239 or equivalent.

name: Italian Literature and the City
description: Survey of Italian Literature through the changing images of Italian cities.
requirements: ILCS 1004.

name: Italian Women Writers
description: Survey of Italy's women writers from the early modern period to the present. Developments of Italian feminism and gender issues.
requirements: ILCS 1004.

name: Jewish Literature and Film in 20th Century Italy
description: Italy's literary and cinematic representations of Jews in the 20th Century. Jewish identity under Fascism, during World War II, and beyond. Taught in Italian.
requirements: ILCS 1004.

name: The Italian Novella
description: Survey of the novella from the Middle Ages to the 20th century. The course explores the cross-cultural origins of the genre and the influence of the Italian novella on other European literary traditions. Taught in English (Italian readings optional). CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Machiavelli, Michelangelo and Renaissance Literature
description: Selected readings from the works of Poliziano, Leonardo da Vinci, Lorenzo de'Medici, Michelangelo, Ariosto, Machiavelli, Castiglione, Tasso, and others.
requirements: ILCS 3237 or3239or 3243 or equivalent.

name: Dante and His Time
description: Selected readings from Dante, Petrarch, Compagni, Villani.
requirements: ILCS 3237 or3239or 3243 or equivalent.

name: Boccaccio and His Time
description: Readings from Boccaccio and others with special attention to the problems of social and sexual ethics.
requirements: ILCS 3237 or3239or 3243 or equivalent.

name: Dante's Divine Comedy in English Translation
description: Dante's poem as a unique synthesis of Medieval culture. Emphasizes its integration of ethics, political thought, and theology with poetic imagination. Taught in English. CA 1.

name: The Literature of the Italian Renaissance
description: A survey, in English, of the major literary and philosophical currents of the Italian Renaissance. Selections from Boccaccio, Petrarch, Pico della Mirandola, Machiavelli, Castiglione, and others. Taught in English.
requirements: ot open to students who have passed ILCS 3251 or 3252.

name: Cinematic Representations of Italian Americans
description: Cinematic representations of Italian Americans in the works of major directors from the silent era to the present. Construction of and attempts to dislodge negative stereotypes of Italian American male and female immigrants. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Topics in Italian Cinema
description: Major topics in modern and contemporary Italian cinema. Taught in Italian.
requirements: ILCS 1004.

name: Italian Cinema
description: Italian cinema from the silent era to the present. Its genres, such as epic film, melodrama, comedy "Italian-style," "Spaghetti-Westerns," and political cinema. Cinema as a reflection on and comment upon the social and political contexts of Italian history from pre-fascist Italy to modernization and beyond. Taught in English. Films in Italian with English subtitles. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Twentieth-Century Italian Literature
description: Major trends in twentieth-century Italian Literature from the early modern period to contemporary times.
requirements: ecommended preparation: ILCS 3237 or3239or3240.

name: Nineteenth-Century Italian Literature
description: Nineteenth-century Italian drama, poetry, and narrative from the Napoleonic period to the years immediately following the conquest of Rome in 1870.
requirements: ecommended Preparation: ILCS 3237 or3239or3240or 3243 or instructor consent.

name: Views of the Environment from Italy
description: Application of current perspectives of ecocriticism to analysis of Italian literature and films that have recorded and imagined the relationship between human and non-human life. Articulation and appraisal of the student's personal relationship to the environment through writing and reflection. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Italian Internship
description: Supervised experience in a work setting using Italian linguistic skills and cultural competencies. Context may include a specific trade or industry, business, medical or clinical setting, public agency, community-based organization, or research collaboration. May be taken in the context of a study abroad program. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: LCS 1147 or approval from instructor of record; instructor consent required.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign language program. Consent of Department Head required, normally granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: Special Topics
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program.
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Variable Topics
description: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Capstone in Italian Studies
description: Advanced language practicum and integration of studies in Italian Literature and Culture.
requirements: ILCS 1004.

name: Elementary Japanese I
description: Introduction to elementary Japanese emphasizing speaking, understanding, reading and writing through a communicative approach.
requirements: pen only to students with no prior contact with the language. May not be taken out of sequence after passing JAPN 1102,1103, or 1104.

name: Elementary Japanese II
description: Further instruction in elementary Japanese emphasizing speaking, understanding, reading and writing skills using a communicative approach involving simple examples from contemporary media and culture.
requirements: JAPN 1101 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing JAPN 1103 or1104.

name: Intermediate Japanese I
description: Increasing communicative abilities in Japanese using more examples from contemporary Japanese media and culture.
requirements: JAPN 1102 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing JAPN 1104.

name: Intermediate Japanese II
description: Increasing communicative abilities in Japanese with stronger emphasis on vocabulary and grammar using examples from contemporary Japanese media, politics, and culture.
requirements: JAPN 1103 or equivalent.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Credits and hours by arrangement. Consent of Department Head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure.

name: Modern Japanese Literature
description: (Also offered as AAAS 2305, ENGL 2305.) Japanese literature across genres from 1868 to the present, studied in English translation. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Special Topics
description: Prerequisites, required preparation, recommended preparation vary.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Independent Study
description: Credits and hours by arrangement. Open only with consent of Director.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: The Press in America
description: The development of American print journalism from 18th century print shops to 21st century corporations; how journalists and their work have evolved and influenced American life. CA 1.
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing JOUR 3002.

name: Introduction to Sports Journalism
description: Exploration of the history of sports reporting, the growth of sports media, the cultural influence of sports coverage, and the fundamentals of sports journalism, including sourcing, interviewing and the production of sports stories on varied platforms.
requirements: annot be take for credit after passing JOUR 1095 when offered as “Introduction to Sports Journalism.”

name: Special Topics
description: An introductory exploration of a specialized area of journalism.
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: News Literacy for the Digital Age
description: Better scrutinize what you see, hear, read, watch and share. Recognize the differences between fact and rumor, news and advertising, news and opinion, bias and fairness. Discover why people get duped by misinformation and how it can spread and become entrenched. Practice journalistic methods of fact checking, investigation, and verification.

name: Newswriting I
description: Defining news; exercising news judgment in a diverse society; employing principles of Associated Press style; writing basic news stories. Laboratory offers intensive newswriting exercises.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Cannot be taken out of sequence after passing JOUR 2001,3005,3030,3040,3045or4091.

name: Newswriting II
description: Live reporting using the university and the surrounding community as a laboratory. Emphasis on fact gathering, interviewing, diversity of sources, news judgment and deadline writing.
requirements: JOUR 2000 W; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Cannot be taken out of sequence after passing JOUR 3000,3012, 3013, 3033 or4091.

name: Literary Journalism
description: Exploration of the relationship between narrative nonfiction journalism and literature. Practice of literary journalism techniques of famous and forgotten writers, incorporating observation, research, and evaluation. Critical survey of diverse literary journalism examples from the 1850s through the present.

name: Journalism in the Movies
description: Viewing and analysis of motion pictures featuring journalistic themes; journalistic history, ethics, legal issues, contrasting forms of media, and other issues. CA 1.

name: Fundamentals of News Programming
description: Exploration of the practical steps required to build a professional newscast for TV, radio, or digital distribution.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: JOUR 1002 and/or JOUR 2000 W. Not open for credit to students who have passed JOUR 2095 when offered as TV and Video News Programming.

name: Mobile Journalism
description: Entry-level multimedia skills course that develops aesthetic and technical skills for storytelling using mobile devices such as smartphones. Capturing and editing photos, audio, and video; practice producing journalistic content for social media platforms.
requirements: ecommended preparation: JOUR 1002 and2000W, which may be taken concurrently.

name: Special Topics
description: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher. Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Global Press Freedom: Journalism, Human Rights, and Democracy
description: (Also offered as HRTS 2110.) Examination of the complex relationship between freedom of the press and the broader exercise of civil liberties and human rights internationally and in the United States. Understanding of the critical importance of a free press in the functioning of democracy and distinguishing between responsible, fact-based reporting and the falsehoods that sustain authoritarian regimes and aspiring authoritarians. Analysis of the various components that go into the gathering and dissemination of news while engaging in critical thinking about the vulnerability of the press to coercion, the power structures that limit and enable freedom of expression, and the potential for journalism to expose injustice among marginalized and traditionally exploited populations.

name: Journalism Portfolio I: Multimedia Skills
description: Introduction to online and multimedia skills used by journalists; emphasis on ethical practices. Students provided portfolio space on a department-maintained site.
requirements: JOUR 2000 W. Open to Journalism majors, others with permission.

name: The Art of the Interview in Documentary Filmmaking
description: Exploration of the technical and ethical practices of preparing for and conducting filmed interviews. Development of essential skills for documentary film production and engagement in exercises that deepen understanding of how recorded interviews drive narratives forward.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: JOUR 2000 W,2111. Not open for credit to students who have passed JOUR 2095 when offered as Art of Interview in Documentary Filmmaking.

name: Community News Reporting
description: In-depth reporting across platforms on local and state issues and events, including government, politics, schools, public safety, and a diverse base of community organizations and groups.
requirements: JOUR 2001 W.

name: Community News Reporting
description: In-depth reporting across platforms on local and state issues and events, including government, politics, schools, public safety, and a diverse base of community organizations and groups.
requirements: JOUR 2001 W; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Journalism Ethics
description: Discussion of such contemporary problems as privacy, good taste, community standards, effectiveness of the press and responsibility of the press.
requirements: JOUR 1002. May not be taken out of sequence after passing JOUR 4091.

name: Online Journalism
description: Application of newswriting techniques to online journalism including assembling and producing interactive news stories.
requirements: JOUR 2000 W.

name: Feature Writing
description: Writing and reporting human-interest stories, personality profiles, and other features; developing skills for nonfiction storytelling with scenes, dialogue, and descriptive narrative.
requirements: JOUR 2001 W; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Sports Reporting Across Multiple Platforms
description: Evaluate some of the best sports journalism of the past and present, report and write a variety of sports stories, cover UConn sports, produce sports packages for broadcast and digital platforms, meet working sports journalists.
requirements: JOUR 2000 W. Recommended preparation: JOUR 2111.

name: Media Law
description: The First Amendment, free speech, free press and prior restraint; issues in news gathering, recording, photography, investigative reporting and covering courts; tort law including defamation, privacy, emotional distress; intellectual property and internet regulation.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Multiplatform Editing
description: News value; information verification; editing for grammar, spelling, punctuation and style; headline writing; search engine optimization; handling visuals; building basic data visualizations; basic layout and design for print and digital platforms; aggregation; interactive news story production; audience engagement and social media.
requirements: JOUR 2000 W. Recommended preparation: JOUR 2001 W.

name: Design for Digital Journalists
description: The fundamentals of visual communication design as applied to modern media. Topics include design principles, aesthetics, social media, intuitive design, typography, layout, photo editing, color theory, motion graphics, and informational graphics.
requirements: JOUR 3030.

name: Podcasting
description: Researching, recording, writing and producing news podcasts and associated web and social media posts. Ethical considerations.
requirements: JOUR 2000 W. Not open for credit to students who have passed JOUR 3095 when offered as Introduction to Podcasting.

name: Newswriting for Broadcast and Digital Media
description: Application of newswriting and news reporting techniques for broadcast, digital video and digital audio. Practical use of digital media recording equipment and professional audio/video editing software.
requirements: JOUR 2000 W.

name: Reporting and Editing TV News
description: This is an advanced broadcast journalism class that teaches students how to gather, edit and deliver accurate, newsworthy information for television newscasts. Students develop the skills needed to report  news and organize newscasts through actual experience in and out of class.
requirements: JOUR 3040.

name: Live News Program Production
description: Assemble a video newscast in a team-oriented, deadline-driven broadcast studio environment. Rotate through a variety of newsroom jobs including writer, producer, anchor, reporter, graphics creator and videographer. Write scripts, edit video and develop on-air presentation skills.
requirements: JOUR 3041. Not open for credit to students who have passed JOUR 4091 when offered as Live News Program Production.

name: Specialized Journalism
description: An introduction to specialized fields such as business, science, education, arts, sports, and entertainment reporting. Students will examine some of the best work in the fields and will consider ethical issues and other problems.
requirements: JOUR 2000 W.

name: Environmental Journalism
description: Explores specialized coverage of environmental issues by journalists, emphasizing news reporting with the opportunity to produce print, visual and multimedia news reports.
requirements: JOUR 2000 Wor consent of the instructor. Open to Juniors or higher.

name: Professional Seminar
description: Journalists discuss the economic, technological, sociological and ethical issues that challenge their profession.
requirements: JOUR 2000 W, which may be taken concurrently.

name: Visual Journalism
description: Examines current trends in visual digital journalism; develops skills in photojournalism, multimedia production and video storytelling. Professional-grade camera equipment available for students to borrow for course activities.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing JOUR 4065. Recommended preparation: JOUR 2000 Wand JOUR 2065.

name: Honors Thesis Preparation Seminar
description: Honors students choose topics for their theses or projects, develop research proposals and apply for funding if needed. Students work as a community of scholars to discuss and support each other's work. Usually taken the semester before JOUR 3097, Honors Thesis.
requirements: OUR 2000, JOUR 2001 and at least three other journalism credits at the 2000-level or above.

name: Foreign Study
description: May be repeated for credit with permission of Department Head. Consent of Department Head required before the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.

name: Honors Thesis
description: Students in the Honors Program undertake in-depth research and writing under the guidance of a faculty member. Majors must consult with the departmental Honors Advisor and develop a research proposal in the semester before taking the course.
requirements: JOUR 2000 Wand2001W; six additional 2000 level or above credits of JOUR.

name: Variable Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.

name: Journalism Portfolio II: Content Development
description: Development of online and multimedia skills used by journalists; emphasis on ethical practices. Students will contribute journalism content completed in other courses and develop new content to build a professional portfolio provided on a department-maintained site.
requirements: JOUR 2111 or JOUR 2065. Corequisite: JOUR 2065. Recommended preparation: JOUR 2000 Wand JOUR 2001 W.

name: Black Documentary Film Archival Practices
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3575.) Critical and historical examination of Black American archival usage through documentary films and media.
requirements: tudents must have taken a film or media course where they learned how to edit.

name: Publication Practice
description: Students and faculty work together to research, write, edit and produce a publication.

name: Investigative Reporting
description: Using the Internet, databases, and other computer resources to research and report on the actions of courts, businesses, public agencies, and governments. Consideration of ethical questions.
requirements: JOUR 2001 W.

name: Video Storytelling
description: Explores journalistic storytelling techniques through video. Students will learn how to gather video and audio content and develop production and post-production techniques to create and publish extended narrative multimedia projects.
requirements: ecommended preparation: JOUR 2065 and3065; students interested in this course should have prior experience with video storytelling.

name: Supervised Field Internship
description: Students research, report and write for newspapers, news departments of radio and television stations, and online publications under supervision of professionals.

name: Independent Study
description: Open to qualified students who present suitable projects for independent work in journalism.

name: Journalism Portfolio III: Professional Presentation
description: Completion of student journalism portfolios that include examples of journalistic endeavors in print, still and video photography, audio and multimedia packages.
requirements: JOUR 3111.

name: Exercise and Wellness for Everyone
description: Overview of the five pillars of health (exercise, nutrition, sleep, stress and relationships); role of exercise in health promotion and disease prevention across the lifespan; impacts of exercise in leisure time, culture, community, careers and the workplace.

name: Courses in Lifetime Sports Program
description: A variety of lifetime sports and skills are offered. The teaching of each activity will be geared to individual, dual, and team activities. Students who have physical disabilities in the least restrictive environment possible. Participants requiring accommodations should contact the Program Coordinator.
requirements: his course may be repeated with change of activity and/or skill level, not to exceed 3 credits toward graduation of combined AH 1200 and KINS 1160 credits. Students in the Dept. of Kinesiology may count up to 6 different activities for 6 credits.

name: Fundamentals of Exercise Testing
description: Laboratory assessment of health and fitness principles including to resting measurements, functional capacity, anaerobic power and threshold, body composition, lactate threshold, flexibility and functional movement. Emergency procedures and protocols during exercise testing and training are discussed throughout. Participation in conducting and performing fitness tests is required.
requirements: nstructor consent; CPR/AED and First Aid required prior to start of course.

name: Fundamentals of Resistance Training
description: Focuses on skills related to the fundamentals to resistance training including anaerobic ability, muscular strength, muscle endurance, power, and flexibility. Course content is meant to compliment the knowledge and fundamentals around individualized resistance training programs as discussed in KINS 3545 Resistance Training for Health and Performance.
requirements: ecommended preparation: KINS 3545. Not open for credit to students who have passed KINS 1160.

name: Introduction to Athletic Training
description: An introduction to basic principles of the athletic training profession. Content includes history of the athletic training profession, sports medicine team concepts and applications, environmental influences, health assessment screenings, basic injury and illness assessment, management and treatment, protective equipment, strength and conditioning concepts, and health risks related to the physically active. An overview of athletic training professional organizations and the role the athletic trainer plays in the health care system is introduced. Risk factors associated with blood-borne pathogens (BBP) and common diseases that affect the active population are investigated. Concepts of universal precautions and BBP training will also be provided.

name: Exercise Prescription
description: Addresses the Frequency, Intensity, Time, and Type or FITT principle of exercise prescription for apparently healthy adults; healthy populations with special considerations such as children, older adults, and women who are pregnant; and special populations with chronic disease and health conditions such as overweight and obesity, and cardiovascular, pulmonary, metabolic, and musculoskeletal disease. CA 3.
requirements: ecommended preparation: KINS 1100.

name: Internship
description: Field service or experiences in cooperating agencies.
requirements: tudents must complete all concentration requirements excluding Athletic Training prior to taking an internship. Open to Kinesiology majors.

name: Independent Study for Undergraduates
description: Laboratory or library research to expand understanding of a specialized topic in sport, leisure, or exercise sciences.
requirements: ust be of senior standing.

name: Independent Study for Undergraduates
description: Laboratory or library research to expand understanding of a specialized topic in sport, leisure, or exercise sciences.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open only to seniors with consent of the Department Head.

name: Field Experiences in Rehabilitation, Health Care, and Sport
description: For students interested in a career in healthcare (physical therapy, athletic training or related field) and/or sport a chance to engage in observation opportunities within the various clinical settings of healthcare, sports medicine, and/or sport performance. Inter-professional discussion with topics related to professional development, transition to practice, job readiness, interviewing, job negotiations, and effective communication in the workforce.
requirements: nstructor consent. Recommended preparation: KINS 1160, CPR/First Aid.

name: Mental Health in Sport
description: Examines the impact that sport performance can have on the athlete’s mind and body as they devote time, energy, and effort into developing their skills in their given sport. Student-athletes navigate unique stressors and can be at greater risk to experience a negative impact on their mental health and well-being. Topics to be covered may include athlete identity, personality disorders, disordered eating, substance abuse, body dysmorphia, depression, suicide ideation, anxiety, as well as mental health resources for athletes and care providers.
requirements: PSYC 1100.

name: Exercise Psychology
description: The psychological components associated with exercise and sport performance. Specifically, how the psychosocial aspects (e.g., group cohesion, motivation, leadership, team vs. individual sport) and health related aspects (e.g., exercise behavior and adherence, burnout/overtraining, and injury) of sport and exercise relate.

name: Biomechanics of Injury and Sport
description: Introduction to biomechanics related to injury and sport. Explores both the statics and dynamics of motion including kinetics and kinematics. Examines biomechanical issues of human movement related to exercise/sport and injury and the biomechanics of different body tissues. Uses examples from research and mass media to complement the teaching materials in the course.
requirements: PNB 2264 and2265.

name: Aerobic Training for Health and Performance
description: Focuses on the knowledge, skills, and understanding of the scientific principles on which to design individualized aerobic training programs needed for optimal performance, health improvement, disease treatment, and injury prevention. Presents analysis techniques of human physiology specific to aerobic training and performing. Laboratory and field methods to evaluate aerobic ability, lactate threshold, economy, anthropometrics, and aerobic performance characteristics will be discussed.
requirements: KINS 4500; open only to students in Kinesiology programs, others by consent of instructor.

name: Scientific Writing in Aerobic Training for Health and Performance
description: A writing intensive class integrated with course content in KINS 3530.
requirements: KINS 4500; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open only to students in Kinesiology programs, others by consent of instructor. Corequisite: KINS 3530. Not open for credit to students who have passed KINS 3530W.

name: Resistance Training for Health and Performance
description: Focuses on the knowledge, skills, and understanding of the scientific principles on which to design individualized resistance training programs needed for optimal performance, health improvement, disease treatment, and injury prevention. Presents analysis techniques of human physiology specific to resistance training and performing. Laboratory and field methods to evaluate anaerobic ability, flexibility, muscular strength and power and body composition will be discussed.
requirements: pen only to students in Kinesiology programs; others by consent of instructor. Corequisite: KINS 4500.

name: Scientific Writing in Resistance Training for Health and Performance
description: A writing intensive class integrated with course content in KINS 3545.
requirements: KINS 4500; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open only to students in Kinesiology programs. Corequisite: KINS 3545. Not open for credit to students who have passed KINS 3545W.

name: Exercise Prescription for Clinical Populations
description: Introduction to theories and techniques of exercise prescription for a variety of special populations. Emphasis is placed on pathophysiology, clinical exercise testing, and the acute and chronic effects of exercise on clinical populations. Populations will include cardiovascular, pulmonary, metabolic, and neuromuscular disease among other diseases and chronic conditions. Guidelines to appropriate cardiovascular and resistance training protocols for these and other populations will be discussed in detail.
requirements: KINS 2227. Recommended preparation: Enrollment as an Exercise Science undergraduate student.

name: Introduction to Honors Research
description: The student will meet with KINS faculty members and attend laboratory/program staff meetings to survey the opportunities available for future Honors Thesis research.
requirements: pen only to Honors Students in Kinesiology Programs.

name: Honors Literature Review
description: The student will identify specific Honors Thesis research questions and will write a library research paper that will serve as the thesis Literature Review.
requirements: pen only to Honors Students in Kinesiology Programs.

name: Honors Thesis
description: The student will collect and interpret data and will write the Honors Thesis, completing work begun during KINS 3615.
requirements: NGL 1070 or1010or1011; open only to Honors Students in Kinesiology Programs.

name: Exercise Science Capstone
description: Introduction to the fundamental concepts of research and scientific inquiry as these concepts apply to understanding and evaluating published research. Students will be able to make informed decisions about the relevance of published research to their own practice and research.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; KINS 4500. Not open for credit to students who have passed KINS 4205W.

name: Scientific Writing in Exercise Science
description: A writing intensive course integrated with course content from KINS 4204. Students will prepare a scientific manuscript and present their work in a public presentation.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; KINS 4500. Corequisite: KINS 4204.

name: Exercise Physiology
description: An organ systems approach to optimal human performance including metabolism, energy transfer, nerve transmission, muscle contraction, endocrine control, and cardiopulmonary physiology.
requirements: PNB 2264 and2265.

name: Advanced Topics in Health and Sport Performance
description: Fundamental concepts and physiology in Exercise Science with focus on special topics and conditions that challenge the human exercise response. These include stressful environments, use of ergogenic aids and special diets, exercise in special conditions, and advanced topics associated with fatigue, the immune system and stress/sleep deprivation: incorporating current research in these and other select areas.
requirements: KINS 4500. Open only to students in Kinesiology programs; others by consent of instructor.

name: Scientific Writing in Advanced Topics in Health and Sport Performance
description: A writing intensive course integrated with course content from KINS 4510.
requirements: KINS 4500. Corequisite: KINS 4510. Not open for credit to students who have passed KINS 4510W.

name: Elementary Korean I
description: Development of ability to communicate in Korean, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic communicative needs within a cultural setting.
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing KORE 1102,1103, or 1104.

name: Elementary Korean II
description: Development of ability to communicate in Korean, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic communicative needs within a cultural setting.
requirements: KORE 1101 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing KORE 1103 or1104.

name: Intermediate Korean I
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Korean within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Korean-speaking world.
requirements: KORE 1102 or equivalent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing KORE 1104.

name: Intermediate Korean II
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Korean within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Korean-speaking world.
requirements: KORE 1103 or equivalent.

name: Special Topics
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Independent Study
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: How Design Shapes Our World
description: (Also offered as ART 1005, DMD 1005.) An engaging exploration into the fundamentals of design. Students will learn how design is part of our everyday life. Designing is a flexible and iterative process that thrives on communication and collaboration. Emphasizing a broad and scalable purpose, the course will illustrate how design can be applied and adapted to different contexts and media.

name: Landscape Architecture: Graphics I - Design Drawing
description: Knowledge and theory of graphic representation, exploration and development of design form. Introduction to basic design principles. Application of graphic and design theory through free-hand drawing in a studio environment. Abstraction and transformation of form emphasized.

name: Landscape Architecture: Graphics II Design Communication
description: Knowledge and theory of visual perception and model making. Application of theory in the creation of various graphic products including plan, section, elevation, paraline and perspective drawings.  Controlled free hand and computer methods in a studio environment.
requirements: LAND 2110; open only to Landscape Architecture majors.

name: The Common (Shared) Landscape of the USA: Rights, Responsibilities and Values
description: An introduction to the study of vernacular landscapes in the USA with an emphasis on the relationship between societal values and land use patterns. CA 1.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: History of Designed Landscapes
description: The development of designed landscapes is followed through time, emphasizing influences on current landscape architecture theory and practice.
requirements: LAND 2210 Eor with instructor consent.

name: Biophilic Cities and Landscapes
description: An introduction to the science and application of biodiversity with an emphasis on urban design strategies to promote biophilic cities and landscapes.

name: Landscape Architecture: Design I - Site Analysis
description: Knowledge and theory of site design and site analysis.  Dimensional requirements and appropriate relationships of site elements and systems. Collection and analysis of site data including legal, physical and cultural factors.  Application in a variety of site design projects. Field trips are required.
requirements: LAND 2110 and2210E; open to Landscape Architecture majors only.

name: Landscape Architecture: Graphics III - Computer Applications
description: Knowledge and theory of computer use in landscape architecture. Computer applications for data gathering, analysis and graphic communication. Application of knowledge and theory to a variety of site planning and design projects.
requirements: LAND 2120; open only to Landscape Architecture majors.

name: Sustainable Environmental Planning and Landscape Design
description: Theories, concepts, and methods for sustainable planning and design of the land to balance and integrate the needs for conservation and development. Literature and case-study based, writing intensive exploration across critical contemporary themes such as climate change, urbanization, health and wellness, and globalization.

name: Landscape Architecture: Construction I - Site Engineering
description: Theory and practice in manipulating landform in landscape architecture.  Earthwork computation, drainage systems, sedimentation and erosion control, roadway design and low-impact design.
requirements: LAND 2120; open only to Landscape Architecture majors.

name: Landscape Architecture: Construction II - Planting Design
description: Knowledge and theory of the role of plants as visual, spatial, ecological, and cultural design elements and systems. Analysis and creation of planting plans that support and develop design concepts and respond to physical site conditions. Application on a variety of project types in a studio environment. Formerly offered as LAND 3330.
requirements: LAND 3310; open only to landscape architecture majors.

name: Landscape Architecture: Construction III - Materials and Methods
description: Knowledge and theory of site construction. Characteristics and installation methods of materials including concrete, masonry, wood and metal.  Application of knowledge and theory through development of construction drawings and related documents for site construction projects. Formerly offered as LAND 3320.
requirements: LAND 3310; open to Landscape Architecture majors.

name: Landscape Architecture: Design II - Space, Form and Meaning
description: Knowledge and theory of spatial form in architecture, landscape architecture and urban design. Application of theory in the creation of 3-dimensional landscape models in a studio environment. Student attitudes about self-expression, environmental issues and social responsibility will be explored.
requirements: LAND 2410; open to Landscape Architecture majors.

name: Landscape Architecture: Design III - Program Development
description: Knowledge and theory of site design and planning with a focus on program analysis and development.  Design of appropriate form and function through precedent study and research on user and client needs, development regulations and site context.  Application of theory to a variety of project types and scales. Field trips required.
requirements: LAND 3420; open to Landscape Architecture majors.

name: Landscape Architecture Internship
description: Provides opportunity for students to gain practical experience, knowledge, and professional skills in a work environment related to landscape architecture. Students work with an instructor and internship supervisor to develop a learning contract for meaningful and educational tasks and experiences and submit written documents at the conclusion of the internship. This course may be repeated provided that the sum total of credits earned does not exceed six credits. Students taking this course will be assigned a grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory). Consent of instructor and department head required.
requirements: nstructor and department head consent.

name: Special Topics in Landscape Architecture
description: Credits, prerequisites, and hours as determined by the Senate Curricula and Course Committee.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: Undergraduate Research in Landscape Architecture
description: Individualized research conducted under the supervision of a faculty instructor. The student is required to submit a final project and/or report at the conclusion of the course. Consent of instructor and department head required.
requirements: nstructor and department head consent.

name: Variable Topics in Landscape Architecture
description: Topics and credits to be published prior to the registration period preceding the semester offerings. May be repeated with a change in content.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: Independent Study in Landscape Architecture
description: Individual academic interests pursued by the student under the supervision of a faculty instructor. Students are expected to submit project-related documents and/or reports. Consent of instructor and department head required.
requirements: nstructor and department head consent.

name: Landscape Architecture: Seminar
description: A lecture and discussion-based course that builds a framework to critically investigate the extended geographies of urban socio-ecological processes. Opportunities are given for students to develop their interests within the discipline of landscape architecture connecting theory and practice to contemporary debates in the field.
requirements: pen to Landscape Architecture majors only; instructor consent required.

name: Landscape Architecture: Professional Practice
description: Business, legal and professional dimensions of landscape architecture. Modes of practice, licensure and ethics, and contract development and administration. Emphasis on portfolio development and licensure preparation.
requirements: LAND 2220; open only to Landscape Architecture majors.

name: Landscape Architecture: Design IV - Community Planning
description: Knowledge and theory of design of large scale landscapes such as open space systems, village and town centers and residential subdivisions. Application of theory to a variety of projects including community outreach work. Field trips are required.
requirements: LAND 3430; open only to landscape architecture majors.

name: Landscape Architecture: Design V - Capstone
description: Knowledge and theory of site planning and design.  Application of theory and skills from previous design courses to a single, comprehensive site planning and design project. Field trips are required.
requirements: LAND 4440; open to Landscape Architecture majors.

name: Introduction to Latina/o Studies
description: Interdisciplinary examination of the Latina/o experience and impact across the United States. Consideration of behavioral, institutional, and societal perspectives; national and transnational identity; cultural, legal, and educational issues. CA 2. CA 4.

name: Latino Literature, Culture, and Society
description: (Also offered as SPAN 1009.) Critical approaches to Latinos/as and cultural representation, production, and agency, as impacted by globalization and local dynamics. Will engage the value and function of  race, gender and sexuality in popular culture, literature, film, music, digital culture, visual arts, and urban culture.  Taught in English. Knowledge of Spanish is not required. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Latino Literature, Culture, and Society
description: (Also offered as SPAN 1009 W.) Critical approaches to Latinos/as and cultural representation, production, and agency, as impacted by globalization and local dynamics. Will engage the value and function of race, gender and sexuality in popular culture, literature, film, music, digital culture, visual arts, and urban culture. Taught in English. Knowledge of Spanish is not required. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Introduction to Latin America and the Caribbean
description: (Also offered as HIST 1600.) Multidisciplinary exploration of the historical development of such aspects of Latin America and the Caribbean as colonization and nation formation; geography and the environment; immigration and migration; race, ethnicity, and gender in society, politics, economy, and culture. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Introduction to Latin America and the Caribbean
description: (Also offered as HIST 1600 W.) Multidisciplinary exploration of the historical development of such aspects of Latin America and the Caribbean as colonization and nation formation; geography and the environment; immigration and migration; race, ethnicity, and gender in society, politics, economy, and culture. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Foreign Study
description: Course work undertaken within approved Study Abroad programs, usually focusing on the history, culture, and society of a particular Latin American or Carribean country or countries. Consent of Director of Latin American and Caribbean Studies required before departure.

name: Migrant Workers in Connecticut
description: (Also offered as HIST 1570.) Interdisciplinary honors course on the life and work experiences of contemporary Latin American and Caribbean migrant workers with focus on Connecticut. Integrated service learning component. Field trips required. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Latin American Histories through Popular Cultures
description: (Also offered as HIST 1630.) A consideration of art and popular culture as vehicles for understanding Latin American history from the late 1800’s to today. Dynamic primary sources such as songs, films, carnival parades or professional soccer matches, television programs, and works of art will serve as case studies that students will analyze, contextualize, and historicize. Each week considers a different time period and focuses on a particular political, economic, or social movement or ideological trend, using a cultural text of the era to understand each.

name: Latin American Histories through Popular Cultures
description: (Also offered as HIST 1630 W.) A consideration of art and popular culture as vehicles for understanding Latin American history from the late 1800’s to today. Dynamic primary sources such as songs, films, carnival parades or professional soccer matches, television programs, and works of art will serve as case studies that students will analyze, contextualize, and historicize. Each week considers a different time period and focuses on a particular political, economic, or social movement or ideological trend, using a cultural text of the era to understand each.

name: Latinos, Leadership and Mentoring
description: Introduces issues affecting Latinos in higher education.   Leadership and mentoring training.  Students analyze responsibilities and commitments in context of leadership for the common good and for purposeful change.

name: Introduction to Latino-American Writing and Research
description: Students refine writing skills and learn how and where to conduct transnational academic research on the Latino-American experience. Interdisciplinary approaches, historical background of Latino American studies. CA 4.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011or instructor consent; open to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: 1000-level introductory course on Latino or Latin American Studies.

name: Latinos in Connecticut: Serving the Community
description: Students partner with Latino agencies to apply research and writing skills to community needs. Community theory, digital literacy, historical background of CT Latinos, contemporary issues that impact the population. Service learning component.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: LLAS 2011 W.

name: Foreign Study
description: Course work undertaken within approved Education Abroad programs, usually focusing on the history, culture, and society of a particular Latin American or Caribbean country or countries.

name: Human Rights in Latin America
description: (Also offered as HRTS 2450.) Fundamental concepts and recurrent challenges of human rights in Latin America.

name: Economic Development in Latin America and the Caribbean
description: (Also offered as ECON 2474.) Survey of the economic history of Latin America and the Caribbean. Analysis of present-day development issues in the region, including economic growth, poverty, education, and health.
requirements: ECON 1200 or both ECON 1201 and1202.

name: New England and the Caribbean Plantation Complex, 1650-1900
description: (Also offered as HIST 2507, MAST 2507.) New England’s role in the creation and expansion of the Caribbean plantation complex. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Cuba in Local and Global Perspective
description: (Also offered as HIST 2621, AFRA 2621.) Major themes in Cuban politics and culture. Local and global perspective. Key topics include race, gender, class, cultural movements and practices, slavery, political economy and movements, nationalism. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: History of Gender and Sexuality in Latin America and the Caribbean
description: (Also offered as HIST 2622, WGSS 2622, AFRA 2622.) Topics may include: empire and colonialism/anti-colonialism; slavery, science, and the state; cultural practices and institutions; feminisms and masculinities; law and public policies; immigration; forms of labor and political mobilization; sex and reproduction; and human rights from historical perspective. Formerly offered as AFRA/HIST/LLAS/WGSS 3622.

name: Role Playing History: The Mexican Revolution
description: (Also offered as HIST 2630.) Students study the early history of Mexico as preparation for immersive role-playing its Revolution. Students recreate interactions among figures of the nation’s civil war, and then apply lessons of imaginative dialogue to a historical assessment of the war and its aftermath.

name: Special Topics in Latino and Latin American Studies
Contemporary Latin America
description: (Also offered as ANTH 3021.) Survey of anthropological contributions to the study of contemporary Mexico, Central America, South America, and the Hispanic Caribbean. Special focus on the comparative analysis of recent ethnographic case studies and local/regional/national/international linkages.

name: The Caribbean
description: (Also offered as ANTH 3029.) Comparative perspectives on the cultural formation of Caribbean societies; the region's demographic, economic and political links with the wider world.

name: Latinx Psychology
description: (Also offered as PSYC 3107.) Empirical and theoretical literature on psychological experiences of Latino Americans. Impact of race, culture, and ethnicity on psychological development.
requirements: PSYC 1100.

name: Making the Black Atlantic
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3208, HIST 3208.) Recent scholarship on the central role played by African-descended communities in shaping the early history of the Americas and their interconnection beyond geopolitical boundaries; race, gender, sexuality, class, religion, cultural movements and practices; slavery, political economy, and political movements.
requirements: ecommended preparation: AFRA/HIST/ HRTS 3563 or AFRA/ HIST 3564 or3620; or HIST/ LLAS 3609.

name: Contemporary Issues in Latino Studies
description: Topics in socio-demographic patterns, cultural identity claims, community organization, migration and citizenship issues of Latino groups in post-WWII United States. Emphasis on comparative analysis and on policy implications. CA 4.

name: Puerto Rican/Latino Studies Research
description: Students design, execute and write original, library or archival-based research on Latino/a experience using documents, films, literary works, surveys, photographic and newspaper materials.

name: History of Latinos/as in the United States
description: (Also offered as HIST 3674.) Settlement and growth of Hispanic-origin populations in the United States today, from Spanish and Mexican settlement of the western United States to the growth of Latino communities. Student oral history project. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Latinos/as and Human Rights
description: (Also offered as HIST 3575, HRTS 3221.) Latino/a issues related to human, civil and cultural rights, and gender differences.

name: Latina Narrative
description: (Also offered as WGSS 3258.) Feminist topics in contemporary Latina literature and cultural studies.

name: Latina/o Literature
description: (Also offered as ENGL 3605.) Extensive readings in Latina/o literature from the late nineteenth century to the present. CA 4.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011, or instructor consent; open to juniors or higher.

name: Studies in Latina/o Literature
description: (Also offered as ENGL 3607.) Advanced study of a theme, form, author, or movement in contemporary Latina/o literature.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011, or instructor consent; open to juniors or higher.

name: Latin American Minorities in the United States
description: (Also offered as ANTH 3041.) Emphasis on groups of Mexican, Puerto Rican and Cuban origin, including treatment and historical background, social stratification, informal social relations, ethnic perceptions, relations and the concept of Latino identity.

name: Latino Health and Health Care
description: (Also offered as HDFS 3442.) Overview of health and health care issues among Latinos in the United States.  Particular attention is paid to cultural and social factors associated with health and well being (e.g. migration, acculturation, SES).
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Literature of Puerto Rico and the Spanish Caribbean
description: (Also offered as SPAN 3265.) Readings and discussions of major authors and works of the Spanish Caribbean with special emphasis on Puerto Rico.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SPAN 3178 or instructor consent.

name: Latino Political Behavior
description: (Also offered as POLS 3662.) Latino politics in the United States. Political histories of four different Latino populations: Mexican, Puerto Rican, Cuban and Central American. Different forms of political expressions, ranging from electoral behavior to political art. CA 4.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Immigration and Transborder Politics
description: (Also offered as POLS 3834, AMST 3271.) U.S. immigration policy, trans-border politics, and the impact diasporas and ethnic lobbies have on U.S. foreign policy, with emphasis on Latino diasporas.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Director of Latin American and Caribbean Studies required before departure. May count toward the major with consent of advisor.

name: Topics in Human Rights in Central America
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3294, SPAN 3294.) This winter session course in Costa Rica considers a contemporary topic of interest in human rights in the Central American region. Topics may include migration, indigenous rights, women's rights, economic development, environmental rights, and more. Offered as part of the Experiential Global Learning program. With a change in topic may be repeated for credit for a maximum of six credits.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: Media and Diverse Audiences
description: (Also offered as COMM 3320.) Issues of race, ethnicity, culture, class, gender, and sexuality in mainstream and alternative media. Analysis of how diverse groups use the media, are represented in, and interpret media content.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: COMM 1000,2300or2600.

name: Latinas and Media
description: (Also offered as WGSS 3321, COMM 3321.) The role of ethnicity and race in women's lives. Special attention to communication research on ethnic and racial minority women. CA 4. Formerly offered as LLAS 3264/ WGSS 3260.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Soap Opera/Telenovela
description: (Also offered as COMM 3322.) Socio-cultural functions of soap operas/telenovelas as mediated serials constructed by commercial organizations and consumed by United States and global audiences.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: COMM 1000,2300or2600.

name: Power and Health in Latin America and the Caribbean
description: (Also offered as ANTH 3327, HRTS 3327.) History, theories, and concepts about the human right to health and structural inequalities in the region.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: The Latinx Family
description: (Also offered as HDFS 3470.) Current issues in the study of Latinx youth and families from a social and developmental psychological perspective. Topics include parenting, youth development and adjustment, risky and healthy behaviors, cultural values, and immigration.

name: Latino Sociology
description: (Also offered as SOCI 3525.) The economic, social, political, and cultural experiences of Latinos in the United States. CA 2. CA 4.

name: Latino Sociology
description: (Also offered as SOCI 3525 W.) The economic, social, political, and cultural experiences of Latinos in the United States. CA 2. CA 4.

name: Human Rights on the U
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3602.) A view of the U.S./Mexican border from the perspective of immigrants and border residents. Course considers autobiography, film and documentary, poetry, fiction and non-fiction in the context of human and civil rights concerns on both sides of the border. Students analyze the effectiveness of narrative and representational strategies, activist interventions, and national and international responses to the needs of migrants and border dwellers. Through border, narrative and human rights theories, students piece together a global conversation on migrant rights.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: 1000-level course in LLAS.

name: Latin America in the Colonial Period
description: (Also offered as HIST 3607.) Pre-Columbian Civilization in America, the epoch of conquest and settlement, together with a study of the Ibero-Indian cultural synthesis which forms the basis of modern Latin American civilization. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: The Hispanic World in the Ages of Reason and Revolution
description: (Also offered as HIST 3608 W.) The transformation of Spanish America from the Bourbons in 1700, through the wars of independence and the struggle to build stable national states in the Nineteenth Century.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: HIST 3607.

name: Latin America in the National Period
description: (Also offered as HIST 3609.) Representative countries in North, Central, and South America and the Caribbean together with the historic development of inter-American relations and contemporary Latin American problems. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Comparative Slavery in the Americas
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3618, HIST 3618.) The rise and fall of trans-Atlantic slavery. Topics include resistance, migration, antislavery mobilization, abolitionism, empire, revolution, cultural production, political economy, labor, gender, race and identity formation.

name: History of the Caribbean
description: (Also offered as HIST 3619, AFRA 3619.) Encounter experience; slavery, antislavery mobilization, and abolitionism; colonialism; citizenship and nation building; race and gender; political cultures and movements; migration/immigration; cultural production; and political economy; topics will be examined from a historical perspective. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: History of the Caribbean
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3619 W, HIST 3619 W.) Encounter experience; slavery, antislavery mobilization, and abolitionism; colonialism; citizenship and nation building; race and gender; political cultures and movements; migration/immigration; cultural production; and political economy; topics will be examined from a historical perspective. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: History of Modern Mexico
description: (Also offered as HIST 3635.) The emergence of modern Mexico from independence to the present with emphasis on the Revolution of 1910. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
requirements: ecommended preparation: HIST 3607.

name: History of Migration in Las Americas
description: (Also offered as HIST 3660 W.) Applies broad chronological and spatial analyses of origins of migration in the Americas to the experiences of people of Latin American origin in Connecticut.  Addresses a range of topics from the initial settlement of the Americas to 21st century migrations. CA 1. CA 4.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: LLAS 1190, ANTH 3042, HIST 3635, HIST 3609 or HIST 2674/ LLAS 3220; LLAS 3210. Spanish useful but not required.

name: Borderlands of the Americas
description: (Also offered as HIST 3662.) A consideration of the importance of borderlands in the expansion and consolidation of European empires in the American continent, and later, in the shaping of newly independent republics. Contemporary issues related to Latin American borders, including migration, smuggling, violence, and the role of the state in shaping the borders of national cultures and societies.

name: Puerto Rican Politics and Culture
description: (Also offered as POLS 3667.) Legal and political history of the relationship between Puerto Rico and the United States with an emphasis on the question of United States empire and the politics of cultural resistance.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Latina History and Biography
description: (Also offered as HIST 3675, WGSS 3675.) Examination of the history of Latinas in the US with a focus on women, gender, and sexuality. Students will consider how historians use oral histories, life histories, memoirs, biographies, and testimonials as sources to restore Latinas to histories from which they were previously omitted. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Field Study
description: Work in cultural community-oriented setting(s).

name: Variable Topics in Latino and Latin American Studies
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Independent Study in Latino and Latin American Studies
Experiential/Service Learning Seminar
description: (Also offered as AAAS 4100, AFRA 4100, WGSS 4100.) Interdisciplinary examination of the history of social justice organizing in the U.S.; theories, strategies, and practice of community organizing movements such as those for immigration, environmental, reproductive, and racial justice. Includes practice in community organizing and political advocacy.

name: Field Internship in Latino Studies
description: Work in cultural community-oriented setting(s).

name: Latin American Studies Research Seminar
description: Capstone course in which majors and minors in Latin American Studies design, execute and write up original, library-based research on Latin America. Some readings may be in Spanish or Portuguese.

name: Language and Mind
description: Discussion of nature-nurture debate with specific reference to language acquisition. Pros and cons of Chomsky's Innateness Hypothesis. CA 1.

name: Language and Environment
description: Effects of geography, society, and politics on language use and variation (sociolinguistics). The geographical spread, growth and death of languages (language ecology). CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: The Diversity of Languages
description: Overview of world languages and language families. Typological classifications of linguistic properties: what can we expect in the structure of a language? Unity and diversity of language systems. Mechanisms of language change and variation. CA 2. CA 4.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Department Head or advisor may be required prior to the student's departure.

name: Special Topics Lecture
description: Credits, prerequisites and hours as determined by the Senate Curricula and Course Committee.
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: The Science of Linguistics
