description: Laboratory techniques related to composition of foods, and the physical and chemical changes that occur during preparation.
requirements: NUSC 1165; concurrent enrollment in NUSC 3233; CHEM 2241 or2443; open to Nutritional Sciences and Dietetic majors, others with instructor consent. May not be taken out of sequence after passing NUSC 3271 or 3273.

name: Profession of Dietetics
description: Overview of dietetic internships and application process.  Resume writing, job placement, ethics and dietetics.
requirements: USC 1245; open only to Nutritional Sciences Didactic Program students; others with consent.

name: Medical Nutrition Therapy II
description: (Also offered as DIET 3250.) Continuation of Medical Nutrition Therapy I. Further investigation of the interrelationships of physiology and biochemistry of disease and dietary intervention.
requirements: DIET 3150 or NUSC 3150; open only to Dietetics majors and NUSC Didactic Program students.

name: Food Services Systems Management Laboratory/Discussion
description: Laboratory/discussion of quantity food preparation, recipe modification, cost analysis, recipe nutrient analysis and application of food sanitation.
requirements: NUSC 3233,3234. Open only to NUSC students enrolled in NUSC 3272.

name: Food Service Systems Management I
description: (Also offered as DIET 3272.) Quantity food procurement, preparation and distribution; recipe standardization and menu development; sanitation and safety; portion and quality control; systems approach and delivery systems.
requirements: pen only to junior or higher Dietetics and Nutritional Science majors, others with instructor consent. Recommended preparation: NUSC 3233,3234. Not open to students who have passed NUSC 3270.

name: Nutritional Sciences Internship
description: Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: NUSC 1165 and2200. Open to juniors or higher; open to Nutritional Science majors with consent.

name: Nutrient and Food Analysis
description: An overview of analytical techniques and instrumentations commonly used in the food industry to determine food quality. Laboratories involve hands-on trainings on analytical equipment to collect and analyze experimental data on various food samples.
requirements: CHEM 2241 and NUSC 1165. Not open for credit to students who have passed NUSC 5350.

name: International Studies in Nutritional Sciences
description: Variable topics. Coursework undertaken within approved study abroad programs.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Experience in Food Service Systems Management
description: Application of principles of food service management. Supervised placement. No more than six credits of experience or independent study may apply toward the major.

name: Experience in Medical Nutrition Therapy
description: Mentored experiences in Medical Nutrition Therapy that include traditional (e.g., hospitals, long term care centers) and contemporary (e.g., wellness clinics, sports nutrition practice) placement with registered dietitians/nutritionists. No more than six credits of experience or independent study may apply toward the major.
requirements: NUSC 3150.

name: Dietetic Career Readiness
description: Preparing the dietetic internship application. Exploring dietetic careers, resume and personal statement writing and evaluating strengths and weaknesses.
requirements: NUSC 3245. Instructor consent required.

name: Nutritional Biochemistry and Metabolism
description: Metabolism and functions of carbohydrates, proteins, fats, minerals, and vitamins.

name: Writing in Nutritional Sciences
description: A writing-intensive class that emphasizes both style and content consistent with the discipline of Nutritional Science.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; NUSC 4236, which must be taken concurrently.

name: Nutrition for Exercise and Sport
description: Basic nutrition principles. Physical activity, exercise, sport performance and consequences of nutritional ergogenic aids.

name: Dietary Supplements and Functional Foods
description: Provides students with an understanding of the uses, effectiveness, and safety of nutraceuticals, botanicals, herbals, and dietary supplements.
requirements: pen only by instructor consent. Recommended preparation: NUSC 1165, and CHEM 2241 or CHEM 2443.

name: Immunological Mechanisms of Disease
description: Assessment of immune function in the pathophysiology of various diseases including allergy, autoimmune diseases, cancer, infectious diseases, and metabolic syndrome with an emphasis on the roles of diet and host microbiota in shaping immune development and function. Patient case studies will be used to facilitate learning outcomes.
requirements: NUSC 1165 or BIOL 1107; CHEM 2241 or2443. Not open for credit to students who have passed NUSC 5270.

name: Food Service Systems Management II
description: (Also offered as DIET 4272.) Institutional menu development; cost and budgeting; equipment layout and design; personnel management; marketing and merchandising; purchasing and inventory control.
requirements: DIET 3272 or NUSC 3272.

name: Seminar
description: Review, evaluation, and oral and written presentation of contemporary nutrition issues.
requirements: NUSC 2200.

name: Special Topics
description: Topics and credits to be published prior to the registration period preceding the semester offerings.

name: Senior Thesis in Nutrition
description: Consent of honor advisor and department head required.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011or 2011; open only by consent of honors advisor and department head;

name: Independent Study
description: Individual study and research with faculty. Written report. No more than six credits of experience or independent study may apply toward the major.

name: Entrepreneurship in Food and Agriculture
description: A comprehensive overview of key elements involved in identifying critical needs and key elements for the commercialization of food and agriculture-based technologies.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: OSH Internship
description: (Also offered as AH 4291.) Application of the principles and concepts of hazard assessment and safety management to an actual workplace under the supervision of an approved onsite supervisor. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 credits applied to the major. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: pen only to BGS students and Allied Health Sciences majors, juniors or higher, and OSH Certificate students; others with consent.

name: Navigating the Future of Technology
description: (Also offered as BADM 2220.) Explores the dynamic intersection of business and emerging technologies, preparing students to understand and address the challenges and opportunities of the tech-driven business world. Emphasizes creativity, critical thinking, and collaboration through engaging lectures, discussions, and projects. Students will have a foundational understanding of the impact of technologies like AI, blockchain, and IoT on businesses and society.
requirements: pen only to business students.

name: Business Information Systems
description: (Also offered as BADM 3103.) An introduction to key information management principles and the foundation for advanced operations and information management electives. Students learn to manage, organize, and analyze information across a variety of programs and systems. Students gain experience manipulating data, creating and modifying databases, and working within information systems that are essential to business operations.
requirements: pen only to Business majors of sophomore or higher status, others with consent of OPIM Department Head. May not be taken out of sequence after passing OPIM 3207,3211,3301,3302,3505, or 3506.

name: Operations Management
description: (Also offered as BADM 3104.) Introduction to concepts, models, and information systems applicable to the planning, design, operation and control of systems which produce goods and services. Topics include process design, facility locations, aggregate planning, inventory control, and scheduling.
requirements: pen only to Business majors of junior or higher status.

name: Analytics for Business Intelligence
description: The course introduces students to the field of analytics and business intelligence. It positions them to structure and successfully complete analytics projects. The course exemplifies and explores how businesses gather and use data as well as set up and execute business problems. Students will make use of programming tools to build predictive models.
requirements: OPIM 3103 or BADM 3103; open only to Analytics and Information Management majors of junior or higher status. May not be taken out of sequence after passing OPIM 3211. Not open for credit to students who have passed OPIM 5604.

name: Database Design and Management
description: (Also offered as BADM 3204.) This course introduces market-leading techniques for transaction processes as well as decision making and business intelligence, that help to identify and manage key data from business processes. Provides the essential tools required for further data mining applications. Combines lecture, class discussion and hands-on computer work in a business-oriented environment.
requirements: OPIM 3103 or BADM 3103; open only to Analytics and Information Management majors of junior or higher status. May not be taken out of sequence after passing OPIM 3211.

name: Information Security
description: (Also offered as BADM 3207.) Introduces the basic principles of information security, its role in reducing information risk exposure, and tools and solutions that can be used to prevent information loss and business interruption. Discusses appropriate laws and industry standards for IT Governance. Presents the process of information systems audit, discusses tools of IT audit and its role in detection and prevention of fraud and other data anomalies. An introduction to risk management software and methodologies will also be covered.
requirements: PIM or BADM 3103, which may be taken concurrently; open only to Analytics and Information Management majors of junior or higher status. May not be taken out of sequence after passing OPIM 3211.

name: Systems Analysis and Design
description: System development methodologies for business information systems. Project management concepts, hardware and software technology, and organizational considerations are explored. Students participate in a system development project.
requirements: OPIM 3103,3203,3204and3207; Open only to Analytics and Information Management majors of junior or higher status.

name: Spreadsheet Modeling for Business Analysis
description: (Also offered as BADM 3301.) This course provides an introduction to business decision and data analysis with electronic spreadsheets in Excel, the primary quantitative analysis software in business environments. Modeling and decision techniques are covered in combination with Excel functions and tools. Applications in different business functional areas are also covered. Each student is required to bring a laptop installed with Microsoft Excel that can connect to the internet.
requirements: PIM or BADM 3103; Open only to business majors of junior or higher status.

name: Data Visualization
description: (Also offered as BADM 3302.) Introduces the techniques and best practices in visualizing data. Examines cognitive function and its role in data visualization designs; showing that data visualization can reveal answers and questions alike. Utilizing state of the art software, the use of parameters, filters, calculated variables, color, space and motion to visually articulate the data are surveyed. The use of dashboards to quickly reveal data-driven information that has daily relevance to executives, managers, supervisors and line personnel are investigated. Each student is required to bring a laptop (with Windows or Mac OS) that can connect to the Internet and handle required software (see School of Business specifications).
requirements: PIM or BADM 3103; Open only to business majors of junior or higher status.

name: Business Software Development
description: (Also offered as BADM 3401.) This course introduces students to the development of computer software for business information processing. Topics include flowcharting, pseudocode, programming with a business-oriented computer language, file processing concepts, and on-line and batch processing. Formerly offered as OPIM 3220.
requirements: pen only to business majors of junior or higher status.

name: Mobile Application Development
description: (Also offered as BADM 3402.) This course will show students how to develop cross-platform mobile applications for both iOS and Android systems. Students will learn how to plan and create their own mobile applications. Graphical User Interface (GUI) design skills as well as programming logics will be taught and emphasized throughout the course. Upon completion of this course, students should be able to use the programming skills they learn to develop user-friendly mobile apps for both iPhones and Android devices. Formerly offered as OPIM 3224.
requirements: pen only to business majors of junior or higher status.

name: UX / UI Design
description: (Also offered as BADM 3403.) This course is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of user experience (UX) and user interface (UI) design principles, methodologies, and practices. The course will cover the structure of design thinking and guide students through the iterative design process, from initial concept development to final UI implementation.
requirements: pen only to business majors of junior or higher status.

name: Business Database Management
description: Introduction to the development and implementation of database applications. Topics covered include costs and benefits of database approach, database design lifecycle, the relational data model, Structured Query Language, database applications development and data warehousing. Students will learn the relational database concept and participate in the hands-on design and implementation of a database using the relational architecture and a database management system. Cannot be used to fulfill Analytics and Information Management (AIM) major requirements. Offered only at regional campus locations.
requirements: OPIM 3103 or equivalent; open only to business majors of junior or higher status, others with consent of Operations and Information Management Department Head.

name: Business Application Programming
description: Development of business application software using structured and object-oriented programming techniques. The emphasis is on programming logic, rapid application development techniques and personal productivity tools. Topics include program design techniques, programming constructs, interface development techniques, event driven programming, file and database processing, and object linking and embedding. Cannot be used to fulfill Analytics and Information Management (AIM) major requirements. Offered only at regional campus locations.
requirements: OPIM 3103 or equivalent; open only to business majors of junior or higher status, others with consent of OPIM Department Head.

name: Business Data Analytics I
description: Presents essential data analytics topics. Covers basic programming logic and techniques necessary for developing business data applications. The course will also cover topics related to data preprocessing and data cleaning with a light introduction to data mining and visualization techniques. Cannot be used to fulfill Analytics and Information Management (AIM) major requirements. Offered only at regional campus locations.
requirements: OPIM 3103 or equivalent; open only to business majors of junior or higher status, others with the consent of the OPIM Department Head. Cannot be used to fulfill Analytics and Information Management (AIM) major requirements.

name: Business Data Analytics II
description: Presents data analytics principles and state-of-the-art data mining software, with an emphasis placed on applications in business. The course provides an introduction to a variety of statistical techniques and algorithmic principles used in data mining. Various data mining procedures will be discussed and subsequently implemented using state-of-the-art analytics toolsets. Cannot be used to fulfill Analytics and Information Management (AIM) major requirements. Offered only at regional campus locations.
requirements: OPIM 3510 or equivalent; open to business majors of junior or higher status, others with department head consent.

name: Project Management for Business Data Analytics
description: Introduction to the concepts necessary for both project managers and project team members to deliver successful data analytics projects on time, on budget and in scope. The phases and knowledge areas of project management, as defined by the Project Management Institute (PMI), are covered as well as the tools and techniques in each area for successful project management. An introduction to appropriate project management software will also be covered. As part of the course, students will be divided into teams, with each team responsible for the satisfactory management and completion of a data analytics report. Cannot be used to fulfill Analytics and Information Management (AIM) major requirements. Offered only at regional campus locations.
requirements: pen only to business majors of junior or higher status, others with consent of OPIM Department Head. Credit will not be given if OPIM 5270 has been taken to fulfill undergrad degree requirements.

name: Managerial Supply Chain Management
description: (Also offered as BADM 3601.) This course is designed to introduce students to the fundamentals of supply chain management. It will discuss the parts of a supply chain and how they relate to each other. Techniques to manage supply chain related interactions and relationships will also be taught. Topics will be presented with a focus on preparing students to make decisions relating to supply chain management. Specific skills that will be taught are business analysis, sourcing, quality, global impacts, financial considerations, contracting, negotiation, and other skills for managing a supply chain.
requirements: pen only to business majors of junior or higher status.

name: Supply Chain Logistics
description: (Also offered as BADM 3602.) This course will introduce students to supply chain logistics that manages movement and storage of goods, services, and related information from source to destination along the supply chain. Topics include distribution network design, supply/demand planning, inventory management, transportation planning, warehouse operations. Students will learn quantitative methods and analytics tools and apply them to various decisions in supply chain logistics.
requirements: STAT 1000 Qor STAT 1100 Qor equivalent; open only to business majors of junior or higher status.

name: Project Management and Planning
description: (Also offered as BADM 3603.) Provides an introduction to the concepts necessary for both project managers and project team members to deliver successful projects on time, on budget and in scope. The phases and knowledge areas of project management, as defined by the Project Management Institute (PMI), are covered as well as the tools and techniques in each area for successful project management. An introduction to Microsoft Project software will also be covered.
requirements: pen only to business majors of junior or higher status. Credit will not be given if OPIM 5270 has been taken to fulfill undergraduate degree requirements.

name: Network Design and Applications
description: (Also offered as BADM 3701.) Principles and applications of business telecommunications emphasized. Course covers important network systems as well as crucial techniques in building these systems. Students participate in network design and implementation project.
requirements: pen only to Analytics and Information Management majors of junior or higher status. May not be taken out of sequence after passing OPIM 3211.

name: Risk, Trust, and Modern Security
description: (Also offered as BADM 3702.) This course explores systems of trust and the technologies used to support them.  Students will take an interdisciplinary look at the assessment of risk and explore modern methods used to cover various types of risks.
requirements: OPIM 3207 or BADM 3207. Open only to business majors of junior or higher status.

name: Introduction to Cryptocurrency and Blockchain Technology
description: This course explores the fundamental knowledge of blockchain technology, its practical applications and impact in industries. The course discusses the popular cryptocurrencies on the market, their operating mechanisms, and related decentralized applications including Defi, NFTs, DAOs, and Web 3.0. The course will also evaluate the ethical, legal, social, and environmental impacts of Blockchain technology.
requirements: OPIM 3103; open only to business majors of junior or higher status.

name: Internship in Operations and Information Management
description: Designed to provide students with an opportunity for a supervised internship relevant to one or more major areas within the Department. Students will work under the supervision of one or more professionals in the specialty in question. Student performance will be evaluated on the basis of an appraisal by the field supervisor and a detailed written report submitted by the student. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: ompletion of first-year - sophomore School of Business Requirements and consent of instructor and Department Head; open only to Business majors of junior or higher status.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Department Head required, prior to the student's departure. These credits must be awarded for regularly scheduled course work at a recognized foreign university in the field of information systems or in the student's Applications Area; if in the Applications Area the consent of both the Department Head and the Head of the Applications Area is required. Prior to taking the course the student must sign up for the course in advance as a course in that Applications Area. No credits can be counted toward required courses in the Analytics and Information Management (AIM) major.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher; consent of Department Head required, prior to the student's departure.

name: Special Topics
description: Classroom course in special topics in operations management, operations research and information management as announced in advance for each semester.
requirements: OPIM 3103 and others as announced separately for each offering; open to juniors or higher.

name: Independent Study
description: Individual study of special topics in operations management, operations research and information management as mutually arranged between a student and an instructor.
requirements: pen only to business majors of junior or higher status.

name: Independent Honors Research in OPIM
description: Students are expected to develop their own plan for a research project, conduct the research, and write-up this research, consulting periodically with a faculty member.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher; open only to OPIM Department Honors Students with consent of the instructor.

name: Senior Thesis in Operations and Information Management
requirements: OPIM 4996; open only to OPIM Department Honors Students with consent of instructor and Department Head; open to juniors or higher.

name: Biomedical Issues in Pathobiology
description: This introductory course focuses on current global issues of health and disease to describe fundamental topics in pathobiology. Global biomedical concerns regarding infectious diseases, population, cancer, biotechnology and environmental health will be addressed. Course content will provide examples of the impact of veterinary and human pathology on world health issues.

name: Diseases, Medicine, and Social Determinants of Health
description: Introduction to the biology of disease, with an emphasis on health and medicine. Topics include disease mechanisms, defense responses, and sociological factors influencing disease.

name: One Health: People, Animals, Plants, and the Environment
description: Exploration of health concepts and ecosystems where people, animals, plants, and the environment interconnect and impact each other. CA 3.

name: Exploring Careers in Pathobiology
description: Exposure to the Pathobiology major and careers in Pathobiology through interactions with professionals in relevant careers, training in basic laboratory safety and research compliance, and development of a personalized career journal.

name: Fundamental Biomedical Laboratory Techniques
description: Hands-on, basic biomedical research laboratory techniques with an emphasis on chemical and biological safety, as well as laboratory proficiency.

name: Special Topics
description: Credits, prerequisites and hours as determined by the Senate Curricula and Course Committee.
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Anatomy and Physiology of Animals
description: A study of the anatomy and physiology of animals with reference to pathological changes of the component parts of the body.
requirements: BIOL 1107 or equivalent.

name: Modern Biomedical Laboratory Techniques
description: Comprehensive project-based laboratory course utilizing a variety of modern biomedical techniques to identify an unknown pathogen and express antigens for vaccine and diagnostic assay development. Topics covered include next-generation sequencing, CRISPR gene editing, mRNA technology, gene cloning and expression, protein purification and analysis, immunoassay, and reverse transcription quantitative PCR development.
requirements: BIOL 1107 or equivalent.

name: Health and Disease Management of Animals
description: Designed for students who plan to own and work with domestic animals. Its purpose is to develop student competence in disease management and to foster an intelligent working relationship with their veterinarian. The course will cover a systematic study of infectious and noninfectious diseases of domestic animals from the standpoint of economy and public health.
requirements: BIOL 1107 or equivalent.

name: Medical Microbiology: Bacteria and Fungi
description: Fundamental biology of pathogenic bacteria and fungi including host-pathogen interactions and microbiological laboratory techniques.
requirements: BIOL 1107 or equivalent.

name: Medical Microbiology: Viruses and Parasites
description: Fundamental biology of medically relevant viruses and parasites including host-pathogen interactions and microbiological laboratory techniques.
requirements: BIOL 1107 or equivalent.

name: Medical Cell Biology
description: Foundations of cellular structures and molecular basis of disease, from essential components of eukaryotic cells to cellular responses to injury and disease.
requirements: BIOL 1107 or equivalent.

name: Foreign Studies in Pathobiology
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program.

name: Seminar
description: Majors may take this course in each semester of the senior year.

name: Special Topics
description: Topics and credits to be published prior to the registration period  preceding the semester offerings.

name: Independent Study
description: Special problems in connection with departmental research programs and diagnostic procedures for diseases of animals. Some suggested topics are histopathologic laboratory procedures, clinical hematology, diagnostic bacteriology, diagnostic parasitology.

name: Histologic Structure and Function
description: Designed for students in biologic, paramedical and animal sciences; its purpose is to integrate histologic and cellular structure with function, utilizing human tissues and those from other vertebrates.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher; open only with consent of instructor. Recommended preparation: PATH 2100 or PNB 2264-2265 or PNB 2274-2275 or an equivalent course in vertebrate anatomy and physiology.

name: Principles of Animal Virology
description: Structure and classification of viruses, cultivation and multiplication, pathogenesis and epidemiology of viral infections, host response, oncogenic viruses, immunization against, and laboratory diagnosis of viral diseases.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Principles of Animal Virology
description: Structure and classification of viruses, cultivation and multiplication, pathogenesis and epidemiology of viral infections, host response, oncogenic viruses, immunization against, and laboratory diagnosis of viral diseases.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Immunobiology
description: Principles of basic and clinical immunobiology; phylogeny and ontogeny of the immune response, characteristics of the immune response, cellular and humoral immunity; central and peripheral lymphoid tissues; mechanisms of immunologic injury and immunologic diseases; comparative and veterinary immunology; transplantation and tumor immunology.
requirements: BIOL 1107 or equivalent.

name: Diagnostic Techniques for the Biomedical Sciences
description: Theoretical basis and practical exposure to modern laboratory methods used in the biomedical sciences for disease diagnosis.
requirements: BIOL 1107 or equivalent.

name: Emerging Infectious Diseases and Pandemics
description: Mechanisms of emergence that different pathogens have used to cause disease in new hosts.

name: Systems Pathophysiology I
description: Organ-based study of human and animal diseases. Use of gross, microscopic, and physiologic evidence to diagnose disease. Topics covered include respiratory, cardiovascular, hematopoietic, lymphoid, musculoskeletal, and urinary systems.
requirements: ecommended preparation: Previous coursework in Cell Biology. PATH 3810 and PATH 3820 can be taken in any order.

name: Systems Pathophysiology I Laboratory
description: Inquiry-based laboratory course on systems pathophysiology, using gross, microscopic, and physiologic evidence to diagnose diseases of the respiratory, cardiovascular, hematopoietic, lymphoid, musculoskeletal, and urinary systems.
requirements: PATH 3810, which may be taken concurrently.

name: Systems Pathophysiology II
description: Organ-based study of human and animal diseases. Use of gross, microscopic, and physiologic evidence to diagnose disease. Topics covered include central nervous, skin, hepatobiliary, endocrine, and digestive systems.
requirements: ecommended preparation: Previous coursework in Cell Biology. PATH 3810 and PATH 3820 can be taken in any order.

name: Systems Pathophysiology II Laboratory
description: Inquiry-based laboratory course on systems pathophysiology, using gross, microscopic, and physiologic evidence to diagnose diseases of the central nervous, skin, hepatobiliary, endocrine, and digestive systems.
requirements: PATH 3820, which may be taken concurrently.

name: Chronic and Inflammatory Diseases
description: Investigation of chronic and inflammatory diseases like asthma, arthritis, and cancer, enabling students to identify risk factors, describe disease mechanisms, and design diagnostic and therapeutic treatment plans that address socioeconomic, cultural, and access-related factors.
requirements: ecommended preparation: A course in physiology such as PATH 2100, or PATH 3810, or PATH 3820, or PNB 2250, or PNB 2264-2265, or PNB 2774- PNB 2776, or equivalent.

name: Bioinformatics in Molecular Epidemiology of Infectious Diseases
description: Basic concepts and terminologies in bioinformatics and infectious disease epidemiology. Hands-on, practical experiences in sequence analysis: database, alignment, phylogenetic analysis, and visualization of data.
requirements: ANSC 3121, MCB 2400, or MCB 2410.

name: Pathobiology Honors Thesis
description: Writing of Honors thesis based on an independent research project in Pathobiology.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open only to Honors students; instructor consent required.

name: Principles of Antibacterial Development
description: Designed to cover important concepts and pioneering strategies currently being used to develop novel antibacterials.
requirements: MCB 2610, or an equivalent course in general microbiology or bacteriology with consent of the instructor. Open to juniors or higher.

name: Vaccines and Immunotherapeutics
description: Students develop an understanding of approaches for scientists and engineers to use the immune system to combat infectious and chronic diseases. Both traditional and modern molecular approaches to vaccine and immunotherapy design will be discussed. Students will gain an appreciation for the transition from basic research to practical applications.
requirements: ecommended preparation: Previous coursework in Immunology or equivalent.

name: Principles of Pathobiology
description: The body's response to chemical, physical, and microbial injuries including the functional and morphologic alterations in disease of the major organ systems.
requirements: PATH 2100 or PNB 2264-2265 or PNB 2274-2275 or an equivalent course in vertebrate anatomy and physiology; open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: PATH 3100 or equivalent course in histology or cell biology.

name: Health and Disease Management of Animals
description: Designed for students who plan to own and work with domestic animals. Its purpose is to develop student competence in disease management and to foster an intelligent working relationship with their veterinarian. The course will cover a systematic relationship of infectious and noninfectious diseases of domestic animals from the standpoint of economic and public health.
requirements: SAAS 111 and112and a college course in biology.

name: Special Topics
description: Total credits allowed toward graduation requirements are restricted as outlined in Ratcliffe Hicks Section.

name: Independent Study
description: An independent study project is mutually arranged between a student and an instructor. Students are advised to read the Ratcliffe Hicks School regulation limiting the number of credits which may be applied toward graduation.

name: Elementary Persian I
description: Introductory reading, writing, speaking, listening and cultural context. Development of linguistic skills required to interact in everyday contexts. Intended for students with no previous knowledge of Persian.

name: Elementary Persian II
description: Continuation of PERS 1101. Development of oral and written skills. Deepening of cultural competence. Taught in English and Persian.
requirements: PERS 1101 or comparable proficiency; instructor consent required.

name: Intermediate Persian I
description: Further development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Persian within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Persian-speaking world.
requirements: PERS 1102 or equivalent.

name: Intermediate Persian II
description: Further development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Persian within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Persian-speaking world.
requirements: PERS 1103 or equivalent.

name: Drugs: Actions and Impact on Health and Society
description: Introductory survey of common drugs used medically and nonmedically. Biological emphasis with historical, cultural, social implications. General Concepts: mechanisms of action, modification drug response, new drug development. CA 3.
requirements: ot open to Pharmacy students.

name: Toxic Chemicals and Health
description: Human and environmental health issues and problems associated with voluntary and involuntary exposure to toxic chemicals. Toxic chemical risks as compared to other societal health risks, the processes of scientific risk assessment, how environmental and human exposure to toxic chemicals are interdependent, and the social and environmental management of toxic chemical risks. CA 3.

name: Fundamentals of Pharmacology
description: Fundamental concepts of pharmacology. The content empowers students to identify how drugs are formulated, how they work in the body, some of the main drug classes, and the main drugs within those classes.

name: Special Topics
description: Credits and hours as determined by the Senate Curricula and Courses Committee.

name: Fundamentals in Chemical Biology
description: Bridges the gap between traditional undergraduate curricula in chemistry and biology through the interdisciplinary topic of chemical biology. Fundamental topics in chemistry are reviewed and explained within the context of biological environments. Introduction to current state-of-the art techniques and methods used in chemical biology research. Analysis and interpretation of data from chemical biology experiments and use this information to generate scientific conclusions.
requirements: CHEM 1128 Qor CHEM 1148 Q, and BIOL 1107.

name: Pharmacy Research Seminar
description: (Also offered as PHRX 3012.) A seminar series providing an overview of current research areas and contemporary issues in pharmacy practice and the pharmaceutical sciences.
requirements: ecommended Preparation: A cumulative gpa of 2.3 or above is normally required.

name: Special Topics
requirements: pen only to Pharmacy students.

name: Honors Thesis in Pharmacy
description: (Also offered as PHRX 3097 W.)
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open only to honors students within the School of Pharmacy with consent of the instructor and Associate Dean.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: (Also offered as PHRX 3099.) Designed primarily for qualified students who wish to extend their knowledge in the various fields represented in the School of Pharmacy. A divisional and pharmacy cumulative grade point average of 2.8 or above is normally required for enrollment. A written summary of work performed is required at the end of each semester.

name: Cellular Biology
description: Introduction to basic principles in cell biology, intracellular signaling, gene expression and biotechnology in the pharmaceutical sciences.
requirements: pen only to students in the School of Pharmacy. Must have satisfied the pre-pharmacy prerequisites. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHRX 3001.

name: Immunology
description: Principles of immunology underlying disease processes.
requirements: PHRX 3000; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Foundations in Bioorganic Chemistry
description: Fundamental knowledge of medicinal and natural products chemistry, metabolic biotransformation, and drug design.
requirements: pen to students in the School of Pharmacy who have satisfied the pre-pharmacy prerequisites.

name: Nutrition
description: Principles of enteral and parenteral nutrition related to prescription and non-prescription medication effects. Classification of nutrition status, and nutrition assessment . Identification of drug-nutrient deficiencies/interactions and preparation of disease-specific nutritional care plans. Evaluation, resources, and classification of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM).
requirements: PHRX 3000,3002; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Cellular Principles for Mechanisms of Drug Action
description: Integrated concepts of subcellular structure and function particularly as targets of and/or responsible for mechanism of action of select, exemplar drugs relevant to medical pharmacology and drug toxicity.
requirements: ust have satisfied the Pharmacy Pre-Professional prerequisites for admission to the PharmD program.

name: Introduction to Therapeutics
description: Foundational understanding of the main drug classes, including small molecules as well as protein and nucleotide-based therapeutics.
requirements: ust have satisfied the Pharmacy Pre-Professional prerequisites for admission to the PharmD program.

name: Drug Information I
description: A blended course designed to introduce students to drug information resources that are common in pharmacy practice and the process of answering drug information questions by using these resources to retrieve accurate information. There is a mixture of scheduled face-to-face class meetings and class activities via HuskyCT (presentations, readings, quizzes, assignments, discussions and other activities).
requirements: ust have satisfied the pre pharmacy prerequisites; open to students in the first professional year of the PharmD curriculum. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHRX 3007, 3052 or 4001.

name: Drug Information II
description: Development of skills to identify and use information from primary literature in clinical or research practice and to assess research methodology, biostatistics, epidemiology in drug information literature.
requirements: PHRX 3006; open only to student in the School of Pharmacy. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHRX 4001 or 4053.

name: Communications and Professional Identity
description: This course highlights best practices for effective interpersonal, interprofessional, and team communication. Students will develop their communication skills and begin forming their professional identity.
requirements: ust have satisfied the Pharmacy Pre-Professional prerequisites for admission to the PharmD program.

name: Principles of Drug Action
description: Fundamental mechanisms of drug actions and effects with emphasis on interactions with cellular macromolecules and resulting downstream signaling events. Autonomic drugs and nomenclature.
requirements: pen only to students in the School of Pharmacy. Must have satisfied the pre-pharmacy prerequisites. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHRX 3040.

name: Self-Care and Non-Prescription Medications Module
description: This course will provide student pharmacists with the knowledge and problem-solving skills needed to assess an individual’s health status and current practice of self-treatment using over-the-counter self-care products.
requirements: ust have satisfied the Pharmacy Pre-Professional prerequisites for admission to the PharmD program.

name: Pharmacy Research Seminar
description: (Also offered as PHAR 3012.) A seminar series providing an overview of current research areas and contemporary issues in pharmacy practice and the pharmaceutical sciences.
requirements: pen only to students in the School of Pharmacy

name: Pharmacotherapy Essentials Module
description: This course establishes the essentials in pharmacotherapy concepts and serves as the foundation for future therapeutics modules. It provides an introduction to medication therapy considerations across the lifespan (pediatric, pregnancy and lactation, geriatrics).
requirements: PHRX 3004, PHRX 3005, PHRX 3030, PHRX 3010.

name: Cardiovascular Module
description: Develop and demonstrate the breadth of knowledge in the foundational sciences associated with cardiovascular patient care. Apply foundational knowledge in prevention and/or treatment of commonly encountered cardiovascular disease states.
requirements: PHRX 3004, PHRX 3005, PHRX 3030.

name: Pharmacokinetics/Biopharmaceutics
description: Provides an understanding of the basic principles of pharmacokinetics and biopharmaceutics and describe how to apply the basic principles to the rational design of dosing regimen.
requirements: ust have satisfied the Pharmacy Pre-Professional prerequisites for admission to the PharmD program.

name: Foundations in Pharmaceutics I
description: Principles underlying the formulation, dissolution, stability and release of drug products for optimum delivery.  Dosage forms discussed include colloids, suspensions, emulsions, suppositories, aerosols, ointments and transdermals.
requirements: PHRX 3030; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHRX 4030.

name: Non-Sterile Pharmaceutical Compounding
description: Preparation of non-sterile dosage forms, with attention to solutions, solids and dispersed systems.
requirements: PHRX 3030; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHRX 4030.

name: Foundations of Pharmaceutics I
description: This course will provide an understanding of the basic principles of thermodynamics, ionic equilibrium, chemical kinetics and diffusion; application of these principles to formulation, stability and dissolution of a drug product, and drug release from the dosage form for optimum therapeutic outcome.
requirements: PHRX 3030

name: Non-Sterile Pharmaceutical Compounding
description: This course focuses on compounding techniques and standards used in preparing pharmaceutical dosage forms that are not required to be sterile.
requirements: PHRX 3061

name: Neurology Module
description: Principles of pathophysiology, pharmacology, medicinal chemistry, clinical pharmacokinetics and pharmacotherapy (including both prescription and non-prescription medications) as they apply to neurologic drug therapy management.
requirements: PHRX 3000,3002, and 3009; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHRX 4040.

name: Public Health and Healthcare Policy
description: This course provides students with a fundamental understanding of public health, health policy, and population health. Students will draw connections between pharmacy and public health and explore ways in which pharmacists can aid in solving our nation's health problems.
requirements: ust have satisfied the Pharmacy Pre-Professional prerequisites for admission to the PharmD program.

name: Evidence-Based Pharmacy
description: Designed to facilitate student's understanding of the need for and value of evidence-based practice, to describe steps and processes involved in conducting a systemic review and meta-analysis and to teach students how to critically assess the validity of systemic reviews and meta-analyses and their roles in shaping clinical practice.
requirements: pen only to students in the pharmacy program.

name: Drugs and Society
description: Examination of the broad impact of drugs on society including health, athletic competition, lifestyle and appearance, literature, movies, reproduction and sexual behavior, drug abuse and advertising.
requirements: pen only to students in the pharmacy program.

name: Discovering the Leader Within
description: Students will read a popular leadership book and participate in activities focused on its content. Discussion posts, study guides and participation in in-class discussions. Applications to fundamental principles to pharmacy practice. Culminates with a discussion with the author or other leadership expert. This course can be repeated for credit because each year will focus on a new book.
requirements: pen only to students in the pharmacy program.

name: Future Pharmacy Leaders
description: A broad overview of leadership development, appreciation of personal strengths, and professional development. Run in collaboration with the University's Office of Leadership Programs, with the school's Phi Lambda Sigma members serving as mentors.
requirements: pen to first year Pharmacy students.

name: Pharmacy Skills Development I
description: Introduction to the pharmacists' patient care process and interprofessional practice competencies. Students will develop patient care skills including but not limited to immunization administration and education, vaccine scheduling and CPR training. These activities will be applied in IPPE (Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experiences) at selected community pharmacy practice sites.
requirements: ust have satisfied the pre-pharmacy prerequisites; open to juniors or higher in the School of Pharmacy program.

name: Pharmaceutical Industry Fundamentals for Pharmacists
description: This course is designed to familiarize students with the fundamental concepts related to careers in the pharmaceutical industry.

name: Pharmacy Skills Development I
description: This course will ensure students have basic introductory pharmacotherapy knowledge, immunization essentials, and foundational skills for pharmacy math.
requirements: ust have satisfied the Pharmacy Pre-Professional prerequisites for admission to the PharmD program.

name: Pharmacy Skills Development II
description: Reinforces the use of the pharmacists' patient care process and interprofessional practice competencies. Students will develop patient care skills including management of selfcare with over the counter (OTC) products, taking medication histories, use of OTC testing devices, assessing patient medication regimens, interprofessional communication skills, and taking blood pressure measurements. These activities will be applied in IPPE (Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experiences) at selected community pharmacy practice sites.
requirements: HRX 3020 or3060; open to juniors or higher in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Pharmacy Skills Development II
description: This course will apply the pharmacist’s patient care process to introductory community and ambulatory practice.
requirements: PHRX 3008, PHRX 3010, PHRX 3062.

name: Special Topics
requirements: pen only to students in the pharmacy program.

name: Honors Thesis in Pharmacy
description: (Also offered as PHAR 3097 W.)
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open only to honors students within the School of Pharmacy with consent of the instructor and Associate Dean.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: (Also offered as PHAR 3099.) Designed primarily for qualified students who wish to extend their knowledge in the various fields represented in the School of Pharmacy. A divisional and pharmacy cumulative grade point average of 2.8 or above is normally required for enrollment. A written summary of work performed is required at the end of each semester.
requirements: pen only to students in the pharmacy program.

name: Pharmacoeconomics
description: Application of pharmacoeconomic principles to formulary management, health-related quality of life, cost-benefit analysis, and pharmacoeconomic literature analysis.
requirements: ECON 1201; PHRX 4050; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy .

name: Current Topics in Pharmacy
description: Presentation of a specific sub area of pharmacy with focus on biological, chemical, clinical/therapeutic, sociological or legal/ethical aspects of drugs, dosage forms or health care systems to improve the student's writing, presentation, and discussion skills.
requirements: PHRX 3006,3007and3008; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Foundations in Pharmaceutics II
description: Principles and factors affecting performance of dosage forms classified as dispersed systems: suspensions, emulsions, suppositories, aerosols, ointments and transdermals.
requirements: PHRX 3031 and3032; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Sterile Pharmaceutical Compounding
description: Dosage forms preparation and basic techniques for compounding sterile dosage forms.
requirements: PHRX 3031 and3032; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Psychiatry Module
description: Principles of pathophysiology, pharmacology, medicinal chemistry, clinical pharmacokinetics and pharmacotherapy (including both prescription and non-prescription medications) as they apply to psychiatric drug therapy management.
requirements: PHRX 3040; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Immunology Module
description: Principles of pathophysiology, pharmacology, medicinal chemistry, clinical pharmacokinetics and pharmacotherapy (including both prescription and non-prescription medications) as they apply to immunologic drug therapy management.
requirements: PHRX 3001 and PHRX 3040; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Gastroenterology Module
description: Principles of pathophysiology, pharmacology, medicinal chemistry, clinical pharmacokinetics and pharmacotherapy (including both prescription and non-prescription medications) as they apply to gastroenterological drug therapy management.
requirements: PHRX 4040 and4041; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Endocrine Module
description: Principles of pathophysiology, pharmacology, medicinal chemistry, clinical pharmacokinetics and pharmacotherapy (including both prescription and non-prescription medications) as they apply to endocrinologic drug therapy management.
requirements: PHRX 4040 and4041; open only School of Pharmacy students. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PHRX 5052.

name: Dermatology Module
description: Principles of pathophysiology, pharmacology, medicinal chemistry, clinical pharmacokinetics, and pharmacotherapy (including both prescription and non-prescription medications) as they apply to dermatologic drug therapy management.
requirements: PHRX 4041; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Pharmacy Practice Management
description: This course is designed to provide students with 1) and understanding of the core management principles used across pharmacy settings; 2) exposure to practical experiences on practice-specific management topics; 3) application of pharmacy practice management principles to “real-world” management challenges.
requirements: PHRX 3008 and3050; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Advanced Compounding
description: Advanced techniques and knowledge in prescription compounding will be applied to the preparation of extemporaneously prepared dosage forms that meet the needs of individual patients.
requirements: PHRX 4031; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Urban Service Track
description: An interprofessional program designed to develop future health professionals dedicated to caring for urban underserved populations and working in interprofessional teams. Open to UConn Urban Health Scholars only.
requirements: pen only to UConn Urban Health Scholars.

name: Advanced Clinical Concepts in Pain Management
description: Emphasis is placed on evaluation of the pain patient, the pharmacology of analgesics, adjuvant agents and interventional techniques for the treatment of pain such as patient controlled analgesia, nerve blocks, intrathecal pumps, and alternative therapies (relaxation, Reike therapy, hypnosis, acupuncture). The role of the pharmacist in acute and chronic pain management, palliative care and special populations (pediatrics, geriatrics) will be addressed. Regulatory issues and "hot topics" such as addiction issues in pain management, health disparities in pain care, and pain contracts will also be discussed.
requirements: PHRX 3040; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Developing Pharmacy Leaders
description: Provides training and experience in leadership skills to include  identifying personal strengths, envisioning change, team building and advocacy in the field of pharmacy.
requirements: pen only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Follow the Money: Impact of Payment Reform and Health Policy on Pharmacy Practice
description: Introductory course on the impact of health care delivery and payment reform on new practice opportunities for pharmacists. Topics include patient-centered medical homes, accountable care organizations, community health teams, population health, medication therapy management, value-based insurance design, and new reimbursement models to support pharmacists in direct patient care roles. A holistic view of these topics is examined from the consumer/patient, health care professional, payor, and health-system perspectives.

name: Leadership in Pharmacy
description: Second in a two-semester sequence for students in the LEADERS Track. Provides an introduction to effective leadership through an exploration of leadership styles and concepts and their application to various opportunities and challenges in pharmacy.

name: Organizational Dynamics for Corporate and Non Profit Leaders
description: Introduces pharmacy students to regional C-Suite healthcare executives. Showcases best-practice organizational and leadership dynamics found in corporate and boardroom settings, including meeting with healthcare executives to learn about their careers.  Discussions with C-Suite executives will illuminate behaviors, traits and skills needed to lead an organization. Roles and responsibilities of board of directors, organizational staff, and senior leadership will be explored. Through a simulated non-profit organization, students will apply corporate governance policies and parliamentary procedures to prepare them for leading meetings and organizations upon graduation.
requirements: pen only to students in the pharmacy program.

name: Healthcare Ethics and History
description: Introduction to healthcare ethics, engages students with an interest in treating patients in case-study practice scenarios allowing them to develop a working knowledge of ethical principles and render patient care decisions based upon ethical reasoning. Introduces ethical concepts and professional codes of ethics, and discusses the application of these concepts to contemporary examples of health care scenarios. Introduces the history of American healthcare, exploring the period from our nation's founding to the present. Introduces the theories of health and disease that have changed over time as has the role of healthcare professionals and the pharmaceutical industry.
requirements: pen to students in the School of Pharmacy. Recommended preparation: PHRX 3050.

name: Pharmacy Skills Development III
description: Reinforces the use of the pharmacists' patient care process and interprofessional practice competencies. Introduction to continuing professional development and interviewing skills. Students will develop patient care skills including, assessment of patient medication regimens, perform medication reconciliation, and accurate computation of pharmaceutical calculations essential to safe pharmacy practice. These activities will be applied in IPPE (Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experiences) at selected institutional pharmacy practice sites. Completion of community IPPE hours contributes toward one credit in this course.
requirements: HRX 3021 or3065; open to seniors in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Pharmacy Skills Development IV
description: Reinforces the use of the pharmacists' patient care process and interprofessional practice competencies. Reinforcing and applying skills learned in previous courses. Develops patient care skills including assessment of patient medication regimens of increasing complexity and diabetes device education for patients. Students will prepare to engage with pharmacy medication distribution processes, pharmacy informatics processes, patient safety, and professional networking. These activities will be applied in IPPE (Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experiences) at selected institutional pharmacy practice sites.
requirements: HRX 4020 or4063; open to seniors in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Cardiovascular Module
description: Principles of pathophysiology, pharmacology, medicinal chemistry, clinical pharmacokinetics and pharmacotherapy (including both prescription and non-prescription medications) as they apply to cardiovascular drug therapy management.
requirements: PHRX 4042 and4043; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Infectious Disease Module
description: Principles of pathophysiology, pharmacology, medicinal chemistry, clinical pharmacokinetics and pharmacotherapy (including both prescription and non-prescription medications) as they apply to infectious disease drug therapy management.
requirements: PHRX 5040,5063(or PHRX 5041 and 5042); Open only to students in the School of Pharmacy PharmD program.

name: Hematology/Oncology Module
description: Principles of pathophysiology, pharmacology, medicinal chemistry, clinical pharmacokinetics and pharmacotherapy (including both prescription and non-prescription medications) as they apply to hematologic/oncologic disorders drug therapy management.
requirements: PHRX 5040,5063(or PHRX 5041 and 5042); Open only to students in the School of Pharmacy PharmD program.

name: Special Populations
description: Development of knowledge and skills necessary to make appropriate, patient-population specific, pharmacotherapeutic contributions to patient care.
requirements: PHRX 3030,3040,4040,4041,4042,4043,4044,5040,5063(or 5041 and 5042); Open only to students in the School of Pharmacy PharmD program.

name: Clinical Toxicology
description: Introduction to acute toxicity in humans to common drugs, chemicals and household products. Physical and laboratory assessment of common poisonings including the development of clinical management plans for common poisonings and the prevention of poisoning.

name: Patient Assessment
description: Teaches and reinforces patient assessment skills essential in the provision of pharmaceutical care to patients. This includes application of medical literature as it applies to patient care.
requirements: PHRX 3003,3006,3007,3040,4040,4041,4042,4043,4044and4050; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Pediatric Pharmacotherapy
description: Extended therapeutic knowledge of common pediatric disease states and an understanding of some of the specific pharmacologic concerns in the pediatric population.
requirements: .S. in Pharmacy Studies.

name: Careers in Pharmacy
description: Survey of career options available to Pharm.D. graduates and the broad role of pharmacy graduates in healthcare. Exploration and self-examination of critical professional and personal factors that will contribute to greater career satisfaction.
requirements: .S. in Pharmacy Studies.

name: Pharmacotherapy of Diabetes Mellitus
description: To enhance students' perception of diabetes mellitus as a multi-organ disease and to provide the necessary skills to recognize challenges to management, analyze laboratory data, and apply evidence-based medicine to real-world practicalities when developing a therapeutic plan.
requirements: PHRX 4043; open only to Pharmacy students.

name: Pharmacy Skills Development V
description: Reinforces the use of the pharmacists' patient care process and interprofessional practice competencies. Develops patient care skills including medication reconciliation, use of point of care testing devices, smoking cessation, CPR recertification, and pain management. These activities will be applied in IPPE (Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experiences) at selected service learning clinics and Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience (APPE) practice sites. This is a Service Learning course designed to challenge students to gain a greater appreciation for the profession of pharmacy as it relates to their communities and societal needs. Students will have the opportunity to work in an interprofessional environment with other health profession students and providers to assist the student in developing professional attitudes, judgment, and skills needed to function as a team. Completion of institutional IPPE hours contributes toward one credit in this course.
requirements: PHRX 4065 or 4021; open to students in the Doctor of Pharmacy program.

name: Pharmacy Law and Regulatory Affairs
description: An examination of federal and Connecticut statutes, regulations, policies, executive orders, and court decisions (with comparative law analysis of certain other States' specific pharmacy laws, and discussion of federal and international treaties) that regulate the practice of pharmacy, including the mitigation of prescription drug abuse and diversion.
requirements: HRX 4051 or PHRX 4062; open to students in the Doctor of Pharmacy program.

name: Respiratory/Renal Module
description: Principles of pathophysiology, pharmacology, medicinal chemistry, clinical pharmacokinetics and pharmacotherapy (including both prescription and non-prescription medications) as they apply to respiratory and renal disorders drug therapy management.
requirements: PHRX 4042 and PHRX 4043; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy. Not open for credit to students who have passed PHRX 5041 or 5042.

name: Pharmacy Skills Development VI
description: Student's readiness for embarking on Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experiences and for working collaboratively on health care teams will be assessed. Service Learning in this course is designed to challenge students to gain a greater appreciation for the profession of pharmacy in relation to societal needs and the community. Students will work in an interprofessional environment with other health professional students and providers to develop professional attitudes, judgment, and skills needed to function as a team. Completion of simulation and service learning IPPE hours contributes toward one credit in this course.
requirements: PHRX 5060 or 5020 and 5047; open only to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Continuous Registration
description: Allows continuous registration in the professional pharmacy program while enrolled in the dual degree programs of PharmD/MBA and PharmD/MPH.
requirements: .S. in Pharmacy Studies.

name: Professional Experience in Community Pharmacy
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes in the provision of patient care in a community pharmacy. Gain the knowledge, skills, and attitudes necessary to efficiently fill prescriptions while focusing on patient safety, inter-professional communication and patient satisfaction. Required.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Health System Pharmacy
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes in the provision of pharmacy services in a health system pharmacy. Gain hands-on experience with operational and clinical duties of a staff pharmacist. Departmental workflow and interprofessional collaboration will be practiced. Required.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Ambulatory Care
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes in the provision of patient care in the ambulatory setting. Emphasis is on optimizing medication-related outcomes in patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration, and patient/caregiver education. Required.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in General Medicine
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of care to general medicine inpatients. Emphasis is on optimizing medication-related outcomes in patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration, and patient/caregiver education. Required.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Cardiology
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of care to patients with cardiac diseases. Emphasis is on optimizing medication-related outcomes in patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration, and patient/caregiver education. Direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Infectious Disease
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of care to patients with infectious diseases. Emphasis is on optimizing medication-related outcomes in patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration, and patient/caregiver education. Direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Oncology
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of care to patients with cancer. Emphasis is on optimizing medication-related outcomes in patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration, and patient/caregiver education. Direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Psychiatry
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of care to patients with psychiatric diseases. Emphasis is on optimizing medication-related outcomes in patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration, and patient/caregiver education. Direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Pediatrics
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of care to pediatric patients. Emphasis is on optimizing medication-related outcomes in patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration, and may include patient/caregiver education. Direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Geriatrics
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of care to geriatric patients. Emphasis is on optimizing medication-related outcomes in patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration, and patient/caregiver education. Direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Community Pharmacy II
description: Students apply knowledge, skills and attitudes in a unique community pharmacy setting. Examples of this type of practice include, but are not limited to, compounding and specialty pharmacy. Non-direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Critical Care
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of care to critically ill patients. Emphasis is on optimizing medication-related outcomes in patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration and may include patient/caregiver education. Direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Emergency Medicine
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of care to emergency medicine patients. Emphasis is on optimizing medication-related outcomes in patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration, and patient/caregiver education. Direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Home Health Care
description: The student will apply knowledge of pharmacy practice and skills in patient interaction to the provision of pharmaceutical care to patients in their homes. Emphasis is on optimization of medication-related outcomes in patients with common medical disorders served by home health care pharmacists, including medication assessment, efficacy and safety monitoring, and patient education.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Health System Pharmacy II
description: Applying knowledge, skills and attitudes in a focused area of pharmacy services in a health system pharmacy. Emphasis is on problem-solving and project work within specialized operations in a health systems pharmacy. Non-direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Industry
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the roles of pharmacists in the pharmaceutical industry. Non-direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Managed Care
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the practice of managed care pharmacy. Emphasis is on the development of strategies that optimize pharmacotherapy within the economic constraints of a managed care system. Non-direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Nuclear Pharmacy
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of patient care in a nuclear pharmacy. Emphasis is on hands-on instruction in radiation safety, radioisotope prescription processing, compounding, dispensing and providing pharmacist cognitive services. Non-direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Long-term Care
description: Applying knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of patient care in a long-term care pharmacy setting. Emphasis is on optimizing medication-related outcomes in patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration, and professional education as it relates to medication distribution in long-term care. Non-direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Surgery
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of care to surgical patients. Emphasis is on optimizing medication-related outcomes in patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration, and patient/caregiver education. Direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience In General Medicine II
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes in the provision of patient care in a unique general medicine inpatient setting. Emphasis is on continued development of optimizing medication-related outcomes in patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration, and patient/caregiver education. Direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Ambulatory Care II
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes in the provision of patient care in a unique ambulatory setting. Emphasis is on continued development of optimizing medication-related outcomes in patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration, and patient education. Direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Anticoagulation Service
description: Applying knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of care to patients with thrombotic disorders. Emphasis is on optimizing medication-related outcomes in patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration, and patient education. Direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Hospice Care
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes in the provision of care to patients in the final stage of terminal illness. Emphasis is on optimizing medication-related outcome in hospice patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration, and patient/caregiver education. Direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Clinical Toxicology
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of services to patients and caregivers requesting assistance in addressing both acute and chronic toxicity situations in various settings. Students will also participate in didactic sessions designed to increase their knowledge of toxicology. Non-direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Investigational Drug Service
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of service in investigational drugs. Emphasis is on the process of randomization, patient selection and documentation of study procedures. Non-direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Drug Information
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of drug information services in a variety of settings. Students will learn to follow site policies and procedures with respect to providing information subsequent to inquiries. Non-direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Pediatrics II
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of care to pediatric patients in a unique setting. Emphasis is on continued development of optimizing medication-related outcomes in patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration, and may include patient/caregiver education. Direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Industry II
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the roles of pharmacists in the pharmaceutical industry. Non-direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in a Professional Organization
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of service to a professional organization. Emphasis is on the provision of advocacy, communication and support for organization members. Non-direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience at Food and Drug Administration (FDA)
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes in a variety of settings within the Food and Drug Administration while learning about the regulatory process. Non-direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Oncology II
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes to the provision of care to patients with cancer in a unique setting or patient population. Emphasis is on optimizing medication-related outcomes in patients through medication therapy management, interprofessional collaboration, and patient/caregiver education. Direct patient care.
requirements: HRX 5047 or PHRX 5065; open to students in the School of Pharmacy.

name: Professional Experience in Psychiatry II
description: The student will apply knowledge, skills and attitudes in the provision of patient care in a unique psychiatric setting.
