description: Foundations of modern systems that produce the majority of food calories consumed in North America and other developed countries. Benefits and environmental risks associated with modern food production systems. Alternative food production systems and sustainability. Local food production and food security. Food production and climate change.

name: Turfgrass Management
description: An overview of turfgrass adaptation, selection, and management. Topics include turfgrass growth, physiology, soil interactions, establishment, and maintenance. Cultural system practices for lawns, golf courses, athletic fields, and other turf areas. Turfgrass pest management practices for weeds, insects and diseases.
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing SAPL 315.

name: Turfgrass Management Laboratory
description: Grass establishment, grass identification, athletic field turfgrass playability evaluations, soil testing, turfgrass pest identification, turfgrass pest monitoring techniques and fertilizer spreader and sprayer calibration.
requirements: SAPL 110, which may be taken concurrently.

name: Introduction to Plant Science
description: A general course designed to give students a broad view of the field of horticulture as well as a working knowledge of the fundamentals of plant growth.

name: Introduction to the Horticulture of Cannabis
description: Fundamentals of the production cycle of Cannabis including horticultural management, identification of crop issues, elite feminized seed production, seed propagation, vegetative propagation, pruning, training, optimization of cannabinoid content and post-harvest handling. Overviews of Cannabis business operations world-wide and in Connecticut, exploring lab testing procedures, cannabidiol extraction technologies, the Connecticut medical marijuana program and government regulation of the industry. Taught with PLSC 2130.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SAPL 120.

name: The Great American Lawn: History, Culture and Sustainability
description: The largest irrigated crop in the U.S. is located right outside your window. Examines the health, social, cultural, and environmental impacts of one of America's greatest obsessions. Taught with PLSC 1060.

name: Golf Course Management
description: Discussion of the specialized field of golf course management. Topics: cultural techniques including soil aeration, topdressing, mowing, and thatch removal; grass or species selection, fertilization, irrigation, personnel, golf course pest management and equipment and inventory management. Field trips required.

name: Landscape Architecture: Graphics I - Design Drawing
description: Knowledge and theory of graphic representation, exploration of landscape, design, and materials. Introduction to basic design principles. Application of graphic and design theory through free-hand drawing in a studio environment.
requirements: ot open to students who have completed LAND 2110.

name: Principles of Turfgrass Irrigation Systems
description: Turfgrass irrigation systems, principles of hydraulics, irrigation components, design, installation and repair.  Students will design irrigation systems for various turf areas.  Field trips and fieldwork will be required. Taught with PLSC 3300.

name: Professional Development for Turfgrass Industries
description: Topics include human resource information, communication skills, turfgrass pesticide laws and compliance, labor laws and compliance, bid specifications, resume writing, interviewing, golf course management structures, business ethics, and benefits of professional association membership. Guest lecturers include industry professionals and representatives. Taught with SPSS 3400.

name: Introduction to Soil Science
description: Physical and chemical properties of soils; nature and use of fertilizer and lime materials; management of soils for crop production including soil testing, tillage and fertilization practices, and conservation practices.
requirements: ay not be taken out of sequence after passing SAPL 315.

name: Advanced Turfgrass Management
description: Effects of environmental stresses and turfgrass management practices on growth, development and physiology of turfgrasses. Implementation of proper management practices to promote optimal turfgrass health under stress conditions. Taught with PLSC 3150.
requirements: SAPL 110 and300.

name: Woody Plants: Common Trees, Shrubs and Vines
description: Taxonomy, identification, ornamental characteristics, cultural requirements and landscape use of deciduous and evergreen woody plants most often utilized in landscapes of the northeastern United States and similar environs.
requirements: SAPL 120.

name: Herbaceous Ornamental Plants
description: Identification, nomenclature, cultural requirements and landscape uses of herbaceous perennials, ornamental grasses, ferns, annuals and bulbs. Study of live plants is required.

name: Small Fruit Production
description: The commercial production of small fruits and grapes in the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic regions including varieties, fruit-growing systems and pruning, site requirements, harvesting methods, post-harvest requirements, marketing, pest complexes and IPM strategies of the major berry crops.

name: Principles and Concepts of Agroecology
description: Application of ecological processes to modern agricultural production practices. Crops and their environment. Soil quality and maintenance of soil productivity. Sustainability of agroecosystems.

name: Floral Art
description: The study of flower arrangement as an art form with emphasis on historical background, artistic principles, color harmony, and care of perishable media. Individual expression is encouraged in the creation of floral composition.

name: Garden Center Management
description: Techniques and concepts essential in managing and operating a garden center. Topics include goal setting, retailing, finance, business planning and pricing.

name: Urban Plant Systems: Construction and Maintenance
description: Technical information on the effective construction and maintenance of planted systems. Structural and functional components of plant systems. Provision of ecosystem services. Overviews of a wide spectrum of planted systems including streetscaping, green roofs and green walls, rain gardens and bioretention, and phytoremediation systems. Techniques of soil modification. Plant selection. Establishment and maintenance of woody and herbaceous plants: planting, preservation, pruning, mulching, irrigation, and fertilization. Taught with PLSC 3550.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SAPL 120,410,430. Not open for credit to students who have passed SAPL 740.

name: Indoor Plants and Interiorscaping
description: Taxonomy, identification, ornamental characteristics, cultural requirements and use of tropical plants. Principles of interiorscaping in the home, office, public buildings, and related locations.

name: Vegetable Production
description: Fundamentals of soil management and crop plant husbandry as applied to commercial vegetable production and home gardening. Horticultural principles of crop growth. Focus is on sustainable practices. Field laboratory will consist of field trips (some outside designated laboratory time) during the early part of the semester to organic and conventional farms to observe production and marketing practices. Field trips required.

name: Plant Propagation
description: Theory and practice in sexual and asexual propagation of horticultural plants, emphasizing the anatomical, physiological, and ecological principles involved. Laboratories provide practical experience with seeds, division, cuttings, budding, grafting, layering and tissue culture.

name: Nursery Production
description: Priniciples of field and container production of nursery stock.  Emphasis on production practices for woody nursery stock from propagation to sales.

name: Greenhouse Technology and Operations
description: Introduction to greenhouse crop management with emphasis on structures, environmental control systems, and management techniques used to control crop response.
requirements: SAPL 120.

name: Greenhouse Management Field Study
description: Students will be introduced to greenhouse crop production techniques and methodologies. Course follows a travel-course format, in which students participate in regularly scheduled field trips to commercial greenhouse operations in Connecticut and neighboring states. Students will make observations on the mechanical systems, management considerations, and crop production practices employed by commercial businesses.
requirements: SAPL 670, which may be taken concurrently.

name: Advanced Cannabis Horticulture
description: Advanced concepts of Cannabis production, management, processing and product development that build upon SAPL 130. Students will choose highly focused study of either indoor controlled environment production or outdoor cultivation of Cannabis for part of the course. Taught with PLSC 3680.
requirements: SAPL 130 or PLSC 2130 or permission of instructor.

name: Plant Pest Control
description: A practical survey of practices used for insect, disease and weed pests of turf, flowers, shrubs, trees and food crops. Consideration will be given to quarantine, mechanical, biological and chemical means of control. Field trips may be required.

name: Integrated Pest Management
description: Principles of integrated pest management covering insect, disease, and weed problems with emphasis on turfgrass, ornamentals, and greenhouse production. Environmental impacts and pest control strategies will be covered.
requirements: APL 800 or810.

name: Internship
description: Students will work with professionals in an area of their interest. Written reports, daily logs, and/or evaluations by professional supervisors may be required. Open to qualified students with consent of advisor and Department Head.

name: Special Topics
description: Total credits allowed toward graduation requirements are restricted as outlined in Ratcliffe Hicks Section.

name: Independent Study
description: An independent study project is mutually arranged between a student and an instructor. Total credits allowed toward graduation requirements are restricted as outlined in the Ratcliffe Hicks section of the Undergraduate Catalog.

name: Special Topics
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Independent Study
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Introduction to Political Theory
description: Major themes of political theory such as justice, obligation, and equality, and their relevance to contemporary political concerns. CA 1.

name: Introduction to Comparative Politics
description: A survey of institutions, politics, and ideologies in democratic and non-democratic states. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: Introduction to Nonwestern Politics
description: A survey of institutions, ideologies, development strategies, and the political processes in nonwestern culture. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: Career Development for Political Science Majors
description: Introduction to potential careers for political science majors, the steps that professionals working in those careers took to gain employment, and the skills that professionals developed to excel in those careers.

name: Introduction to Research in Political Science
description: The process, objectives, and methods of research in political science.

name: Introduction to International Relations
description: The nature and problems of international politics. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: Introduction to International Relations
description: The nature and problems of international politics. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: Introduction to American Politics
description: Analysis of the organization and operation of the American political system. CA 2.

name: Introduction to American Politics
description: Analysis of the organization and operation of the American political system. CA 2.

name: Introduction to Research
description: Introduction to research and research methods in political science.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: Classical and Medieval Political Theory
description: An examination of Greek, Roman and early Judeo-Christian political ideas and institutions, and their relevance to the present. Formerly offered as POLS 3002.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Modern Political Theory
description: Major political doctrines of the modern period up through the end of the 19th century, and their influence upon political movements and institutions as they are reflected in the democratic and nondemocratic forms of government. Formerly offered as POLS 3012.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Transatlantic Contemporary Political Theory
description: Major political writings from 1900 to the present. Formerly offered as POLS 3017.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Political Theory in Film
description: Exploration of political theoretical questions through essays and films. CA 1. CA 4-INT.
requirements: ecommended preparation: POLS 1002.

name: Privacy in the Information Age
description: Honors course providing a thematic overview of privacy from a variety of disciplinary perspectives. Public policy, legal and ethical debates surrounding privacy and the impact of technology and scientific advances on how privacy is conceptualized, valued, enacted, and protected.

name: Privacy in the Information Age
description: Provides a thematic overview of privacy from a variety of disciplinary perspectives. Public policy, legal and ethical debates surrounding privacy and the impact of technology and scientific advances on how privacy is conceptualized, valued, enacted, and protected.

name: Politics of Oil
description: Historical and contemporary role of oil in comparative politics and international relations. CA 2.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; Recommended preparation: POLS 1202 or1207.

name: Comparative Social Policy
description: Institutional structures of modern welfare states, including systems of social insurance, healthcare, and education. Assessment of leading political explanations for their growth and cross-national differences among them. Formerly offered as POLS 3214.
requirements: POLS 1202 or1207or instructor consent; open to sophomores or higher.

name: Introduction to Government and Politics in the Middle East and North Africa
description: The politics of the contemporary Middle East. Topics may include state formation, authoritarianism, democratization, and the Arab Spring uprising. Taught in English. CA 2. CA 4-INT.
requirements: ecommended preparation: POLS 1202.

name: Introduction to Government and Politics in the Middle East and North Africa
description: The politics of the contemporary Middle East. Topics may include state formation, authoritarianism, democratization, and the Arab Spring uprising. Taught in English. CA 2. CA 4-INT.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: POLS 1202.

name: Political Institutions and Behavior in Western Europe
description: Comparative analysis of the governments and politics of Western Europe.

name: Latin American Politics
description: Theories and institutions of Latin American politics, with emphasis on issues of stability and change. Formerly offered as POLS 3235.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Chinese Politics and Economy
description: Chinese political structure and policymaking process, attempts at democratization, process and outcome of economic reforms, development challenges in contemporary China. Formerly offered as POLS 3245.
requirements: pen only to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: a 1000-level course in Economics.

name: Politics In Africa
description: (Also offered as AFRA 2252.) The political systems in contemporary Africa; the background of the slave trade, imperialism, colonialism, and the present concerns of nationalism, independence, economic development and military rule. Emphasis on sub-Saharan Africa. Formerly offered as AFRA 3252 and POLS 3252.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Political Violence
description: The forms, causes, and consequences of political violence including terrorism, insurgency, and civil war. Addresses why individuals and groups take up arms; how and why nonstate actors employ specific strategies of violence; how states fight back; and how conflicts end. Formerly offered as POLS 3429.
requirements: ecommended preparation: POLS 1202 or1402.

name: Nuclear Security
description: The development of nuclear weapons and their consequences. Topics include the science and history of nuclear weapons, as well as nuclear proliferation, terrorism, and strategy.
requirements: ecommended preparation: POLS 1402.

name: Maritime Politics
description: (Also offered as MAST 2460 E.) The political dimensions of the world’s oceans. This course draws upon international relations theories to analyze states, international law, intergovernmental organizations, trade, and non-state actors with respect to the world's largest bodies of water. CA 2.

name: Making the Modern American Presidency
description: Developments in the presidency from the constitutional era through President Hoover.
requirements: ecommended preparation: POLS 1602.

name: Modern American Presidency
description: Developments in the presidency from President Franklin Roosevelt to the present.
requirements: ecommended preparation: POLS 1602 and 3600.

name: Religion and Politics in America
description: The interaction and relationship between religion and politics in the U.S. political system. CA 4.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: POLS 1602.

name: American Political Parties
description: An analysis of the aims, organization, and growth of parties in the United States.
requirements: POLS 1602.

name: American Political Parties
description: An analysis of the aims, organization, and growth of parties in the United States.
requirements: POLS 1602; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Politics of Inequality
description: Relationship between democracy and inequality. Economic inequality and its causes, poverty, public opinion, inequalities in political voice and representation, public policy, the role of money in politics. Formerly offered as POLS 3618.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: State and Local Government
description: The practical working of democracy and the role of state and local governments.

name: Legal Reasoning and Writing
description: Simulation of the "Moot Court" experience. Students will develop legal writing and oral argumentation skills in relation to hypothetical appellate cases about free speech, religion, rights of the accused, separation of powers, and equal protection claims.

name: Women and the Law
description: (Also offered as WGSS 2807.) The development of constitutional and statutory standards for treatment of women under the law in the United States.

name: Women and the Law
description: (Also offered as WGSS 2807 W.) The development of constitutional and statutory standards for treatment of women under the law in the United States.

name: Criminal Justice in Practice
description: Exploration of the American Criminal Justice system through simulations, interactions with practitioners in the field, visits to institutions within the system, and service projects with organizations working within the system.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Not open for credit to students who have passed POLS 2998 Wwhen offered as Criminal Justice in Practice.

name: Quantitative Analysis in Political Science
description: Explanation of the quantitative methods used in political science. Application of these methods for the analysis of substantive political questions. Formerly offered as POLS 2072Q.
requirements: ecommended preparation: High School Algebra II and a mathematics course.

name: Advanced Quantitative Methods in Political Science
description: Explanation of advanced quantitative methods used in political science. Application of these methods and relevant statistical software for the analysis of substantive political questions. Formerly offered as POLS 2073Q.
requirements: POLS 2972 Qor STAT 1000 Qor SOCI 3211 Qor equivalent.

name: Special Topics in Political Issues
description: An exploration of political issues at the national and international levels.

name: Directed Research I
description: Faculty-directed investigation of a research topic in political science.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: Variable Topics in Contemporary Political Issues
description: An exploration of contemporary political issues at the national and international levels. May be repeated for credit with a change in subject matter.

name: Variable Topics in Contemporary Political Issues
description: An exploration of contemporary political issues at the national and international levels. May be repeated for credit with a change in subject matter.

name: Black Political Thought
description: Exploration of black U.S., Caribbean, and African political thought, with a focus on processes of and resistance to racialization, enslavement, and colonization.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011, open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1002 and AFRA 2211.

name: Western Marxist Tradition
description: Exploration of the social and political theories of Marx and Engels, and of later interpretations and modifications of their ideas.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Political Theory and Popular Music
description: Exploration of political theories and their relationships to contemporary popular musical genres including folk, hip-hop, pop, reggae, and rock. Students will conduct original analyses connecting political theories to contemporary popular music genres and artists.
requirements: ecommended Preparation: POLS 1002 or 3012/W. Not open for credit to students who have passed POLS 2998 when offered as “Political Theory and Popular Music.”

name: Historical Women Political Thinkers
description: (Also offered as WGSS 3027 W.) Critical study of the writings of several historical women political thinkers.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011, open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1002.

name: American Political Thought and Ideology
description: American political thought from the colonial to the contemporary period. Political thought discussed as the ideological expression of the larger sociopolitical situation.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Power, Politics and Art
description: A study of power and politics through a survey of major political ideologies and their expression in art and architecture, in various past and present cultures, both as a means of political socialization and a tool of resistance and protest. CA 4-INT.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Theories of Human Rights
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3042.) Various theories of human rights, both historical and contemporary. Conceptual arguments both in favor and critical of the theory and practice of human rights will be considered, with literature taken primarily from philosophy and political theory.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Democratic Theory
description: Survey of theories of democracy from classical times to the present; analysis of defenders and critics of democracy.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1002, 3002 or 3012.

name: Political Protest and Ideology
description: Variants of major ideologies such as liberalism, socialism, communism, anarchism, fascism, and feminism in their socio-historical context, as well as alternative visions from the Third World.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Critical Race Theory as Political Theory
description: (Also offered as AMST 3082.) Interdisciplinary scholarship on racial identity, legal decisions, and political action from the perspective of political science and political theory. Topics include interactions between states and social movements, the intersections of race, class, gender, and membership, and the problems with both post-racialism and identity politics.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1002.

name: Comparative Political Parties and Electoral Systems
description: A focus on political party and electoral systems around the world, including advanced industrial nations, transitional nations, and less developed nations.  Issues such as the relationship between electoral and party systems, democratic reform, voting behavior, and organization of political parties are examined.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Comparative Political Parties and Electoral Systems
description: A focus on political party and electoral systems around the world, including advanced industrial nations, transitional nations, and less developed nations. Issues such as the relationship between electoral and party systems, democratic reform, voting behavior, and organization of political parties are examined.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Environmental Policy and Institutions
description: (Also offered as PP 3203.) Development of environmental policies and institutions and their effects on the motivations and the actions of individuals and groups with implications for questions of equity, justice, and sustainability. Draws on approaches from comparative politics, public policy, and international relations.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Voting Behavior and Public Opinion Around the World
description: How voting behavior differs across countries. Topics may include turnout, class voting, the electoral role of religion, accountability for the economy, vote buying, ethnic politics, attitudes toward welfare, support for democracy, and anti-Americanism.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1202 or POLS 1207.

name: Comparative Political Economy
description: Introduction to overlapping themes in economics and political science including the substantive and emperical relationship between these two in advanced industrial democracies.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Sustainable Energy in the 21st Century
description: (Also offered as ENGR 3209 E, HRTS 3209 E.) Political, socioeconomic, environmental, science and engineering challenges of energy sources; comparison of feasibility and sustainability of energy policies around the world.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Comparative Perspectives on Human Rights
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3212.) Cultural difference and human rights in areas of legal equality, women's rights, political violence, criminal justice, religious pluralism, global security, and race relations.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Women in Political Development
description: (Also offered as WGSS 3216.) How women and gender circumscribe political life and generate relationships of inequality and justice on a global scale.   Topics may include conflict and security, development, human rights and legal systems, labor and migration, nation building, political economy, and transnational justice.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher, others by consent.

name: Politics of Russia and the Former Soviet Union
description: The social and political structure of the former Soviet Union, the causes and outcome of efforts to reform it, and the development of democratic politics in Russia and other former Soviet republics.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Gender Politics and Islam
description: (Also offered as WGSS 3249.) Construction of gender in Islamic texts and history, the religion's interaction with other patriarchal cultures and systems, western interventions and their impact, male leaders' reform efforts, women's movements.

name: The Political Economy of East Asia
description: Economic, political, and social development of East Asia. CA 2.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: 1000-level courses in political science and economics.

name: The Political Economy of East Asia
description: Economic, political, and social development of East Asia. CA 2.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: 1000-level courses in political science and economics.

name: Politics and Human Rights in Global Supply Chains
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3256.) Political and human rights implications of regulating contemporary global supply chains: official regulatory frameworks; non-regulatory approaches to rule-making (such as voluntary corporate codes of conduct and industry standards); social responses to the dilemmas of "ethical" sourcing of goods and services.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1202 and1402and POLS/ HRTS 3212.

name: Politics and Human Rights in Global Supply Chains
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3256 W.) Political and human rights implications of regulating contemporary global supply chains: official regulatory frameworks; non-regulatory approaches to rule-making (such as voluntary corporate codes of conduct and industry standards); social responses to the dilemmas of "ethical" sourcing of goods and services.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011, open to Political Science and Human Rights majors and minors; open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1202, POLS 1402 and POLS/ HRTS 3212.

name: Contemporary International Politics
description: Problems in international relations with emphasis on changing characteristics of international politics.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Globalization and Political Change
description: Origins and contested definitions of globalization, and its impact on national, regional and international institutions and political processes. Designed for upper-level undergraduate students with a solid grounding in comparative politics and international relations.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Globalization and Political Change
description: Origins and contested definitions of globalization, and its impact on national, regional and international institutions and political processes. Designed for upper-level undergraduate students with a solid grounding in comparative politics and international relations.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Political Science Fiction
description: International relations theory and speculative fiction as interpretations and interrogations of war, peace, politics, knowledge, and imagination. Formerly offered as POLS 3710.

name: International Political Economy
description: Politics of international economic relations: trade, finance, foreign direct investment, aid.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Global Environmental Politics
description: (Also offered as EVST 3412.) Politics of how humans and natural systems interact. Managing the global environment, regulating resource commons, and coordinating to solve environmental problems.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: International Security
description: Theory and practice of international security. Topics include why groups use terrorism, why states go to war, the emergence of humanitarian intervention, and the role of technology ranging from nuclear weapons to computer viruses. CA 2.
requirements: ecommended preparation: POLS 1402.

name: International Security
description: Theory and practice of international security. Topics include why groups use terrorism, why states go to war, the emergence of humanitarian intervention, and the role of technology ranging from nuclear weapons to computer viruses. CA 2.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: POLS 1402.

name: National and International Security
description: Key American national security issues as integral parts of the larger problem of global security.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: International Organizations and Law
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3418.) The role of intergovernmental and nongovernmental organizations and international law in world affairs with special attention to contemporary issues.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: International Organizations and Law
description: The role of intergovernmental and nongovernmental organizations and international law in world affairs with special attention to contemporary issues.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Politics, Propaganda, and Cinema
description: Lectures and films from several nations serve to illustrate techniques and effects of propaganda, analyzing the pervasive impact that propaganda has on our lives. The course concentrates on the World War II era.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: The Politics of Torture
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3428.) Examination of the usage of torture by state and non-state actors. Questions include, "Why is torture perpetrated?" "What domestic and international legal frameworks and issues related to the use of torture?" "How effective are existing legal prohibitions and remedies?" "Who tortures?" and "How does torture affect transitional justice?"
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Evaluating Human Rights Practices of Countries
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3430.) Examination of the ways in which governments, businesses, NGOs, IGOs, and scholars assess which human rights are being respected by governments of the world. Hands-on experience in rating the level of government respect for human rights in countries around the world.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Honors Core: Excavating the International in Everyday Practices
description: Examination of daily international practices utilizing an everyday objects lens, with attention to ethical implications for activism, change, and social justice.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: POLS 1402.

name: Recent American Diplomacy
description: The foreign relations of the United States from the first World War to the present.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Gender and War
description: (Also offered as WGSS 3440.) Gender aspects of war. Masculinities and militaries; gender-based war violence; laws of war and post-war conditions for male and female soldiers and civilians. Formerly offered as POLS 3247 and WGSS 3247.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: The Politics of American Foreign Policy
description: Instructions, forces and processes in the making of American foreign policy. Emphasis will be on contemporary issues.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: War and Technological Change
description: Exploration of how technological developments affect the causes, conduct, and outcomes of war.
requirements: ecommended preparation: POLS 1402.

name: International Relations of the Middle East
description: The foreign policies and security problems of Middle Eastern States; sources of regional conflict and competition - oil, water, borders, religion, ideology, alliances, geopolitics, refugees, and superpower intervention.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Arab-Israeli Conflict
description: Political relations between Arabs and Israelis with an emphasis on war and diplomacy.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Arab-Israeli Conflict
description: Political relations between Arabs and Israelis with an emphasis on war and diplomacy.

name: The Presidency and Congress
description: The contemporary Presidency and its interactions with the Congress in the formation of public policy.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Congressional Apportionment and Redistricting
description: Empirical analyses and reporting of research on these fundamental democratic processes. CA 2.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: POLS 1602; POLS 2072Q or STAT 1000 Qor STAT 1100 Q.

name: Congress in Theory and Practice
description: In-depth analysis of the U.S. Congress, including representation, elections, policy formation, law making, and organization.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: How to Fix an Election: The Politics of Election Administration in the United States
description: An analysis of the politics of election administration. Topics include: the roles of state and local governments; the participation of candidates, political parties, and voters; convenience-voting options, new technologies, voter turnout, and voter errors; redistricting; voter suppression and voter fraud; and prospects for reform.
requirements: POLS 1602.

name: The Art, Science, and Business of Political Campaigns
description: An analysis of strategy, communications, fundraising, and voter mobilization in contemporary political campaigns.
requirements: POLS 1602.

name: American Politics in Film
description: An examination of films that describe the development of American political institutions, norms, and values; that portray the processes exhibited in contemporary political institutions or the behaviors that characterize modern-day politicians; or that interpret recurring clashes in American politics. CA 2.
requirements: POLS 1602, and ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Electoral Behavior
description: Explaining elections and the basis for voters' decisions.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Congressional Elections
description: Campaign organization, strategy, and election outcomes in Congressional elections. Topics include candidates and nominations, the roles of political parties and interest groups, campaign communications, campaign finance, and electoral reform.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher; freshmen and sophomores by permission. Recommended preparation: POLS 1602.

name: American Political Economy
description: Theoretical foundations of the American political economy. Examination of selected public policy issues, including interaction between economic factors and incentives, and democratic institutions and processes.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: American Political Leadership
description: Study of American political leadership as it relates to political culture, institutions and democratic principles.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Public Opinion
description: (Also offered as PP 3030.) Concepts, theories, structure, and substance of public opinion.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Public Opinion
description: (Also offered as PP 3030 W.) Concepts, theories, structure, and substance of public opinion.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Connecticut State and Municipal Politics
description: An examination of contemporary Connecticut politics on the state and municipal levels.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Connecticut General Assembly
description: Study of the state's legislative process through readings, discussions, and field work.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher; cumulative GPA of 2.8 or higher. Corequisite: POLS 3991 offered as "CGA Legislative Internship."

name: Urban Politics
description: (Also offered as URBN 3632.) Political systems and problems confronting urban governments.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Urban Politics
description: (Also offered as URBN 3632 W.) Political systems and problems confronting urban governments.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Race and Policy
description: (Also offered as PP 3033, AFRA 3033.) Examination of contemporary public policy through the lens of race.

name: African-American Politics
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3642.) Political behavior, theory, and ideology of African-Americans, with emphasis on contemporary U.S. politics. CA 4.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Black Leadership and Civil Rights
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3647.) Black leadership, emphasizing the principles, goals, and strategies used by African-American men and women to secure basic citizenship rights during the civil rights era.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Politics and Ethics
description: Relationship between power and ethics in political life.  Examination of ethical perspectives on political decisions and issues. Formerly offered as POLS 3850.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Black Feminist Politics
description: (Also offered as WGSS 3652, AFRA 3652.) An introduction to major philosophical and theoretical debates at the core of black feminist thought, emphasizing the ways in which interlocking systems of oppression uphold and sustain each other.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Latino Political Behavior
description: (Also offered as LLAS 3270.) Latino politics in the United States. Political histories of four different Latino populations: Mexican, Puerto Rican, Cuban and Central American. Different forms of political expressions, ranging from electoral behavior to political art. CA 4.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Puerto Rican Politics and Culture
description: (Also offered as LLAS 3667.) Legal and political history of the relationship between Puerto Rico and the United States with an emphasis on the question of United States empire and the politics of cultural resistance.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: LGBTQ+ Politics in the United States
description: (Also offered as WGSS 3670.) A brief history of the LGBTQ+ population in the United States and an understanding of how members of that community engage in the political process.
requirements: ecommended Preparation: ENGL 1010, POLS 1602, WGSS 2250; Recommended for upper-level students. Not open for credit to students who have passed POLS 2998 when offered as "LGBTQ+ Politics in the US."

name: Women and Politics
description: (Also offered as WGSS 3052.) An introduction to feminist thought, the study of women as political actors, the feminist movement and several public policy issues affecting women.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Practicum in Campaigns and Elections in the United States
description: Study of and skill-development to effectively participate in U.S. political campaigns and elections.
requirements: POLS 1602, and one of POLS 2607,2622,3603WQ,3604,3606,3608,3612,3613, or 3625/ PP 3030, or instructor consent.

name: Constitutional Law
description: The role of the Supreme court in expounding and developing the United States Constitution. Topics include judicial review, separation of powers, federalism, and due process.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Constitutional Rights and Liberties
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3807, AMST 3807.) The role of the Supreme Court in interpreting the Bill of Rights. Topics include freedoms of speech and religion, criminal due process, and equal protection.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Judiciary in the Political Process
description: The Supreme Court in the Political Process.
requirements: POLS 1602; open to juniors or higher.

name: United States Constitutional Dictatorships
description: An evaluation of America’s founding Constitution as an anti-democratic text that can be interpreted to enable a dictatorship. Political theories and constitutional interpretations of democracy and dictatorship. Examination of case studies that document how dictatorial interpretations of the Constitution have been used to legitimate the oppression of various groups of people, including women and people of color.

name: Law and Society
description: Leading schools of legal thought, fundamental principles and concepts of law, the basic framework of legal institutions, and judicial procedure.  Particular attention is devoted to the general features of American law as it affects the citizen, and primary emphasis is placed on the function of law as a medium for attaining a balance of social interests in a politically organized society.
requirements: pen only to juniors or higher. When students intend to take several courses in the Judicial Process field, it is recommended that 3817 be taken first.

name: Law and Popular Culture
description: (Also offered as AMST 3822.) Exploration of themes in the study of law and courts by contrasting scholarly work against representations of such themes in movies, televisions, and other media of popular culture.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Law and Popular Culture
description: (Also offered as AMST 3822 W.) Exploration of themes in the study of law and courts by contrasting scholarly work against representations of such themes in movies, televisions, and other media of popular culture.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Politics of Crime and Justice
description: Criminal justice in the United States, with emphasis on the links between law, politics, and administration.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Maritime Law
description: (Also offered as MAST 3832.) International and domestic legal concepts concerning jurisdiction in a maritime setting.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Immigration and Transborder Politics
description: (Also offered as LLAS 3271, AMST 3271.) U.S. immigration policy, trans-border politics, and the impact diasporas and ethnic lobbies have on U.S. foreign policy, with emphasis on Latino diasporas.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Public Administration
description: The politics of public administration. Role of administrative agencies and officials in American national, state, and local governments.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: The Policy-making Process
description: Introduction to the study of policy analysis. Consideration of description and prescriptive models of policy-making. Examination of several substantive areas of national policy in the United States.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Politics, Society, and Education Policy
description: Analysis of interactions among educational policy, politics, and other social forces. Insights and concerns from politics and other social sciences disciplines applied to different levels and types of schooling.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Supervised Field Work
description: Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Department Head required, normally to be granted before the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.

name: Directed Research II
description: Faculty-directed investigation of a research topic in political science.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: Independent Study
description: Open only with consent of instructor and department head.

name: Political Science Colloquium
description: Faculty research presentations demonstrating current topics of investigation within the department, literature review skills, and research design techniques. Recommended for sophomore and junior Honors students who are beginning their thesis research. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: nstructor consent. Recommended preparation: recommended for sophomore or junior Honors students.

name: Senior Seminar
description: Required for students in the Honors Program. Weekly seminar on selected topics in political science. Students must complete this course prior to their final semester.
requirements: POLS 4894; open only to juniors or higher; instructor consent required.

name: Senior Thesis
description: All honors students writing an honors thesis in Political Science must take this course in each of their last two semesters.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to junior or higher Honors students.

name: Elementary Portuguese I
description: Development of ability to communicate in Portuguese, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic survival needs within a cultural setting.

name: Elementary Portuguese II
description: Development of ability to communicate in Portuguese, orally and in writing, to satisfy basic survival needs within a cultural setting.

name: Intermediate Portuguese I
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Lusophone world.
requirements: PORT 1102 or equivalent.

name: Intermediate Portuguese II
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills within a cultural setting. Readings to enhance cultural awareness of the Lusophone world.
requirements: PORT 1103 or equivalent.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Department Head required, normally before the student's departure.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Department Head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: Special Topics
description: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Variable Topics
description: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: General Psychology I
description: Basic principles that underlie mental processes and behavior; research methodology, biopsychology, sensation, perception, learning, memory and language. Ordinarily this course should be taken in the fall semester. CA 3.

name: General Psychology II
description: Psychology as a social science. Research methodology, developmental, personality, clinical, abnormal and social psychology. CA 2.
requirements: PSYC 1100. PSYC 1101 and1103may not both be taken for credit.

name: General Psychology II (Enhanced)
description: Psychology as a social science. Research methodology, developmental, personality, clinical, abnormal and social psychology. Applications of theory, writing, and demonstrations during discussion periods. CA 2.
requirements: PSYC 1100; Not open for credit to students who have passed PSYC 1101. May not be taken concurrently with PSYC 1101.

name: Principles of Research in Psychology
description: Design, analysis, and reporting of psychological research. Experimental and quasi-experimental designs, laboratory and correlational techniques, research ethics.
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103; STAT 1000 Qor1100Qor Statistics Q 1000 level. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PSYC 3250,3251, 3450, 3550, 3551,3552, or 3899.

name: Principles of Research in Psychology
description: Design, analysis, and reporting of psychological research. Experimental and quasi-experimental designs, laboratory and correlational techniques, research ethics.
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103; STAT 1000 Qor1100Qor STAT Q 1000 level; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. May not be taken out of sequence after passing PSYC 3250,3251, 3450,3550W, 3551W, or 3552.

name: Introduction to Multicultural Psychology
description: General introduction to cross-cultural and multicultural issues and the role psychology has played in understanding the experiences of diverse groups. CA 4.
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103.

name: Psychology of Human Sexuality
description: Sexuality from across psychological science, highlighting relevant theoretical perspectives, methodology, and empirical research.
requirements: ecommended preparation: PSYC 1100.

name: Physiological Psychology
description: Physiological processes related to motivation, emotion, sensory processes, motor skills, learning, and psychiatric conditions.

name: Drugs And Behavior
description: An overview of drug effects on chemical transmission in the nervous system, with an emphasis on the behavioral/psychological effects of drugs.
requirements: PSYC 1100 or BIOL 1107.

name: Sensory Systems Neuroscience
description: Cellular, circuit, and neural systems basis of sensation and perception including evolutionary and ecological differences among mammals.
requirements: PSYC 1100 or BIOL 1107 or BIOL 1108.

name: Learning and Memory: From Brain to Behavior
description: Neurobiological basis of learning and memory, including topics in genetics, evolution and ethology.
requirements: PSYC 1100 or BIOL 1107 or1108. Recommended preparation: PSYC 2200.

name: Psychological Disorders
description: Nature of psychological disorders, theories and data regarding symptoms, etiology, treatment and prevention of mental health disorders.
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103.

name: The Study of Personality
description: Theories, methods, and research in both clinical and experimental approaches to personality.
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103.

name: Developmental Psychology
description: Social behavior, personality, perception, cognition, language, intelligence, learning, biobehavioral processes, and research methodology in developmental perspective.
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103.

name: Learning
description: Learning and memory principles found in animal research and their relationship to human behavior. Human and other species' specific types of unique learning abilities.
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103.

name: Cognitive Psychology
description: Different views of mental representation and processes involved in memory, language comprehension, perception, attention, and problem solving. Historical development of models in cognitive psychology.
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103.

name: Science of Learning and Art of Scientific Communication
description: Lecture, discussion, and team-based presentations related to the principles of learning and the essentials of scientific communication.
requirements: pen only to Honors students; instructor consent required.

name: Industrial/Organizational Psychology
description: Applications of psychology in the workplace: Measurement, personnel decisions, performance appraisal, training, motivation, worker attitudes, leadership, ergonomics and job design, workplace health and safety.
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103.

name: Social Psychology
description: Attitudes, social cognition, social influence, interpersonal relations, group dynamics.
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103.

name: Social Psychology of Multiculturalism
description: Introduction to theoretical perspectives and behavioral research that seek to explain the nature and mechanisms of intergroup relations and the psychology of culture, prejudice, and biased behavior. CA 4.
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103. Recommended preparation: PSYC 2700.

name: The History and Systems of Psychology
description: Philosophical and scientific origins and major schools, including structuralism, functionalism, behaviorism, gestalt, and psychoanalysis.
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103; PSYC 2300 or PSYC 2300W or PSYC 2301 or PSYC 2400 or PSYC 2600 or PSYC 2700; PSYC 2200 or PSYC 2500 or PSYC 2501 or PSYC 3201 or PSYC 3500 or PSYC 3501.

name: The History and Systems of Psychology
description: Philosophical and scientific origins and major schools, including structuralism, functionalism, behaviorism, gestalt, and psychoanalysis.

name: Psychological Testing
description: Practical and theoretical interpretation of common personality, industrial, educational, cognitive, and attitude tests. Evaluating utility, test bias, and error. Using tests in clinical, educational, and workplace settings.
requirements: PSYC 2100 Q.

name: Psychology of Women
description: (Also offered as WGSS 3102.) Gender roles, socialization, women and work, women's relationships, violence against women, and other topics. Theory and research. CA 4.
requirements: hree credits of 2000 or 3000 level psychology.

name: Environmental Psychology
description: Reciprocal relationships between built and natural environments and human behavior.
requirements: PSYC 1100 and1101or1103.

name: Health Psychology
description: The interface between psychology and health is examined using a biopsychosocial model. Topics include stress and coping, health promotion, adjustment to chronic illness, and the psychology of health behaviors
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103.

name: Black Psychology
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3106.) Empirical and theoretical literature on psychological experiences of African Americans. Impact of race, culture, and ethnicity on psychological development. CA 4.
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103.

name: Latinx Psychology
description: (Also offered as LLAS 3107.) Empirical and theoretical literature on psychological experiences of Latino Americans. Impact of race, culture, and ethnicity on psychological development.
requirements: PSYC 1100.

name: Animal Behavior
description: (Also offered as EEB 3201.) Principles of animal behavior derived from a review of descriptive and analytic studies in laboratory and field. Sometimes offered in multimedia format.
requirements: BIOL 1102 or1107; PSYC 1100.

name: Motivation and Emotion
description: (Also offered as COMM 3241.) Cognition, brain mechanisms, biofeedback, aggression, sex, competence, social influence, and conformity.
requirements: PSYC 1100, and 1101 or 1103; open to juniors or higher.

name: Laboratory in Animal Behavior and Learning
description: A laboratory course to supplement PSYC 3201.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; PSYC 2100 Q; PSYC 2200 or2500or3201.

name: Laboratory in Physiological Psychology
description: Techniques employed in experimental investigation of the anatomical and physiological bases of behavior.
requirements: PSYC 2100 Q; PSYC 2200, which may be taken concurrently.

name: Drugs and Behavior Laboratory
description: Techniques employed in the experimental investigation of drug action. Laboratory exercises illustrate behavioral and neural effects of various psychoactive pharmacological agents such as stimulants, antipsychotics, antidepressants, antiparkinsonian drugs, anxiolytics, sedative/hypnotics.
requirements: PSYC 2100 Qand2201.

name: Sensory Neuroscience Laboratory
description: Techniques employed in the experimental investigation of sensory neuroscience. Laboratory exercises in psychophysics and assessment of human and animal sensory abilities. Elementary computer programming is used to synthesize and process sound files and analyze psychophysics data.  A one-hour lecture and two two-hour labs each week.
requirements: PSYC 2100 Qand3501.

name: Current Topics in Behavioral Neuroscience
description: Selected topics vary with each offering (e.g., The Neurobiology of Memory and Decision-Making, Sensory Coding and Decoding, Animal Models of Basal Ganglia Dysfunction, Animal Models of Developmental Disorders).

name: Abnormal Child Psychology
description: Theory, research, treatment, and prevention in developmental psychopathology from infancy through adolescence.
requirements: PSYC 2400.

name: Introduction to Clinical Psychology
description: History of clinical psychology as a profession; graduate training and ethical responsibilities; assessment and treatment of psychological disorders; and clinical sub-specialities.
requirements: PSYC 2300.

name: Social Development
description: Social development in infancy, childhood, and adolescence. Theoretical approaches and practical applications. Special emphasis on critically evaluating empirical research.
requirements: PSYC 1100,1101or1103; and PSYC 2400 or HDFS 2100.

name: Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience
description: Survey of current research and methods in developmental cognitive neuroscience, an interdisciplinary scientific field at the boundaries of neuroscience, developmental psychology, and cognitive science.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Laboratory in Developmental Psychology
description: The techniques necessary for performing psychological research on young children; advanced topics.
requirements: PSYC 2100 Qand2400; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Current Topics in Developmental Psychology
description: Selected topics (e.g., infant development, peer relations, cognitive development, and developmental psychobiology) that may vary with each offering.
requirements: PSYC 2400.

name: Current Topics in Developmental Psychology
description: Selected topics (e.g., infant development, peer relations, cognitive development, and developmental psychobiology) that may vary with each offering.

name: The Psychology of Language
description: Those aspects of language that make it a uniquely efficient vehicle for communication and thought.
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103.

name: Sensation and Perception
description: Sensory and perceptual processes in vision, hearing, touch, taste, and smell.
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103.

name: Psychology of Consciousness
description: The role of consciousness in human cognition is examined by comparing the conscious and unconscious operation of mental faculties including perception, memory, learning, and thought.
requirements: PSYC 1100; open to sophomores or higher.

name: Computer Modeling of Cognitive Processes
description: Symbolic and connectionist approaches to modelling vision, problem solving, planning, deduction, language understanding, learning, and memory.
requirements: PSYC 2501 or3501.

name: Music Perception and Cognition
description: (Also offered as MUSI 3504.) Perception and cognition of music including physics of sound, auditory perception and characteristic qualities of music.
requirements: PSYC 1100 or instructor consent.

name: Laboratory in Cognition
description: Selected experiments from the following topics: memory processes, categorization, language comprehension and problem solving.
requirements: PSYC 2100 Qor2100WQ; PSYC 2500 or2501, which may be taken concurrently; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Laboratory in Sensation and Perception
description: Techniques for the study of sensory capacities and perceptual processes.
requirements: PSYC 2100 Q; PSYC 3501, which may be taken concurrently.

name: Social-Organizational Psychology
description: Social psychological phenomena in the workplace.  Social perceptions, personality, stress, work-related attitudes, motivation, team decision-making, and effectiveness, leadership and influence, organizational culture.
requirements: PSYC 2600. Recommended Preparation: PSYC 2700.

name: Human Factors Design
description: Application of information about human abilities and limitations to the design of systems, products, tools, computer interfaces, tasks, jobs, and environments for safe, comfortable and effective human use.
requirements: PSYC 1100.

name: Occupational Health Psychology
description: Models, research methods, and research-to-practice applications in the interdisciplinary field of occupational health psychology, and how these are used to enhance the safety, health and well-being of workers in all occupations and to create healthier workplaces and organizations.
requirements: PSYC 1101 or1103; and PSYC 2600 or consent of instructor.

name: Psychology of the Arts
description: The perception, emotion, motivation, cognition and cultural experience of art and artists.
requirements: PSYC 1100 and1101or1103; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; three credits of 2000 or 3000 level Psychological Science coursework.

name: Laboratory in Social Psychology
description: Methods and techniques of research in social psychology. Supervised research investigations.
requirements: SYC 2100 or STAT 1100 Q; PSYC 2700.

name: Laboratory in Social Psychology
description: Methods and techniques of research in social psychology. Supervised research investigations.
requirements: PSYC 2100 Qor STAT 1100 Q; PSYC 2700; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Current Topics in Social Psychology
description: Selected topics (e.g., social influence, person perception, pro-social behavior) vary with each offering.
requirements: PSYC 2700.

name: Current Topics in Social Psychology
description: Selected topics (e.g., social influence, person perception, pro-social behavior) vary with each offering.
requirements: PSYC 2700; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Prejudice and Conflict
description: Overview of the psychological bases of prejudice and conflict in individuals and society.
requirements: PSYC 1101 or1103.

name: Field Experience
description: Supervised field work in clinical, community, or organizational settings. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory.)
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Department Head or advisor may be required prior to the student's departure.

name: Seminar in Psychology
description: Recent developments in psychology. Topics vary with each offering.
requirements: PSYC 1100; PSYC 1101 or1103.

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Participant activities related to research.
requirements: ecommended Preparation: PSYC 2100.

name: Independent Study
description: Students are expected to develop their own plan for a research project, conduct the research, and write-up this research, consulting periodically with a faculty member.
requirements: PSYC 2100 Q.

name: Senior Thesis in Psychology
description: Hours by arrangement.
requirements: hree credits of PSYC 3889 or3899; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open only to Honors students with consent of instructor and Department Head.

name: Introduction to Public Health
description: A basic foundation in public health principles and practices. Individual and group field assignments required. CA 2.

name: Introduction to Epidemiology
description: Provides overview of epidemiological concepts and methods for examining the distribution and causes of health and illness across populations. Stresses the application of epidemiology in advancing health research, disease prevention efforts, and medical care delivery. Primarily suited for, but not limited to, juniors and seniors interested in public health.

name: Disability Law, Policy, Ethics, and Advocacy
description: (Also offered as AH 3303.) Aspects of public policy and social issues that affect the lives of persons with disabilities and their families, including federal legislation, discrimination in employment, the principles of self-determination, self-advocates' roles in planning and implementing policy, and bioethical issues surrounding life and death decisions.

name: Introduction to Public Policy
description: Public policy history and institutions, government administration and systems, policy analysis, contemporary policy issues, polling and influences on policy making. CA 2.

name: Survey Research Methods
description: (Also offered as URBN 2100.) Theory and practice of surveys, including overall project design, questionnaire development, sampling, methods of data collection and data analysis.

name: Survey Research Methods II
description: Advanced exploration of the practice of survey research and questionnaire design.

name: Cases in Public Policy
description: Exploration of policy analysis using case studies on various contemporary policy topics.

name: Public Opinion
description: (Also offered as POLS 3625.) Concepts, theories, structure, and substance of public opinion.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Public Opinion
description: (Also offered as POLS 3625 W.) Concepts, theories, structure, and substance of public opinion.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Budgeting in Public Service Organizations
description: Introduction to the policy and management issues surrounding how governments budget and spend the money they raise.

name: Race and Policy
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3033, POLS 3633.) Examination of contemporary public policy through the lens of race.

name: Nonprofit Advocacy, Government Relations and Law
description: Legal landscape of nonprofit organizations; theory and application of effective tactics and approaches to advocacy and government relations by nonprofit organizations.

name: Program Development and Evaluation
description: Techniques for evaluating and improving organizational performance and the ability to deal with the challenges posed by changing environments. Topics include strategic planning, program development, program implementation, evaluating effectiveness, and performance measurement and improvement.

name: Survey Research Analysis and Reporting
description: Analytic writing skills that apply specifically to preparing survey research reports.
requirements: ecommended preparation: PP 2100.

name: Public Policy Issues
description: An exploration of fundamental issues in public policy, public management and public opinion.

name: Environmental Policy and Institutions
description: (Also offered as POLS 3203.) Development of environmental policies and institutions and their effects on the motivations and the actions of individuals and groups with implications for questions of equity, justice, and sustainability. Draws on approaches from comparative politics, public policy, and international relations.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Financial Management for Public and Nonprofit Organizations
description: Management of financial resources in public service organizations. Topics include variance analysis, cost analysis, public sector and nonprofit accounting, financial statement analysis, and forecasting.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher, others by consent.

name: Social Policy
description: Examination of the concepts and principles of public policy analysis, with applications to important  social issues.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher, others by consent.

name: Special Topics
description: Credits and hours by arrangement.
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Child and Family Policy
description: Theory and practice of child and family policy. Topics may include marriage and divorce, fertility, employment, and human capital.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher, others by consent.

name: Foreign Study
description: Consent of Department Head required, normally before the student's departure.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. Consent of Department Head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure.

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Variable Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Social Justice for the Social Work Profession
description: Overview of the social work profession and generalist social work practice at micro, mezzo and macro levels. Formerly offered as SOWK 3000. CA 2.

name: Special Topics in Social Work
description: Introduces new and innovative material into the curriculum on an experimental basis.

name: Human Behavior and Social Environment I
description: Examines theories of human behavior in the social environment from a "person-in-environment" approach. Focuses on macro contextual factors that shape human experience.
requirements: pen only to Bachelor of Social Work students.

name: Human Behavior and Social Environment II
description: Examines theories of human behavior of individuals, families, communities, groups, and organizations and lifespan development. Open only to Bachelor of Social Work students.
requirements: pen only to Bachelor of Social Work students.

name: Social Welfare Policy and Services
description: Provides an overview of social welfare and social policy in the United States and the emergence of the social work profession in a historical perspective.
requirements: pen only to Bachelor of Social Work students.

name: Advocacy for Social Policy Change
description: Provides a basis to understand the process of social policy development and conceptual frameworks for social policy analysis. Engage in policy practice to address social and economic well-being.
requirements: pen only to Bachelor of Social Work students.

name: Understanding Social Justice and Diversity through Intergroup Dialogue
description: Examines the mechanisms of human oppression on various levels and focuses on engaging diversity and differences in social work practice and advancing human rights and social and economic justice. Students participate in intergroup dialogue.
requirements: pen only to Bachelor of Social Work students.

name: Research Methods for Social Work Practice
description: Introduces students to basic concepts and procedures of social work research. Includes research design, ethics, and culturally sensitive research practice.
requirements: pen only to Bachelor of Social Work students.

name: Social Work Practice with Individuals and Families
description: Develops generalist social work practice knowledge, values, and skills from a strengths-based, empowerment model at the micro level. Prepares students to practice with individuals and families from differing backgrounds.
requirements: pen only to Bachelor of Social Work students.

name: Social Work Practice with Groups
description: Focuses on the mezzo-level of social work practice, primarily formal groups. Theory, knowledge, and analyses of group dynamics and the development of effective group work skills are emphasized.
requirements: pen only to Bachelor of Social Work students.

name: Social Work Practice with Communities and Organizations
description: Prepares students to work with organizations and communities. Practice skills are developed that promote social work ethics and values, including advancing human rights and social, economic, and environmental justice.
requirements: pen only to Bachelor of Social Work students.

name: Practicum Education I
description: Placement in community-based organizations. Students will engage in 203 hours of supervised practicum experience in generalist social work practice in the fall semester of their senior year. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: pen only to Bachelor of Social Work students. Corequisite: SOWK 3800.

name: Practicum Education II
description: Students continue their practicum placement within a community-based organization. They will engage in 203 hours of supervised practicum experience in generalist social work practice in the spring semester of their senior year. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: pen only to Bachelor of Social Work students. Corequisite: SOWK 3801.

name: Practicum Seminar I
description: Concurrent with their practicum placement, students attend practicum seminar. Focus on critical thinking and integrating practicum experiences with theories and evidence-based research, the development of professional identity, self-reflection, cultural competence, and identifying ethical issues.
requirements: pen only to Bachelor of Social Work students. Corequisite: SOWK 3700.

name: Practicum Seminar II

name: Sociology of Race and Religion
description: An introduction to the sociological study of race and religion. Centers on the social constructionist approach to race and religion within the context of North America. Topics may include the Black Church, segregation, theologies of liberation, immigration, identity formation, “ethnic” religion, urban vs. rural practices of religion, diversity, racism, and social change.

name: Sociology of Race and Religion
description: An introduction to the sociological study of race and religion. Centers on the social constructionist approach to race and religion within the context of North America. Topics may include the Black Church, segregation, theologies of liberation, immigration, identity formation, “ethnic” religion, urban vs. rural practices of religion, diversity, racism, and social change.

name: Science, Medicine, and Race
description: An introduction to science, medicine, and the construct of race. Employs a variety of scholarly literatures but centers on the social constructionist approach to race. Topics may include colonialism, eugenics, and Darwinism; notions of biology and species; the causes and consequences of health inequities across the color-line; genetic and genomic research; and DNA and ancestry testing.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SOCI 1001.

description: Happiness as a social construction that shapes and is shaped by human societies and their social structures and processes. The social causes, nature, and consequences of the pursuit of happiness as a socially defined and organized phenomenon.

description: Theories and research in the sociology of mental health; emphasis on how sociologists analyze mental illness, the social and structural causes of mental illness, and the social and institutional responses to people experiencing mental illness.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

description: How society defines a behavior as deviant, how and why members of society react to those who act this way, why people engage in deviant behavior, their experiences when labeled as deviants, and how they manage the stigma. May consider extreme body modification, drug abuse, mental illness, prostitution, suicide, and unconventional beliefs within the above context.

Topics may include the symbolic meaning of guns, the Second Amendment, different types of gun violence, and approaches to reducing various forms of gun violence such as suicide, mass shootings, and everyday gun violence.

name: Elementary Spanish I
