requirements: SPAN 1004 or instructor consent.

name: Spanish for the Health Professions
description: Introduction to medical terminology and language uses in Spanish for students desiring to use Spanish in the health professions. Intercultural preparation to work with patients of Latino and Hispanic origin.
requirements: SPAN 1004 or three or more years of Spanish in high school.

name: Composition and Reading for Speakers of Spanish
description: Grammar, written composition, and readings for speakers of Spanish with little or no formal training. Emphasis is on Puerto Rican literature.

name: Intermediate Spanish Composition
description: Provides a thorough review of grammar and methodical practice in composition leading to command of practical idioms and vocabulary.
requirements: SPAN 1004 or three or more years of Spanish in high school.

name: Spanish Conversation: Cultural Topics
description: In-depth development of speaking skills through cultural readings, group discussions and oral presentations on selected topics concerning the Spanish-speaking world.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SPAN 3178 or instructor consent.

name: Spanish Civilization to the Modern Period
description: An interdisciplinary course analyzing the politics, social structures, and cultural life of Spain from its beginnings to the start of the nineteenth century.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SPAN 3178 or instructor consent.

name: Ibero-American Civilization and Culture
description: History of the major social, intellectual, and artistic trends of Spanish-speaking America.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SPAN 3178 or instructor consent.

name: Language and Culture of U
description: Comparison of linguistic, historical and cultural backgrounds of various Hispanic groups in the U.S. through fiction, non-fiction, films, music, and guest speakers.
requirements: SPAN 1004 or instructor consent.

name: Contemporary Spanish America
description: An interdisciplinary course concerned with present-day cultural, social, and political structures of Spanish America. Revolutionary and counter-revolutionary ideas in contemporary society and the struggle for social, political and economic stability.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SPAN 3178 or instructor consent.

name: Contemporary Spain
description: An interdisciplinary course analyzing the politics, social structures and cultural life in Spain today. Spain in relation to Western Europe and the community of nations.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SPAN 3178 or instructor consent.

name: Women's Studies in Spanish
description: Women in Spanish and Ibero-American literature. Women's writings. The development of Spanish and Ibero-American feminism. Contemporary issues concerning women in the Spanish-speaking world.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SPAN 3178 or instructor consent.

name: Issues in Hispanic Thought
description: Selection for study of a major world issue debated in the Iberian Peninsula or in Ibero-America by great thinkers. A history of the issue, taking into account international cultural contexts.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SPAN 3178 or instructor consent.

name: Topics in Hispanic Cultures
description: Selected topics. Cross-disciplinary approach to the study of Peninsular and Hispanic American cultures: the colonial heritage in Latin America; intellectual traditions and national identities; cultural production under military regimes; and experience of exiles; among possible topics.
requirements: ecommended Preparation: five semesters of college Spanish.

name: Introduction to Literary Study
description: Introduction to literary analysis through a variety of critical approaches: readings in poetry, drama, and prose fiction with explanation of terms useful to the study of literature.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SPAN 3178 or instructor consent.

name: Great Works of Spanish Literature from its Origins to the Golden Age
description: The study of selected poems, plays, fables and novels reflecting the development of Spanish society from feudalism to world empire.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SPAN 3178 or instructor consent.

name: Literature of Crisis in Modern Spain
description: The study of selected poems, plays, short fiction, and novels reflecting the clash between tradition and progress in nineteenth- and twentieth-century Spain. CA 1.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SPAN 3178 or instructor consent.

name: Great Works of Modern Spanish-American Literature
description: Study of the most significant texts of "Modernismo" with focus on Rubén Darío. The "avant-garde" in Spanish America. The narrative of the "boom" and its impact on present-day literature.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SPAN 3178.

name: Advanced Spanish Composition
description: Treatment of the finer points of Spanish grammar. Exercises in translation and free composition. Stylistic analysis of texts chosen from Spanish or Latin American authors, newspapers, and magazines.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: SPAN 3178.

name: Spanish Phonetics
description: A study of the sounds of the language and drills to improve pronunciation. Recommended for all majors and for those who expect to teach Spanish.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SPAN 3178 or instructor consent.

name: Spanish Communicative Grammar
description: Grammar in context. Linguistic awareness. Culture in relation to grammar. Focus on language knowledge and language use.
requirements: SPAN 3178.

name: Film in Spain and Latin America
description: Film language and genre in Spanish and Latin American cinema. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Latin American Film
description: Offers insights into Latin American cinema and video production. Provides tools for analyzing film and its expression of socio-political and aesthetic debates in the continent.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SPAN 3178 or instructor consent.

name: Spanish Film
description: Class explores the way film has expressed debates over Spanish identity and history, including the role of film under Franco, in the new democratic Spain, and as part of a postmodern Europe.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SPAN 3178 or instructor consent.

name: Special Topics in Latin American National Cinemas
description: Selected Latin American national cinema. Focus on identity, aesthetics, and history. Taught in English.

name: Studies in Spanish-American Literature
description: Readings and discussions of specific aspects of Spanish-American literature. Consult department for particulars each year.
requirements: ecommended Preparation: SPAN 3201

name: Studies in Spanish Golden Age Literature
description: Readings and discussions of specific aspects of Golden Age literature. Consult department for particulars each year.
requirements: ecommended Preparation: SPAN 3200.

name: Studies in Spanish Literature of the Eighteenth and Nineteenth Centuries
description: Readings and discussions of specific aspects of the literature of the period. Consult department for particulars each year.
requirements: ecommended Preparation: SPAN 3200.

name: Studies in Spanish Literature of the Twentieth Century
description: Readings and discussions of specific aspects of the literature of the period. Consult department for particulars each year.
requirements: ecommended Preparation: SPAN 3200.

name: Literature of Puerto Rico and the Spanish Caribbean
description: (Also offered as LLAS 3265.) Readings and discussions of major authors and works of the Spanish Caribbean with special emphasis on Puerto Rico.
requirements: ecommended preparation: SPAN 3178 or instructor consent.

name: The Spanish-American Short Story
description: Readings of major authors and works with special emphasis on the development of the short story since the nineteenth century and on its relations to other short narrative forms (such as the fable, the cuadro de costumbres, or the tradición) as well as to significant moments of Spanish-American social history. CA 1.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: SPAN 3178.

name: Spanish Internship
description: Use of linguistic and cultural skills in Spanish in a professional training context such as an internship or in industry in a Spanish-speaking country. Requires contract agreed to in advance by student, internship field supervisor, and program director, detailing expectations for the credits earned. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in a foreign study program. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor. Consent of Department Head required, normally to be granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.

name: Topics in Human Rights in Central America
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3294, LLAS 3294.) This winter session course in Costa Rica considers a contemporary topic of interest in human rights in the Central American region. Topics may include migration, indigenous rights, women's rights, economic development, environmental rights, and more. Offered as part of the Experiential Global Learning program. With a change in topic may be repeated for credit for a maximum of six credits.
requirements: nstructor consent.

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Variable Topics
description: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Independent Study
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Senior Seminar for Spanish Majors: Selected Topics in Hispanic Literature
description: Topics focused on a particular area of Spanish or Latin American literature, culture or linguistics.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Introduction to Communication Disorders
description: Introduction to normal communicative processes and to disorders of communication. CA 2. CA 4.

name: Introduction to Communication Disorders
description: Introduction to normal communicative processes and to disorders of communication. CA 2. CA 4.

name: Speech and Hearing Science
description: Fundamentals of acoustics specifically oriented to voice, speech production, and hearing. Human response to sound and its measurement. Introduction to acoustic instrumentation and software used in communication sciences. Examples of concepts to be covered include frequency, intensity, decibels, filters, pitch, loudness, formants, critical bands, and masking.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: MATH 1060 or the equivalent. Not open to students who have passed CDIS 1155Q or SLHS 3247.

name: Anatomy and Physiology of Speech, Hearing, and Swallowing
description: Anatomical, neurological and physiological principles fundamental to the understanding of speech, hearing, and swallowing.
requirements: pen to soph or higher. No open for credit for students who have passed SLHS 3247.

name: Speech and Language Acquisition
description: How children learn their first language, the effects of language on their thinking and behavior.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Introduction to Phonetic Principles
description: The analysis of speech through the application of phonetic theory.
requirements: LHS 2156 and2203; open to juniors or higher.

name: Introduction to Audiology
description: An introduction to the nature, causation, assessment and management of hearing impairment and the principles and techniques of public school conservation programs.
requirements: LHS 2156 and2203; open to juniors or higher.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics taken in foreign study program. Consent of Department Head required, normally granted prior to the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the advisor.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.

name: Variable Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary by section; open to juniors or higher.

name: Independent Study
description: The course, for superior students, includes independent reading, periodic conferences, and such other work as desired by the instructor.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Bilingualism in Typical and Atypical Populations: Language and Cognition
description: Biological and cognitive factors associated with language acquisition, cognitive reserve, Developmental Language Disorders in bilinguals. Emphasis on diagnosis, cognitive factors in language selection, and differences in reading opaque vs. transparent languages.
requirements: nstructor consent, open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: basic phonetic principles or phonology courses, language development and language disorders.

name: Neuroscience of Cognitive and Communication Disorders
description: Anatomy and physiology of the central nervous system. Brain mechanisms that underlie speech, language, hearing, and cognition. Neurogenic communication disorders.
requirements: SLHS 2203 and2204; open to juniors or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing SLHS 4335.

name: Neuroscience of Cognitive and Communication Disorders
description: Anatomy and physiology of the central nervous system. Brain mechanisms that underlie speech, language, hearing, and cognition. Neurogenic communication disorders.
requirements: SLHS 2203 and2204; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing SLHS 4335.

name: Introduction to Aural Rehabilitation
description: An introduction to the effects of hearing impairment on communication. Communication strategies for adults and children with impaired hearing are discussed.
requirements: SLHS 3248; open to juniors or higher.

name: Introduction to Aural Rehabilitation
description: An introduction to the effects of hearing impairment on communication. Communication strategies for adults and children with impaired hearing are discussed.
requirements: SLHS 3248; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Introduction to Articulation, Voice, and Fluency Disorders
description: Communication problems resulting from disorders of speech, voice, and fluency. Assessment and management strategies in settings including public schools, hospitals, and rehabilitation centers.
requirements: LHS 2156,2203,2204, and 3247; open to juniors and higher. May not be taken out of sequence after passing SLHS 4335.

name: Introduction to Language Disorders in Children
description: Development, measurement, and function of language in children. Emphasis on child language disorders and their causes. Assessment and management strategies in settings including public schools and private clinics.
requirements: SLHS 2204; open to juniors or higher.

name: Introduction to Language Disorders in Children
description: Development, measurement, and function of language in children. Emphasis on child language disorders and their causes. Assessment and management strategies in settings including public schools and private clinics.
requirements: SLHS 2204; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Senior Thesis
description: Preparation of a thesis and its presentation to the department.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to junior or higher Honors students.

name: Data Science and Society Using R
description: (Also offered as STAT 1010.) Foundational principles and societal impacts of data science, exposing students to what data science can do and informing them about the knowledge needed for further study. Students will be introduced to the R statistical programming language. They will develop essential skills in data/computer/programming literacy, basic statistical analysis, and visualization while exploring real-world data science issues, preparing them for future studies and careers in data-driven workforce.
requirements: ot open to students who have passed STAT 3215 Qor STAT 3675 Q.

name: Special Topics
description: May be repeated with a change in topic.

name: Applied Data Analysis Capstone
description: Development and execution of student-led research projects:  Problem formulation; integration of statistics, computing, and domain knowledge; collaboration; communication; reproducibility; project management.
requirements: STAT 3255. Not open for credit for students in the Bachelor of Science in Statistical Data Science program.

name: Introduction to Statistics I
description: A standard approach to statistical analysis primarily for students of business and economics; elementary probability, sampling distributions, normal theory estimation and hypothesis testing, regression and correlation, exploratory data analysis. Learning to do statistical analysis on a personal computer is an integral part of the course.
requirements: tudents can receive no more than four credits from STAT 1000 Qand1100Q. Students who have passed a 2000-level or above STAT course or who are taking such a course concurrently cannot take 1000-level STAT courses.

name: Data Science and Society Using R
description: (Also offered as DSDA 1010.) Foundational principles and societal impacts of data science, exposing students to what data science can do and informing them about the knowledge needed for further study. Students will be introduced to the R statistical programming language. They will develop essential skills in data/computer/programming literacy, basic statistical analysis, and visualization while exploring real-world data science issues, preparing them for future studies and careers in data-driven workforce.
requirements: ot open to students who have passed STAT 3215 Qor STAT 3675 Q.

name: Elementary Concepts of Statistics
description: Standard and nonparametric approaches to statistical analysis; exploratory data analysis, elementary probability, sampling distributions, estimation and hypothesis testing, one- and two-sample procedures, regression and correlation. Learning to do statistical analysis on a personal computer is an integral part of the course.
requirements: tudents can receive no more than four credits from STAT 1000 Qand1100Q. Students who have passed a 2000-level or above STAT course or who are taking such a course concurrently cannot take 1000-level STAT courses.

name: Introduction to Statistics II
description: Analysis of variance, multiple regression, chi-square tests, and non-parametric procedures.
requirements: STAT 1000 Qor STAT 1100 Q. May not be taken out of sequence after passing STAT 3115 Q, STAT 3215 Q, or STAT 3515 Q.

name: Statistical Programming
description: Introduction to statistical programming via Python including data types, control flow, object-oriented programming, and graphical user interface-driven applications such as Jupyter notebooks. Emphasis on algorithmic thinking, efficient implementation of different data structures, control and data abstraction, file processing, and data analysis and visualization.
requirements: MATH 1132 Q, or instructor consent. Recommended preparation: CSE 1010 or prior programming experience. Not open to students who have passed CSE 2050 or2500or ECON 3322 or5322.

name: Biostatistics for Health Professions
description: (Also offered as AH 3005.) Introduction to biostatistical techniques, concepts, and reasoning using in a broad range of biomedical and public health related scenarios. Specific topics include description of data, statistical hypothesis testing and its application to group comparisons, and tools for modeling different type of data, including categorical, and time-event, data. Emphasis on the distinction of these methods, their implementation using statistical software, and the interpretation of results applied to health sciences research questions and variables.
requirements: course in pre-calculus or higher; STAT 1000 Qor1100Qor higher. Open to CAHNR students and Statistics majors, juniors or higher; others with instructor consent. Not open to students who have passed PUBH 5409.

name: Statistical Methods
description: Basic probability distributions, point and interval estimation, tests of hypotheses, correlation and regression, analysis of variance, experimental design, non-parametric procedures.
requirements: MATH 1132 Qor 1152Q; students may not receive more than three credits from STAT 3025 and 3345. May not be taken out of sequence after passing STAT 3115 Q,3215Q,3515Q,4190or4625.

name: Analysis of Experiments
description: Straight-line regression, multiple regression, regression diagnostics, transformations, dummy variables, one-way and two-way analysis of variance, analysis of covariance, stepwise regression.
requirements: STAT 2215 Qor3025Qor instructor consent. Not open for credit to students who have passed STAT 3215 Qor5315.

name: Applied Linear Regression in Data Science
description: Applied multiple linear regression analysis in data science, with an emphasis on modern statistical regression methods: simple linear regression and correlation analysis, multiple linear regression, analysis of variance, goodness of fit, comparing regression models through partial and sequential F tests, dummy variables, regression assumptions and diagnostics, model selection and penalized regression, prediction and model validation, principles of design of experiments, one-way and two-way analysis of variance.
requirements: STAT 2215 Qor3025Qor instructor consent. Not open for credit to students who have passed STAT 3115 Qor5315.

name: Introduction to Data Science
description: Introduction to data science for effectively storing, processing, analyzing and making inferences from data. Topics include project management, data preparation, data visualization, statistical models, machine learning, distributed computing, and ethics.
requirements: MATH 1132 Q, STAT 2255 or COGS 2500 Qor ECON 3322, STAT 3115 Qor3215Q, or instructor consent

name: Probability Models for Engineers
description: Probability set functions, random variables, expectations, moment generating functions, discrete and continuous random variables, joint and conditional distributions, multinomial distribution, bivariate normal distribution, functions of random variables, central limit theorms, computer simulation of probability models.
requirements: MATH 2110 Qor 2130Q. Students may not receive more than three credits from STAT 3025 Qand3345Q, or from STAT 3345 Qand3375Q.

name: Introduction to Mathematical Statistics I
description: The mathematical theory underlying statistical methods. Probability spaces, distributions in one and several dimensions, generating functions, and limit theorems.
requirements: grade of C+ or better in MATH 2110 Qor 2130Q. Not open for credit to students who have passed STAT 3345 Qor 5585. May not be taken out of sequence after passing STAT 3445Q.

name: Introduction to Mathematical Statistics II
description: Sampling distributions and parameter estimation. Neyman-Pearson theory of hypothesis testing, correlation, regression, analysis of variance.
requirements: STAT 3375 Q. Not open for credit to students who have passed STAT 5685. May not be taken out of sequence after passing STAT 4875.

name: Undergraduate Seminar
description: The student will attend 6-8 seminars per semester, and choose one statistical topic to investigate in detail. The student will write a well-revised, comprehensive paper on this topic, including a literature review, description of technical details, and a summary and discussion.
requirements: STAT 2215 Qor3115Q; STAT 3025 Qor3375Q; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Design of Experiments
description: Methods of designing experiments utilizing regression analysis and the analysis of variance.
requirements: STAT 2215 Qor3025Qor instructor consent. Credits may not be received for both STAT 3515 Qand BIST/ STAT 5515.

name: Statistical Computing
description: Introduction to computing for statistical problems; obtaining features of distributions, fitting models and implementing inference (obtaining confidence intervals and running hypothesis tests); simulation-based approaches and basic numerical methods. One hour per week devoted to computing and programming skills.
requirements: STAT 3025 Qor3375Q. Recommended preparation: an applied statistics course.

name: Elementary Stochastic Processes
description: (Also offered as MATH 3170.) Conditional distributions, discrete and continuous time Markov chains, limit theorems for Markov chains, random walks, Poisson processes, compound and marked Poisson processes, and Brownian motion. Selected applications from actuarial science, biology, engineering, or finance.
requirements: STAT 3345 Qor3375Qor MATH 3160.

name: Variable Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Field Study Internship
description: Supervised field work relevant to some area of Statistics or Data Science with a regional industry, government agency, or non-profit organization. Evaluated by the field supervisor and by the instructor (based on a detailed written report submitted by the student). Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: ompletion with a grade of 'C' or better in STAT 3025 Qor3375Q, and STAT 3115 Qor3215Qor3515Q. Completion of first year-sophomore general CLAS requirements.

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Introduction to Statistical Learning
description: Modern statistical learning methods arising frequently in data science and machine learning with real-world applications: linear and logistic regression, generalized additive models, decision trees, boosting, support vector machines, and neural networks (deep learning).
requirements: STAT 3115 Qor STAT 3215 Q; MATH 2210 Q, which may be taken concurrently; or instructor consent. Recommended preparation: Background in computer programming is preferred, but not required.

name: Undergraduate Research
description: Supervised research in probability or statistics. A final written report and oral presentation are required.

name: Sampling Theory
description: Sampling and nonsampling error, bias, sampling design, simple random sampling, sampling with unequal probabilities, stratified sampling, optimum allocation, proportional allocation, ratio estimators, regression estimators, super population approaches, inferences in finite populations.
requirements: STAT 3445.

name: Introduction to Biostatistics
description: Rates and proportions, sensitivity, specificity, two-way tables, odds ratios, relative risk, ordered and non-ordered classifications, trends, case-control studies, elements of regression including logistic and Poisson, additivity and interaction, combination of studies and meta-analysis.
requirements: STAT 3025 Q.

name: Clinical Trials
description: Basic concepts of clinical trial analysis; controls, randomization, blinding, surrogate endpoints, sample size calculations, sequential monitoring, side-effect evaluation and intention-to-treat analyses. Also, experimental designs including dose response study, multicenter trials, clinical trials for drug development, stratification, and cross-over trials.
requirements: STAT 3115 Qor STAT 3515 Q

name: Applied Time Series
description: Introduction to prediction using time-series regression methods with non-seasonal and seasonal data. Smoothing methods for forecasting. Modeling and forecasting using univariate, autoregressive, moving average models.
requirements: STAT 3445.

name: Applied Spatio-Temporal Statistics
description: Applied statistical methodology and computing for spatio-temporal data, including visualization, models, and inferences. Extreme value analysis in spatio-temporal contexts. Focus on models that account for spatio-temporal dependence and inferences that provide appropriate uncertainty measures, with applications to real-world problems using open-source software.
requirements: STAT 3445; STAT 3215 Qor3675Qor instructor consent. Recommended preparation: Experience with R.

name: Nonparametric Methods
description: Basic ideas, the empirical distribution function and its applications, uses of order statistics, one- two- and c-sample problems, rank correlation, efficiency.
requirements: STAT 3445.

name: Data Science in Action
description: Capstone course in data science. Real-world statistical data science in practice: problem formulation; integration of statistics, computing, and domain knowledge; collaboration; communication; reproducibility; project management.
requirements: STAT 3255; STAT 3025 Qor3375Qor MATH 3160 or instructor consent. Corequisite: STAT 4916 W. Open only to Statistical Data Science majors.

name: Writing in Data Science
description: The course is a companion course to STAT 4915, which must be taken concurrently. Students will write a well-revised and comprehensive paper on their STAT 4915 course project, including literature review, description of technical details, reproducible statistical and data scientific analyses, and discussion of results.
requirements: STAT 3255; STAT 3025 Qor3375Qor MATH 3160 or instructor consent; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Corequisite: STAT 4915 must be taken concurrently with STAT 4916 Wor instructor consent.

name: Translating Literature: Practice and Theory
description: Introduction to theoretical aspects of literary translation. Translation of a diverse array of literary texts into English.
requirements: orking knowledge of a language other than English required.

name: Translating Literature: Practice and Theory
description: Introduction to theoretical aspects of literary translation. Translation of a diverse array of literary texts into English.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; Working knowledge of a language other than English required.

name: The Art of Literary Translation
description: Introduction to the practical aspects of literary translation with a focus on translating different types of literary texts into English. Working knowledge of a language other than English required.
requirements: orking knowledge of a language other than English required.

name: The Art of Literary Translation
description: Introduction to the practical aspects of literary translation with a focus on translating different types of literary texts into English. Writing intensive.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; Working knowledge of a language other than English required.

name: Special Topics in Translation Studies
description: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Holster Research Proposal Development
description: Developing research ideas into fundable, discipline-appropriate research applications. Topics may include drafting and revision of statements; meeting compliance requirements; budgeting; completing a literature review; creating a timeline; and practicing interview skills. Culminates in proposal for Holster Scholars Program. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: First-Year Honors Seminar
description: An overview of some aspects of university education. Designed to help students set learning goals to be achieved during the baccalaureate experience.
requirements: pen only to Honors students. Must be a First-year student.

name: FYE University Learning Skills
description: An overview of the university experience with a focus on acquiring learning skills and understanding resources available for academic success.
requirements: pen to First-Year or Sophomore students only.

name: FYE Learning Community Seminar
description: An overview of topics relevant to the theme of the Learning Community.
requirements: pen to First-Year or Sophomore students only.

name: First Year Seminar
description: Guided research or reading, discussion, and writing on topics of professional interest to the instructor. Course materials promote independent learning and active engagement in the academic life of the university. May be repeated for credit with a change in content.
requirements: pen to First-Year or Sophomore students only.

name: Learning Community Service-Learning
description: Activities, discussions, and critical reflections related to service-learning, community engagement, and/or experiential learning activities specific to the theme of a learning community.  Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory). This course may be repeated for a total of four semesters with change of activity and/or skill level.

name: Supervised Internship Experience
description: Supervised fieldwork of six to eight hours per week (for a minimum of 80 hours) for 8-10 weeks, relevant to major and/or career goals. Mid semester and final evaluations are prepared by the field supervisor and the course instructor. This course does not fill any general education or major requirements. Formerly offered as UNIV 1991.
requirements: pen to matriculated undergraduates only, students must have a minimum GPA of 2.0. Students must secure a satisfactory internship position prior to the end of the second week of the semester of enrollment in this course. May be repeated one time, with permission. Open to matriculated undergraduates only, students must have a minimum GPA of 2.0. Students must secure a satisfactory internship position prior to the end of the second week of the semester of enrollment in this course.

name: Documented Internship Experience
description: Supervised fieldwork of 8-10 hours per week for 8-12 weeks for a minimum of 80 hours at the internship site. Evaluations by the field supervisor and the course instructor. Students must have a minimum GPA of 2.0. Students must secure a satisfactory internship position prior to the end of the second week of the semester. May be repeated one time, with permission. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: International Study
description: Course work undertaken within approved Education Abroad programs. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: Special Topics
description: Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: International Study
description: Course work undertaken within approved Study Abroad programs.  May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 17 credits.

name: Special Topics
description: May be repeated with a change in topic.

name: Independent Study
requirements: pen to First-Year or Sophomore students only.

name: Preparation for STEM Academic Research
description: Preparation for STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) undergraduate research projects and academic research assignments to prepare for graduate school.

name: The BLACC Program, Black Leadership and Community Cultivation
description: Successful mentoring strategies and strategies for effective communication and discourse. Students will learn about and recognize the consequences of stereotype threat and will develop proficiency in mentoring African American college students to become lifelong learners.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Tutoring Principles for Quantitative Learning
description: An interdisciplinary introduction to peer-to-peer tutoring in quantitative courses. Readings on individualized learning assistance and adapting instruction to different learning styles. Training in techniques to guide peers towards becoming independent learners with higher levels of reasoning and assessment of knowledge in quantitative disciplines.  Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: Gender, Sexuality and Community
description: Weekly lecture and discussion series with guest scholars, community activists, and educators from assorted disciplines. Critical investigation and exploration of interrelationships of gender, sexuality and community.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Individualized Study Across Academic Disciplines
description: Introduction to disciplinarity, multidisciplinarity, and interdisciplinarity. Recommended for students exploring an application to the Individualized Major Program.

name: TYE: Transition Year Experience
description: Designed to support regional students who must transition to Storrs to finish their degree, to be taken the semester before their first semester at Storrs. Students will be paired with Campus Change Peer Mentors who will help them prepare the skills and develop the community that will allow them to thrive at Storrs.

name: International Study
description: Course work undertaken within approved Education Abroad programs. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: International Study
description: Course work undertaken within approved Education Abroad programs.

name: Peer Mentor Leadership Development Course
description: Focus on personal growth and leadership development to foster empowerment of self and others through peer mentoring. Students will explore social, cultural, personal, and academic issues that affect first-year students, in particular first-generation college students from underrepresented populations. Some topics covered are empathy, MBTI, effective communications, the transition to college, growth mindset, cultural diversity, and self-awareness.
requirements: pen only with consent of instructor, open to sophomores or higher.

name: Variable Topics
description: Current and emerging local/global topics of general interest to the university community. Open to all students. May be repeated for credit with a change in topic. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: Variable Topics
description: Current and emerging local/global topics of general interest to the university community. Open to all students.

name: Entrepreneurial Approaches to Community-Centered Innovation
description: Foundational knowledge necessary for involvement in multi-semester experiential learning programs on current/emerging topics of general interest to the University community. Open to all students following a successful application. May be repeated for credit with a change in topic, up to a total of six credits.
requirements: nstructor consent; enrollment in this course is through application and is open to undergraduate students of any major at UConn.

name: Interdisciplinary Honors Seminar
description: An interdisciplinary seminar designed for honors students and open to other qualified students. Topics vary from semester to semester. May be repeated  for credit with change of topic. Sponsored by the Honors Program.

name: Learning Community Advanced Seminar
description: A variable topics course designed to help students engage with the advanced academic and enrichment opportunities unique to their learning community. This course is only open to sophomores, juniors, or seniors in learning communities.
requirements: pen to sophomores, juniors, or seniors in learning communities.

name: Special Topics
description: Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: Interdisciplinary Internship Field Experience
description: Repeatable to a maximum of 12 credits. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).

name: International Study
description: Course work undertaken within approved Study Abroad programs. May be repeated for credit (to a maximum of 17).

name: Special Topics
description: With a change in topic; may be repeated for credit.

name: Independent Study
description: May be repeated for credit.

name: Capstone Course
description: All students with an approved individualized major plan of study who are not earning a double major nor have another capstone course on their plan of study must register for this course during their last academic year. Students will integrate their interdisciplinary major through a capstone paper.
requirements: onsent required by instructor and the Individualized Major Program Director; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; senior standing with an approved individualized major plan of study; and an approved placement, research or project.

name: Senior Thesis
description: All honors students writing a thesis for their individualized major plan of study must register for this course during their last academic year. Students must present their thesis to the Individualized Major Program. Students must have obtained a thesis advisor and have an approved thesis topic before registration.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; senior standing with an approved individualized major plan of study; consent required by instructor and the Individualized Major Program director.

name: Senior Year Experience
description: An overview of the transition to life beyond the University with a focus on life skill awareness and development including financial literacy, career readiness, and reflection on the meaning and value of the undergraduate experience. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: pen to seniors only.

name: SYE Seminars
description: An overview of the transition to life beyond the University with a focus on life skill awareness and development including financial literacy, career readiness, and reflection on the meaning and value of the undergraduate experience. Each section will be open to select populations based on major or other affiliation and will have unique elements within assignments or in-class activities that are related to the specific entity. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: pen only to seniors; instructor consent required.

name: Senior Year Experience
description: An overview of the transition to life beyond the University with a focus on life skill awareness and development including financial literacy, career readiness, and reflection on the meaning and value of the undergraduate experience. Each section will be open to select populations based on major or other affiliation and will have unique elements within assignments or in-class activities that are related to the specific entity. Assignments will be graded with a rubric for a letter grade.
requirements: pen only to seniors.

name: Global Urbanization
description: (Also offered as GEOG 1200.) A broad discussion of the role and structure of cities around the world from the first cities to contemporary times. Special emphasis will be placed on the mechanisms by which cities and ideas about them have been diffused from one place to another and on the changing forces that have shaped cities over time and across space. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Exploring Your Community
description: Various aspects of urban and community life emphasizing the interplay of social justice, diversity, individual and social well being. Explores theories, concepts, and methods in community studies. May contain a service learning component. CA 2. CA 4.

name: Exploring Your Community
description: Various aspects of urban and community life emphasizing the interplay of social justice, diversity, individual and social well being. Explores theories, concepts, and methods in community studies. May contain a service learning component. CA 2. CA 4.

name: Site and Sound: Understanding Cities Through Popular Music
description: Examination of urban issues and trends like race, gender, class, sexuality, place attachment, politics, economics, environmentalism, and social activism by interpreting the lyrics and videos of popular music. CA 2. CA 4.

name: Site and Sound: Understanding Cities Through Popular Music
description: Examination of urban issues and trends like race, gender, class, sexuality, place attachment, politics, economics, environmentalism, and social activism by interpreting the lyrics and videos of popular music. CA 2. CA 4.

name: Cities of Imagination
description: Introduction to planned cities. Topics may include concepts in urban planning, past and present planned cities, considerations of ethics and inclusion in planning. CA 2.

name: Variable Topics
description: May be repeated for credit with a change in subject matter

name: Introduction to Urban and Community Studies
description: Introduction to the analysis of urban development with particular stress on those problems pertinent to the American central city.

name: Survey Research Methods
description: (Also offered as PP 2100.) Theory and practice of surveys, including overall project design, questionnaire development, sampling, methods of data collection and data analysis.

name: Research Methods and Analysis in Urban and Community Studies
description: Introduction to research methods and analysis techniques useful in understanding urban issues and assessing public and non-profit social programs.
requirements: TAT 1000 or 1100. Open to sophomores or higher.

name: Qualitative Methods in Urban and Community Studies
description: An introduction to qualitative methods used in urban social research. Interdisciplinary techniques for data collection and analysis, including visual and narrative analysis, participant observation, interviewing, and archival research.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Qualitative Analysis of Urban and Community Studies
description: An introduction to qualitative methods used in urban social research. Interdisciplinary techniques for data collection and analysis, including visual and narrative analysis, participant observation, interviewing, and archival research.

name: City and Community in Film
description: (Also offered as AMST 2400.) Aesthetics, history, and contemporary relevance of American films that feature the urban, suburban, and/or small town landscape as a major "character" shaping plot and story. Films read closely as texts that make meaning through a range of tools, including narrative, mise-en-scene, editing, camera work, and genre conventions. CA 1.

name: The History of Urban America
description: (Also offered as HIST 2541.) The development of Urban America with emphasis on social, political, physical, and environmental change in the industrial city.

name: The History of Urban America
description: (Also offered as HIST 2541 W.) The development of Urban America with emphasis on social, political, physical, and environmental change in the industrial city.

name: Work and Economic Justice
description: Interdisciplinary analysis of conservation and the human-environment relationship from a cross-cultural perspective. Major topics include sustainability, environmental ethics, climate change, natural disasters, health, and environmental justice.
requirements: ot open to students who have passed URBN 3998 when offered as Work and Economic Justice. Recommended preparation: URBN 2000.

name: History of Urban Latin America
description: (Also offered as HIST 2650.) The development of Latin American cities with emphasis on social, political, physical and environmental change, from Spanish conquest to present. CA 1.

name: Urban Sociology
description: (Also offered as SOCI 2901.) Social and physical organization of cities and suburbs.

name: Urban Sociology
description: (Also offered as SOCI 2901 W.) Social and physical organization of cities and suburbs.

name: Variable Topics
description: May be repeated for credit with a change in subject matter. Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Urban Geography
description: (Also offered as GEOG 3200.) Analysis of the growth, distribution, and functional patterns within and among Western cities. Application of urban geographical concepts to city planning problems.

name: Urban Problems
description: (Also offered as SOCI 3903.) Social problems of American cities and suburbs, with emphasis on policy issues.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Urban Problems
description: (Also offered as SOCI 3903 W.) Social problems of American cities and suburbs with emphasis on policy issues.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Urban Parks and Sustainability
description: Historical and contemporary analysis of park issues related to the social, ecological, and economic sustainability of cities, such as the racial politics of park advocacy, the changing social practices of park use, the privatization of public space, urban resilience and green infrastructure, and the relationship between parks, gentrification, and urban sustainability. CA 2.

name: Urban and Regional Economics
description: (Also offered as ECON 3439.) Economic problems of cities and regions: urban markets for land, labor, and housing; location decisions of businesses and households; metropolitan transportation problems; urban/suburban fiscal relations; urban and regional environmental quality; and the economics of crime.
requirements: ECON 2201 or2211Q. Recommended preparation: ECON 1200 or1202; MATH 1071 or 1110 or 1121 or 1131 or 1151.

name: Urban Politics
description: (Also offered as POLS 3632.) Political systems and problems confronting urban governments.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Urban Politics
description: (Also offered as POLS 3632 W.) Political systems and problems confronting urban governments.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher.

name: Internship in Urban Studies: Seminar
description: Description, analysis, and evaluation of the fieldwork portion ( URBN 3991) of the internship. Written reports are required.
requirements: ust be taken concurrently with URBN 3991.

name: Internship in Urban Studies: Field Study
description: A fieldwork internship program under the direction and supervision of a faculty member affiliated with the Urban Studies faculty. Hours by arrangement with hosting agency, 42 hours per semester per credit. Students taking this course will be assigned a final grade of S (satisfactory) or U (unsatisfactory).
requirements: ust be taken concurrently with URBN 3981.

name: Foreign Study
description: Special topics in a foreign-study program. Consent of Department Head required, preferably prior to the student's departure.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Understanding Your Community
description: Examination of an urban area or local community. Production of a detailed case study including historical perspective, analysis of issues and stakeholders, evaluation of internal strengths and weaknesses as well as external threats and opportunities. Proposal of strategies for addressing problems and advancing equity, growth, and development.
requirements: URBN 2000; open to Urban and Community Studies majors in their senior year only.

name: Senior Thesis
description: Research and writing of an urban and/or community focused thesis. Students must have a thesis advisor and an approved thesis topic.

name: Special Topics
description: Prerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Gender and Sexuality in Everyday Life
description: How gender, sex, and sexuality are woven into systems of difference and stratification that shape everyday life. Examines these processes in the family, education, work, and politics with sensitivity to the diversity of individual experiences across class, racial ethnic groups, cultures, and regions. Provides experience in introductory research methods to analyze the social construction and structural organization of gender and sexuality. CA 2. CA 4.

name: Women in History
description: (Also offered as HIST 1203.) The historical roots of challenges faced by contemporary women as revealed in the Western and/or non-Western experience: the political, economic, legal, religious, intellectual and family life of women. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Women's Contemporary Writing in the Arab World
description: (Also offered as ARIS 1170.) An exploration of feminist texts, literary texts, and popular fiction. Topics may include: the role of women’s writing from the nineteenth century to the present in public life; women’s writing in social and political movements such as the Arab Spring; the intersectionality of class, race, gender, and nation in Arabic literature; and the unique challenges faced by Arab women writers. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: Women's Contemporary Writing in the Arab World
description: (Also offered as ARIS 1170 W.) An exploration of feminist texts, literary texts, and popular fiction. Topics may include: the role of women’s writing from the nineteenth century to the present in public life; women’s writing in social and political movements such as the Arab Spring; the intersectionality of class, race, gender, and nation in Arabic literature; and the unique challenges faced by Arab women writers. Taught in English. CA 1. CA 4-INT.

name: International Study
description: Consent of program director required, normally before the student's departure.

name: Gender and Science
description: The historical, sociological, economic, and political processes that shape the ways that gender, race, class, sexuality and nation intersect with science, medicine and technology. CA 4-INT.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Gender and Science
description: The historical, sociological, economic, and political processes that shape the ways that gender, race, class, sexuality and nation intersect with science, medicine and technology. CA 4-INT.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to sophomores or higher.

name: Gender and Globalization
description: Construction and reproduction of gender inequality and the gendered nature of global structures and processes. Key topics include women's rights as human rights; women's work; gender, development, and the global economy; migration; religious fundamentalism; reproduction, health, and HIV/AIDS; education; violence against women; and gender, war, and peace advocacy. CA 2. CA 4-INT.

name: Feminisms and the Arts
description: Interdisciplinary exploration of drama, the visual arts, music, literature, social action art, and/or film through feminist, queer, and trans theory. Includes creative projects and activities. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Women, Gender and Film
description: Examines how images, stories, and formal constructions in film frame gender identities through Indigenous, decolonial, feminist, and queer critique. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Women, Gender and Film
description: Examines how images, stories, and formal constructions in film frame gender identities through Indigenous, decolonial, feminist, and queer critique. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Critical Approaches to Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies
description: Theories, practice, and methodologies of the Women's, Gender, and Sexualities Studies interdiscipline.

name: LGBTQ Sexualities, Activism, and Globalization
description: Globalization of LGBTQ identities, cultures and social movement activism, and cultures from a transnational perspective; use, role, and impact of digital media. CA 4-INT.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: LGBTQ Sexualities, Activism, and Globalization
description: Globalization of LGBTQ identities, cultures and social movement activism, and cultures from a transnational perspective; use, role, and impact of digital media. CA 4-INT.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to sophomores or higher.

name: Latin American and Latinx Feminist Theory and Praxis
description: Introduction to the dynamic field of Latin American and Latinx feminist theory and praxis with special emphasis on theoretical, artistic, creative, and activist approaches. Includes creative assignments and curatorial projects.

name: Latin American and Latinx Feminist Theory and Praxis
description: Introduction to the dynamic field of Latin American and Latinx feminist theory and praxis with special emphasis on theoretical, artistic, creative, and activist approaches. Includes creative assignments and curatorial projects.

name: Women, Gender, and Violence
description: (Also offered as HRTS 2263.) Discussion of various forms of gendered violence in the United States and in a global context. Physical, sexual, emotional and structural violence; social, political and personal meanings of gendered violence; special emphasis on women.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher. Recommended preparation: Any 1000 or 2000 level WGSS course.

name: Gender, Capitalism, and Poverty
description: Exploration of gender inequities within the frameworks of transnational capitalism with a focus on the impacts of race, class, war, and migration.
requirements: ecommended preparation: Any 1000-level WGSS course.

name: LGBTQ+ History in the United States
description: (Also offered as HIST 2525.) This course traces the history of LGBTQ+ identities, relationships, and politics in the United States from the late 18th century to the present, with a focus on changing forms of romantic and sexual relationships; the growth of LGBTQ+ communities; and the history of LGBTQ+ activism.

name: History of Gender and Sexuality in Latin America and the Caribbean
description: (Also offered as HIST 2622, LLAS 2622, AFRA 2622.) Topics may include: empire and colonialism/anti-colonialism; slavery, science, and the state; cultural practices and institutions; feminisms and masculinities; law and public policies; immigration; forms of labor and political mobilization; sex and reproduction; and human rights from historical perspective. Formerly offered as AFRA/HIST/LLAS/WGSS 3622.

name: Sociology of Sexualities
description: (Also offered as SOCI 2680.) Explores the social organization, construction, and politics of sexualities, particular focus on lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer experiences and the intersection of sexualities, gender, race, and class. CA 4.

name: Sociology of Sexualities
description: (Also offered as SOCI 2680 W.) Explores the social organization, construction, and politics of sexualities, particular focus on lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer experiences and the intersection of sexualities, gender, race, and class.

name: Women and the Law
description: (Also offered as POLS 2807.) The development of constitutional and statutory standards for treatment of women under the law in the United States.

name: Women and the Law
description: (Also offered as POLS 2807 W.) The development of constitutional and statutory standards for treatment of women under the law in the United States.

name: Professional and Technical Writing for Social Justice
description: (Also offered as ENGL 3020 W.) Critical analysis of and engaged practice in technical and professional communication and writing for both specialist and non-specialist audiences about complex topics. Attention to questions of rhetoric, representation, social justice, and ethics in contexts including, but not limited to, class, disability, gender, race, and sexuality.

name: Historical Women Political Thinkers
description: (Also offered as POLS 3027 W.) Critical study of the writings of several historical women political thinkers.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011, open to juniors or higher. Recommended preparation: POLS 1002.

name: Women and Politics
description: (Also offered as POLS 3672.) An introduction to feminist thought, the study of women as political actors, the feminist movement and several public policy issues affecting women.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Psychology of Women
description: (Also offered as PSYC 3102.) Gender roles, socialization, women and work, women's relationships, violence against women, and other topics. Theory and research. CA 4.
requirements: hree credits of 2000 or 3000 level psychology.

name: The Politics of Reproduction
description: National and transnational politics of reproduction including: contraception, sexuality education, abortion, childbirth, surrogacy, adoption, health care policy and funding.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher; sophomores by consent of instructor. Recommended preparation: any 1000 or 2000-level WGSS course.

name: The Politics of Reproduction
description: National and transnational politics of reproduction including: contraception, sexuality education, abortion, childbirth, surrogacy, adoption, health care policy and funding.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher; sophomores by consent of instructor. Recommended preparation: any 1000 or 2000-level WGSS course.

name: Art Books, Book Arts, and Publishing as Radical Practice
description: (Also offered as ART 3125.) A hands-on studio exploration of book arts and independent publishing. Topics include various layout methods, printing technologies, bookbinding structures, and distribution channels, contextualized by an introduction to historical and contemporary artistic, literary, feminist, queer, and BIPOC radical publishing models that challenge conventions.

name: Women in Theatre: Gender Identity and Expression on the Stage
description: (Also offered as DRAM 3130.) A critical study of women's participation in the art of theatre, with particular attention to theatre as a tool for exploring gender identity and expression. Focus on plays and performances, primarily from the 20th- and 21st-century United States, analyzing how evolving feminist concerns are reflected in women's theatrical work and how changing concepts of gender and other intersectional identities are embodied on the stage. CA 4.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Gender and Communication
description: (Also offered as COMM 3210.) Differences in male/female communication, and an examination of cultural assumptions regarding gender in the communication process. Critically analyze the theory, politics and practice of communication and gender.
requirements: COMM 1000 or instructor consent. Recommended preparation: COMM 2200.

name: Women in Political Development
description: (Also offered as POLS 3216.) How women and gender circumscribe political life and generate relationships of inequality and justice on a global scale.   Topics may include conflict and security, development, human rights and legal systems, labor and migration, nation building, political economy, and transnational justice.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher, others by consent.

name: Feminist Theory
description: (Also offered as PHIL 3218.) Philosophical issues in feminist theory. Topics may include the nature of gender difference, the injustice of male domination and its relation to other forms of domination, the social and political theory of women's equality in the home, in the workplace, and in politics.
requirements: ne three-credit course in Philosophy at the 1100-level or any three-credit 1000 or 2000-level WGSS course.

name: Gender Politics and Islam
description: (Also offered as POLS 3249.) Construction of gender in Islamic texts and history, the religion's interaction with other patriarchal cultures and systems, western interventions and their impact, male leaders' reform efforts, women's movements.

name: Genders and Sexualities
description: Intersectional examination of diverse constructions of gender and sexuality. Focused exploration of selected topics.

name: Gender Representations in U
description: Forces in the U.S. that shape and reshape gender in popular culture. CA 2.

name: Gender Representations in U
description: Forces in the U.S. that shape and reshape gender in popular culture. CA 2.

name: Women and Gender in the Deaf World
description: (Also offered as ASLN 3254.) The roles of women inside and outside the Deaf world. How language and cultural barriers perpetuate the roles defined for and by d/Deaf women within Deaf and hearing societies.
requirements: ecommended preparation: Any 1000 or 2000-level WGSS course.

name: Sexual Citizenship
description: Sexuality as a significant axis of citizenship. How sexual citizenship differs in national, historical, and international contexts. How its different constructions influence such issues as welfare, adoption, marriage, and immigration. CA 4-INT.

name: Sexual Citizenship
description: Sexuality as a significant axis of citizenship. How sexual citizenship differs in national, historical, and international contexts. How its different constructions influence such issues as welfare, adoption, marriage, and immigration. CA 4-INT.

name: Feminist, Queer, and Trans Theories
description: Exploration of foundational and current critical theory in feminist, queer, and trans studies. May offer an intermediate-level survey of theoretical perspectives or be structured around a theme.
requirements: ecommended preparation: WGSS 2250.

name: Feminist Disability Studies
description: Social, historical, cultural, and political constructions of the intersecting categories of gender and disability. Through a wide variety of texts and cultural examples, exploration of how disability is gendered, gender is disabled, and both are interwoven by race, ethnicity, class, nationality, sexuality, and subcultures.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher; sophomores by consent of instructor. Recommended preparation: Any 1000 or 2000-level WGSS course.

name: Feminist Disability Studies
description: Social, historical, cultural, and political constructions of the intersecting categories of gender and disability. Through a wide variety of texts and cultural examples, exploration of how disability is gendered, gender is disabled, and both are interwoven by race, ethnicity, class, nationality, sexuality, and subcultures.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; open to juniors or higher; sophomores by consent of instructor. Recommended preparation: any 1000 or 2000-level WGSS course.

name: Latina Narrative
description: (Also offered as LLAS 3230.) Feminist topics in contemporary Latina literature and cultural studies.

name: Gender in the Workplace
description: Examination of the gendered dimensions of migration and labor in the global economy and its impact on workers in the US and select other countries.
requirements: ny 1000 or 2000 level WGSS course.

name: Producing Critical Feminist Scholarship
description: Exploration of the theoretical underpinnings of diverse critical scholarship used by WGSS researchers and the significance of praxis for fostering knowledge production in this interdisciplinary and transnational field. Ethical dilemmas faced by feminist, critical race, queer and trans scholars and other critical scholars, activists, artists, and policy makers. Experiential opportunities in designing and producing WGSS scholarship.
requirements: WGSS 2250; ENGL 1007 or1010or1011.

name: Gender, Sexuality, and Social Movements
description: Examination of social movements as related to intersections of gender, race, sexuality, disability, class, nationality, ethnicity. May include related topics such as capitalism, democracy, globalization, economic justice, the environment, health, sexual freedom.
requirements: ecommended preparation: Any 1000 or 2000 level WGSS course.

name: Gender, Sexuality, and Social Movements
description: Examination of social movements as related to intersections of gender, race, sexuality, disability, class, nationality, ethnicity. May include related topics such as capitalism, democracy, globalization, economic justice, the environment, health, sexual freedom.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011. Recommended preparation: Any 1000 or 2000 level WGSS course.

name: Masculinities
description: Social construction of masculinity and how maleness is gendered. Examination of the multiple forms of masculinity as influenced by differences in social and cultural expressions of gender, race, ethnicity, class, nationality, sexuality, disability and subcultures.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher; sophomores by consent of instructor. Recommended preparation: Any 1000-level or 2000-level WGSS course.

name: Seminar on Rape Education and Awareness I
description: Explores issues of sexual violence and trains those enrolled to facilitate rape awareness workshops for the campus community. Students are required to attend an intensive two-day training program and participate in weekly seminars.

name: Issues in Human Sexuality
description: (Also offered as HDFS 3277.) Contemporary issues concerning human sexuality; impact upon individuals and family units.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Latinas and Media
description: (Also offered as LLAS 3321, COMM 3321.) The role of ethnicity and race in women's lives. Special attention to communication research on ethnic and racial minority women. CA 4. Formerly offered as LLAS 3264/ WGSS 3260.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Anthropological Perspectives on Women
description: (Also offered as ANTH 3350.) Major conceptual and historical problems in the study of gender in anthropology. Women's roles in different historical and contemporary settings, and new understandings of family, kinship, power, and cultural ideologies.

name: Gender, Justice, and Hashtags
description: Examination of gender and social media activism across digital platforms and historical and geographic contexts with a focus on race and gender equality, social justice, and human rights. Topics may include the creation of publics and feminist counterpublics, disinformation, globalization, trolling, gender-based violence, and gender/racial bias in artificial intelligence.
requirements: ecommended Preparation: Any 1000 or 2000-level WGSS course.

name: Women in the Bible
description: (Also offered as ANTH 3402.) An introduction to Biblical interpretation from a feminist perspective, examining how women are represented in the Hebrew Scriptures and the New Testament.  Issues of authorship, translation, point of view, cultural context and language.

name: Women and Religion
description: (Also offered as ANTH 3403.) Gender issues in the world's religions. Survey of women's theological standing, ritual activities and participation in a cross-cultural sample of religions, both monotheistic and polytheistic.

name: Gender and Sexuality in Modern Europe
description: (Also offered as HIST 3416.) The construction of gender difference and ideas about sexuality in western Europe since 1789. Masculinity and femininity; sexuality, identity and the state; European power and personhood in global context.

name: Gender and War
description: (Also offered as POLS 3440.) Gender aspects of war. Masculinities and militaries; gender-based war violence; laws of war and post-war conditions for male and female soldiers and civilians. Formerly offered as POLS 3247 and WGSS 3247.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: Economic Foundations of Gender Inequality
description: (Also offered as HRTS 3445.) Economic approaches to gender inequality in political representation, economic opportunities, access to education, and health.
requirements: ot open to students who have passed or are taking ECON 2445.

name: Women, Gender and Health
description: (Also offered as SOCI 3453.) Social factors shaping women's health, health care, and their roles as health-care providers.
requirements: pen to sophomores or higher.

name: Constructions of Race, Gender, and Sexuality in U
description: (Also offered as HIST 3560.) Examination of historical development, interconnections, and complexities of conceptions of race, gender, and sexuality in U.S. from European conquest to the present.

name: History of Women and Gender in the U
description: (Also offered as HIST 3561.) Gender ideologies of indigenous and settler cultures, changing conditions of women's and men's lives as the U.S. became a nation, while emphasizing intersections with ethnicity, race, class, religion, and region.

name: History of Women and Gender in the United States, 1850-Present
description: (Also offered as HIST 3562.) History of gender and the lives and cultural representations of women in the U.S., emphasizing intersections with race, sexuality, class, region, and nation.

name: African American Women's History
description: (Also offered as AFRA 3565, HIST 3565.) African American women's history in the United States, including black women's activism and leadership; roles within the larger African Diaspora; engagement in local, national, and international freedom struggles; and redefinitions of identities as wives, mothers, leaders, citizens, and workers. Special attention given to the diversity of black women’s experiences, and to the dominant images of black women in America from Mumbet (the first enslaved woman to sue for her freedom and win) to contemporary issues of race, sex, and class. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Women's Literature
description: (Also offered as ENGL 3609.) Works written by women from different countries and centuries. CA 4.

name: Women's Literature 1900 to the Present
description: (Also offered as ENGL 3611.) Modern and contemporary works written by women from different countries. CA 4.

name: LGBTQ+ Literature
description: (Also offered as ENGL 3613.) Literature focusing on gender and sexual diversity across cultural contexts. Experiences of, for example, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex, queer, hijra, and two-spirit people. CA 4.

name: Black Feminist Politics
description: (Also offered as POLS 3652, AFRA 3652.) An introduction to major philosophical and theoretical debates at the core of black feminist thought, emphasizing the ways in which interlocking systems of oppression uphold and sustain each other.
requirements: pen to juniors or higher.

name: LGBTQ+ Politics in the United States
description: (Also offered as POLS 3670.) A brief history of the LGBTQ+ population in the United States and an understanding of how members of that community engage in the political process.
requirements: ecommended Preparation: ENGL 1010, POLS 1602, WGSS 2250; Recommended for upper-level students. Not open for credit to students who have passed POLS 2998 when offered as "LGBTQ+ Politics in the US."

name: Latina History and Biography
description: (Also offered as HIST 3675, LLAS 3675.) Examination of the history of Latinas in the US with a focus on women, gender, and sexuality. Students will consider how historians use oral histories, life histories, memoirs, biographies, and testimonials as sources to restore Latinas to histories from which they were previously omitted. CA 1. CA 4.

name: Feminism and Science Fiction
description: Feminist approaches to science fiction. Human and non-human embodiments - humans, aliens, and cyborgs - and the social issues their interactions raise: reproduction and colonization; racial, sexual, and gender apartheid; "human" rights and the rule of law. CA 4.

name: Internship Program
description: A field placement in an organization related to the student's major field of study. Work is overseen by the field work supervisor and the Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies Internship Coordinator.
requirements: ne WGSS course.

name: International Study
description: Consent of program director required, normally before the student's departure. May count toward the major with consent of the director.

name: Special Topics
requirements: rerequisites and recommended preparation vary.

name: Variable Topics

name: Experiential/Service Learning Seminar
description: (Also offered as AAAS 4100, AFRA 4100, LLAS 4100.) Interdisciplinary examination of the history of social justice organizing in the U.S.; theories, strategies, and practice of community organizing movements such as those for immigration, environmental, reproductive, and racial justice. Includes practice in community organizing and political advocacy.

name: Capstone Seminar
description: Synthesis of studies in the discipline, including discussion of major concerns and topics in WGSS research and praxis. Exploration of post-graduate pathways intersecting with students’ interests and goals and application of feminist research methods and theories to a research project.
requirements: ENGL 1007 or1010or1011; WGSS 2250; Open to Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies majors only. Open to seniors; juniors by consent of instructor. Recommended preparation: WGSS 3265 W.
